title: Leeteg: Babes, Bars, Beaches, and Black Velvet Art
author: Cook, CJ*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s weird to read a book about an artist whose work you admire but whose personality you kind of abhor. There’s a lot of good-natured descriptions ofIt’s weird to read a book about an artist whose work you admire but whose personality you kind of abhor. There’s a lot of good-natured descriptions of Edgar Leeteg, painter of black velvet masterpieces, as a boozer, a brawler, and an all-time lothario. These aspects add to his myth, and I love that sort of myth-making. I’ve read a lot of histories about talented white straight dudes from the early-to-mid twentieth century and there’s always a bit of legend that comes with the reality. Less easy to incorporate into the fun-loving concept is Leeteg’s misogyny, xenophobia, homophobia, and racism. The authors are clear on all these fronts but tend to shrug them off. I don’t think a wide-eyed biography (bordering a little on hagiography) has to necessarily decry its subject matter on moralities not consistent with 21st century values, but it’s something that took a little of the shine off of Leeteg’s legend for me.As for the art? It’s amazing. I’ve read a lot about lowbrow art (a designation Leeteg himself would probably approve of for his work), and I think it’s time to start recognizing it as legitimate art. I’m not one of those people who think we should canonize every formerly “bad” thing because it now has a cult following (yes, even Grease 2, which I love). But Leeteg’s art - despite the medium, despite the fact that he painted from photographic inspiration - evokes such a time, a place, and an attitude that I believe it deserves recognition as art, full stop. ...more

title: Before the Birds Sang Words
author: Bruce, Ken

review: For such a quaint attraction, the Enchanted Tiki Room was a groundbreaking blockbuster in its day. When it first opened, no one had ever seen anythingFor such a quaint attraction, the Enchanted Tiki Room was a groundbreaking blockbuster in its day. When it first opened, no one had ever seen anything like it. Birds were singing calypso! Flowers were singing in Hawaiian! The very walls were coming to life! The attraction, a favorite of Disneyland parkgoers for half a century, came to its current form after years of painstaking trial and error, sponsorships coming and going, assistance from a government missile system, and more. The creative talents of designers, actors, singers, artists, and technicians came together to bring Walt Disney's astounding (and ever-shifting) vision to life, and Ken Bruce's book delves into every aspect of that vision. From deep dives into Disney histories, making tech advancements accessible and exciting, and maintaining a reverence for tradition while also understanding the limitations and preconceptions of the time period, Bruce delivers an exhaustive and thrilling book on one of the best theme park experiences of all time....more

title: The Autobiography of Matthew Scudder
author: Block, Lawrence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I fell into the world of Lawrence Block as I fall into most new authors: through Stephen King. While doing research on a book about King special editiI fell into the world of Lawrence Block as I fall into most new authors: through Stephen King. While doing research on a book about King special editions, I discovered that the novelist from Maine had written an introduction to a limited edition of one of Lawrence Block's crime novels. Now: I love crime fiction, and I'd somehow never heard of this guy. All at once, I was presented with a new-to-me writer with scads of unread novels, and I was the happiest reader on the planet.It took me two years to get through the majority of Lawrence Block. He's written plenty of worthy fiction and nonfiction, but his two major series are probably the biggest draw. One, focusing on gentleman burglar Bernie Rhodenbarr, is comic and almost cozy in its episodic, rarely-changing way. They're delightful. The Matt Scudder novels are different. Dark and dramatic, they follow an unlicensed private detective named Matthew Scudder, solving murders and wrestling with his private demons in New York. The first few books are very good, but they're living inside the mind of an alcoholic who is doing his best to bear up under the weight of his own failures and unbelievable trauma. It's when Scudder hits rock bottom and starts going to AA that the books gain a deeper resonance - as he moves past his dependence on alcohol and pain and starts putting his life on a better, happier path. I was slightly apprehensive, then, when I realized that the Autobiography of Matthew Scudder was going to focus exclusively on the early years; in a way, this would be a prequel to the first Scudder novel, 1976's Sins of the Fathers. My apprehension was unwarranted. It's not just that we're reading a book written by Lawrence Block, who continues to command language, tone, and character at an immensely high level this late in his career. It's that we're reading a book "written" by Matt Scudder, whose life experiences and way of thinking make those early recollections thrilling, in a low-key and weary sort of way. Most of the Scudder books are about the how, about the what. This one's about the why. Matthew Scudder is such a well-crafted, well-developed character that even without shootouts and explosions and chases and struggles, the why is immensely compelling.One conceit I loved (because I love writerly peccadillos) is that the Matt Scudder novels really are written by Lawrence Block, based on stories told to him by Scudder. Block intrudes a few times in this manuscript, but never in a distracting way (although one winking aside late in the book blames Block for getting a detail wrong in one of the earlier novels; the "real" Scudder doesn't remember what actually happened). As badly as I would love more Scudder novels, both the character and his author are in their 80s. I don't think we'll be seeing Scudder again, and if not, that's okay. We've got a long line of fine books, none of them duds, and this is a fantastic capstone to one of the best crime fiction series of all time. That's good enough for me. ...more

title: Whip It
author: Cross, Shauna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OK, so I saw the movie whip it with Elliot Page and directed by Drew Barrymore. Really, really loved it despite the fact that it was like a classic spOK, so I saw the movie whip it with Elliot Page and directed by Drew Barrymore. Really, really loved it despite the fact that it was like a classic sports movie with all the same tropes and beats. And my current obsession with rollerskating immediately had me buying the book that inspired the movie, and I was positive. I would love it, because the author wrote the screenplay.But the book is… kind of difficult. A lot of it is trying to be extremely cool in a late aughts way. I didn’t really realize until recently that that was a profoundly uncool way to be cool. I mean, we were pretty disaffected in the 90s and Reality Bites has a terrible message but the language and the dismissal of anyone who isn’t you in this book is a little hard to take. Did people really say ‘rents? Like for real, and not making fun of hip slang?In the movie, Bliss Cavender is a bit self involved, but still really interesting and a good person to have as your main character. Her relationship with her dad is a lot more interesting. She actually has a pretty good heart. I’m guessing that some of that came in the screenplay as like a second draft to make the main character a little less of a jerk. I nearly gave up on this book a couple of times, because I was like, I want to like you, but you are really hard to like.Things get a lot easier and better in the second half of the book, and you get to like Bliss and understand her a little bit more. I didn’t really like how the major, massive dénouement is a sort of shoved offscreen into a side paragraph. I was really looking forward to reading that part.I hate to be giving this book fewer stars, because the movie was better, but the movie really was better. Whether it was the writing, directing, the acting, the nuance in the side characters, or just the fact that it felt more like a complete story , the movie was just better. I would recommend this book but with reservations. And definitely see the movie....more

review: You know, I was reading this book and enjoying its sort of aimless, picaresque tale of a tenured English professor who may or may not hate his job. WiYou know, I was reading this book and enjoying its sort of aimless, picaresque tale of a tenured English professor who may or may not hate his job. Willian Henry Deveraux, Jr - Lucky Hank - was charming and foolish and smart and also kind of a jerk, and following him was fascinating but not quite satisfying. Events were occurring but nothing really seemed to be happening. And then there's this one-two punch near the end of the book that offers a symmetry I was not expecting, elevating this small story into something larger, smarter, more engaging than I had realized when I was in the middle of it. Lucky Hank spends so much time on his ironies and desire to push everyone away that when actual emotion intervenes, it's a little shocking. This would have gotten three stars for me until Russo upped the stakes and threw the entire story into a new context. I think I loved it. ...more

review: All I know is that I looked up from my book at midnight. I still had a quarter of the book to go and I was about to click off my bedside light and try to sleep. My husband came into the bedroom and turned on his light. Normally I'd complain, because I can't sleep with his light on. Instead, I picked The Free back up and kept reading. And kept reading. And then I had to be awake at 5:30 and here it was, almost 2:00, and I STILL couldn't put the book down, not until I found out what was going to happen to Freddie, and Pauline, and Jo, and Leroy. I didn't like the conclusions to some of these stories, but they were satisfying nonetheless. I'm so glad I read this book. ...more

title: Dickens and Prince: A Particular Kind of Genius
author: Hornby, Nick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I see a book by Nick Hornby, I imediately pick it up. His name is as close to a guarantee that I will like a book, then almost any other factor. When I see a book by Nick Hornby, I imediately pick it up. His name is as close to a guarantee that I will like a book, then almost any other factor. Still, I was skeptical. A book about Prince and Dickens as twin souls across a hundred plus years seemed almost gimmicky. And yet, as I read the book, I found more and more evidence that people of genius and incredible output do have more similarities and differences.I loved Hornby’s discursive delves into both artists, comparing, and sometimes contrasting who they were, where they came from, and the people whose lives they impacted. There’s similar upbringing, their relationships to, and with women, their reactions to superstardom and the perception that they were not being paid what they were worth. All of it really does seem like these two creative people are intertwined in some profound way. Most interesting is that while I like both Dickens and Prince, I’m not what you would call a giant fan of either. This book made me think that I should become one. It also made me think that I should write a book similar to this about two similar men in the same fields as Prince and Dickens, who have inspired me endlessly, and who are similar enough to base a book on. We’ll see where the future lies....more

review: I keep seeing people call this book “harrowing.” And it is, somewhat. But it’s also just extremely well written, and features a science-fiction premisI keep seeing people call this book “harrowing.” And it is, somewhat. But it’s also just extremely well written, and features a science-fiction premise that I have been reading about in books for sometime. When I was a teenager, I read a book called Building Blocks, which was about someone who travels back in time and sees how his grandfather really was towards his father. Not the kindly old man that he thought he was.I got some similar feelings from this, but it’s a lot more intense. Dana, a Black woman from the late 1970s, travels back in time to save the life of a young boy, who is the son of a slave owner. She has keep going back to his time and saving him, sometimes with her husband, who is white, most of the time alone. What she goes through in the early 1800s is so intense and so brutal, but mostly this is a book about compassion. Or, it’s about how when you start to see somebody as less than human, you can’t ever see them any other way. Compassion, and anti-compassion. I really loved reading this book, but I don’t know if I could read it again....more

title: Stephen King: A Complete Exploration of His Work, Life, and Influences
author: Vincent, Bev*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don’t think I would be the Stephen King fan, and occasional scholar, I am today without the work of so many people writing about Stephen King. It’s I don’t think I would be the Stephen King fan, and occasional scholar, I am today without the work of so many people writing about Stephen King. It’s a bit of a cottage industry; looks about King take up an entire bookcase in my home office. I’ve written a few of them. Our passions drive us.This new book by Bev Vincent is the sort of book I would have wanted to read when I was 14 years old. I had gotten into King In a big way, and reading books by George Beahm, Stephen Spignesi, Michael Collings, and Douglas Winter helped to fuel my interest in the writer and the man behind these books I liked so much. This book falls into that category, halfway between an appreciation and a primer for the work of King. It’s not fan nonsense, which is always a worry when you pick up a book about a writer is popular as Stephen King. It also doesn’t go down that literary rabbit hole where everything has to be rationalized in order to justify an interest in a pop writer. Vincent strikes and excellent balance, serving both a new reader, and somebody who has spent 3/4 of their life steeped in the man’s fiction and lore.Also, I’m a sucker for any book that looks at the newer work with an unjaundiced eye. I’ve been around long enough to have heard “Stephen king was good until…” for most of my reading life. I love Vincent’s look at King work from the beginning all the way up to present day, treating each novel and collection as an individual work, even as he takes on decade chunks as natural summations.I wish I could give this book to myself at 14, when I was reading those Stephen King quiz books, and the Stephen King Companion for the first time. I might’ve helped me get better than a C- on that first essay on King I wrote. Or maybe it would just make me want to read more. And that, I think, is why book like this exists in the first place....more

title: The Nineties
author: Klosterman, Chuck
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really wanted to make this book last. Of course, because it’s Chuck Klosterman, there was no way I was going to. I inhaled this book so quickly and I really wanted to make this book last. Of course, because it’s Chuck Klosterman, there was no way I was going to. I inhaled this book so quickly and so ferociously. I made up chores so that I could listen to the audiobook for longer. I only skipped the very small part on football because I do that with everyone of Klosterman‘s books. Everything else was as exciting and interesting and slightly harrowing, just like the rest of his books.I lived in the 90s. I have never understood it. The whole Gen X thing doesn’t really make any sense to me, even though I staunchly identify as such. I’ve read a lot of books about specific phenomena in the 1990s, books and movies and books and sweeping generational changes. But I’ve never read something that takes on the entire decade, tries to unpack what it was, and, it to a slightly lesser degree, explain what it meant.Klosterman’s topics range from pop culture to politics, sports to domestic terrorism. Occasionally, all those things are the same thing. In a decade remembered as being kind of soft, kind of quiet, a lot of really crazy stuff happened. We kind of forget that the stuff we kind of lauded Bill Clinton for the stuff that we kind of hate him for now. We kind of forget how insanely into the movie American Beauty we were, because it’s easy to talk about how queasy it always seemed. Klosterman talks a lot about revisionist history, the kind I often see on twitter whenever people try to claim that people always liked The Phantom Menace.And, even though the movie Reality Bites bothered me at the time, I never really understood why until I read this book. Part of it is that Winona Ryder’s character sides with the ostensibly principled terrible boyfriend instead of the virtuous, slightly shallow boyfriend. Only in that specific time in American history could that have been seen as the right choice (though I knew it wasn’t, even then). Though this book talks about politics and O.J. Simpson and 9/11, I think that that movie really sums up the most of my 90s experience. We were all trying to pretend we were after something real, after something authentic, and all of that was its own form of fake.I don’t know if the 90s themselves were real. But I do know I’m glad I have this book about the 90s, because it helps me understand that unreality just a little bit better. I loved this book....more

title: Detroit Tiki: A History of Polynesian Palaces & Tropical Cocktails
author: Tadey, Renee
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The first book I ever read on this thing we call "tiki" was a slim volume by Foshko and Henderson called California Tiki, published by History Press. The first book I ever read on this thing we call "tiki" was a slim volume by Foshko and Henderson called California Tiki, published by History Press. I picked it up in a California bookstore while visiting my friend Josh, knowing a little about tiki but not being all that versed in it. It was a great introduction. I learned a little about the history, the culture. I think I was more interested in classic Los Angeles at the time, but the whole Polynesian Pop thing grabbed me in a way I didn't expect. It gave me a foot in the door. The Press has dipped back into the waters of classic tiki and establishments a couple of times in surprising ways. I mean, you expect a tiki retrospective of California. You don't expect Ohio Tiki, which came next. And you REALLY don't expect Detroit Tiki. Detroit? The Motor City? Home of Bob Seger and Stroh's and Motown? Tiki!?Indeed yes! This is one of those books where it feels like the author really wanted to talk about one establishment (like the books on the Mai-Kai or the Kahiki Supper Club), but there wasn't QUITE enough information to fill a full volume, so they had to branch out. I'm glad they did. The big focus of this book is on Chin Tiki, a tiki palace that was open for decades in downtown Detroit, created and managed by Marvin Chin. All the usual nostalgia markers are there: the exotic decor, the waterfalls, the dancing. But Chin's was three floors and the bandstand rose from floor to floor on a hydraulic elevator, which ... holy shit, the opulence of the 1960s. The book also covers the Mauna Loa, which is a tragedy of extravagance. Booth huts and pearl diver girls and authentic carvings and more waterfalls than you could ever hope to count. There and gone in four years. Detroit Tiki talks about all the hardships the city faced in the mid-60s: the riots, the GM strike, the economic downturn ... not to mention the supposed end of the tiki craze, which coincided with the cynicism of Vietnam and Watergate and the rise of hippie culture. A quick check in to the Detroit Trader Vic's and the book is complete, but even though it only really focused on three establishments, I got more of a feel for the era and the place than I did in the technically more widely encompassing Ohio Tiki. This one really felt more like the Kahiki Supper Club book. And now I'm wondering if there shouldn't be a New England Tiki book. And if someone like me shouldn't write it......more

title: Always Crashing in the Same Car: On Art, Crisis, and Los Angeles, California
author: Specktor, Matthew*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have an unexplainable, bafflingly intense love of Los Angeles. When asked to describe why, of all places, LA, my stock answer is that it's because iI have an unexplainable, bafflingly intense love of Los Angeles. When asked to describe why, of all places, LA, my stock answer is that it's because it's so sincere about its insincerity. (That's the whole tiki thing, too: authentically inauthentic. I apparently love places and themes whose oxymoronic natures make them both appealing and unknowable.)Author Matthew Specktor has his own strange romance with LA - and, perhaps necessarily, with the Hollywood of it. At times he insists he's a novelist and doesn't want to be dragged into the role of screenwriter, which seems almost beneath his contempt until he's lauding screenwriters. He hates the city unless he's in love with it. And he can't stand Hollywood, except this whole book is about Hollywood, and the love of it, and its almost inevitable heartbreaks.It's a book about failures, either eventual or baked-in. We get probing looks into the successes and downfalls, or the unsung and under-sung careers, of figures like Carole Eastman, Eleanor Perry, Warren Zevon, Tuesday Weld, Hal Ashby, Michael Cimino, more. Specktor likes the real stories but he has no problem talking about the myths either, the way Hollywood lionizes or buries talent, seemingly on a whim. Throughout this look into the intermittent renown of talented Angelinos threads a narrative of Specktor's own life: his excruciating relationship with his alcoholic mother (and boy, did that slice cut deep); his romantic failings; his literary failings; his obsession with a break-up that meant more to him than it should have. Bizarrely, none of this feels self-indulgent. In relating the tale of Hollywood's forgotten, Specktor finds communion - if not comfort - in his own stories of wasted talent, dark turns, forgotten names. It's not a love letter to Los Angeles, nor is it a condemnation. It's somewhere in between, and the title underscores that: for every success in Hollywood, there is a failure. Sometimes those things happen to the same people. And it doesn't end, it just perpetuates. Hollywood is the car. ...more

title: City Primeval
author: Leonard, Elmore
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Of course the reason why I started reading City Primeval was because there’s going to be a new Justified mini series, and it’s based on this book. ElmOf course the reason why I started reading City Primeval was because there’s going to be a new Justified mini series, and it’s based on this book. Elmore Leonard created the characters that were later adapted to Justified, and even though this book has nothing to do with those characters, it’s still Elmore Leonard in the Elmore Leonard world.Now, a confession: I have never read an Elmore Leonard novel. I know I should. I like crime novels, I like dark novels, and apparently I like his writing style. But until city primeval, I never really gave him a shot. This may be the year that I go deep.It’s interesting, reading crime novels sit in the 80s; as a somewhat progressive reader in 2022, the novel at times comes across as shockingly sexist … until it doesn’t. When it comes to stuff like sexism, classism, and racism - not to mention homophobia and transphobia - you sometimes have to ask yourself if it’s the characters or the author making these judgments and saying these things. Still, it’s a little shocking seeing the n-word dropped just all the time, even though it’s the bad guy dropping it. And there are three main women in the book - one competent and smart cop who’s sort of “just like the boys,” one a smart lawyer who makes a lot of bad judgment calls (and the good guy main character calls her out for trying to be a “tough broad”), and a simpering girlfriend. Maybe I’m judging all of this with contemporary eyes, but it just didn’t feel as well realized as it could have. Maybe that was just the 80s.Did I like it? Yeah I liked it. In a way, I would have liked it more if what seemed like the ending actually happened. As it stands, the ending we get is a little bit more conventional than the one that seemed promised. It’s still a good ending, and it provides better closure, but the ending I thought we were getting would have meant more, I think. Or maybe I’m just a psychopath. It would have been a very dark ending.So: not my favorite crime novel, but quite entertaining and very readable. I think I’m going to give this Elmore Leonard fellow another shot....more

title: Classic Penguin: Cover to Cover
author: Buckley, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I asked for this book for Christmas and could not have been more delighted when I opened it. One of the dangers of asking for a book sight unseen is tI asked for this book for Christmas and could not have been more delighted when I opened it. One of the dangers of asking for a book sight unseen is that you receive it and then it doesn’t live up to whatever expectation you have in your head. Just lived up to every expectation and then surpassed every single one as well.The thrust of the book is quite simple: Penguin Books has done a lot of interesting cover design over the years. Collections like the horror line, Shakespeare, Christmas Classics, and more, present books both classic and new with updated and refreshed cover art, buy some of the most unexpected an interesting designers in illustrators around the world. This book seeks to capture the breadth of those designs, and whether or not they were successful.By and large, they are. In addition to just presenting pictures of these fantastic designs, we get commentary by illustrator’s, writers, and heads of design and Penguin books. I loved watching the evolution of a design, and seeing how even famous and brilliant artists have dark nights of the soul.I am fascinated by books, and I am fascinated by design. This book brought both of those things together in such a clean and well presented way that I can’t fault it for anything. I got so many ideas in my head from looking at all of these illustrations, and now I want to do more art than ever before. Thanks, book!...more

title: On Animals
author: Orlean, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Man was I excited when I heard about this book. I didn’t even know Susan Orlean was writing another book. As it turned out, she wasn’t, precisely. LikMan was I excited when I heard about this book. I didn’t even know Susan Orlean was writing another book. As it turned out, she wasn’t, precisely. Like the Ann Patchett book of essays I read last year, this is a collection of pieces from across Orlean’s career. Unlike the Patchett book, this focuses on one particular interest: the world of animals. The essays are quite good, bookended by dissertations about Orlean’s interest in animals and her life on the small farm she runs herself. The last part is presented in a form of small blog entries about the goings on at her farm and what happens when things start to get uprooted. It’s a good finale for the book, but it did make me a little sad.In between her introduction and the final slow goodbye, there are plenty of essays about donkeys, mules, whales, pandas, chickens, and lost dogs. About animal actors, and animal activists. About the many ways in which rabbits can cause devastation, and the fine line they straddle between being pets and being dinner. About oxen, and how they are the most important thing in the world until they are not.I read some s of this book; some folks seem to be up in arms that Orlean has not followed through on updating some of these essays. For example, Keiko, the Free Willy whale, Did not last long in the open season. The way Orlean presents the story, it’s a little open ended. I don’t really see a problem with that. The breadth of an animal’s life can’t be summed up in a single essay. Things are going to happen after the essay is over. That doesn’t mean it wasn’t a good place to end it.But I now want, is a new book, one lengthy and detailed and on a single subject. I loved Rin Tin Tin and The Orchid Thief, but I’m still not sure I will ever captured that high I got from The Library Book. But while I search, I’m going to keep ending up with great nonfiction literature. I guess that’s all I can ask for....more

title: 100 Things We've Lost to the Internet
author: Paul, Pamela*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I guess I thought it would be funnier.Essentially a listicle in book form, Pamela Paul's 100 Things We've Lost to the Internet felt like it should be I guess I thought it would be funnier.Essentially a listicle in book form, Pamela Paul's 100 Things We've Lost to the Internet felt like it should be interesting and thought-provoking, a little silly and a little profound. I LOVED her book, My Travels with Bob, about keeping track of all the books she read in a reading journal named Bob. But this? This was difficult.Every single topic - from "Boredom" to "Working Independently" to "Social Cues" and everything in between - feels like a harangue, a dire warning that we have lost far too much by giving our souls to the internet. Zennials don't know how to type. Our ability to have closure with anything has been ripped from us. People are taking our childhood pictures and selling them on the Dark Web. There were some fun and funny parts of this book, but basically it's the same diatribe over and over again: by connecting with everyone, you connect with no one, especially yourself. Nothing is real, everything is manufactured, and everything you ever loved will be stripped away.Certainly I agree with Paul on some of this stuff, and yes it's alarming that the internet has rendered some of our old practices obsolete so quickly. But the sort of moral panic and hectoring that crops up in so many of these entries feels a bit much for a book like this. Was it me? Was it the marketing? Was it the expectation? I thought it would be pithy and it just made me feel bad. Ironically, I found myself reading the entry about how we never read books in bed before sleep anymore in bed before sleep. I kind of regret reading this one and that's weird for me. ...more

title: Christine
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I guess it’s one of my favorite books. It’s certainly the book I read the most over the last 15 or so years. I remember getting the paperback for ChriI guess it’s one of my favorite books. It’s certainly the book I read the most over the last 15 or so years. I remember getting the paperback for Christmas 1990 - thirty-two years ago!!! - and falling in love with the book as deeply as Arnie Cunningham falls in love with his car. Maybe there was an obsessiveness to my love then. Although as I’ve grown and my intensity for Stephen King has mellowed (slightly!), I find I can still get the same thrill from this book at 46 as I got when I was 15. That’s a rare sort of magic, I think.Every time I read it, I find new things to cherish and savor. Like this time, I knew that Horlicks University was the same one in Creepshow’s “The Crate,” but only this time did I pick up on the mention of the janitor in that story going missing. Because he got eaten! By the crate creature!!Christine hits the sort of melancholy notes that I feel most deeply in the dead of winter; that it’s a tragedy sort of transcends what should be a slightly ridiculous story about the haunted car and the boy who loves her. It makes me feel. It makes me ache. I have a tattoo of a 1958 Plymouth Fury on my arm and it wouldn’t be there if I didn’t have this kind of connection. I started out with the audiobook, but I decided to read the last chapter with the hardcover in front of me, remembering the days when owning hardcovers was the grandest luxury I could imagine....more

title: Tiki Surf Witches Want Blood
author: Penny, Will

review: It’s the classic randy tiki dream: a couple of white beachbums go on the search for killer waves and find an island of topless wahines, ready for pleaIt’s the classic randy tiki dream: a couple of white beachbums go on the search for killer waves and find an island of topless wahines, ready for pleasure and partying day and night! This glorious black and white comic-book throwback to an imagined time when islands of buxom women who used their black magic talents to concoct tropical libations were only too eager to lure lovestruck mainland dudes into their land of black enchantment. It should feel misogynist and/or culturally suspect, but it curiously doesn’t. It’s like a charming, two-fisted throwback to a place and time that only exists in the weird, invented world of Polynesian pop. A Tijuana bible for the tiki set. (A tikiuana bible?)I can’t tell if this is a comic adventure story that exists as an excuse to publish cocktail recipes or if it’s the other way around, but I’m fully in either way. The drinks - starting with a Zombie and including a Surfer’s Blood, an RIP Tide, and more - all look delicious. And now I wanna make some kook juice. More of this! All the time!...more

title: Five Decembers
author: Kestrel, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s an exhilarating mid century crime noir, and some of the most fascinating things about it are what genre trappings is sidesteps. There are a numbeIt’s an exhilarating mid century crime noir, and some of the most fascinating things about it are what genre trappings is sidesteps. There are a number of women in this novel, many that would be considered “exotic” by some writers in the hardboiled game, and yet none of them are caricatures. NONE OF THEM ARE FEMMES FATALES. I kind of didn’t realize that until I was 3/4 of the way through the book. It’s almost shocking.Our main guy, Detective Joe McGrady, is on the hunt for a double murderer right in his own Hawaiian backyard. Is it a political murder or a murder of passion? It certainly seems personal, and grisly. The hunt for the killer takes him first to Hong Kong and then to Japan, right as the US is entering World War II. He becomes a victim of circumstance, of timing, and maybe of people putting him in the wrong place at the most convenient time.Everyone kept telling me how great this novel was, and when I first began it I was like well, the writing is good and the murder is really intense, but I didn’t understand why people liked it so much. Now I’m fully on board. This is a book unlike any I’ve ever read, and the fact that it works within and against the trappings of hard crime novels only enhances its appeal. I hate saying that books transcend a genre; the only thing you accomplish by saying that is ghettoizing the genre you ostensibly love. But Five Decembers understands crime novels, and wants to see what happens when a crime novels stretches its legs and visits more worlds than the hard-bitten one it was born into. There are romances here. A war novel. A historical fiction book. And a whole lot of crime. I’m glad I finished this book when I did. One of the best books of 2021....more

author: Bachman, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s been a hot minute since I read The Long Walk last. Maybe over a decade. The first four Bachman novels are odd little pockets in the Stephen King It’s been a hot minute since I read The Long Walk last. Maybe over a decade. The first four Bachman novels are odd little pockets in the Stephen King canon. They’re bleak, harsh, and don’t have happy endings. They’re about singular-minded straight white men determined to win at any cost, despite the fact that society is trying to kill them. I guess that also applies to Thinner, but that book doesn’t have the same tone. Blaze does, kind of.I’m a little bit further away from the ages of the walkers in the book now, and there are some holes that I never really thought about before. Some latent homosexuality stuff that didn’t really ring true this time, and people finding wells of strength to yell or to run when it honestly doesn’t seem like they would. None of that really detract from my enjoyment of this book, if enjoyment is really what you call watching 99 young men be slaughtered in a societally–funded murder spree.I did enjoy it, though, in the same way I enjoyed The Hunger Games and the way I’ll probably dig Squid Game when I see it. In fact, one of the things I kept thinking about was that this could totally be a movie now and people would like to see it. Or a Netflix miniseries, something like that. All I know is that this was sort of some thing I needed for the state of mind that I am in currently. It may not be easy but it’s full of suspense....more

title: A Room of One’s Own
author: Woolf, Virginia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: And here we come to the end.Okay, it's not the end. It's arbitrary, really. Last year, I set myself a goal of 70 books and because it was Our Year of And here we come to the end.Okay, it's not the end. It's arbitrary, really. Last year, I set myself a goal of 70 books and because it was Our Year of Covid, I blasted well past that number. My twin obsessions, tiki history and Ann Patchett, took up so much of my year, but there was so much comfort in re-reads and one-off discoveries. I devoured books, both the physical and the audio (and occasionally digital). When I look back on 2020, it's reading (as well as, like, constant, unending fear) that is the undercurrent of things. This year ... well, look, 2021 didn't exactly get back to "normal," but I got a lot busier. My art picked up. I was going into the office. Midday naps and the attendant reading fell by the wayside. I was going to the gym instead of working out at home. And I was writing more. I had a 300,000-word novel to finish. So reading, as it does, takes a hit.70 is a funny number. To some folks, it is a pinnacle of books read that will never be reached. To others, it's a way station whose actual destination is somewhere in the hundreds. For me, it's good. Not great. Not astounding, like last year's. But good. And I'm glad I hit the 70 mark on a terrific book.I've been wary about reading Virginia Woolf. I'd read Mrs. Dalloway a while back and I found it difficult to get through. It was impressionistic and stream-of-consciousness, and I can get into that sometimes, but that one proved a little ungraspable. Her fiction, I may have determined, might not be for me. But this was non-fiction, and non-fiction about writing. That's my catnip. So I plunged in.I spend a lot of time thinking about writing. Stephen King was and is my main inspiration, at least as far as fecundity and work ethic go. He says that life isn't a support system for writing, it's the other way around ... but he also never stops writing. He just never stops. I've taken that model on in my own work. I like writing so much. I like it when it takes too much out of me. I like it when I can devote my whole self to it. It's maybe not healthy, but it's my approach. It's my first obsession.So it's alarming, sort of, to read this short book about being told you cannot do that. A Room of One's Own is Virginia Woolf's thesis that, in order to be a writer of fiction AND a woman, you must have your own money and a room you can lock yourself away in. It's kind of shocking to me that in the 1920s, these concepts seemed relatively new, and somewhat shocking. We think the whole "patriarchy reacting badly to social change" is sort of new, but good God! Virginia Woolf isn't allowed on a college campus because she's a woman, or into a certain set of rooms. If she didn't have her own money, she wouldn't have been able to write novels, because she would have been forced into a life of either servitude or scraping. We learn that the suffrage movement made men of the age so, so angry, because equality has always, to a segment of the population, seemed like disparity. If I cannot have an inferior, then how am I superior?One of the most interesting discourses in this series of essays is when Woolf reads a contemporary woman novelist's not-very-good novel. In one minute, Woolf is talking about how clunky the book is, and that she kind of doesn't like it. But she's also thrilled that it exists, that a woman was given the chance to write a merely okay novel in her own voice. It's that age-old problem when it comes to art and pioneering, isn't it? If you are a woman (or Black, or gay, or trans), you have to be the absolute best in order to be given a portion of the recognition as your middling white cis male contemporaries. I listened to this podcast about Sidney Poitier's roles, and how he had to be one of the best doctors in the world to even be considered an equal to the white family in Guess Who's Coming to Dinner? That spirit is sadly alive in so many fields - not just artistic, but in academia, as well. A little while back, there was a news story about a scientist who landed a rocket on a comet. All the headlines read, "This young lady did this." Like our impression should be surprise and admiration that the person who did this was a WOMAN; like a dog standing on hind legs, what a marvel it seems that it happens at all.I was furious for much of the book. Woolf is never passive in her dealings with the rules of men, but in the first third of the book, every time she is met with a patriarchal obstacle, she shifts her way of thinking. "Well," she says over and over again, "I found a better use of my time than doing that thing I wasn't allowed to do. Isn't it great that I get to do that thing rather than the thing I really wanted to do, but can't because I'm just a girl?"It's a terrific book. A hard book. A book that, unfortunately, is contemporary enough for me to not be as shocked at "how things used to be," because so many of those things still are. Women write whatever they want now, and that's, at least, better ... but it's not where it needs to be. Look at what happens when a woman wins an Oscar for directing. Look at what happens when a woman asks that more female journalists interview her. A lot has changed, and a lot hasn't. So this book, as well as being my current favorite Woolf (the same thing happened to me when I read Hemingway's A Movable Feast; nonfiction by fiction writers seems to be a thing I like), is also important. I'm so glad I read it.Now, let's see what lies past 70. ...more

title: A Night to Remember
author: Lord, Walter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One thing I didn’t take into consideration when I started this book was that I wasn’t only reading a book about the 1912 sinking of the Titanic. I wasOne thing I didn’t take into consideration when I started this book was that I wasn’t only reading a book about the 1912 sinking of the Titanic. I was also reading an author writing that book in 1955. It’s a nonfiction novel, written like an historic epic with a cast of thousands. It paves the way for stuff like In Cold Blood … the main difference being that Walter Lord, unlike Capote, doesn’t figure into his own account. Lord’s omniscient narration works to capture a whole story, narrowing in on as many human experiences as possible. In his book, there are heroes and cowards, but curiously, Lord himself stays out of those sort of judgments (mostly). The reader is left to decide what they would do when faced with such unthinkable decisions. There are women who are stronger and more gallant than the men (the unsinkable Molly Brown makes an appearance). There’s the Captain who, indeed, seems to have gone down with the ship. There’s the story of a man escaping the sinking ship being dressed as a woman. It’s a scandal … unless it’s an Irishman who did so; then it’s barely interesting. The class thing is interesting. I read some s by publications contemporary to A Night to Remember, and they all say Lord’s book totally avoids recounting the events through an upper-class lens. He doesn’t really avoid that, though, and it’s easy to understand why: first-class passengers got off the ship in far greater numbers than second-class or steerage. More of them lived to talk about it.And it’s kind of interesting when he says that everything changed then, and people were a lot more willing to be disillusioned. It seems, in the middle of the book, that Lord argues that that may be a good thing… even at the same time as he laments a new lack of gallantry and manners. “It’s cool that we understand the precariousness of the world a lot better now, but remember when everything was nicer?” It’s kind of apt sentiment for the mid-century, when nuclear families were a thing and everyone moved to the suburbs.The big shadow, of course, is cast by James Cameron‘s film from the 1990s. It’s almost impossible to read this book without thinking of the images in the film. There’s also a lot of scientific stuff that the movie was more concerned with than the book was. It’s funny; the movie tends to get dinged for over-sentimentalizing things, cluttering up an historic recounting with Jack and Rose. But the movie was also concerned with historical accuracy to an almost weird degree; knowing that the ship is slowly sinking is eerie here, but I’ve been spoiled by seeing it crack in half and plunge.I really liked this book, though. So much of it seems like chaos and then the chaos stops and everything gets really quiet for a while. Then you sort of missed the chaos. There’s so many ironies about the Titanic, and so much in the way of mistakes and hubris and just bad luck. We always think the most solid things can’t sink, and sometimes they do....more

title: The Miraculous Journey of Edward Tulane
author: DiCamillo, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So here’s my weird Kate DiCamillo story.I’m reading a book right now by Ann Patchett, called These Precious Days. In it, she has an essay about the chSo here’s my weird Kate DiCamillo story.I’m reading a book right now by Ann Patchett, called These Precious Days. In it, she has an essay about the children’s book author Kate DiCamillo, and how she, Patchett, had to get over her prejudice of children’s lit not being “real” lit. I listened to the audio of that essay, waiting in the baggage claim of Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, for Warren to pick me up.Two days later, we’re in an independent bookstore, which I’d wanted to go to shop for Christmas gifts but also to see if they had any Kate DiCamillo books. I was about to ask Warren if he knew where the Children’s section was so I could find her books, and he says, unprompted, “Hey do you know that author Kate DiCamillo? She’s local and walks her dog past my house all the time.”I gawped at him. Could he read my mind? This was a signal that I needed to read this woman’s work.I picked up a few books, having read Because of Winn-Dixie for the first time at the start of what we’re all calling “the pandy” now. I’d loved that book and now have no idea why I never went further. Last night, I loaned my aunt Abby one of the new books and took The Miraculous Journey of Edward Tulane up to my room.Did I know that I could be this touched, this wowed by a tale of a china-doll rabbit that couldn’t move, couldn’t react, and, at the start of the book, couldn’t really feel? I honestly didn’t. Throughout the story, Edward is neutral. He moves when people move him. He can’t look at the stars unless someone tilts him that way. That his immobility can be read as a metaphor for stagnant emotion might be beside the point. The point is that he has no interest in loving or being loved at the start of the novel, and his miraculous journey is all about discovering whether love is possible. It is a remarkable story that made me tear up at least twice. And now I absolutely need to read more by DiCamillo, even if, for some reason, I never see her walking her dog....more

title: These Precious Days: Essays
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2020 was my whirlwind Ann Patchett year. While we were all binge-watching TV, I was also binge-reading Patchett. I’d read The Dutch House in 2019 and 2020 was my whirlwind Ann Patchett year. While we were all binge-watching TV, I was also binge-reading Patchett. I’d read The Dutch House in 2019 and made indefinite plans to “really try some of her other stuff,” when I had time. In 2020, I had so much time.The problem with a binge-read of a writer who has written under a dozen books is that you can come to the end relatively quickly. I’d cut my teeth on Stephen King, whose accurate mantra is “Here, sir, there are always more tales.” Not so with Patchett. I read Run in a day. I read Taft in two. I craved her books. Needed them on some fundamental level I couldn’t entirely explicate. They were water in the endless desert of time.Then I finished, and the waiting began. When would the next Ann Patchett come? I needed the new book. I needed my Patchett fix. The answer came in early 2021: her new book was coming in December. Not a novel, but a book of essays.At first, I was ambivalent. I’d loved Patchett’s book on her friend Lucy Greely, and I’d liked her prior book of essays, This Is the Story of a Happy Marriage. But the fact that it wasn’t fiction made me preemptively wary. It was statistically impossible that I would like this book as much as I would enjoy a novel.So why did I binge-read it? Or, more accurately, binge-listen? Patchett had read her own audiobook of These Precious Days, and listening to her tell her own stories might have been the balm I needed on my anxieties this cold season. I traveled to Minneapolis with the book in my ears, reveling in her essay on the cover art of her books.(Jhumpa Lahiri has a book on the subject I read this year, and even though both authors are smart and witty about the failures and occasional successes of cover art, I preferred Patchett’s take. Maybe because I’m more familiar?)The book is structured in such a smart way, a way that allows us to read it with the momentum of reading a novel. The introduction is titled “Essays Don’t Die,” and it’s followed by a surprisingly funny tale about the three men who’d functioned as her father over the course of her life, all of whom who have since died. This is a taste of what’s to come, but not immediately.It would be wrong to say that These Precious Days is all about death, even though the shadow of a pandemic hangs over much of the book, and even though its title essay is a long, heartfelt ode to her friend Sookie, who is dying of cancer. The book is brimming with life: stories about a youthful trip to Paris, about knitting as an act of salvation, about a lack of children and what that doesn’t mean. Nearly every essay grabbed me and held me in its temporary thrall (my one holdout being “The Worthless Servant”; I find religion interesting and writing about it smart, but this one didn’t work for me).As we near the end, however, the essays about death and dying rise to a crescendo. They are about the people who die, the legacies they leave, and the people left to remember them. It’s not sad, really; to me, these ruminations on dying only underscore the earlier essays on living. Life is what happens before the end, so live it.This was the Ann Patchett book I needed....more

title: Taboo: The Art of Tiki
author: McIntosh, Martin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really need to pinpoint when the big tiki revival began, but it started happening in the mid-1990s and has only grown since then. This book, Taboo: I really need to pinpoint when the big tiki revival began, but it started happening in the mid-1990s and has only grown since then. This book, Taboo: The Art of Tiki, was written in 1999, sort of at the precipice of acceptance as a revived art form/trend/vibe. Shag was already making himself known as THE mid-century/tiki revival artist, and folks like Mark Ryden were offering highly detailed illustrative art that reinforced the tiki precepts while making them new for a generation that was playing catch-up.But … art in the 1990s, man. I mean, no tiki artist has the same style or adheres to the same specific subject matter, but there were definitely trends in which the 90s indulged. This was the decade of EXTREEEEEME everything. Commercial art and design was in your face, blowing everything up, exploding with New and Bold and This Ain’t Your Dad’s Tiki.There’s a place for a lot of that. I mean, tiki was never really subtle. And there’s no way I can sit here and love classic Edgar Leeteg black velvet wahine art and try to get prudish about naked ladies in this book’s art. (And I’m not in general; Van Aron’s “God’s Gift of Spam” doubles down on the tiki idol’s original phallic symbolism by having a tiki present Spam on his dick, and there’s a topless hula dancer. And a bat. It’s ridiculous and a little offensive and I love it.)But some of the art in here goes beyond unsubtle and approaches garishness. That might have been the point. The revival owes a lot of its initial success from the punk scene and the influence of underground comix, so it’s not really surprising that some of this art feels like an extension of those aesthetics. Maybe a lot if this stuff isn’t for me. I’ll tell you, the parts of the book I loved most were the three introductions - one by editor Martin McIntosh, an examination of the original movement by tiki expert Sven Kirsten, and a great deep dive into the rumblings of the revival by Boyd Rice. All fantastic.And some of the art really spoke to me, too, and what I think I’m discovering is that a lot of my favorite stuff is both mid-century and timeless. The aforementioned Shag and Ryden, the carving and sculpting by Bosko, and the fantastic black and white photographs of tiki-themed apartment buildings by Lesley Marlene Siegel were among my absolute favorites. Maybe a lot of the other stuff just wasn’t for me.I think though that this slim volume might actually be a necessary text. Along with The Book of Tiki by Kirsten, this presents a look at the beginning of the tiki revival, just as it was gaining steam. Books written now, or more recently, are all about the current look at Tiki, or deep dive into the original history. A contemporary look at the start of this new era is pretty damn exciting, but like all art, your mileage may vary....more

title: No One Is Talking About This
author: Lockwood, Patricia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I first saw the cover of this book in a bookstore in New York City, I didn’t understand the irony. I didn’t understand that the title was meant tWhen I first saw the cover of this book in a bookstore in New York City, I didn’t understand the irony. I didn’t understand that the title was meant to be, at the same time, real and cheeky and ironic and a little heartbreaking.“No one is talking about this.” It’s one of those Twitter things. Sometimes you mean it in an absurdist way: “There was a cartoon about a sentient Rubik’s Cube?! No one is talking about this!!!” Sometimes it’s used to describe something that everyone is talking about, because irony is Twitter’s bread and butter, even if we can’t always define it properly, because it’s like rain on your wedding day.And sometimes we don’t talk about it on Twitter because no one likes to read about grief. No one likes to read about tragedy unless we can be militant or woke about it. No one likes to read about personal atrocities, because that’s not funny or performative enough. No one is talking about this because no one wants to read about this.Patricia Lockwood’s book is broken into two parts. The first part basically talks about Twitter and Instagram and meme culture, and it’s so hard to talk about that stuff without sounding out of touch. I wonder if in 10 years, the stuff she describes is going to feel as outdated and post generational, like what happened when I tried to go back to Microserfs. My friend Jeff, who read this book before I did, underscored exactly how difficult it is to catch the right tone of Twitter in book form. Lockwood does it, and it’s almost upsetting how accurately she paints a picture of the online world. But it’s also funny. Like, extraordinarily funny. In the first 10 minutes of reading this book, I laughed out loud at least three times. When you talk about Twitter, and the jokes and the memes and the absurdist cultural references, you have to remember that this sort of ephemera is often really clever. It’s hilarious much of the time, triggering those tiny little jolts of dopamine that give us minor happies. It’s why we keep coming back even when it consumes us.The second half of the book posits the question what happens when actual tragedy hits a person who has spent their life extremely online. I kept expecting a life lesson, an exploration into the dividing line between being a persona and being a person. The issue with that - and the reason Lockwood isn’t interested in a lesson like that - is that there’s no real dividing line anymore. We are all persons and we are all personas. I don’t know if it’s funny or sad or just life.I was kind of rocked by this book. Some parts in the second half were a little difficult to read, but the prose is so compelling I never considered stopping. Lockwood has a style I’ve never actually encountered in a novel, but which I have seen online. Tweets, a lot of them, are meant to be short, pithy, and interesting enough to get you to engage with them. What happens when the tone of that is stretched across a narrative that describes something so real you can’t really tweet about it? I really liked this book. But I’m also really just glad I read it. I’m still trying to figure out what it means, because I saw myself so much in the life of that narrator. Have I lost the ability to live a real life because I live so much of it in my phone? Or has my phone made me a more conscientious, thoughtful, and maybe even funny person? I’m writing this  in the notes app using speech to text, and I’m going to copy and paste it into Goodreads. Maybe that says something too. But probably not.Man, this is a minor miracle of a book. ...more

author: Lo, Malinda*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh, this book is so good!It centers on mid-century Chinatown in San Francisco, where 17-year-old Lily Hu is about to discover something about herself Oh, this book is so good!It centers on mid-century Chinatown in San Francisco, where 17-year-old Lily Hu is about to discover something about herself that will change the entire course of her life. I watched, with growing excitement and not a little recognition, as Lily slowly starts to piece the puzzle of her own queerness together. That my own coming-out happened in the early 1990s and repeated a lot of the same patterns both comforts and appalls me. In Lily's terror of her desires, her reluctances and hesitations, her insane mood shifts, I absolutely saw myself. I just wish that in the intervening forty years, things had changed a little more.But Lily's got the deck stacked against her in a lot of other ways. 1. She's a woman. 2. She's a Chinese-American (in the book, Caucasian characters call her an "Oriental," which was common enough back then and not necessarily considered an insult, but I liked that Lily bristles at the othering term, just the same), and 3. She's living in the 1950s, when being either of those things was more than a little suspect. I liked that author Malinda Lo didn't spend too long on the male gaze or the T R A G E D Y of homosexuality. I sometimes find in books and movies that depict queer people of different eras, it all has to be about SADNESS and LONGING and PUNISHMENT. Even progressive stuff in the 70s had lonely people dying alone, in the 80s and 90s had AIDS as a finale to too many lives, in the aughts had feints toward cohesive stories that always fell in the shadows of their heterosexual counterparts (and sometimes murder and torture). It long stunned me that one of the best and most progressive depictions of gay people I found in a 1980s novel was in Stephen King's It, which edges into stereotype and ends in brutal murder.What I've long wanted is a book that gave a historical context for a queer existence and a queer relationship that recognized the dangers of the day without necessarily giving into them. Sometimes Lily's reluctance and nervousness frustrated me, but of course I understood all of that. How strange was it for young me discovering what it is about men I liked, and being repulsed by myself and afraid about who I was? How infinitely more strange it would be for someone like Lily Hu, and for the girl she starts to fall in love with. I first saw this book on my last trip into New York, and ... I think I bought it for Tracey? Or she had already read it and couldn't stop gushing over it. I kept texting her throughout my read with stuff like, "BAD THINGS BETTER NOT HAPPEN TO THESE LESBIANS." I loved Lily Hu. I loved her friend Kath. I loved this book....more

author: Rooney, Sally*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Most recently, my friend Jeff recommended this one to me, but I think it's fair to say that everyone did. For a little while, the hype around Normal PMost recently, my friend Jeff recommended this one to me, but I think it's fair to say that everyone did. For a little while, the hype around Normal People was everywhere, and ... well, not annoying, but all-consuming. Sometimes I love that. Sometimes it puts me off. I didn't really have any desire to read this one. So of course eventually I gave in and figured out why it had all this hype and it's now one of my favorite novels of the year.Two main characters - Connell and Marianne - keep bashing against one another, bouncing off, and coming back together. They're sexual. They're friends. They're not speaking. They're intertwined inextricably. And on and on, and it should feel repetitive and annoying but it never does. Sometimes I get frustrated with the characters for not saying what they really need and want, and it's kind of fascinating to watch both of them change eventually. Late in the book, Marianne asks Connell something and I cringed because I was like, he's going to be evasive and not answer directly. And then he DOES, and that's when I realized that these people have grown both as a team and as separate entities in so many ways from where we first see them.You wonder if Connell's confidence is at the expense of Marianne. You try to figure out if Marianne's kink is healthy emotionally or not. You continue to see Connell giving Marianne chances, and then Marianne giving Connell chances, and there's a cycle of need and want and desire that was so compelling that I am forced to accept the open ending, even though I don't totally want to. I was in love with reading about these people and, eventually, in love with them. I'm so happy I read this. ...more

title: Frankenstein: The 1818 Text
author: Shelley, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When my friend Tracey and I were younger and she was in grad school, she was assigned to read this and write an essay about it. She was hemming and haWhen my friend Tracey and I were younger and she was in grad school, she was assigned to read this and write an essay about it. She was hemming and hawing about having to write this three page essay, and so I told her that every time she mentioned the title, she should call it, “Frankenstein, or, the Modern Prometheus.” We were very funny and clever in our twenties.I don’t know why I was never compelled to read this book. I read Dracula when I was in high school, and I’ve been reading Stephen King my entire life. For some reason, I just thought that this was going to be a really tough read. As it turned out, the language, the characterization, plot, all of it – it was remarkably easy to read and understand, at times actually kind of compulsively addictive.As it further turned out, a lifetime of knowing this book only through the movie, and many allusions to that over the years, gave me an extremely incomplete concept of what this book was all about. There was no Igor. No late night grave robbing. Lightning as a means of animating dead flesh was alluded to, but not explicit. I knew going into this at the creature was a lot more articulate then I had been led to believe, but I had no idea that it was sort of a monologuing villain.Most of the visceral horror is “off stage,” which is fine for a novel like this. Our real horrors come from the tenuousness of life, what it means to be alive if all it is is torment. One of the cleverest things about the book is how the creature turns the tables on Frankenstein; after being born into a life he didn’t ask for and being rebuked by his creator, the creature curses Frankenstein to keep living. I loved how he gives Frankenstein just enough sustenance to survive, specifically so that he’ll remain haunted and depressed. That’s harsh as hell.After all these years of not having read this classic of the canon, what have I learned? Mostly that a good book is a good book, and has the power to move us and scare us over the course of centuries. It’s a powerful novel, and its power has not diminished - neither in the years since it was written nor due to the pop culture flotsam and jetsam of a work interpreted and reinterpreted countless times. Now, of course, I want to read all about it, to study the various meanings that smarter folks than me have figured out. This is the exciting start of another literary journey....more

review: It's Spooky Month and I decided to re-read a Stephen King novella collection that ... isn't entirely spooky. I've been letting some of the more recentIt's Spooky Month and I decided to re-read a Stephen King novella collection that ... isn't entirely spooky. I've been letting some of the more recent titles build up so I'm not re-reading King constantly, but I've also been kind of depressed lately and King is a refuge. I think I actually liked this one more this time than the first time. The first and last novellas - "Mr. Harrigan's Phone" and "Rat" - are character-driven classic horror/fable stories with some Stephen King glitter on them. Slipping into those was like slipping into warm jammies on a cold day. "The Life of Chuck," is a triumvirate of tales told in backwards order about a man named Chuck and his short, somewhat interesting life. And then there's the title story, "If It Bleeds," which probably could have been a novel itself. King is working on a new Holly Gibney novel (HOLLY GIBNEY, SUPERNATURAL DETECTIVE* *not the real name) and while some folks are grumbling, I'm all for it. I love Holly and her slow but sure move toward confidence. I think I might need to re-read The Outsider before the new one comes out. Anyway, I once again liked this, and now want more King. I think I'm gonna go with an oldie this time. ...more

review: I don't know if it would be the same if I were reading the text version vs the audio version, but the onslaught of characters caught me a little off gI don't know if it would be the same if I were reading the text version vs the audio version, but the onslaught of characters caught me a little off guard at first. Normally, when I read books in a series, the series has been around for a while and I binge. So for the first couple chapters, getting reacquainted with Detective Matthew Venn, his husband Jonathan, and his small detective team of Jen and Ross, was as much of a commitment as learning all the new characters, AND dealing with a murder. (A grisly one, too, where someone is found stabbed to death with a shard of glass in the neck.) Eventually, I caught up and grew involved. Yes, Venn with his inadequacies and guilt and mother issues; yes, Jen with her drinking that might be a problem and two kids she worries about; yes, Ross, torn between trying to be a traditionalist and a good husband and tolerant person. All these people started coming into focus as we delved further into the community surrounding them, and the murders unsettling this arty, touristy seaside town. I always feel like I'm damning a book with faint praise by calling it easy to read, but I can tell you from experience that a book being challenging doesn't mean it's good (it doesn't mean it's bad, either; either extreme is limiting). Mysteries tend to be plotted affairs, and this is a good plot, moving along with precision and speed and enough red herrings to fill an aquarium. In some mysteries, the plot is beside the point, a convenient hook to hang good characters on. But Cleeves doesn't operate like that. The characters are important, and I love looking into their lives and their slow growths as people - but it's almost refreshing that the mystery itself is front and center.I have a bunch of other Cleeves to read. She isn't showy, necessarily, for some reason, her settings and prose don't seem to lend themselves to binging (that could be the drier UK crime novel thing; I feel the same way about the Maisie Dobbs books). But I know that when I go back to her eventually, I'm going to find a well-written, exciting, easily digestible novel that will linger in my head awhile. What more do you need from a crime story?...more

title: The Mysterious Bookshop Presents the Best Mystery Stories of the Year: 2021
author: Child, Lee*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I finally got to visit the Mysterious Bookshop on one of my pre-pandemic trips to New York City. It’s such an unassuming place for some thing that hasI finally got to visit the Mysterious Bookshop on one of my pre-pandemic trips to New York City. It’s such an unassuming place for some thing that has loomed very large my mind. They used to be a couple of great mystery bookstores in Boston, but that no longer seems to be a thing. Even the best things are ephemeral.When Otto Penzler, proprietor of the Mysterious Bookshop and the press associated with it, announced the annual anthology of best mystery stories (this time compiled and edited by superstar Lee Child), I was excited. Then I found out that Stephen King had a story in there, and I could not have smashed that order button fast enough.As it turned out, I had read the Stephen King story - “The Fifth Step“ - before, and had forgotten I’d read it. That didn’t really matter of course, because the thing about the fifth step is that King is not appearing in this volume because his name is Stephen King. It’s because his story is really one of the best of the year. Of course, none of these stories was in here because of name recognition. Sometimes with anthologies, some second-rate story by a famous person will make it in just so you’ll buy the book. That did not happen here. Not even with the presence of Sara Paretsky, whose VI Warshawski gets to strut her stuff. Not even with a lost story by Sue Grafton, who never got to write the last book in her alphabet series. Lee Child would have been forgiven for including her story in here even if it wasn’t all that great. Rest assured: it’s all that great.All the stories in here are great. You’ve got private detectives, police procedural rules, crimes of passion and crimes of circumstance. Sometimes you hate the killers. Sometimes you cheer them on. There is a Sherlock Holmes pastiche in here by David Marcum that I was sure was going to feel a little arch, and then I was completely sucked in by it.This year, I’m giving anthologies a shot in the way that I really haven’t in the past. I have long bought volumes with a single Stephen King story in them, because I have a great interest, and failed to read many of the other stories in them. I don’t really know why. Maybe it was my unfamiliarity with the short story medium. Stephen King was cool, but it was a bridge too far for other authors for me. I think I’m curing myself at this time. This is the second volume of a fantastic short fiction I read this year, and I kind of want to read more. I’m very happy I read this....more

title: Chasing the Boogeyman
author: Chizmar, Richard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Here's the thing: you know it's a novel. Chizmar underscores that right up front. In the intro, he specifically states that this isn't real, this is aHere's the thing: you know it's a novel. Chizmar underscores that right up front. In the intro, he specifically states that this isn't real, this is a figment of my imagination. In the afterword, he reiterates this point, calling out by name all the people he made up and all the events that didn't happen. None of that matters. Throughout reading the book and now, after it's over and I'm thinking about it, all I can think of is: those poor dead girls.Because Chizmar has structured his book like a true-crime story, it's easy to get lost in the invented reality - especially because he tells it from a first person point of view, and ladles on the verisimilitude early and often. It's as much a childhood memoir as it is an ersatz true story about a serial killer stalking his hometown; think of it as part In Cold Blood, part Dandelion Wine. The parts merge uncomfortably, but that's by design. This is a rite of passage story, and unfortunately the rite is the (invented) unsolved murders of four young girls in Chizmar's (real) hometown of Edgewood, Maryland. Chizmar puts on his amateur investigator hat and faces darkness over and over, emerging on the other side a writer, a married man, and the publisher of the magazine Cemetery Dance. The Rebecca/Psycho-esque interview near the end of the book, in which we get a lot of explanations, should have tamped down the effect of this creepy book, but it somehow only made it creepier. That we don't have ALL the answers yet is frustrating, but in a way that feels more exciting than exasperating. And real. Let's not forget that. This book feels absolutely real, and because of that, I'm going to have a little trouble getting to sleep tonight....more

title: Star Trek: Designing the Final Frontier: How Midcentury Modernism Shaped Our View of the Future
author: Chavkin, Dan

review: Two of my favorite interests are mid century modern design and Star Trek. How excited I was, then, that I found a book that explored how mid-century mTwo of my favorite interests are mid century modern design and Star Trek. How excited I was, then, that I found a book that explored how mid-century modern design defined Star Trek, and how Star Trek and its design influenced America?! Answer: extremely.I’ve been obsessed with Star Trek my entire life, but for some reason never really paid attention to stuff like set design or props beyond a tricorder or a phaser. This book goes deep into how the sets made Star Trek look super futuristic, even though most of the furniture, artwork, and fashion came from commercial stores that sold to everyone. With its swooping curves and space-age philosophy, the 1960s were, in a design sense at least, all about the future in every way, shape, and form.I liked learning about the designers and manufacturers behind these modern pieces, but I really loved seeing them in context. I also loved the chapter on brutalism and how this seemingly dystopian concept also helped shape the idea of a stark, but no less beautiful, future.As long as Star Trek exists, even in just our memory, there is going to always be a new way to examine and talk about it. This book just really hit exactly my serotonin centers. At the end of the book, there are a few pages of ads for mid century furniture and they are so exciting and kitschy and interesting. No Googie stars, but lots of those arches and points I love so much. At the end of the book, the authors provide a catalog of pieces found on the show, along with the designer and which episodes the pieces are found in.This is a very niche book, but I think it is exactly the sort of thing that a fan of both Star Trek and mid century modern design can get into easily. I have a book on monorails that I want to try right now, just to stay in this mindset....more
