title: When Women Invented Television: The Untold Story of the Female Powerhouses Who Pioneered the Way We Watch Today
author: Armstrong, Jennifer Keishin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I tweeted to the author: "I kind of didn't think TV really existed before I Love Lucy." And she tweeted back, "Me neither until I started researching I tweeted to the author: "I kind of didn't think TV really existed before I Love Lucy." And she tweeted back, "Me neither until I started researching this book!"But of COURSE there was television before I Love Lucy. Lucy tends to overshadow much of what went before because she was not only super popular in her day, but syndication makes sure she has remained popular in perpetuity. But it's not just Lucy that hid the early days of early television. See, as a culture, we tend to think of "early TV" in the way that the advertisers and producers and, heck, politicians at the time thought about it: patriarchal, with the happy female homemaker in the kitchen and 2.5 kids running around like scamps. It's not how reality ever was, but because this was such a pervasive image in the formative years of TV, it sticks in our minds - both as what TV was and what America was. We were fed lies that made us forget the pioneering women who made television possible. Gertrude Berg, who took her radio serial, The Goldbergs, about the exploits of a Jewish-American family living in New York onto live TV. Irna Phillips, who invented soap operas, starting with The Guiding Light. Hazel Scott, the first African American to host a national evening variety program. And of course, Betty White, was one of the first women to produce, write, and star in her own show ... and who is still shining today. All these women helped force people to sit up and notice TV, and notice the women at the center of the programs they watched and loved. Hazel Scott refused to play pickaninny characters - or maids, or servants - preferring to play herself and to sing her swinging versions of classic songs. And she was heard. Betty White, who co-starred on a FIVE AND A HALF HOUR DAILY SHOW that was mostly improv, before she became a talk-show host and early sitcom star. It's kind of astounding to discover this rich history, and to learn how it was all swept aside in the wake of McCarthyism, the Red Scare, and post-WWII patriarchy, as men realized they could wrest control over the airwaves.In a lot of ways, When Women Invented Television is frustrating. To learn that Gertrude Berg - who basically invented the sitcom - was seen as possibly "too Jewish" to hold down new shows is insane. Even more insane is how they tried to tone down the Jewishness of Fran Drescher and Jerry Seinfeld, believing that Jewish sitcoms could not be popular. And this is like FIFTY YEARS after Berg had her first successes. Hazel Scott should have paved the way for a whole generation of talented Black women, but she was labeled a Communist (though she was anti-Communist) and eventually the white men in charge decided she wasn't worth the hassle. These women's stories are structured as inspirational, and they are ... but the codas are a little sad. You start off with the knowledge that these pioneering careers are mostly forgotten, but you forget that as the stories continue and success starts to pile up. None of those successes were really built to last ... except, of course, in the case of Betty White, who is still going strong in her 90s. At least, the book seems to be saying, one slipped through. It's not enough, but it'll do. ...more

title: Defender of the Innocent: The Casebook of Martin Ehrengraf
author: Block, Lawrence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love this book.It's a re-read, so I won't spend too much time analyzing it. Here's what you need to know about Martin Ehrengraf: he's a criminal lawI love this book.It's a re-read, so I won't spend too much time analyzing it. Here's what you need to know about Martin Ehrengraf: he's a criminal lawyer who only takes a fee when his client is completely exonerated. His clients are almost always completely exonerated. The fees are almost astronomically high ... and you'd better pay them. Because the way Ehrengraf assures that his clients are innocent is by making sure someone else is guilty - by fair means or foul. Mostly foul.The cool thing about this collection is the thing that some of its detractors seem to hate. The stories follow a basic formula. A client comes to Ehrengraf needing to beat a murder rap. Cut to: the client meeting with Ehrengraf some time later, discussing how they beat that rap, with attendant exposition and often some gory details. We rarely see Ehrengraf kill or forge or break and enter up close; everything is inference, and viewing everything from something of a cold distance is even more unsettling. For me, the best part of these stories isn't "How is Ehrengraf going to set his client free," but "How is Lawrence Block going to twist the formula to make THIS story fresh and exciting enough?" I love how he makes the absolutely guilty innocent. I love how sometimes he has to walk back someone's innocence and make them guilty again. I love it when his characters try to get out of paying Ehringraf, and what happens. All of it is sneakily exciting, and fun in a detached, yet thrilling way. It's like what American Psycho might have been if that book had been half as good. I'm looking forward until enough time goes by when I can be thrilled by this book again. ...more

title: Nightbitch
author: Yoder, Rachel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn't entirely know what to think about this book when I first heard about it. It was getting some great notices, but mainly I was into the title. I didn't entirely know what to think about this book when I first heard about it. It was getting some great notices, but mainly I was into the title. Nightbitch. What a strange and thrilling name for anything. Then I found out it was about a woman who believes she's turning into a dog. Sold. A++, no notes. I'd probably have liked it if it was the sort of straightforward tale I'd initially thought it was. I'm a sucker for werewolf stories and this seemed at least adjacent to that. What I got was a lot more thought-provoking. I keep wanting to describe it as "post-partum lycanthropy," even though that's not entirely right. I also want to call it a feminist work that plumbs the weird world of inherent bias against women and mothers, and how that bias extends to the women's and mothers' sense of their own capacities. It is that, absolutely; one of the novel's most interesting and provoking points is that believing you have no support structure doesn't mean you don't ACTUALLY have a support structure. Sometimes you just have to ask. But that's not it, not all of it. We find "the mother/Nightbitch/MM" at a crossroads in her life, in her motherhood, and in her career as an artist. She's at the breaking point. We don't know if her belief that she's turning into a dog is all in her head, all real, or something in between. I'm pretty sure we get answers eventually, but I'm not positive. There's an interesting intersection here of magical realism and horror and straightforward drama that is fascinating and compelling to experience. How much of the mother's life is a performance? How much of the performance is her life? Where does art end and motherhood begin, and vice versa? And does she really eat living rabbits with her jaws?I hesitate to call this book thought-provoking, even though it is, because that term comes with a lot of baggage. It doesn't explain how much FUN this book is. You keep expecting the mother's acceptance of her more feral self to hurt her in some way - estrangement, castigation, ridicule. We are instead treated to the idea that commitment to your authentic self can actually set you free, and it's told in such a way that you believe it entirely. I loved this book. ...more

title: Collectibles
author: Block, Lawrence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sometimes I have difficulties finishing books of short stories, especially if those short stories are from a bunch of separate authors. I make it a poSometimes I have difficulties finishing books of short stories, especially if those short stories are from a bunch of separate authors. I make it a point to buy these Lawrence Block anthologies because Block is one of my favorite writers (#3 after Stephen King and John Irving, right before Ann Patchett and and John Steinbeck), and I like to support my favorite writers. Unfortunately, what often happens when I pick up an anthology like this, I read one and a half stories and then put the book down and I'm like, do I really want to stop and start like this all the way through? It's weird. I'm weird.And as it turned out, I'm also wrong. I DID want to stop and start all the way through. This collection (ha!) is so strong, story in and story out, that it eventually stopped feeling like a collection of stories and started to feel like one piece. A BOOK rather than A JUMBLE OF TALES. The deeper I got into Collectibles, the more the volume took on the resonance and excitement of a novel.Will there be ghosts? Maybe (Junior Burke's "The Evan Price Signature Model"), but not necessarily terrifying ghosts. How about crimes and double-crosses? Yes, to great effect in Joe Lansdale's "The Skull Collector" and "Devil Sent the Rain Blues (Pm 13040)," by David Rachels. Dark hearts abound in Dennis Lehane's masterful "A Bostonian (In Cambridge)" and Block's own "Collecting Ackermans," but there are plenty of good souls, too - look no further than S.J. Rozan's "Chin Yong-Yun Meets a Mongol," or "Bar Wall Panda," by Rob Hart. This collection is bursting with stuff I didn't know I needed. Gay mafiosos (thank you, Thomas Pluck), comic book nerds who have to decide whether or not to be villains (Alex Segura), and a wacked-out Marilyn Monroe robot from the future, thanks to Joyce Carol Oates and her "Miss Golden Dreams 1949."I at least liked every single story in this collection, but loved most of them. There were so many endings I didn't expect, so many twists I didn't see coming. I especially liked the excerpts from Otto Penzler's Mysterious Obsession, a memoir of rare books he's collected over the years. I am a sucker for stories about books, especially the ones people cherish and fall in love with. And this right here is a book I fell in love with and am going to cherish. Plus, it introduced me to a bunch of writers I didn't know before that I now need to read more from. Maybe that's the best thing about an anthology like this - it's great on its own, but it's also a map to other greatness far afield. I'm so happy I read this book. ...more

title: The Final Girl Support Group
author: Hendrix, Grady*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's such an audacious premise. All those slasher film series you remember? A Nightmare on Elm Street, Friday the 13th, Halloween, Scream (and even moIt's such an audacious premise. All those slasher film series you remember? A Nightmare on Elm Street, Friday the 13th, Halloween, Scream (and even more obscure ones like Silent Night, Deadly Night and Leprechaun) are real-life events. The women who survived their killers - usually by "blooding," killing their potential murderers - are known as "final girls," as they are in those movies horror fans love so much. So in this alternate reality, what happens to those final girls after the slashing is done? Who do they become?The answer lies in the title, but that's just the beginning of it. We narrow in on our hero, Lynette Tarkington, who attends the group monthly with her fellow survivors. There's some tension here, because Lynette isn't "really" a final girl. She merely played dead while her killer cut a swath through her family and several cops on Christmas Eve. Those events (and their "sequel" - another meta touch in a book that's beyond meta is how the remaining final girls are actually targeted again and have to keep surviving) have haunted Lynette so deeply that she's built literal indestructible walls around herself, and adhering to an OCD routine that is so byzantine it borders on madness. Beyond that, the group is falling apart. One of the big questions of TFGSG is how long a person should relive trauma before it stops being healthy and starts being a habit. The book also wonders what it says about a society that reveres slasher films, and how when we talk about them, we don't often talk of the dead or even name the final girls. These are films about Freddy, Jason, Michael, Leatherface, Ghostface ... and their attendant body counts. That Freddy Kreuger, a literal child murderer, could have become a pop culture icon is a little bit bizarre. I can't say anything. I still have my Freddy glove I got when I was twelve. One of the reasons the women in TFGSG find it hard to move beyond their worst experiences is because movies have been made about their lives. Not documentaries, but slasher films. In one of the book's interstitial epistolary excerpts, people actually rank the series best to worst, reveling in the bloodiness of these exploitative films. Maybe the final bow that ties this whole meta package together is that it is, in itself, a slasher story. The final girls are being targeted, and the only one that seems to want to do anything about it is the one no one believes: our hero Lynette. Because she's crazy, just like Nancy was crazy in the first Nightmare movie, or like Laurie Strode was crazy in Halloween. We follow Lynette as she proves and disproves her own theories, gets arrested, almost gets killed, and eventually faces her monster for the last time. An interesting subtext in this novel is what purpose a slasher film serves in a world where mass shootings are disturbingly commonplace; what use is bringing a machete to a gun fight? I like that we got all the answers to those questions, and that the big finale felt, well, final. I was wondering if Hendrix was going to set the book up for a sequel, which might have been interesting. I suppose he could, and I'd definitely read it, but I really like the way things are now. Damage happens, but it can be dealt with. The monsters don't always win. Sometimes, the final girl lives another day, and doesn't have to fight to do it.  ...more

title: Avenue of Mysteries
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is my first re-read of Avenue of Mysteries and I'd forgotten how much I like it. At first, it seems like a greatest-hits sort of book. What it laThis is my first re-read of Avenue of Mysteries and I'd forgotten how much I like it. At first, it seems like a greatest-hits sort of book. What it lacks in bears and Amsterdam, it makes up for in clairvoyant children and religious discourse (a la Owen Meany), circuses (Son of the Circus), a clinical look at the AIDS crisis (In One Person), transsexuals (The World According to Garp), and sexually aggressive older women (Until I Find You and ... well, most of John Irving's novels). But dig just a little bit below the surface and there's a rich, idiosyncratic novel that Irving tells just so well. It concerns a novelist (!) named Juan Diego, who is on a journey to Manila to fulfill a promise to a itinerant draft-dodger he'd met in his home country of Mexico. The destination almost doesn't matter, but the fact that Juan Diego spent his childhood in Oaxaca and the rest of his life in Iowa City gives him a feeling of displacement that he doesn't really ever shake. He's a little unstuck in time, too; while he's on his travels to Manila, his mind keeps insisting he remember his childhood in Mexico, and the sister with whom he'd spent it, and how he finally escaped. All the while, the novelist is caught between a mother and daughter (maybe?) who direct his travels and have sex with him. Muriel and Dorothy might also be ghosts, or angels, or some otherworldly sorts. One of the cool things about John Irving novels is that sometimes there's a supernatural element that kind of inserts itself but doesn't distract from the realism of the book. Is that magical realism? I don't know. I just kind of like it.I almost don't want to say this is a cozy book, because I don't know how cozy a book can be where bonfires of burning dead dogs, lion attacks, and tragic deaths involving AIDS-related complications can really be cozy. But I felt very safe inside the book, as I often feel safe in John Irving's hands. I find, as I get older, I can still be critical of novels ... but I can't be all that critical about re-reads, about the books by the novelists I really love. My responses to re-reads are emotional only. This book made me happy and sad in equal measure, and I loved reading it again. I don't need to feel this way every time I read a book, but it's nice to know I can. ...more

title: That Texas Blood, Vol. 1
author: Condon, Chris
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was in the comic book store picking up our weekly funnies when I stumbled across That Texas Blood. I’m a sucker for crime fiction and comics - it’s I was in the comic book store picking up our weekly funnies when I stumbled across That Texas Blood. I’m a sucker for crime fiction and comics - it’s no mistake that my favorite superhero is the street-level brawler Daredevil - and this one seemed particularly intense. I asked the woman running the shop to order me the first trade. I was not wrong around the particularly intense. This first chapter - almost a foreword - delicately introduces us to Texas sheriff Joe Bob Coates, on the morning of his 70th birthday. His wife wants him to go pick up a casserole dish she’d leant to some young neighbors. That this ends in violence and bloodshed is a good indicator as to how the comic is going to play out.The meat of the first arc concerns a man named Ray, who escaped Ambrose County, his bad habits, and his awful brother years before. His girlfriend doesn’t want him to go back home after a mysterious phone call informs him about his brother’s death, but she doesn’t entirely grasp that the boyfriend she knows is not the whole story.The second Ray is back in Ambrose County, things turn immediately bad, and things get even more interesting. We’re introduced to the town heavies. We meet Deputy Flores, Sheriff Coats’ handpicked partner. And we get deeper into what makes this a gothic tale of dark pasts and lost people.There were a few moments in this story - particularly the dream sequences - that are legitimately terrifying. I read it late last night and was too scared to turn off the light. But all of it adds up to a fantastic self-contained story, and as an introduction to what other horrors might come. I’m ready. ...more

title: Billy Summers
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s weird to call Billy Summers a quiet novel, given that its main character is a paid assassin, and that a good chunk of the first half of the book It’s weird to call Billy Summers a quiet novel, given that its main character is a paid assassin, and that a good chunk of the first half of the book is about how his latest - and supposedly final - hit comes off. But this is a book about subverting expectations, and about dual natures. On our first meeting with Billy, we are immediately aware that he shows more than one face to almost everyone. His dumb self, the self his bosses and his clients see, is the one who reads comic books and doesn’t think too deeply. And what might be approximating his real self, he’s both intelligent and thoughtful, reading Émile Zola and developing bonds with his fellow citizens. Add to this a third iteration of his personality, one who is busily crafting his life story as a novel, and you have a man whose many parts may not add up to a whole he likes.His final job puts Billy in the suburbs undercover for a few months, making friends with the neighbors and blending in. This might be the best part of the novel, reminding readers of the “living in the past“ section of 11/22/63, or the on-the-job trials of Joyland. One of King’s most exciting gifts is his alacrity with the mundane, making peoples’ everyday lives feel rich and thrilling. Billy easily makes friends with his neighbors and building-mates, none of it feeling forced. The fact that it’s all an act is one of the things that Billy has to reckon with later on in the book.His moral code throughout is that he won’t kill anybody who isn’t a bad person. But the question that nags at him, especially in the second half of the novel, is what makes a bad person. Can a bad person redeem themselves? Can a good person do bad things? Can an assassin who kills people for money balance the scales by saving a life?These questions haunt the second half of Billy Summers (in all senses). I’m not sure there’s any firm resolution, either, which is probably how it should be. That’s true of a lot of King novels. Speaking of: the classic Stephen King trope about the redemptive power of writing finds a new angle here, just when you thought there couldn’t be new angles. I love that King keeps finding those new angles. Just because we love our protagonist doesn’t mean he’s a good person. I’ve read crime novel after crime novel about antiheroes and criminals you root for, but this isn’t Lawrence Block’s Keller or Richard Stark’s Parker. Billy Summers is kind and sweet and a pretty great mentor. And he also kills people for money. Billy never lets us forget that, and Stephen King doesn’t either....more

review: How do I even begin to rate Belinda Blinked "novels"? Collectively, we've been listening to this book for the past 10-11 weeks via the My Dad Wrote a How do I even begin to rate Belinda Blinked "novels"? Collectively, we've been listening to this book for the past 10-11 weeks via the My Dad Wrote a Porno podcast; Jamie Morton, whose father ("Rocky Flintstone") actually wrote this barely-researched, poorly-edited, and occasionally baffling erotic tale of intrigue and suspense, narrates this series of books while his friends Alice and James listen and comment. It's one of the funniest experiences ever, like MST3K for bad erotica, but it's also weirdly cathartic and, dare I say, involving?I believe it was in Book 4 when I realized I was actually caught up in the (almost completely nonsensical) story; there's some sort of accident, and we worry that Belinda (the, uh, titular star of this book series) might be dead. Like the readers who clambered onto London's docks for the next installment of Little Dorritt, I waited extremely anxiously for the next installment. My thoughts ACTIVELY turned to whether Belinda would be all right. Now here we are in Book 6, which gets off to a somewhat lugubrious start. I worried that, since this was the first of the books to be written after Rocky was aware of the podcast, the story would be more outrageous and/or less bonkers. Nope. Rocky has a style (?) that has evolved over the years, but he remains true to himself, his characters, and his readers. Yes, there is a full-on facial in the last chapter, but there's also such a reversal of fortune at the end that I was left genuinely shocked. Like, this ridiculous story I shouldn't care about that features so much perverse sex (furries! rimming! basically, all the good stuff!) and insane description that the shock ending shouldn't matter ... but it DOES.This experience, honestly, is like reading serialized novels - it's a filthy version of the Saturday Evening Post, or The Green Mile. I have sincerely enjoyed the experience of firing this podcast up every Monday and I'm going to miss it for the months it's not around. They haven't been definitive about Book 7 yet, but I'm hopeful. I need to know what happens next!...more

review: I have read several Grady Hendrix books, and I’ve liked every one I’ve read. Fiction or nonfiction, he has a way with classic horror that I don’t findI have read several Grady Hendrix books, and I’ve liked every one I’ve read. Fiction or nonfiction, he has a way with classic horror that I don’t find in a lot of contemporary authors. So when I say that the Southern Book Club’s Guide to Slaying Vampires is his best book, I’m speaking with some authority.I didn’t quite know what to expect from this one. I’m a sucker (ha!) for books about books, so I kind of assumed there would be some discussion of canonized books and then the folks in the book club would turn into the Scooby Gang and there would be a whole adventure-horror component.What I got was a lot more interesting, and revelatory. SBCGTSV has a lot of interesting things to say about big concepts about what “sticking together” and “saving the children” really mean, especially when you take class and race into the equation. The book is set in the early 1990s in the Deep South, where it’s worse to look embarrassed than to talk about how one of your neighbors might literally be a murderer. The sexism and intense adherence to unspoken rules and mores is enough to make a reader scream, so you can only imagine what it’s doing to Patricia, our hero, who no one believes when she does just that.There’s a part in the novel when I got so disappointed with Patricia that I very nearly gave up on the book. Then I didn’t and I am EXTREMELY glad for it. Her story isn’t the slayer adventure I thought and maybe hoped it would be. This isn’t that kind of horror. This is the horror where things in body bags won’t stay still, where women get impregnated by hellspawn, where children find lethal uses for dental floss. It’s harsh but it’s damned compulsive.I was already enjoying this book when I picked it up this morning and blasted through the final 3/4 of it in a white-hot heat. Sometimes the tension and terror were so amped that the slightest noise made me scream. I love books like that. And it occurs to me that I haven’t read a book like that in awhile. So, thanks, Grady Hendrix. Now, when’s the next one?...more

New characters come in and they recur, changing the nature of the guy at the heart of things. The Rare Coin Score is where, I'd heard, that starts. So I jumped ahead and gave it a whirl. And what a whirl!It's standard Parker heist stuff. Good stuff. The first two sections are Parker setting up the score, the last two sections are fallout from the score, and the middle section, the one not from Parker's point of view, is all about the complications. It works so well here, as does the addition of an actual love interest for Parker. Claire is a great character, because she's neither a total sop nor is she a hard-as-nails tough broad. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In part because I've been a lifelong Stephen King fan, I'm a sucker for writers' stories. Their methods, their tales of writing, and how they became wIn part because I've been a lifelong Stephen King fan, I'm a sucker for writers' stories. Their methods, their tales of writing, and how they became writers in the first place. So when I found out one of my favorite writers, Lawrence Block, was going to publish a book about his beginnings, I thrilled at the notion. I've read enough essays and forewords by Block to know I like the way he talks about himself, never aggrandizing but not overly minimizing, either. He has always come to the subject of himself with a somewhat guarded interest, as if it's a topic he knows very well but doesn't entirely trust his main sources. It's a great way to write and a delight to read. The worry when it comes to autobiographies of creative people is that they're going to spend a lot of time looking for those signature moments in childhood that helped shape them. I understand why those are important, and they can be interesting when told correctly and with economy. Sometimes what we get is a mire in family history that's ... not as fascinating as the writer seems to think, Bruce Springsteen. People who admire someone's work are drawn to the stories of the work before the stories of the person behind it, I think, and I also think that if a writer is doing a good job, those things can become intertwined in a narrative. Lawrence Block does this so deftly in A Writer Prepares that it attains the pace and excitement of a Lawrence Block novel. The thrill comes not from whether Scudder will find the killer or whether Rhodenbarr will get out of the scrape he's found himself in, but whether Lawrence Block can pull another erotic novel out of the ether this month, so he can continue to make a living doing what he does best. Along the way, we delve into the heady world of pseudonyms, the grift of early publishing houses, and the mental state of a man who realizes, after writing dozens of novels, that he might be a very good writer indeed. This is the story of an apprenticeship, of a beginning. As such, we don't really touch at all on much of Block's major fiction; you won't find Scudder, Bernie, or Keller in these pages, aside from a brief mention or two. The magic of A Writer Prepares is that you don't miss the stories behind those stories much, because what we get is so compelling. I'd gladly read an entire book of Block's reminiscences in the publishing world, but I'm content with - and grateful for - this fascinating and often exhilarating look at the life of a novelist who becomes a writer. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of the first books I ever read about Polynesian Pop was called California Tiki, all about the tiki restaurants and bars of California. So many of One of the first books I ever read about Polynesian Pop was called California Tiki, all about the tiki restaurants and bars of California. So many of them were heyday places, from the early days of the American tiki thing, so a lot of them were long gone - either fallen to the downturn of tiki in the 80s or simply shuttered for other reasons. The book got a little monotonous, because so many of the stories were, "This wonderful place that everyone loved. It's now a desiccated ruin." That's essentially how Lost Restaurants of Omaha operates. Here's a gleaming majestic place out of a literal dream and then it became a Wendy's until a fire razed it and they sowed the ground with salt. Okay, not quite that dire. And I don't know what I expected if not that. All the information I needed was in the title: LOST Restaurants of Omaha.Also, who is the target audience for the book? And why is it me? Who is seriously sitting around thinking about Nebraska and wondering how many great restaurants perished there? Again, besides me. Because I'm fascinated by this sort of niche history. I wonder if it sold well.The major problem endemic to the book is that there's nothing overarching. Every chapter is well-researched and well-documented, and there are a lot of great photos throughout. But although a lot of the entries talk about how "exotic" the food in some of these restaurants was for Omaha at the time (Mexican! Seafood! Italian! Anything that wasn't steak!), it really only focuses on the success. "Changing tastes" seems to be the blame for most of these restaurants' demises, but Reiner doesn't really work to tie that together. The last essay in the book, about the chain restaurant Maxine's that was nevertheless more interesting than other Maxine's restaurants, just sort of ends. No epilogue or feeling that these essays were tethered together by any sort of thesis. It was like reading an online listicle - a fascinating one, and one that showcases a lot of this city's more exemplary places - but without hinting at a more trenchant meaning. You can sort of tell from my dates read that I picked it up and put it down for long periods of time. It's a well-written book, and interesting ... but I'm not sure it's compelling. ...more

title: Action Park: Fast Times, Wild Rides, and the Untold Story of America's Most Dangerous Amusement Park
author: Mulvihill, Andy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I cohost a podcast on Disney history. I think about Disney parks a lot in my daily life; they’ve become one of my obsessions, like Stephen King and tiI cohost a podcast on Disney history. I think about Disney parks a lot in my daily life; they’ve become one of my obsessions, like Stephen King and tiki and Springsteen. But while Disney might be the best of the best, there are stories and history about the rest.I had never heard of Action Park until this year. Someone on Twitter mentioned it as being the most dangerous amusement park ever constructed. My friend Jeff scoffed at those insinuations; it wasn’t really THAT bad, he insisted.But for the son of the man who ran the park, it was a bit of a different story. Action Park, the book, is packed with stories of slide rash, broken toes, dislocated wrists, and even the occasional fatality. There’s one story where a ride operator accidentally let ozone blast out of a unit and made over twenty people in the blast radius faint. Asbestos slides that tore up your back. The Cannonball Loop, an ill-advised water slide with an actual loop at the bottom where you might get stuck, or smash your nose, or drown. Most of the tone of the book is astonishment. How Gene Mulvihill could have gotten away with all the stuff he did, while fighting the surrounding town and the parents of the kids who worked and played there. A remarkably unsafe endeavor, Action Park let patrons assume their own risk … which might be okay if the patrons weren’t (1) self-assured that nothing bad would happen to them and (2) often inebriated. This book is a smart and fascinating journey into the history of a park that probably shouldn’t have existed and could never exist today … but, in retrospect, was probably pretty damn cool. The difference between pain and nostalgia is time. ...more

review: Apparently traveling more has upped my reading game. I saw this novel in an airport on my way home from New York, and because books about books are myApparently traveling more has upped my reading game. I saw this novel in an airport on my way home from New York, and because books about books are my Kevnip, I read the flap. It was about a fictional plot SO arresting that it couldn't help but become a bestseller. But could a plot - not an actual story, but a plot - be good enough to steal, even if it meant you were going to have to live every day knowing the plot wasn't yours? And could a plot be good enough, powerful enough, to kill for?I honestly don't want to get into specifics, because The Plot is a smart, twisty book that I legitimately couldn't put down. For about 95% of this book, I had no idea what was going to happen next. Maybe that's me and my way of reading; I like to be surprised, so when I'm in a novel for the first time, I try not to think steps ahead. But closer to the end, I figured out not only the twist, but the twist on the twist. I don't know if that's the book's fault or my fault, or - if it is the doing of the book - if it's even a bad thing.You know what's weird for me as a reader - and, I guess, as a writer, too? Plot is secondary to me. For me, the most important part is if the story works. Are the characters interesting? Is everything moving along well? What's the language like? Author Korelitz has all this stuff nailed. Did I need the lengthy explanation at the end? Maybe not. It wasn't that it ruined the story, it's that it disrupted the momentum, just a little. Which might have been the point. The novel moves at such a breakneck pace that the calm, quiet finale is supposed to sort of be a last gasp of breath, I think. And did I love the epilogue? I fucking LOVED the epilogue. So it all washes out. I want to read more books by Korelitz, and it seems that there's a lot. And I also want to read more books about writers and writing and books and plots and stories. Because I can't get enough Kevnip....more

review: What's the difference between reading a literary website - with its sweeping overviews of books and writers, plus listicles of literary curios - and aWhat's the difference between reading a literary website - with its sweeping overviews of books and writers, plus listicles of literary curios - and a book that does exactly the same thing? I don't know. I used to go on Cracked all the time and I loved their book-themed lists (until they had this hyperbolic listicle about Lovecraft that was both factually wrong and unappealing to read), but before that, I loved nonfiction books about books. I think I might have spent upwards of a year of my life reading and re-reading that John Bear book about the New York Times #1 Bestseller. So when I saw The Curious Reader in a bookstore in New York, I bought it ASAP and dove in.What a book like this does is make you aware of other books - some part of the canon, some not, all worthy from one or more points of view. I kept waiting to "feel bad" for not reading some of the most defining works of literature, as this book tackles most of them: Crime & Punishment, Wuthering Heights, War & Peace. I ended up not feeling weird or guilty because I realize, now that I'm in my forties, that I am capable of reading these books. I earnestly think that reading Moby-Dick changed everything for me, expanding my mind and my sense of my own abilities as a reader. Plus, I'm not saying that it's not satisfying to say I've read Moby-Dick. What I am saying is that this book presented these classics (and new classics) in a way that made them seem accessible to who I am now. I kind of want to read Crime & Punishment and Anna Karenina and Beloved. I want to re-read The Color Purple. I've wanted to read The Joy Luck Club for years! I should read that! Let's make that happen!PS this book also taught me that I never, ever, ever want to read Ulysses. Because sometimes the canon can fuck itself. ...more

review: Earlier this year, I read Jaws for the first time. I was a little taken aback by the soap opera aspect, and the shark attack parts were not as excitinEarlier this year, I read Jaws for the first time. I was a little taken aback by the soap opera aspect, and the shark attack parts were not as exciting or interesting as I thought they might be. The problem with me is that I was comparing it to the movie, and the movie is one of the best, most exciting films ever made.One thing I didn’t know is that book and movie based on actual occurrences. Close to Shore is an account of the real shark behind Jaws, a great white that stalked the New Jersey shore in 1916, killing four people.The end of the book makes it very clear that this is aberrant behavior, and that great white sharks don’t usually behave this way. It also pushes the idea that the shark behind the 1916 attacks might actually not of been a great white. But all that is the back matter. The book understands why we have come to it. We want assurances that a single great white shark killed those people, that it went out of its way to do so, that it took a journey so unusual that it would seem silly if it had been in a movie. But it doesn’t seem silly in the book.Author Michael Capuzzo knows how to talk about shark attacks, managing to infuse terror into scenes when sharks simply graze a human (literally every part of a shark can hurt you, including its skin). But he also is a whiz at verisimilitude, Resenting us with the world of 1916, when swimming in the ocean was new, in the world seemed a lot more innocent. Capuzzo name drops authors, movie stars, and all manner of famous people in his pursuit of giving us an idea of what the Jersey Shore was like in the new 20th century and how a shark attack could go misdiagnosed for so long. I don’t know if this is a case of truth being more interesting than fiction, but I certainly liked this book a lot more than I liked Benchley’s Jaws. Oh maybe if there were more violent sex fantasy scenes, they’d be just about even....more

title: The Constant Rabbit
author: Fforde, Jasper*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Maybe it has to do with the (hopeful) end of the pandemic. I was in New York City two weekends ago, and browsing through a Barnes & Noble with my frieMaybe it has to do with the (hopeful) end of the pandemic. I was in New York City two weekends ago, and browsing through a Barnes & Noble with my friend Jeff. This is a sentence that still seems weird for multiple reasons. I was with a friend of mine? I was in New York? I was in a bookstore? We wandered around the display tables playing our favorite game of "how many have I read" (Jeff inevitably wins; he's more into the zeitgeist than I am), and glancing through the new novels. And there on the cover of this new book I saw spraypainted rabbit face with a cruel red X through it. I've always had an affinity for rabbits, possibly because, according to the Chinese zodiac, I am one. So I picked it up. Euphoria intensifies. The Constant Rabbit is a novel about what happens in the United Kingdom fifty years after the Spontaneous Anthropomorphizing Event, in which eighteen rabbits (not to mention a handful of foxes, weasels, bears, elephants, gophers, and bees) became suddenly humanoid. Fifty years on, the rabbits are dealing with all the torments of underprivileged people - prejudice, hatred, and an ongoing othering. Just because the metaphor is thin doesn't mean it's clumsy; Fforde is too smart and too clever for that. The world-building and culture-building make this a gripping science-fantasy story beyond being just a polemic against racism, jingoism, and classism. Much of it is really just fun.Take the rabbits' propensity for Victorian-era naming, due to their affinity for Beatrix Potter books. Or their love of duels, and of bouncing, and their utter disregard for doors. It all makes sense, but it's also just foreign enough to rate the ire of hate groups (like "Two Legs Good," the most virulent of the hominid-supremacy groups), who both hate and fear the rabbits, who mostly just want to be left alone. Our proxy into this story is a man named Peter Knox, a functionary at an anti-rabbit conglomerate run by an anthropomorphized fox and a bunch of hellish women and men who claim NOT to hate rabbits. The Constant Rabbit is mostly his story: how he realizes he's been doing evil things and pretending he's not, to befriending his rabbit next-door neighbors, to eventually being radicalized against the oppressive class. It helps that we like Peter, and his engaging daughter Pippa, very much; it makes his character arc far more enjoyable ... especially as the book comes to a close and things get, well, hairy.I'm supposed to have read Fforde by now. He writes fiction about fiction and that's some of my favorite fiction, but I've tried him before and wasn't engaged. Maybe I will be now. His inventive plot mechanics, his uniquely British (Douglas Adams-ish, specifically) humor, and his smart, well-written characters all worked for me in The Constant Rabbit, and I'm looking forward to seeing if they work for me elsewhere. ...more

title: The Pearl
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So like:I never had to read this in school. In fact, Steinbeck was NEVER assigned to us in school, not even Of Mice and Men, which is both bizarre andSo like:I never had to read this in school. In fact, Steinbeck was NEVER assigned to us in school, not even Of Mice and Men, which is both bizarre and lucky. I don't know if I would have sought him out later on and fallen so hard for his writing if I had been. And I know this novel/novella is a parable. It's a fairly obvious one, but I wonder how obvious it seemed when it was first published. The whole concept of money (or power) corrupting a person is a standard trope in fiction. Here, we have two dirt-poor people named Kino and Juana who, because their tiny baby has been stung by a scorpion and have to bring it to a corrupt doctor who will only treat those with money, have to find a way to make money quickly. So Kino dives for a pearl and ends up finding a gigantic one. You can see how this plays out. The villagers are first joyful, then jealous. The corrupt doctor decides to finally treat little baby Coyotito, who he POISONS and then HEALS, to prove his power to these people. Then they bring the pearl to some bankers who try to stiff him on the price, so Kino is all like, "Okay, well I'll go somewhere else because this thing is worth a lot more than you want to pay me."And then ... he is continually and systematically punished. I mean, people come to his house and try to steal his pearl. They send trackers after his family with rifles. They burn his house down. They force him on this long trek to a capital city and he doesn't even get there because (SPOILER ALERT FOR A REALLY OLD BOOK)the trackers try to kill Kino and shoot the baby instead. Like they shoot the top of the kid's head off.So, the moral here is supposed to be that money corrupts, right? Maybe the guy should have taken a thousand pesos for this pearl so the rich can get richer. Like, all Kino wants is for his son to learn how to read so that the rich can stop taking advantage of him. Maybe I'm missing the point of the book. It's very well-written, because it's Steinbeck, but "a poor person finally gets a chance to get a leg up and is punished so fucking hard for it" feels like shit. I didn't feel good reading this one. I'm interested to see how the literati view it....more

title: Farewell My Lovely
author: Chandler, Raymond
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't know if I've ever read Raymond Chandler before. I ought to have. My love of crime fiction stretches back almost as long as my love of horror, I don't know if I've ever read Raymond Chandler before. I ought to have. My love of crime fiction stretches back almost as long as my love of horror, and yet I'm still catching up with the classics. The way I came to the genre was Robert B. Parker, on my friend Tracey's recommendation. From there, I discovered Harlan Coben and Dennis Lehane, and I've worked my way forward and backward, trying to fill in the gaps. Hard Case Crime, the publisher specializing in reprinting classic out-of-print crime fiction and new stuff written in the style, has been a big help. Raymond Chandler has always been slightly out of reach. He's a little like Hemingway, even though he makes fun of the man in this book. Everything's a classic and everything's canon. He feels like a tall wall to climb, even though he was writing in a genre many people consider to be lowly and second-rate. What a difference eighty years of re-evaluation and veneration can do. Last year, I read The Big Sleep, the first featuring private dick Philip Marlowe, and I liked it a lot. I liked Farewell, My Lovely a lot too, but so much of it puzzled me. Was I reading it wrong? I loved the language and the tone of the book, but the plot kept seeming to slither out of my reach. In preparation for writing this, I glanced at the novel's Wikipedia page, and it seems that plot confusion was either a circumstance or a feature, not a bug. The book was a "fix-up," a novel cobbled together out of short stories. Chandler apparently didn't care overmuch if the plot made sense, so long as it felt good. And this book feels good. There's a jewel heist maybe? A black man gets killed early on and the n-word was unavoidable for a while; it was almsot okay when the corrupt cops and idiots were using it, but I was taken aback when Philip Marlowe did, too. Also, maybe a gay guy also got killed? It was hard to keep track. But I kept coming back to the language, and how Marlowe isn't some tough guy who couldn't be hurt or waylaid. title: Twenty Five Mystery Science Theater 3000 Films That Changed My Life In No Way Whatsoever
author: Conniff, Frank*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Here's the thing: I came to this book thinking - hoping - that there'd be some behind-the-scenes stuff on the making of MST3K. Even though the years oHere's the thing: I came to this book thinking - hoping - that there'd be some behind-the-scenes stuff on the making of MST3K. Even though the years of my deep obsession with it seem to be over and I've become more of a dabbler, the period of my life when I was more into it than almost anything stick with me. When I gain new over-arching interests, I don't give up on the old ones. Some head into the background and some just continue to insist themselves on my life. I didn't stop being into cheese because tiki swooped in, Blitzen Trapper didn't make me forget Springsteen, and Ann Patchett could never usurp Stephen King. But when you focus on a thing you like, even if you move on and develop new interests, that thing has a tendency to stick in your brain like a fly in amber. You position it at a time and place in your life when it had the most meaning, and in a lot of ways, it's always that. Frank Coniff, aka TV's Frank, was a big part of what made MST3K important for me, and only part of that was because I was extremely attracted to him at the time. So maybe it stands to reason that I assumed this book was going to be Conniff's fond, in-depth memories of all the times they had putting together this show that helped me stay sane during my fringe years. What I realized is something I've known all along about creative people and the art they make: they don't stay mired in it as long as the people who love it do. In this slim book of essays, Conniff uses his time at MST3K and the movies they riffed as a springboard to talk about other stuff: obscure pop culture, some politics, and, most revealingly, himself. While he doesn't go too in-depth, Conniff takes some time out of riffing on things to talk about his early years of drug and alcohol dependence, and how that profoundly affected him. There's one part near the end when he confesses that he wishes he could have enjoyed TV cop shows of the 70s when they were first on, but that he was too busy fucking up his life with addiction at the time. That's such a specific lament, and it's worth the price of this book. ...more

title: The Clothing of Books: An Essay
author: Lahiri, Jhumpa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Here’s where I have to stop hoping every writer will react to things the way that Stephen King does. I’ve been waiting to read this book, because I thHere’s where I have to stop hoping every writer will react to things the way that Stephen King does. I’ve been waiting to read this book, because I thought it would sort of be an interesting look at the way book covers and design inform or fight against the work inside the book. I did get that, to a degree; Jhumpa Lahiri has a lot of interesting things to say about cover art and why it’s so important. I guess I just wanted more examples.To be fair, she does talk about some specific writers and publishers. She likes the uniform look of the Penguin series from the 60s, as well as the types of books series they have in Italy that they don’t really have an America. On the other hand, the idiosyncratic look of Virginia Woolf’s books, designed by her sister Vanessa Bell, inspire her. (For good reason. I looked up those covers and they’re beyond awesome.)I may not know what I was hoping for. Compare and contrast? Painted covers vs photographic? Unsure. Lahiri is uncomfortable with accolades, statistics, and (her least favorite word) blurbs. For her, they are barriers between a writer and their reader. I can see that. You don’t want anyone’s words on a book before you’re allowed to present your own.I think maybe the most interesting part of the book is when Lahiri I was looking at her own books, and the jackets that go with them. As a writer of Indian heritage from America writing in Italy, she has a diverse background for writing, while her book covers tend to just show the Indian stuff: elephants and castles and the Ganges. I liked that sort of behind the scenes stuff and I kind of wanted more.As it turned out, I did really like her writing and maybe it’s time to see what her Pulitzer book is all about. I wonder what the cover looks like....more

title: Lisey's Story
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is my third go-round with Lisey's Story, and, somewhat surprisingly, it was my favorite so far. Stephen King has long talked about this being hisThis is my third go-round with Lisey's Story, and, somewhat surprisingly, it was my favorite so far. Stephen King has long talked about this being his best and/or favorite novel of his own, which always struck me as a little weird. Yes, it has to do with King's favorite subject of writing, specifically what it puts into writers and what it takes out of them. In more recent years, King has taken a deeper look at marriage and love, and what lies at the heart of people who have long histories together. Bag of Bones explored this brilliantly, and there's some of that in Duma Key and the novella "A Good Marriage." Lisey's Story is about both the light heart and the dark heart of a marriage, and why they coexist.My complaints about the book have generally stemmed from the fact that most of the novel isn't Lisey's Story at all; it's her dead husband's Scott's story, and, to a lesser degree, the story of her sister Amanda. Lisey is important but she's far from the only important part of the novel. Jessie Burlingame, to my mind, had more agency than Lisey Landon. But I latched on a little more to what King was trying to say. I think the book is a long mediation on grief, and how grief doesn't come all at once. Not everything in this book is a symbol, but I think there's a lot more symbolism going on than I thought. Amanda is Lisey's way of reconnecting with her family. The psycho Jim Dooley and what happens to him is her way of letting go of the writer side of her husband. She has to let him go - two years of grief is enough - and it always bugged me that Scott's last story, what he called Lisey's Story, wasn't about her but about how he killed his father. Now, I think, it feels like it WAS for her, because it's a way of telling her how to let go of the people you love. How it's necessary, even if you love them. I've always admired this book, but found it a little hard to love. Now, as we anticipate the new miniseries, I think I might have come around to loving it finally. And that's a great feeling. ...more

title: Press Reset: Ruin and Recovery in the Video Game Industry
author: Schreier, Jason*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm awash in media about video game companies right now. I'm just entering Season 2 of Mythic Quest. My husband just bought Skyward Sword for the SwitI'm awash in media about video game companies right now. I'm just entering Season 2 of Mythic Quest. My husband just bought Skyward Sword for the Switch. I'm considering writing a short story set in a development office. There's a whole thing going on in my head.But a lot of that's fiction. For years, I've heard horror stories about the gaming industry; the long, untenable hours, the burnout, the layoffs, the hellish term crunch. All the terrible things game developers have to go through, with no assurance that they won't get laid off after, or the company won't get shut down, or you won't have to move your entire family cross-country. It's a particularly scary way to live and work, and a lot of people in the industry put up with it because it has long seemed the only way. Schreier's book delves deep into the lives of people behind the biggest games in today's industry. I was sort of hoping for a deeper history at first - pocket histories of entertainment industries are my bread and butter - but the more I learned about these companies and the people they marginalized, the more I grew fascinated. You tend to only hear success stories - how Bioshock Infinite was such a humungous hit - but never about the tragic backstories of those successes. I learned a LOT about Curt Schilling, the Red Sox pitcher who thought it would be fun to run a video game company, and ended up bankrupting the business and almost destroying the economy of an entire state and kind of fucked over everyone with his hubris. And I learned about how things might be changing in the industry, due to consultancy firms and unions.If all of this sounds staid and dull, I assure you, it's not. Schreier keeps things going at a fast, exciting pace, always giving you enough information to understand his context but never bogging you down. It's smart and fun to read. I don't ... think I read his first book, which I believe IS a history of the video game industry, but I think I'm going to now. ...more
