title: Project Hail Mary
author: Weir, Andy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For me, Andy Weird is three for three. In anticipation of Project Hail Mary coming out, I read a few s saying his second book, Artemis, was no gFor me, Andy Weird is three for three. In anticipation of Project Hail Mary coming out, I read a few s saying his second book, Artemis, was no good. Strong disagree; in the parlance of this new book: wrong wrong wrong. I loved Artemis, maybe even more than The Martian.And I loved Project Hail Mary more than either.The setup is similar to that of The Martian: it's a guy trapped in space, trying to solve a massive problem using science. A brilliant cavalcade of diverse smart people back on Earth are also working to solve the problem, with nations working together with little rancor or problem. One of the most exciting things about Weir's novels is that the casts are cosmopolitan and mainly focus on smart people using the scientific method to solve issues. Things go wrong. Smart people can do dumb things. Mistakes can be made. But science and fact are at the heart of it all. It's immensely comforting.The problem here is that an invasive species known as astrophage is kind of sort of eating the sun. The earth is cooling way faster than it should (one of the ironies of the book is that our terrible global warming crisis actually saved us a bit). Middle school science teacher Ryland Grace was the guy who figured out what astrophage was, so even though he's not technically one of the world's elite scientists, he gets dragged along, helping the other science people to figure out what to do.The issue is that the book is told in split narrative: the now and the then. We know Ryland is out in space from the very beginning. He gains his memories back slowly, a trickle at a time. And only as we're closing in on the end do we understand some of the darker secrets about his placement in the mission, and why he's there. I honestly don't want to give too detailed a , because figuring all this stuff out along with Grace is so honestly thrilling and charming and fun. Are there dad jokes? Sure there are. That's part of Weir's charm. And yeah, there are pop culture references, but I've seen Weir's work compared to something like Ready Player One, and it's not that at all. He references something and then moves on; science is what drives this book, not memories of Super Mario Brothers 2. (Not that there's anything wrong with Ready Player One! This is just a different experience.)Occasionally I would wonder if I was going to get over my head with the math and science in this. Never once did it matter. Ryland Grace trusts in that stuff, so you can, too. If you just accept that he knows what he's talking about, you don't ever get bogged down. I LOVED this book. ...more

title: Castle in the Air
author: Westlake, Donald E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It honestly should not have taken me this long to finish a caper novel. It's not the book's fault, and it's not Donald Westlake's fault. If anything, It honestly should not have taken me this long to finish a caper novel. It's not the book's fault, and it's not Donald Westlake's fault. If anything, you could kind of blame the world opening back up, and the fact that my own novel has decided to capture my life again. You see, my friends Tracey and Liz are doing this thing where they wake up at 5:30 AM every day and work on writing and the idea was so alluring that I started doing just that. The problem is, the morning time with my coffee used to be when I would read physical books and not let any of the outside world distract me. The pandemic was great for a lack of distraction. It's all back now, and it's why it took me nearly a month to finish a book that should have taken me two days.Here are two things to know about Castle in the Air: 1. When the front cover says, "First publication in 40 years," that means 1980. That means this book is a classic crime novel, and that classic crime novels were coming out in my lifetime. It means I'm old, and so is the rest of the GenX and geriatric millenial crime-come-latelies who are discovering Westlake and Hard Case Crime just now. 2. This book is hilarious. It's hilarious. And I didn't expect that, because even though Westlake is known for his funny crime novels, especially the Dortmunder stuff, I have never read any of it. I've read the novels he wrote under his Richard Stark name, which are also heist novels, but they tend to involve a lot of murder. I've also read Memory, which is stunningly good but extremely serious, and his two dark thrillers, The Ax and The Hook. All fantastic. Very few chuckles.So when I'm in the first few pages of this book, which involves an extremely convoluted plan to steal an ACTUAL CASTLE, and I'm laughing a little reluctantly because ... wait is this funny? And then I realize it's a caper set in Europe, and there are factions of Italian, Spanish, British, and German people working together, none of whom speak each others' language, and that there are double- and triple- and quadruple-crosses afoot. And there's an entire who's-on-first chapter where Westlake is reveling in language and its flexibility and okay. Okay. I know what's happening now. And it's good. Like, really good. You got me again, Westlake! But maybe I should read The Ax again next......more

title: Tiki Modern
author: Kirsten, Sven A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I caught the white whale.All during quarantine, I’ve been reading books on tiki bars, tiki restaurant, the art and history of tiki. I’ve delved into sI caught the white whale.All during quarantine, I’ve been reading books on tiki bars, tiki restaurant, the art and history of tiki. I’ve delved into spinoff subjects, like lowbrow art, Hawaii in the 1950s, and mid-century kitsch. The work of Sven Kirsten informed a lot of what I was reading; his massive The Book of Tiki was one of the major forces in bringing about the tiki revival worldwide. I devoured that one, and all his other books, learning, obsessing, becoming - against all odds - a tiki guy.But one book eluded me. The big one. The sequel. Kirsten’s TIKI MODERN came out as the tiki revival was just gaining steam,and was thus able to look even deeper into what made this trend so durable. Lke its predecessor, it was massive and picture-packed, tracing the pop culture history of tiki, Polynesian Pop, and the concept of the "modern primitive." One of the more interesting aspects about Tiki Modern is that Kirsten doesn't shy away from the racism and misogyny inherent in a lot of early tiki; the images and utilizations of the "beautiful wahine" and the "noble savage" were always a little contentious, especially given the Civil Rights unrest of the time in which tiki was winding down. While Tiki Modern doesn't necessarily provide a key for reckoning with these issues while still allowing us to love this movement, recognizing it in a book as informative and important as this is a great step in the right direction.One of the early s of this book I read, while still trying desperately to find it, complained that it wasn't really about tiki at all, but about Witco, a company that made its name on wood carvings (often made with chainsaws) of tiki and primitive art - some of which was huge and functional, like seats, bars, and tables. I think Kirsten makes a good point that the ascendency of Witco is a big part of what made tiki such a big deal in its mid-century heyday, and how flexible the concept of tiki is, able to encompass cultures beyond what Americans understood as "Polynesia." (And of course, that's always been a part of the bizarre amalgamation of tiki in America: the art and decor is Polynesian, the drinks are Caribbean, and the food is Cantonese. So why not carvings based on African tropes and, yes, cliches?)Like all of Kirsten's books, Tiki Modern helped me better understand what was so alluring about this whole trend, why it captured middle America so completely, and why it was abandoned so abruptly. And I never would have owned it had it not been for that stimulus that hit my account a few short months ago. I paid down credit cards. I paid some bills. And then I went to AbeBooks and found a listing for a like-new copy of this gargantuan tome of tiki. It was expensive - maybe too expensive - but it was out of print and man, did I want it. And what was a stimulus for, anyway, if not to stimulate? Tiki Modern completely captivated me over a period of six days, and there's nothing more you can ask of a book....more

title: For Whom The Bell Tolls
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We're in the middle of the Spanish Civil War. I honestly don't know much about it. It's about revolution, rising up against a fascist dictatorship. AnWe're in the middle of the Spanish Civil War. I honestly don't know much about it. It's about revolution, rising up against a fascist dictatorship. And there's a man at the center of it, the incongruously named Robert Jordan, who, in this reality, did NOT write the Wheel of Time series. And his orders are to blow up a bridge. That's it, that's the whole story. But it's not. Because over the course of the four days (well, three days, as we are reminded sadly at the end), the whole bloody war plays out. It sounds so trite to say this minor act in a major war stands as a metaphor/synecdoche for the whole war, but it's inescapable. Maybe it's a metaphor for war in general. It's not just about Robert Jordan, an American schoolteacher who finds himself a soldier. It's also about a group of guerilla fighters across enemy lines with whom he must team up in order to blow the bridge and complete his mission. Much of the story is about them: the beautiful, nearly broken Maria; the strong and commanding Pilar; the shifty, untrustworthy Pablo; the aged, reliable Anselmo. More. Some of the personalities bristle at first, almost everyone fitting into a "type." But then sketches of traits become real people. The strong woman in charge makes a mistake. The distant Jordan falls in love. A pretentious fop has reserves of bravery. Nobody is who they first seem. That's a big part of why this book works as well as it does.But it's also the machinations of war. The waiting for the right moment, driving people mad. The bureaucracy, the untrustworthiness, the desperation. The seeming futility of war matched against the desire to do one's best, even past the point of endurance. There are harrowing backstories: terrible things the fascists did to the resistance, unspeakable things the resistance did to the fascists, and Robert Jordan's quiet, all-too-apt family history in which he resents his father and idolizes his grandfather, stances he might be recanting near the end of the book. Hemingway manages to encapsulate the horrors of war - and the brief, fleeting moments of beauty people have to find to survive - without going full gore and by using the actual word "obscenity" in the place of obscenities. In a more modern book, that wouldn't fly, and it seems silly at first ... and then it just becomes part of the fabric of this story. You can get used to anything, and maybe that's a meta-commentary on what this book is about. War is numbing and harsh and terrible, but you can get used to it, if you have to. Even if doom hangs over everything you do, you can get used to it. And if you have to die, do it with dignity, and do it fighting. I had no idea Our Year(s) of Covid were going to spur an interest in Hemingway. This feels a lot like when I got into Vonnegut a few years back. I'm interesting in knowing more about him now. Over the course of the last year or so, I've read Hemingway's Big Three: this one, A Farewell to Arms, and The Sun Also Rises. Not to mention A Moveable Feast, my favorite of his books. It remains to be seen if I dip back into The Old Man and the Sea or try one of his lesser books. I really liked this one, even though I don't generally like war stories, and I had my own issues with the character of Maria (who might make more sense if we know she's suffering extreme PTSD), but yeah. I'm apparently a Hemingway guy now. Weird. ...more

title: And a Bottle of Rum: A History of the New World in Ten Cocktails
author: Curtis, Wayne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was sort of a teetotaler most of my life. Drinking was just never my thing. I was at a Stephen King convention at 21 when I first got drunk, on whisI was sort of a teetotaler most of my life. Drinking was just never my thing. I was at a Stephen King convention at 21 when I first got drunk, on whiskey sours in little bottles by my new friends I wanted to impress. I drank very little since then until I was at a work function, and my friend Jenny had me try a "cabana boy," which is Malibu rum and pineapple juice. I loved it. I'd found my drink. Over the years, that was my drink of choice wherever I went. If alcohol was being served, I'd grab that. If it wasn't available, or if I was feeling adventurous, a Malibu and Coke would do. I was in a holding pattern. Then came tiki bars. It started with Trader Sam's Grog Grotto in Walt Disney World and sort of exploded from there. I loved discovering all these different exotic cocktails and finding out why I liked them and why I didn't. I didn't give all that much thought to the rum itself. Even when I started buying rum in mass quantities in Our Pandemic Year, I basically followed what the recipe said. If it asked for a white Puerto Rican rum, I'd grab a John Q Cristal. If it wanted dark Jamaican, Myers always did well. Then and still now, I was never really a rum connoisseur. I like what it does when it mixes with other things, and I'm unsure if I'm ever going to go beyond that. But it still fascinates me.My friend Josh gifted me Wayne Curtis' And a Bottle of Rum for Christmas, and I'd been eager to read it ever since. I love these history lessons when viewed through the lens of something specific (as I had when I read The History of the World in Six Glasses, because I apparently have a penchant for pop history books on beverages). (HA! "Pop." Beverages. Well I thought it was funny.)Books like this are always packed with awesome stories and surprising facts, like the one where we learn that, at least initially, Captain Morgan wasn't all that into rum. How rum got big during the Depression, then sank, then got big again after WWII. It's fascinating to me how relatively often rum goes from classy to tacky and back again. Does any other spirit do that? We start way back in the 1600s, when rum was called Kill-Devil, all the way to the 2010s, to the recent microstill movement in the States. Along the way, we learn about piracy and slavery, the tiki movement and Paul Revere's ride, and so, so much about Hemingway and Cuba. It's all fantastic. I'm a slow reader but I absorbed this book, and not just because of the tiki connection (although I will say whenever I'm about to dip into the Donn Beach or Vic Bergeron story again, I always feel a little cozy. It's the whole "I know this history; how is this guy going to tell it?" Really well, it turns out.)I'm in the phase in my obsession when satellite obsessions are finally coming to the fore. I've now read a book on lowbrow art, and about Hawaii in the 1950s, and now the history of rum. Tiki is endless, and there is still so much more to discover and explore. I love this journey (and this book!)...more

title: Outlawed
author: North, Anna*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I discovered this book when I was casting about for something new to read, just hoping to stumble on quality. I saw that this book was endorsed by ReeI discovered this book when I was casting about for something new to read, just hoping to stumble on quality. I saw that this book was endorsed by Reese Witherspoon, and grabbed it. Reese and I are simpatico.I’ve been describing this book as “If The Handmaid’s Tale was a Western.” That’s not quite right. This is an alternate history, and women do exist for breeding, but that’s really where the similarities end. All you need to know is that a pandemic swept the still-forming United States and the country no longer exists as it had. (Hm.) Now women are expected to marry young and produce many children. If they’re barren? They are witches, and will likely be hung.Ada, our hero, is an apprentice midwife; her mother is the town’s most respected medical person. But when Ada is barren, the town starts blaming all its other ailments on her. If someone’s child dies, it’s because of the witch. If there’s an outbreak of flu, it’s because of the witch. Ada knows she can’t stay in town, or she will be killed. So she becomes an outlaw.Most of this awesome novel concerns what happens when Ada meets up with the Hole in the Wall Gang, a group of banished women who have also become outlaws by necessity. How Ada fits in. How she fails and succeeds. And how, most importantly, she unearths the purpose in herself. One of the best things about this book is that the women at the center are so vehemently defined by what they can’t do that they have to fight to be redefined by what they can do, and by who they are. A note: I’ve read a few books with enby characters, and this one seems to handle the language and nomenclature the best. The lack of pronouns for the character - eschewing even “them” - never really stands out as arch or working too hard to define them. They just are, and that was really refreshing. I really enjoyed Outlawed, and I would love more of Ada’s story. Who knows? Anna North has more books. Time to dive in!...more

title: The Diary of a Bookseller        (Diary of a Bookseller, #1)
author: Bythell, Shaun
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Do you know what this book made me think of? Microserfs. One of my favorite books of all time (that kind of no longer really holds up), Microserfs wasDo you know what this book made me think of? Microserfs. One of my favorite books of all time (that kind of no longer really holds up), Microserfs was about a place and time in America where a group of people who work together could have an insular world that the outside world didn’t touch much. There’s a lot of that in here, even though this is not only a first person point of view, but a true life diary. Shaun Bythell paints these miniature retail stories of this book shop in Wigtown Scotland, The oddballs he works with, the weirdos who shop there, and how sometimes a person who just really loves books comes in and they have a conversation.I kept expecting this book to feel more cynical. Bythell sometimes seems on the verge of anger or world-weariness. He avoids it by reading, and selling, and buying books. One of the most interesting aspects of this book is the way Bythell goes into peoples’ houses and looks at their collections, purchasing what he can. He talks about how difficult it is to purchase libraries of the recently deceased, some thing I never really would’ve thought of until I read this. Like, what happens when you want to be kind, but the books left behind are mostly trash? And because this is a proper diary, you get caught up in the episodic nature of it all. Someone briefly mentioned in a February entry becomes a major part of the story later on in the summer. But it’s not just the big stuff; it’s the way Bythell will find a book vaguely interesting, and pick it up. Six chapters later he’s nearly done and that’s almost as exciting to me as the run up to the book fair, or the parties around Christmas.I keep wanting to say that the author does a good job keeping this book from feeling like a standard bookshop memoir, but I’m not that sure there is a standard bookshop memoir. And if there is I kind of want to read it. I don’t think there are enough books about people running bookstores, who love bookstores. Especially nowadays, which yes, makes me feel as old as it makes you feel. I really liked this book....more

title: Moloka'i        (Moloka'i, #1)
author: Brennert, Alan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I noticed this on my stepmother's Goodreads page and I had no idea what it was. I should have remembered my Michener, from whom I'd already read a faiI noticed this on my stepmother's Goodreads page and I had no idea what it was. I should have remembered my Michener, from whom I'd already read a fairly in-depth accounting of Hawai'i's leper colony on the island of Moloka'i. But Michener is sometimes long on events and short on human emotion; this story, delving into the life of Rachel Kalama, a young girl who, at the age of 7, contracts leprosy and and is sent away from her family forever. It's somewhat easy to look at a book of this nature and say, "This character discovered in her exile how to truly live," and to treat the character as a series of stock heroics. "Bearing up under the strain of both a disease she didn't ask for and a people who no longer want her, Rachel found freedom within." Nope. Not that simple. Rachel has shit luck. She's born into a time in Hawai'i when the indigenous people had no natural defense against the disease. Calling it "leprosy" brings so many connotations, especially for Hawai'ians who had studied the Bibles left by missionaries. Lepers were not only "unclean," they were pretty much unholy. Shipping them off to their own colony away from non-leprous people was seen as the best option. For whom remains one of the most trenchant questions of the novel.Against the odds, Rachel makes friends on Moloka'i, which is great. The only problem is, most of them are also lepers, and lepers tend to die early, after enduring both exile and often painful treatments to eradicate the disease. She meets a non-leprous boy who seems to love her, but who won't touch her. One of her favorite adults on the island goes through a spiral of guilt and shame and attempts suicide. The man she eventually marries ... well, there's no end to tragedy here.So why isn't Moloka'i a Hawaiian retelling of The Little Match Girl? Because Rachel herself is pretty damn awesome. She's not perfect, and boy does she suffer, but she's smart and does tend to be resilient. She decides not to give up every day, so she is noble, but not in a way that makes her feel like a stand-in for an entire people. She's just her, and just her is fascinating and interesting. Except for maybe the tsunami (at this point, it's like, can't this girl catch a BREAK!?), nothing in Moloka'i feels extraneous or harsh for harsh's sake. The deeper I get into Hawai'ian culture and history, the more I want to know. This was a very good book....more

title: The Liar's Dictionary
author: Williams, Eley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was very late at night and I was casting about Audible, desperate for something new to listen to. I saw this book, and the description - it's aboutIt was very late at night and I was casting about Audible, desperate for something new to listen to. I saw this book, and the description - it's about a research assistant whose job it is to find fake words in old dictionaries - hit my literary sweet spot enough for me to smash that download button.Except it's not about that, not really, and my lifelong exposure to the world of jacket-flap summations should have warned me. This is a book about dictionaries, sure, but of course it's more about the people: one building the dictionary, and one dismantling it. In the present, our hero Mallory is the sole employee of Swansby's Dictionary, her boss a kind, slightly doddering old man who has charged her with winnowing out "mountweazels," those fake words that have somehow persisted in many ill-advised printings of the book. Mallory is dealing with a lot. Her job feels unimportant, she's not out of the closet (despite being in a loving, long-term relationship with a more fiery woman named Pip), and she keeps getting calls at work from a psychopath with a voice modulator, telling her they're going to blow up the building because Swansby's has de-gendered the definition of the word "marriage." It's a lot to take.Meanwhile, at the turn of the 20th century, we make the acquaintance of Peter Winceworth, a functionary lexicographer helping to create the first edition of Swansby's. He's forgotten by and dismissed by his co-workers, he has affected a lisp to gain sympathy, and he might be in love with a woman who is the fiancée of his greatest enemy, one of those rugged explorer types named Thrasham, who has a huge red beard and is everything Winceworth is not. These two narratives twist through one another, not quite connecting but not quite standing alone. Both Winceworth and Mallory need some sort of jolt in their lives to figure out what it is they really want. Both have people who care about them, even though they're in their own heads too intensely to understand why. And both stumble across secrets that change their perception of their small world. The more I think about the twin endings, the more I like them, and the more they seem like the absolute right finales for these two. What drives this novel is a love of words - real, made-up, imaginary. The language is so much fun, and when people banter, it's intellectual and satisfying. There are some grand action sequences you don't quite expect, which added and enriched the book. On the other hand, there's a long sequence involving a moth that freaked me out (my motteophobia is rampant), so I had to get over my crawling skin for a few chapters. In the end, The Liar's Dictionary is a very good book. I don't know if I'll read it again, but now I want more by the author. More novels about words, please! ...more

title: Win        (Windsor Horne Lockwood III, #1)
author: Coben, Harlan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've been waiting for this book for about twenty-five years.I first caught the Coben bug sometime in 1996. I was, believe it or not, on a Yoo-Hoo fan I've been waiting for this book for about twenty-five years.I first caught the Coben bug sometime in 1996. I was, believe it or not, on a Yoo-Hoo fan page, and one of the links led me to Coben's Myron Bolitar novels. Bolitar, a sports agent with a nose for solving murders, was a huge Yoo-Hoo (and Batman) fan. I didn't care thing one about basketball, or golf, or baseball, or any other sport. Yet I loved the Bolitar novels. They felt like detective miniseries on TV. Easy to follow, easy to digest, easy to move onto the next.That changed in 1998 with One False Move. I think a lot of series writers discover that, if they're going to keep writing about one character over and over, eventually you have to widen their world and deepen their stories. Coben (who, by the way, I was texting with over AOL around this time), proved more than capable of doing that. Myron Bolitar grew more complex, as did most of his supporting cast, including Esperanza Diaz and Big Cyndi. But Win, Myron's best friend with the preppy good looks and good breeding and the psychopathic streak, seemed to me at least to only grow into more of a stereotype. Win helped Myron with the stuff Myron was not prepared to do. He killed people if they broke his odd and complex moral code. He had a lot of sex with prostitutes and filmed himself doing it, so he could watch the videos later while he meditated. He was a misanthrope, perhaps unable to care for anyone but himself, Esperanza, and especially Myron. In later books, he had a somewhat casual relationship with a woman named Mee, but that seemed more convenient than anything. From his name to his background to his wealth and privilege, Win was something of an antihero trope. You're maybe not supposed to GET him, but you are supposed to grudgingly like him. His awful qualities are what make the good-guy characters look better, and put him in a very appealing gray light.I was excited for a book just about him, but not necessarily because I thought the character could prop up a whole story. This pandemic has been just gross, and Harlan Coben had been with me at the start with The Boy in the Woods. All I wanted was another novel by him, and it didn't matter if it was ill-advised or not.Okay, so: or not. There's something that happens with charismatic lunatics in series, be they TV series or book series: in order to make them more broadly appealing, they get a little watered down. It happened a little with Spike on Buffy the Vampire Slayer. It's happening with Loki in the MCU. It sort of happened with Hawk in Robert Parker's Spenser series. But it didn't happen in Win, and that's sort of thrilling.Win, for all his issues, is not only capable of self-reflection; he's awash in it. One of the best things Coben does early on in this book is establish that Win is capable of realizing he's not perfect, that he can learn from past mistakes and misdeeds, and improve himself. A lot of his supporting cast is multicultural. He's given up the prostitutes for a hookup app that is still pretty skeezy but is more inclusive in its skeeziness. He has glimmers of affection for other characters.Oh, and Win still kills people. Oh, does he. And sometimes he tortures them. The mystery is a pretty thoroughly engaging one; Coben's favorite theme of the past coming back to haunt the present is very much in evidence here, but the circumstances are fresh enough so that the cozy feeling of coming home is offset by the political nature of the whole thing. There's a lot about stolen art and horrifying torture and endless revenge, and all of it's satisfying. I kept waiting to be disappointed that Myron was not at the center of things, but Win can absolutely hold his own here. Besides, Myron comes up enough that you're not really given the chance to miss him.Are there things I didn't like? Nah, not really. I could nitpick about Coben's literary tics, but if I'm gonna be distracted by every "there you are," I'd have to roll my eyes at John Irving's semicolons or Stephen King describing someone crying "lustily." It's part and parcel. What Harlan Coben did here was deliver me a good story featuring a well-known and well-liked character and made it feel new and fresh. I want a second Win novel now. That'd make it a Win-Win. (Hey, Coben did it first.) ...more

title: Scene of the Crime
author: Brubaker, Ed
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Last year, I picked up a hardcover copy of Pulp, a part-Western, part-noir bit of comic narrative by Ed Brubaker and Sean Phillips. I loved it, and woLast year, I picked up a hardcover copy of Pulp, a part-Western, part-noir bit of comic narrative by Ed Brubaker and Sean Phillips. I loved it, and wondered what else these two had done together. This is because I'm an idiot. I've long been familiar with the two names in comics. Brubaker (along with his partner Michael Lark) did a long run on my favorite comic, Daredevil, and also developed and co-wrote Gotham Central, a street-level look at cops in Batman's city. I loved this guy.But Brubaker/Phillips had really made their name in semi-independent crime and horror-noir (Fatale, Criminal, Incognito, The Fade Out), and despite this being directly in my wheelhouse, I avoided it all. Why? Well, I'd like to say it's because I wanted to preserve my favorite writers and artists for a rainy day or something. The truth is, even though I'm a sucker for noir, I hate smoking. I just hate it so much. And if a cover features a character smoking, I will not buy it. It's not that I've mellowed over the years, but The Scene of the Crime - an early 2000s neo-noir written by Brubaker, drawn by Lark, and inked by Phillips - caught me before I could change my mind. I've made a long habit out of rationalizing enjoying art when smoking is involved (being in love with Tarantino films has been a colossal effort), but in Scene of the Crime, my saving grace was that none of the three main characters did it, so I could be safe with them. It's absurd, I know. But it's how my brain has to work to help me like stuff like this. And I do like it. Quite a lot, actually. It's sort of a boilerplate mystery of missing persons, cults, unbelievable abuse, and a lone-wolf private eye with a Dark Backstory. What makes Scene of the Crime work so well is the characters, as is generally the case with crime fiction. Jack Harriman is a young detective trying to move past his demons; he kind of reminds me of Lawrence Block's Matt Scudder, if he was a lot younger. I liked the color of San Francisco - kind of the prime locus of this kind of fiction (it makes me want to read more crime fiction from the 1940s) - and the fact that in this world, a crime-scene photographer can be famous enough to warrant a small museum dedicated to him. Lark's art reminds me a lot of David Aja's work in Hawkeye, a lot of heavy linework and a xerographic feel that makes everything a little grittier. I think I'm going to have to work through my phobia to read more work by these two, especially since The Fade Out is about old Hollywood, and oh my am I a sucker for that stuff. I'm really glad this story is back in print (with extras! a bonus story! behind the scenes stuff! a Bendis intro!) and I'm looking forward to a journey of exploration....more

title: The Extraordinary Life of Sam Hell
author: Dugoni, Robert*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For the longest time, I didn't know what literary itch The Extraordinary Life of Sam Hell was scratching. It starts off as a vaguely religious novel. For the longest time, I didn't know what literary itch The Extraordinary Life of Sam Hell was scratching. It starts off as a vaguely religious novel. The main character, a kid named Samuel Hill, has been born with ocular albinism - red eyes. His mother, a devout Catholic, wants him to go to the Catholic middle school in town, but the headmistress thinks a child known as "Devil Boy" doesn't belong in place like that. Sam's mother's will is as strong as her faith, and she gets him into that school. But here Sam's troubles begin. I figured out halfway through that I was feeling a very distinct John Irving vibe in this book - the John Irving of A Prayer for Owen Meany and Avenue of Mysteries. It's a book about mothers and sons and faith. (Also, incidentally, I wrote a few books like this back in the day, so it made me feel connected to those mid-aughts novels of mine.) And it's a book about the hell people go through, and what rewards wait for them after all their trials.Did I like the book? Yes, quite a bit. I got more invested in the characters than I thought I would, especially Sam and his friend Mickey, a girl he may or may not be in love with. Occasionally, though, it felt as if the characters were becoming symbols. The plot machinations grew slightly more overt as we came closer to the end, where faith and the hidden, unknowable world of God sometimes became shortcuts in writing and character growth. I loved these characters very much, but sometimes I felt like their rewards didn't feel as earned as I wanted them to feel. But I'd recommend it, just the same. It's a literary novel written by a mystery and suspense writer, which means that it's got a lot of emotion but never bogs down in plot swamps. Smart, heartfelt, and very well written - despite my slight misgivings, I really enjoyed this book. ...more

title: Terms of Endearment
author: McMurtry, Larry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Part of why it took me so long to finish this novel is because the author died. I know that's not an excuse. I was reading Slaughterhouse-Five when VoPart of why it took me so long to finish this novel is because the author died. I know that's not an excuse. I was reading Slaughterhouse-Five when Vonnegut died and though I felt like a ghoul, I finished that book and then went into a Vonnegut mini-obsession. It's not as if I haven't read Larry McMurtry before, either. I loved The Last Picture Show and Lonesome Dove. I liked Loop Group, a weird one for me to pick up early (it was at the library and it looked approachable). His trilogy of creative memoirs - Books, Literary Life, and Hollywood - blew me away. I want to read all of those again.When I picked out Terms of Endearment, I didn't know McMurtry was about to die. It was on my to-read pile, near the top, when I found out he'd passed. So, what to do? Read this book as a tribute to his life or put it off in deference to his death? Does anyone else think of this stuff? Just me? You see, I remembered the movie version enough to remember the big stuff - particularly, the major death that colors the whole rest of the film. And I wasn't sure I wanted to read a book about death by an author who had died. I started it, then put it on a sort of indefinite hold. Eventually, I snuck around the other side and downloaded the audio version, and that's the one that I stuck with. Man, is it good writing. Now obviously I say this as a man reading a man's book about women (it didn't pass me by that for a time, I was reading TWO books by men about women, but that's kind of Grady Hendrix's thing so it almost didn't occur to me), but I found the characterizations of Aurora Greenway and her daughter Emma so well-drawn and fully realized that almost every other character felt a little like a cardboard cutout in comparison. I kept expecting to get annoyed with Aurora, who lives a loud, breezy, performative life ... and I didn't get annoyed, because these aren't exactly affectations. Or, if they are affectations, she believes in them completely. There's something so captivating about a person whose entire personality seems like a collection of clichés and idiosyncrasies, but whose real self is such a pure distillation of those very things that it's hard to separate what's overblown and what's at the core. To love Aurora - and people do love Aurora - is to understand that eccentricity is something you cope with and battle with, never quite winning, never entirely losing. The person who understands her the most, her daughter Emma, is an entirely different sort: practical, a little cynical, able to think in less grandiose terms and thus able to cope with a less fulfilling life. It's important that Emma understands Aurora, because it seems obvious that the understanding doesn't go the other way ... until it does, at the most crucial moments. Terms of Endearment is the story of two women whose lives intertwine, unravel, and come back together. Whose lives are radically different except in how very similar they are. The denouement of this one is as affecting as those in Last Picture Show or Lonesome Dove, maybe even more so. I loved this book. I just don't know as if I'll read it ever again. (I will.) ...more

title: Pacific Ocean Park: The Rise and Fall of Los Angeles' Space Age Nautical Pleasure Pier
author: Merritt, Christopher
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For every success story like Disneyland, or Universal, or Knott's Berry Farm, there is a story of a theme or amusement park that strove for greatness,For every success story like Disneyland, or Universal, or Knott's Berry Farm, there is a story of a theme or amusement park that strove for greatness, and ultimately fell short. This is one of those stories, and it's fascinating.Pacific Ocean Park had its beginnings way back at the turn of the 20th Century, and this book does a good job at crafting the prehistory of the park, the beach, and the pier before the actual park came online. And man, what an ambitious park! It's basically a Googie explosion, with a "starfish" entrance that reminds me the Theme Building at LAX. Lots of themed lands like Disneyland, including an undersea world (I got very, very enamored of the term dry-for-wet, a theme park phrase meaning that it's dry but it looks wet; I don't know how I've been in the theme park world this long and have never heard it), a space area, and a Polynesian Pop area with a working train at the far end of the pier. The skyway that took you from one end of the park to the other was made up of dangling plastic bubbles you sat in and saw the raging ocean below. There was a rollercoaster and an Enchanted Forest and so much else that made both my midcentury and theme park brains go bonkers.But the park - known as the P.O.P. (even when referenced in a Beach Boys song) - is no longer there. You know that going in, so this book has no choice but to become a tragedy. It starts with debt, of course, and the high cost of running an amusement venture. The salt air wreaking havoc on rides and facades. And, as things start getting a little seedier, in comes a new park runner named Jack Roberts, who's basically carny-from-carny. He brings in more pitch-til-u-win ventures, and off-the-rack rides. The more ambitious stuff falls into disrepair. By the end, even the shells of the old rides can't stand up against the powers of fire and water and decay. But along the way, there are a lot of bright sports. The outsized optimism in creating a themed environment like this in the first place should be applauded, and I loved how it coincided with the youth movement of the late 50s. All of it's captured in these awesome photographs and copies of old maps and souvenirs. So too, sadly, are the pictures of the park's eventual destruction - although even these are beautiful in their own weird way. I knew very little about this nautical space-age park going in, and I'm just so fascinated that something like this came to be at all. This is a treasure of a book....more

title: Someday Angeline        (Someday Angeline, #1)
author: Sachar, Louis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My friend Tracey gives me kids' and young adult books for holidays. It's a longstanding tradition. Back when we used to work at the bookstore(s) togetMy friend Tracey gives me kids' and young adult books for holidays. It's a longstanding tradition. Back when we used to work at the bookstore(s) together (oh my god, we worked at three different bookstores together), we would compare notes about which kids' books we liked when we were young and impressionable. We'd both read the Judy Blume oeuvre, obviously. We were very sympatico on Taking Care of Terrific, which I was able to take out of the school library when they told me I was too young for That Was Then, This is Now. I don't know where Tracey stands on Beverly Cleary, except that she hates Dear Mr. Henshaw, because apparently she hates books about young boys whose parents are divorced and who develop an unhealthy attachment to a novelist; for some unknown reason, I kinda like that one. So for Christmas this year, I was again in the position of being gently nudged toward books of my youth that I may have missed. In this case, it's Someday Angeline, by Louis Sachar, who ... I MUST have read when I was little, right? You can't escape grade school in the 80s and 90s without experiencing Sachar, having a Roald Dahl moment, or getting traumatized by Cormier, right? I don't THINK I ever read this one. It's another of those books about weird kids, for weird kids ... so right up my alley. The kid here is Angeline, whose first word is "octopus" and who I was convinced was some kind of fish psychic, like Aquaman. Spoiler: she is not Aquaman. But she is kind of a genius, and she's kind of weird because of it, and she has a truly awful sixth-grade teacher who tries to convince her class that Cleveland is the capitol of Ohio. There's honestly a lot in here, from the aforementioned sadistic teacher, to lingering trauma, to the hardcore reality of high-pressure situations where there are no reasonable ways out. A lot of this book is silly (though there's an undercurrent of grief running through it you only grok when you're three-quarters of the way through), but it's honest. There are a few scenes where Angeline just straight-up loses her shit, and Sachar doesn't offer value judgments either way. It's freeing and draining at the same time.If you're a genius and you don't understand why your teacher doesn't want you to live up to your full intelligence, that can be a kick in the teeth. When your dad is your hero but he hates what he does that makes him a hero, that wears you down. Ditto being called a freak in school, and being in need of a friend who gets you. All this is good stuff, oddly exciting stuff, writing that makes me want to swim in the waters of Sachar's writing some more....more

title: Mike Nichols: A Life
author: Harris, Mark*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn’t know much about Mike Nichols when I picked up Mark Harris’s new book. I was familiar with Nichols & May due to a steady diet of Doctor DimentI didn’t know much about Mike Nichols when I picked up Mark Harris’s new book. I was familiar with Nichols & May due to a steady diet of Doctor Dimento as a youth. I was vaguely aware that he’d directed The Graduate, and that was because of Harris himself; I’d read his Pictures at a Revolution and was bowled over by it. Nowadays, I’m usually willing to trust an author I like, no matter what they’re writing about. That keeps working out for me.I wonder if knowing only a little bit about Mike Nichols worked in my favor, because the whole book was a continuing journey of discovery. We get the whole narrative, from his early days of working on two-person sketch comedy and improv with Elaine May, to his initial terror of directing plays and then movies, to his strings of hits and misses, to his uneasy time as an elder statesman. But it doesn't read like a novel, because Nichols's was idiosyncratic, and messy, and sometimes intense.I'm not sure if it's endemic to how Hollywood works (or used to work), but the way Nichols takes on huge projects seems almost accidental. Sometimes he stumbles into things. Sometimes he dares a studio to pay an outrageous salary, daring them to not hire him. Sometimes he basically begs to be convinced. It's as if, at least sometimes, he wants someone to drag him into something so that he'll have something to prove. Once he's inside a film or a play, Nichols usually seems to have a grasp on his talents. Before and after, he is a complete wreck. But that's not always, and that's a big part of the mystery of Mike Nichols. Anything can affect his confidence: drugs, weight gain, poor health, a misunderstanding of the project or the actors he's working with. Almost always, a project eventually clicks with him and that's satisfying. The few times when he seems completely at sea is so frustrating, but it makes you root for him more. That's one of the best things about this book: no matter what Nichols is doing or has done, you always root for him.And I have to applaud Harris for not taking the "greatest hits" way out of things. Often, when I read biographies about people, the focus is either on only their early career, with a gloss on the later stuff, or a "they did THIS!!!! and then a bunch of stuff for years and THEN THEY DID THIS!!!" Harris is just as fascinated as why The Graduate worked and why, in his opinion, Wolf didn't. (By the way, did you know Mike Nichols directed Wolf, with Jack Nicholson!? I didn't! Wow!)Thoroughly engaging, absolutely entertaining, and reverential and critical in equal measure, Mark Harris' Mike Nichols: A Life is a terrific book, one of the best I've read so far this year. Highly recommended. ...more

title: Suicide Hill
author: Ellroy, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a guy who likes crime fiction and mysteries, I've heard a lot about James Ellroy. On paper, it feels like I should love James Ellroy. Then again, oAs a guy who likes crime fiction and mysteries, I've heard a lot about James Ellroy. On paper, it feels like I should love James Ellroy. Then again, on paper, I should love Michael Connelly, and I just don't. I want to. I liked The Poet enough. But I've tried over and over and I'm not snagging on whatever everyone else is snagging on. I suspect that that's going to be the case with James Ellroy. Suicide Hill is the story of a cop and a criminal who are both struggling with rage issues that stem from wanting to save people. In this crazy mix-em-up, Duane Rice - the criminal - is setting up a trio of bank robberies, the first couple of which are subtle and spiral out from the pervert underground of 1980s Los Angeles. Lloyd Hopkins, the cop, is a dangerous, unbalanced police officer who is unafraid to kill to get justice done. There's a hell of a lot of nihilism going on. The person Rice is desperate to save might not care. Criminals and cops alike are bartering for their immortal soul at one time or another. Everyone is either crooked or corrupt. It's both fascinating and exhausting. I liked the IDEA of "there's no one to root for, because it's all bad," but the execution just made me sad. Lloyd Hopkins features in a trilogy I likely won't read. This isn't the first time this year I started a series featuring a recurring cop character somewhere past the first book, and I do wonder if I'd like Lloyd Hopkins, and this series, a little more if I'd begun at the beginning. And look, I love the movie LA Confidential, and I still have a desire to read the book (and likely the quadralogy it's a part of), but I do worry that this icon of crime fiction might not be my bag. ...more

title: The Lives of Lowbrow Artists: Volume 1
author: Costa, Fritz
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of the initial complaints I read about this book was that it didn’t include any art by the artists profiled. Except for the front cover, none of tOne of the initial complaints I read about this book was that it didn’t include any art by the artists profiled. Except for the front cover, none of the work discussed in this volume was replicated or reproduced so that the story of the artist could compare to the art the artist made.It’s a valid criticism, and would hold more weight if we weren’t all reading books with tiny, extremely powerful computers in our pockets at all times. One of the joys I had reading this book, was coming across a title or description and scrambling for my phone so I could look up the art. One of the best things about having this sort of multimedia approach to this book is that if I liked a piece of art referenced, I could go down a rabbit hole of more art, looking up after twenty minutes had gone by, my head dancing from all the lowbrow.And the stories themselves are fascinating. Mostly what I’ve been interested in is tiki-centric, second wave Lowbrow art. I didn’t know it was second wave, and getting a little background on first wave was pretty interesting (lots of hot rods and pretty pinup girls). I also didn’t know we were currently in the third wave, much like we sort of are with tiki itself. Costa explains all of this with a deft touch, seemingly as enthralled with the subject as he hopes the reader is. And what’s not to be enthralled by? Hearing the backstories of Shag, Tim Buskup, Derek Yaniger, Brandi Milne, and Miles Thompson is illuminating, and grow even more so as the book progresses, when you see the influences and intertwinings of this underground world progress and unfold. I have some quibbles. Sometimes the book shifts into present tense for unknown reasons. It’s jarring and weird, but doesn’t shake your confidence in the fidelity of the storytelling. And of course, me being me, I came to this book as a tiki fan looking to read about art in the tiki milieu. That’s totally my fault, though; nothing on the cover ever said there’d be a Brad Parker retrospective in here.And maybe that’s OK: one, this book got me interested in more art than I had been prepared for with my preconceptions. Two, it does say “volume one” on the cover (!!!) And three, and finally, a lot of lowbrow does bump up against tiki, because they are both uniquely American art forms that borrow from many different sources to create something idiosyncratic and brand-new. What a terrific book. ...more

title: The Field Guide to Tiki Decorating
author: Brandon, Kleyla,
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Eventually, I was going to have to get into decor. It's one of the basic tenets of tiki bars and tiki living - surrounding yourself with the fantasy oEventually, I was going to have to get into decor. It's one of the basic tenets of tiki bars and tiki living - surrounding yourself with the fantasy of an imagined South Seas/tropical adventure. The closer and closer I come to turning my home office into a tiki paradise, the more I'm interested in stuff like this.The book is short. Not short; tiny. It's meant to fit in your pocket. Written by the lead designer of both Trader Sam's locations in Orlando and Anaheim, Brandon Kleyla, the book offers a crash course in design theory and some helpful practical tips. Kleyla lays out a few different genres of tiki bars, talks about inspiration, and lays out some of the basics. One of his guest writers, Typhoon Tommy, provides a wealth of how-tos for the home tiki aficionado, like how to create realistic looking "bamboo" out of PVC pipe, and how to realistically age artifacts like lanterns and wooden tikis. It's all pretty good stuff. I only wish it was a lot longer. At one point, Kleyla stresses the importance of layering, but I was hoping for some specific examples, and maybe some real-world comparisons. Still, this breezy read works as both a solid introduction to the world of Polynesian Pop decor and a handbook for creation. Another avenue in the limitless world of tiki. ...more

title: DisneyWar
author: Stewart, James B.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a fascinating book. I couldn't have read this when I was just getting into Disney. In 2007, all I cared about was The Magic, and nothing was goinWhat a fascinating book. I couldn't have read this when I was just getting into Disney. In 2007, all I cared about was The Magic, and nothing was going to come between me and it. I was aware of this book but I steered clear of it, relying on rapturous Disney histories and blogs and, eventually, DisTwitter. OK, so it wasn't all rapturous.DisneyWar charts Michael Eisner's tenure as CEO of the Walt Disney Company. From the early days, when Roy Disney staged a near-coup to get Eisner on board, to the waning final days, when Roy did it again to strip Eisner of his power, Eisner's tenure was tumultuous. I've talked about Eisner's time at Disney plenty on both social media and in my podcast, The Thirty20Eight. But although I knew some of his highlights and lowlights, I knew nothing of the corporate intrigue, the paranoia, and the increasingly insular nature of the company and the man. I don't know how much of the book highlights the latter-era missed chances because it deals with successes we know about, or because they were just so egregious. How Disney gave up a bunch of the profits for The Sixth Sense, because Eisner didn't think it would do well. How he excoriated Finding Nemo as "Pixar will finally have a wake-up call" as to how their golden reign would end. How Eisner passed on CSI and Survivor, which became massive hits elsewhere. Is it all "hindsight is 20/20" or were Eisner's sins just that profound?It's actually kind of tragic after Eisner spearheaded the first Disney Renaissance, starting somewhere around The Great Mouse Detective and ending somewhere around Tarzan. What's most interesting is how Eisner kind of keeps trying to believe he's in Disney's salad days, long - LONG - past the time he is.My only issue with the book is that we didn't really get a lot of theme park stuff. I honestly thought we'd get a big breakdown of WestCot and an in-depth look at California Adventure's bizarre first years. Nothing much on that, or on the changes Eisner brought to the resort hotel concept (adding value resorts), theme park attractions (beyond Mission: Space), and more. There's a lot of ink on Disneyland Paris, but virtually nothing on the Asian parks, or even domestic. It's a ding for me but I get it. This book is more about boardroom malfeasance and mergers and acquisitions and big-screen entertainment rather than Splash Mountain and Barbie at Epcot. Still, even for someone who doesn't really care about corporate movers, shakers, and losers, I found author James B. Stewart's prose moving quickly and the huge moments and shocking reversals so outsized, this could have been fiction. The weirdest thing is that it's not. I really liked this book. ...more

title: Alphabetical: How Every Letter Tells a Story
author: Rosen, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You don't always know what you're going to get with a book like Alphabetical, which purports to tell the etymology and cultural significance of every You don't always know what you're going to get with a book like Alphabetical, which purports to tell the etymology and cultural significance of every letter of "The Alphabet" (which isn't the ONLY alphabet, Rosen is quick to point out, but it is the one that most Western speakers and writers refer to at THE alphabet). Is it going to be light and breezy with a breadth of witticisms and a dearth of facts, or will it be so stuck in the mud of history that it doesn't let the concepts breathe? I've lived through both sorts of books and while I prefer the former, I'm always searching for the Bill Bryson medium. Alphabetical mostly hits that medium. He goes through every letter of the alphabet, talks about why the letter name is pronounced (this is the quirky fun etymological stuff I crave; why is A pronounced AYE, and why the heck is it called a W if it's obviously a double v?), and gives us a pretty thorough overview of how the letter has been used over the years and centuries. In each chapter, we also get a tangent that amounts to a sub-chapter, discussing an aspect of culture we wouldn't have without these letters (like the histories of the word "okay," or why and how ZIP codes happened) that are sometimes only tangentially related to the letter history but are fascinating nonetheless. Along the way, Rosen takes us into his personal history of letters, a recurring motif that continually remains charming because he doesn't bog down. In fact, none of this book bogs down. If you're starting to worry if the chapter about codes and ciphers is getting too in the weeds, just wait; we're going to wipe the whole slate clean and get into D any second. This book, like many overviews, may inspire more than satisfy ... which I believe is its purpose. We get some tantalizing chunks of history - the whole section on the Voynich Manuscript, which might be a hoax springs to mind - and he leaves it up to the reader to go searching the topic further. If an overview of the history of the alphabet is all you want, this book will charm and delight (and the audiobook is read by the author, which is even more of a delight; if you're American, you just have to get used to hearing "zed" a lot). Recommended; now I want more. ...more

title: The Midnight Library
author: Haig, Matt*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: And here we are, finally our first contender for my favorite book of the year. Every time I start a new year of reading, I get worried that this year'And here we are, finally our first contender for my favorite book of the year. Every time I start a new year of reading, I get worried that this year's crop of stuff won't be as good as the last. I scour the internet looking for new books by old favorites, buzzy stuff that fits in my wheelhouse, obscure nonfiction on topics that intrigue me just enough to get deeply into a single book and then stop. Of course, I can always re-read my favorites; Stephen King and John Irving and Ann Patchett and Lawrence Block are right there, waiting to be picked up again. But it's not the same. Re-reading has immense value, but you can't build the pillars of a great reading year on those. Then, after a month or so catching up with the stuff I started in the previous year, new possibilities open up. I sometimes take a stab at madness and think that THIS is the year I'll finally read Jane Eyre or Tess of the d'Urbervilles, and buy them and quietly shelve them and then donate them to used bookshops that cater to, I assume, Dickensian waifs in need of highbrow literature. And then, finally - FINALLY! - I stumble on something I effortlessly love. That book, this year, is The Midnight Library.At this point in American pop culture, we are absolutely familiar with the concept of a multiverse. Parallel (or perpendicular?) spacetimes that coexist at the same time as what we think of as our "normal" lives. In the parlance of The Midnight Library, the life you've always lived is called your "root" life. The other possibilities open up when you almost - but not quite - die. Our story concerns a woman named Nora, who has decided to die. Her life is in shambles: she's lost her regular job, her side gig, and her cat. Her brother won't talk to her. She has nothing and no one and in her pit of despair, she attempts to die by suicide. When she opens her eyes, she is in the Midnight Library, an in-between place in which Nora can shuttle between lives she might have lived if she'd made different decisions along the way. Her guide on this journey is an avatar of one of the few people Nora has trusted in the world, who explains that if Nora finds a happy life elsewhere, then she can remain there forever. The great fun of this novel is finding Nora choosing different lives to live - some tragic, some bland, some fantastic, some near-perfect. As we reach the ending, we have a feeling how things will turn out ... but don't always believe what you think is going to happen. Like Nora's regrets, things in the Midnight Library are not always what they seem. I honestly thought, when I started this book, that Nora was going to shuttle through famous fictional landscapes - she'd be in Alice in Wonderland, or in Moby-Dick, or something like that. I don't quite know where I got that idea. What I got was far richer, and more affirming, than whatever I'd been imagining. I'm so happy I read this book. ...more

title: Stealing the Show: A History of Art and Crime in Six Thefts
author: Barelli, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My THOUGHT when I picked this one up was that it would be a light, accessible history of art theft over the centuries. The title sets you up for that,My THOUGHT when I picked this one up was that it would be a light, accessible history of art theft over the centuries. The title sets you up for that, basically begging you to compare it with stuff like The History of the World in Six Glasses. It's not that, at all. It focuses on one museum - the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City - from rougly the mid-1970s to the mid-1990s. Not particularly a HISTORY, so much, and all of it's from the point of view of security lead John Barelli, whose work in preventing and solving art crime is the real through-line here. So instead of a worldwide scope, it's basically the story of this one guy and this one museum and some thefts that happened there. A little one-note, right?Wrong! Weirdly, wonderfully wrong! Barelli lays out the different sorts of art theft and crime - outside opportunity, inside opportunity, and pro - and from those basic types lays out six (or more) crimes at the Met that have shaken up the museum during his tenure there. We're talking Roman heads. Tapestries. Baseball cards. And maybe - or maybe not - bronze sculptures. It's all really compelling stuff.Along the way, Barelli's career intersects with Princess Diana, 9/11, Scotland Yard, and a pair of shrunken heads. Barelli writes like a cop - precise, no-nonsense, occasional jokes - but the world of art and art crime is so bizarre that it makes for a good juxtaposition. I didn't think I was going to like this book at all and I liked it a lot. The old (paraphrased) Ebert adage is true: it's not always what the book is about, it's how it's about it. ...more

title: Bone Canyon        (Eve Ronin, #2)
author: Goldberg, Lee*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is no reason this book should have taken me two and a half weeks to read. It’s 265 pages, and they are small pages. The story is gripping. GoldbThere is no reason this book should have taken me two and a half weeks to read. It’s 265 pages, and they are small pages. The story is gripping. Goldberg’s writing makes you feel like you’re watching a police procedural on TV. And the Los Angeles setting is catnip to me. So why did it take over half a month to read?Last year, I could have polished a book like Bone Canyon off in a long afternoon. I did that with Ann Patchett’s Run. 2020 was a big shut-in year. For a long time, I didn’t leave my house because we couldn’t. I dove into physical books in a way I hadn’t in awhile. I read out of necessity, as a way to shield myself from the ongoing trauma of the pandemic.That may have changed in this year. Things are more active. Getting back to normal. And my reading is of course suffering. The audiobooks are still moving on a regular clip, but the physical books are what they have been in the past: another thing that competes for my time. And my time is usually thin. When I’m reading, I can only just read. With audio, I can do everything else, but books are their own entity. I have to focus on them to the exclusion of all else. Put into that kind of context, it actually says a great deal about this novel. No matter how distracted I got, I still came back to it, because the story was so good. New detective Eve Ronin decides to solve a triple cold case when bones turn up in the desert following a wildfire. Her department resents her, Andy the only guy she can trust is her partner, who’s retiring soon. Oh, and the killers may be police officers.Aside From occasionally stilted conversation, this book is well written and compulsively readable. I liked all the characters, especially Eve’s mother, who is irritating in a very specific Hollywood way. It’s good and fun and breezy. And it made me finish. Bravo, novel!...more

title: Jaws
author: Benchley, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I mentioned I was reading Jaws, some friends on Twitter warned me that it was "rampantly horny in the second half." I was like, oh there are someWhen I mentioned I was reading Jaws, some friends on Twitter warned me that it was "rampantly horny in the second half." I was like, oh there are some sex scenes? That's not so bad.Nope. It is ... rampantly, needlessly horny. Not just in the second half. Like there's a weird undercurrent (ha! because oceans!) of perverse sexuality in this book that doesn't ever really seem to connect to anything else. Not in character or plot, not even subtextually.Look, we all have a vague idea of what Jaws is: a great white shark shows up in the shallows around Amity, NY, and kills a bunch of people. A police chief named Brody, an ichthyologist named Hooper, and a crusty old salt seaman named Quint all go out to try to kill the fish. Thrills ensue.Only: not as much here in the book. I'm not going to say Benchley wasn't great at writing scenes of suspense. The whole first shark attack is as gripping as that in the movie. Some of the subsequent ones were, as well, including that of a young boy on a raft. (Followed closely by an off-page murder that we only hear about, which is a ... bold choice.)But then there's stuff about the mayor's mob connections, and an awkward dinner party, and - most egregiously - an affair between Brody's wife and Hooper, who is NOT the nebbishy Richard Dreyfus you might expect, but a full on Robert Redford type. At one point, they're at this diner together and he's like, "What are your fun and flirty fantasies" and she's all like, "well, rape of course, like all women." And I'm like, UH BENCHLEY, A WORD?!The affair becomes this sort of stain on a pretty good book, because it doesn't lead anywhere and it doesn't seem to really mean anything. (Though, interesting: when Brody theorizes that Hooper slept with another woman in town, everyone's like, "Nah, she's a lesbian." And it's not really a big deal except to prove Hooper's a liar, which ... I don't know, feels like good sexual politics for the 70s? Weirdly?)A lot of the latter shark-centric scenes are also suspenseful and there are even a few genuine scares. But there's very little, I dunno, lyricism in the book. It feels a little plodding. I'm going to go back and watch the movie soon, but I remember that feeling not just well-crafted but at times poetic. Young Steven Spielberg removed all the chaff, added some more playful elements, turned Quint into Captain Ahab, and made Hooper a different kind of 1970s sex muffin. I can understand, if you'd never seen the film Jaws, that the book might be way more effective. As it stands, I can't break away from the cultural wake of the superior film, and in that light, the book just lacks....more

title: Holiday Jubilee: Classic & Kitschy Festivities & Fun Party Recipes
author: Phoenix, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Realizing I was a midcentury modern fan opened up entire vistas of research and reading to me. The googie architecture, the neon, the kitsch, the entiRealizing I was a midcentury modern fan opened up entire vistas of research and reading to me. The googie architecture, the neon, the kitsch, the entire world of Polynesian Pop: all of it remains fascinating and thrilling to me. It's informed my graphic design and even my writing. So it was only a matter of time before I discovered Charles Phoenix, The Ambassador of Americana. Before I knew it, I'd read his books Addicted to Americana, Southern California in the '50s, and of course Leis, Luaus, and Alohas: The Lure of Hawaii in the '50s. The books all pop with bold color, Phoenix's smiling (manic?) face, and vintage pictures from Phoenix's legendary slideshows. They're great!Holiday Jubilee isn't much different. The author takes on the big holidays - New Year's, Valentine's Easter, 4th of July, Thanksgiving, and of course Christmas - and looks at them through the lens of ironic vintage kitsch. It's mostly charming, delving into culture of America past, with its attendant consumerism and gee-whiz space-age obsession and the neverending allure of absurd food crafting. (Phoenix offers several vintage-style recipes here, all of which are heart attacks wrapped in cheer and most of which involve either meatloaf or cake. Or both!)There does seem to be ... I don't know, a slight bit of cynicism to this book that I didn't detect in the others. Maybe it's the fact that it's about the holidays and I like to see them as fun and - if not sacred - a little more meaningful? I don't know. I like the camp of it all, even the recipes, although if there's one thing that this book impresses on me, it's that my obsession with midmod would not extend to actually living in it; literally everyone smokes. All in all, I remain a huge fan of Charles Phoenix, and I look forward to the day when I can finally see one of his slideshows live. I KNOW!...more

title: Hide Away        (Rachel Marin Thriller, #1)
author: Pinter, Jason*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had never heard of Jason Pinter until a confluence of Mystery Twitter punted his name my way. Through either Lawrence Block's or Thomas Pluck's feedI had never heard of Jason Pinter until a confluence of Mystery Twitter punted his name my way. Through either Lawrence Block's or Thomas Pluck's feeds, I found a tweet where Pinter posted one of his Amazon s. The heading was "ENOUGH," and the "" went on to say that while the book was well-written, the reader was NOT a homosexual, and didn't want to have to deal with that sort of abhorrence in their fiction. Pinter thought it was funny, "warning" potential readers that there was a Black queer woman married to another woman and that they were raising kids together. I was like, sounds like a book I'd be interested in, and downloaded it on Audible.Folks: the Black queer woman isn't the main character, as the Amazon reader led me to suspect. She's a good character - Detective Leslie Tally - and she's well-rounded and smart and cool, but she's not even the main secondary character (a hot rugged Jay Harrington type named John Serrano, who has a Prayer for Owen Meany-inspired PAST). The main character is a woman named Rachel Marin, who has her own P A S T, a single mom with a side gig of a kickass vigilante woman. There's a plot, and it's a good one, involving a disgraced former mayor who may or may not have killed herself. I'm not saying the plot isn't important to the book, because it reveals layers of trauma and direction in Marin's character, especially her devotion to justice at any cost. What's fascinating about the book is what "any cost" eventually means. Marin isn't a superhero, and she makes a few boneheaded decisions because she's convinced she's making them for the right reasons. Some of the very few negative s focus on her bad decisions like it's a flaw, but it's one of the book's main strengths. Marin is kind of Batman, down to the enduring horror of a tragic event; but what a lot of people forget is how haunted Batman is, and how his sense of justice tends to cloud common sense. How can Marin say she's trying to make her world better for her kids, when her kids are so often collateral damage to her actions?I really liked this book, and I've just discovered there's a new Marin book by Pinter I now need to pick up and read. About 75% of the time, Twitter is a cesspool. But every once in a little while, something great comes out of the muck. I'm glad this surfaced. ...more

title: Answers in the Form of Questions: A Definitive History and Insider's Guide to Jeopardy!
author: McNear, Claire
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've read - or tried to read - books about Jeopardy! before. Ken Jennings' Brainiac was a highlight and made me like Jennings more than I had on his iI've read - or tried to read - books about Jeopardy! before. Ken Jennings' Brainiac was a highlight and made me like Jennings more than I had on his initial run of shows. I read Alex Trebek's book last year, which was far more breezy and light than I'd thought it would be. I've tried to read Bob Harris' Prisoner of Trebekistan, but I couldn't really get into it.So here we come to Claire McNear, the first person to write a book on Jeopardy! (at least to my knowledge) without having actually appeared on the show. I don't know if the distance is a quality that makes a book like this work, but I'm not sure it hurts. What we get with Answers in the Form of Questions is somewhere in between Trebek's and Jennings' books - fairly light, with just enough meat on its bones to satisfy Jeopardy! die-hards. When I was coming up as a reader, one of my favorite books about a subject I loved was The Stephen King Companion. It looked at highlights of King's career, offered some sidebars, made the whole phenomenon more accessible and approachable. That's pretty much what McNear does here. There's a sweeping overview of the show's history, how pop culture responded to it (current Jeopardy! might not exist without "Weird Al" Yankovic, WHAT), a little about Trebek, a lot about contestants - former, hopeful, and superstar alike. Because McNear is an endearing writer, this is a comfortable book about a comfortable show. And because it was completed before both the pandemic and Trebek's death, so it's also a time capsule. Things may change for Jeopardy! in the coming years, but this book captures a time and a mindset about the show during Trebek's run. Recommended. ...more

title: Centennial
author: Michener, James A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: And so we begin a new year of James Michener. I keep asking myself if I truly enjoy Michener, or if I like having read Michener. After all, he’s a popAnd so we begin a new year of James Michener. I keep asking myself if I truly enjoy Michener, or if I like having read Michener. After all, he’s a popular writer, not a “literature” writer; if I’m working my way through a 1,000-page time, it’s not for any sort of cultural cachet. It’s just because I like him.So I’ve come to the conclusion with my fourth successful read of a Michener book (after Hawaii, Alaska, and The Novel; Tales of the South Pacific and Space were attempts I need to get back to) that I enjoy Michener novels, mostly. I admire the sweep of history, from prehistory to current day. I get wrapped up in the generational stories, watching young kids grow old become heads of companies and families. Sometimes, though, I get weary of exposition and proselytizing. Centennial is mostly terrific. Early on, we meet a living diplodocus and watch her habits and day. Several immense chapters later, a character finds her bones on his farm. That’s the stuff I love. In between, we meet various indigenous tribes, watch how white men move in and try to wipe them out, and learn all about Hereford cattle. There’s a lot. We also watch how farming, agriculture, and irrigation shape the small Colorado town of Centennial. This shouldn’t be as awesome as it is. I keep thinking it’s going to be dull and it’s not. There’s politics and dry farming and unrequited love and, bizarrely, a crass and shocking murder that could be its own short story. Watching the stuff that springs from that murder is thrilling. So what DON’T I like? Oh my word, the interminable final chapter. It’s all about how great Centennial used to be and how terrible it is now. It’s not just that it’s a downbeat ending; it’s that it takes so long to get there. Even the presence of a pretty sweet love story cannot save that last chapter.Other than that, Centennial is an absorbing, often exciting read. It’s gonna take a little while before I’m ready for the next one, but that’s okay. I can wait....more

There's some fucking around in 361, and a good amount of profundity, if you're willing to look for it. As it was, I liked it. A book about fathers and sons, lies and deceptions. And it's about killing when you don't want to, and killing when you do, and why it's hard both ways. Westlake's mob stuff seems more germane to his Parker novels under the Stark name.
