title: Bruce Springsteen: All the Songs: The Story Behind Every Track
author: Margotin, Philippe
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A few years back, I picked up Brian Hiatt’s Bruce Springsteen: The Story Behind the Songs and loved it (even though, for some reason, he accidently skA few years back, I picked up Brian Hiatt’s Bruce Springsteen: The Story Behind the Songs and loved it (even though, for some reason, he accidently skipped “My Best Was Never Good Enough” from The Ghost of Tom Joad.) Then in 2020, Bruce Springsteen: All the Songs – The Story Behind Every Track came out, and I wanted it more than anything else for Christmas. Apparently, books about Springsteen songs are like books about Beatles songs. I’m going to keep buying them and loving them and wanting more. This is my first book finished in 2021, which is a little alarming since we’re halfway through the month and I haven’t yet made a dent in my 70 Books of 2021 goal. In my defense, this book is almost as gargantuan as the other book I’m currently reading: Centennial, by James Michener. I have a YA novel picked out for my next read and I’m looking forward to the break. And how is this book? Quite good. Though I don’t really care about the tech specs – who played what guitar on which track doesn’t really interest me – I liked the actual stories behind all the songs profiled. Where authors Jean-Michel Guesdon and Philippe Margotin sometimes go wrong is in their interpretations of songs (how the heck is “Hello Sunshine” an ode to the joys of solitude?) … and, very occasionally, chart stats (sometimes they list songs as charting fairly high on the Billboard Hot 100, even if they were never singles; I have to guess that, because the authors are European, their default chart is different from our default chart). The book is packed with facts and pictures – all the stuff I love – and the dedication to ferreting out all those backstories is fruitful. I spent many nights absorbed in this book, wanting to sleep but wanting to know just one … more … thing. Plus, I’ve been re-listening to Springsteen records throughout the whole process and it’s been so good to connect with the music again after reading about it. The book felt kind of interactive in that way.I will question, though, why the authors decided to leave out the whole Ties That Bind box set, not to mention Disc 3 of Essential, all of which contain outtakes that never made it anywhere else. They got all the EPs (though didn’t mention that the American Beauty EP actually did chart on the Top 200 in the States), all the singles, all the core 19 records, but those seem like pretty big misses. (Also, and this is not their fault obviously, but Springsteen is always going to be just a little bit faster than print; Letter to You isn’t covered here, and that makes me just a little sad.)I feel like I’m ragging on the book when it’s done nothing but entertain me in the first weeks of 2021. I really enjoyed being inside these songs and this music, and now that the barrier is broken, I can jump into more books. All of the books....more

title: Palm Springs Holiday: A Vintage Tour from Palm Springs to the Salton Sea
author: Moruzzi, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Since my trip to Palm Springs in 2019, before the world fell apart, I have been fairly obsessed with its dedication to its own midcentury aesthetic. GSince my trip to Palm Springs in 2019, before the world fell apart, I have been fairly obsessed with its dedication to its own midcentury aesthetic. Googie stars and amoeba and Sputnik shapes, a high-end Shag store, tiki bars and breeze blocks and all the stuff that made the 50s great (and, at least to my tourist eyes, little that made it not). Currently it's a gay mecca, packed with folks who get lost in the kitsch of it all. Gay folk love our kitsch. And camp. And glitter.I don't know if Peter Moruzzi is gay (though he alludes to the populace at one point), but he's absolutely hit on why those drawn to vintage California aesthetics from an ironic distance love Palm Springs. After laying the groundwork about men taming the desert in the early 20th century, Moruzzi dazzles us with imagery and extremely short essays on the backgrounds of those images. After that skimming of "Early History," we jump right into a chapter titled "The Original Hotels." Right there, you know what kind of book this is: one dedicated to entertainment, tourism, and the over-the-top indulgence of the jet set in the desert as the midcentury blooms before them.There's some tantalizingly dark stuff in Moruzzi's words - the accidental creation of the Salton Sea, the gentrification that pushed a lot of indigenous people out of the slums, maybe some mob stuff - but the author wisely knows that this isn't the book for that. We want to read about pools and Desert Modern architecture and why neon was too tacky for the city so they had to come up with something else on their road signs. Nighclubs and supper clubs and tiki clubs and gentlemen's clubs. In the later chapters, we travel beyond Palm Springs "down valley," but almost all of Palm Springs Holiday remains in the comforting shadow of the San Jacinto Mountains, and the pleasure industry that sprung up there years before I was born. ...more

title: The Midcentury Kitchen: America's Favorite Room, from Workspace to Dreamscape, 1940s-1970s
author: Archer, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After reading Sarah Archer's Midcentury Christmas book - featuring all sorts of styles and traditions from Christmases Past - I was eager to jump backAfter reading Sarah Archer's Midcentury Christmas book - featuring all sorts of styles and traditions from Christmases Past - I was eager to jump back on the Archer train. This one screamed out to me: instead of Googie wrapping paper, there'd be Googie WALLpaper. Atomic radar ranges! Avocado green! Harvest gold! Archer delivers all this and more. First, there's a crash course in kitchens in the distant ago, the ones to which aristocrats would summon butlers and maids to bring food on silver trays. The look and importance of the kitchen changed as the middle class emerged from World War II and women were expected to leave the factory and go back to work in the home. Archer argues that the elegance of the atomic kitchen might explain why the June Cleaver fifties housewife look - pearls and heels - might not be as sitcommy or farfetched as we might assume. Advertising worked hard to make kitchens seem like careers for women of the era. The word "housewife" gets elevated to the term "hostess," making the everyday kitchen toiler seem more like the head of a neverending party ... even though that's not really what it was. It's a fascinating journey to watch. When I started reading, I didn't think I was going to like the 1970s stuff, but Archer surprised me. The late focus on the greens and gold and oranges of the 1970s was a perfect shift away from the space-age 50s and 60s. I'm just glad we're not moving into the Lisa Frank 80s. I love these midcentury books. They dovetail very nicely into the tiki craze books I've been into all year (and Archer touches on the tiki lore here, too). It helps paint a picture of retrofuturism that I've always loved and understand more deeply now. ...more

title: I Will Judge You by Your Bookshelf
author: Snider, Grant*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wonder if there's a way to call something "precious" without it sounding condescending. Because I Will Judge You by Your Bookshelf is 8,000 kinds ofI wonder if there's a way to call something "precious" without it sounding condescending. Because I Will Judge You by Your Bookshelf is 8,000 kinds of precious, but in this case, that's a very good thing. Author/illustrator Snider loves books and the writing of them to such a degree that the good and gentle humor of this book is matched only by the intensity of its passion. Books are an addiction. Books are an escape. Books are a mirror AND a door. Maybe these are tried and true clichés, but with Snider's charming illustrations and often rhyming sets of comic panels, these insights feel fresh. Along the way we're treated to an alphabetical tour through a writer's day, a pretty searing look at the stodgy "canon" of English literature, and an illustrative look at the library of a reading child's mind (including, I have to add, an illustration of the big brain "It" from A Wrinkle in Time, the EXACT ILLUSTRATION that I did in fourth grade when we had to draw an alternate book cover for a book we liked and I got a bad grade. I swear it looked just like this thing.)I don't know what I was expecting when I first grokked this book. A friend from Twitter found it on my wish list and said, "Yes, Kevin needs that." Which is absolutely true! I don't know if I expected comics and I was a little thrown by it. But its charm and its wit won me over pretty quickly. A nice breezy way for a book lover or writer to spend an afternoon, smiling the whole time....more

title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
author: Skloot, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have been interested in this book for a very long time. It came out when I still worked in bookstores (and bookstores were a thing), and I remember I have been interested in this book for a very long time. It came out when I still worked in bookstores (and bookstores were a thing), and I remember finding the whole thing a little daunting. First off, even though I'd read Bryson's A Short History of Nearly Everything, I still had a bit of a science inferiority complex. This was going to be a book about cell culture and biology, and honestly I was scared I wasn't going to understand it. Secondly, it seemed to be a book about institutional racism, and I'm always unsure if I'm qualified to read deeply about race - while at the same time, I know as a white guy, I should educate myself as much as possible. Lots of internal questions, and basically what it all boiled down to was: shouldn't I try to know more about science, and shouldn't I try to know more about pervading racism?The answer is yes, but it's not just yes. The real answer is that this book is definitely anchored in science - it's about cells taken from a woman named Henrietta Lacks (the cells are designated HeLa), and the fact that those cells are still alive and dividing and multiplying all these years since her death. Institutional racism? Sure, especially during a harrowing reveal about what happened to Henrietta's possibly autistic daughter. But more than anything, this book is about family, and what makes a family; is it just cells, or is it something more?Surprisingly, much of the book centers on Debra Lacks, Henrietta's daughter, who never got to know her mother and who was on her journey to understand, through the persistence of her cells. Like a lot of the best narrative nonfiction, the author, Rebecca Skloot, is a part of the story, becoming Debra's friend (and occasional adversary) as they seek the truth of Henrietta's legacy. It's a convoluted truth, and the fact that Henrietta's cells are out in the world helping to develop treatments for polio and AIDS (and, I found out, COVID-19) while her family had been struggling in poverty and anonymity is a little hard to take. Skloot presents all the information without much bias, understanding how violating it is to have your tissues used without your knowledge ... while also knowing that without those tissues, polio might never have been cured. It's heady waters.But it's not a heady read. Skloot, like Bryson, gives us just enough science to help us understand Henrietta's ongoing story, but doesn't bog us down. It's pop science, the stuff I can grasp, as well as a helix of biography and biology. I really enjoyed this book, even the parts that hurt to read. Science is about stuff you need to know, even if sometimes you don't want to know it. So I liked the book, but I'm also really just glad I read it. ...more

title: What If It's Us        (What If It's Us, #1)
author: Albertalli, Becky*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A friend of mine recommended this to me, and at first I was unsure. It's a young adult gay romance, and I wasn't sure I'd be into something like that.A friend of mine recommended this to me, and at first I was unsure. It's a young adult gay romance, and I wasn't sure I'd be into something like that. When you're 45, the memory of your first love and first kiss can seem very distant. Honestly, I was afraid the book would make me mad; I didn't have books like this when I was young. If there were gay characters in YA, they were sad and tortured and Very Brave. They weren't just messy teenagers who fucked up sometimes and won sometimes and otherwise had pretty regular lives. Instead of pissing me off, What If It's Us genuinely excited me. It's the story of Ben and Arthur, two boys who find each other in New York City during one offbeat summer. It's also about how they don't meet, and how they screw up, and how they sometimes win. I really loved it.What was most fun for me was how large their separate worlds were. Ben's Puerto Rican, and that is sometimes a big deal and sometimes not. He has an ex, and he's in summer school, and a best friend. Arthur's parents seem headed for a divorce, he's a summer intern, and his two best friends are back home in Georgia, and one of them is acting weird. It never feels like these other characters exist JUST to prop up Our Duo. These lives feel lived-in, and real, with a sense of weight and history.My friend said this book was the thing that convinced him to come out. I can believe it. It's a book rooted in the magic of love, but still realistic about how difficult love is. If you can, listen to the audiobook, where the characters of Ben and Arthur swap chapters from their own points of view. Just sweet and quietly revolutionary. The sequel comes out next year and I'm ready for it. ...more

title: Hell Hath No Fury Like Her: The Making of Christine
author: Gambin, Lee
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You know, I don't think I've ever read a full-length book on the making of a movie. The closest I've come, I think, was Pictures at a Revolution, whicYou know, I don't think I've ever read a full-length book on the making of a movie. The closest I've come, I think, was Pictures at a Revolution, which is about the making of the five best picture nominees of 1968. I've read plenty of think pieces on stuff like Citizen Kane, Taxi Driver, the work of Tarantino - my favorite prestige films. But I have long, long had a soft spot for both the book and movie of Christine, and even though I didn't think I'd enjoy this sort of oral history approach, I liked it a lot.Author Gambin curates interviews with people from all over the production of the film, from the actors to the FX people, the editors and producers. I thought there might be, you know, DRAMA, because you hear about that stuff happening on movie sets all the time. The truth is that the shoot was mostly one big happy family. If you think that sounds boring, I assure you, it wasn't. There's a big cult following surrounding the film, but even if you're only a casual fan, getting this deep into it is satisfying and fun. I learned a few things about the special effects, a few things about the young actors ("I honestly could have died in that moment" becomes a sort of recurring theme, especially with Alexandra Paul, Keith Gordon, and Malcolm Denare, one of my earliest crushes). For some reason, I've always thought director John Carpenter was curmudgeonly, but here he comes across as that cool, friendly uncle you can watch horror films with. I knew but maybe forgot that he was coming off The Thing when he made Christine, and my impression of The Thing was that it was always the revered film it is now. But it tanked and got terrible s when it came out, so Christine was sort of the rebound picture. The fact that Christine made double its budget back must have been a confidence booster.At the start of every chapter, Gambin analyzes and mythologizes segments of the movie. He brings in a lot of interesting perspective, from feminist theory and queer theory to film technique and the role Christine has in the pantheon of killer-vehicle pictures. I liked most of these introductions very much, aside from a lengthy plot synopsis of a different film in the canon called The Car. I found it interesting, but it might have been more so if there'd been a broader range of compare/contrast examples.But man, did I love this book. It's exactly the book I needed right now: a nerdy deep dive into the background of one of my favorite movies, based on one of my favorite books. Sometimes, you just want to be a little pampered. ...more

title: Midcentury Christmas Stocking Stuffer Edition
author: Archer, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This may not be a month for deep thought. With the pandemic still raging (and surging in some places), all the stuff I love shut down, and my ChristmaThis may not be a month for deep thought. With the pandemic still raging (and surging in some places), all the stuff I love shut down, and my Christmas celebrations mostly canceled, I don't really have the headspace for challenging books. I tried Hemingway's For Whom the Bell Tolls, and I know I'm going to like it eventually. What I want to do now is get lost in Stephen King novels, and - apparently - look back with nostalgia at midcentury kitsch and design. That's what I can handle right now.Sarah Archer's tiny book (the stocking stuffer edition!) is cram-jam with imagery and reminiscences of the holiday season from the 1950s to the early 1970s. Broken up into easily digestible chapters like Aluminum Trees, Christmas Wrapping, and Christmas Cards, Midcentury Christmas is almost entirely a breezy, history-lite exploration of this fascinating era of American history. While Archer touches on some of the not-great aspects of the time period - the non-equal rights of women and people of color, the fear of nuclear war, the consumerism that came with the modern-since-the-1800s version of Christmas - that help to give a fuller picture of the time, this is largely a celebration.What is sort of interesting is that, near the end of the book, Archer begins to focus on the DIY movement of the time, and how both that and the interest in midcentury markers like Googie stars and atomic imagery are once again in vogue, especially during the holidays. She chooses this note to end the book on and doesn't really sum up the whole of the experience, but her late focus on Better Homes and Gardens magazine (and its Christmas issue) stands in for a punctuation on the era. I really liked this book....more

title: Different Seasons
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's one of my favorite books and has been ever since I got into King. I remember sprawling out on my borrowed waterbed when I was 15 or 16, finishingIt's one of my favorite books and has been ever since I got into King. I remember sprawling out on my borrowed waterbed when I was 15 or 16, finishing "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption" for the first time, just marveling at the power of it. And then in comes "Apt Pupil" to suckerpunch me. I read that one at my grandparents' house, which was even more terrifying because my grandfather was Jewish, and stories about Nazis always freaked me out.A part of me will always feel a little cheated, because I'd seen Stand By Me dozens of times before I ever read "The Body." In fact, it was one of the very few FORBIDDEN movies in my household. My Dad had taped it off HBO, and every time he and my stepmother were out of the house, I'd watch a little bit more, sometimes getting 20-30 minutes of movie in before I heard their car pull into the driveway and I had to eject and put the tape back in its place. Even watching it piecemeal was powerful. When I finally got to watch the whole thing at my Aunt Marg's house, it sank into me so deeply, like a wound that never stops bleeding. It's hard not to compare the novella and the movie. There are times in the story when one character says a line attributed to a different one in the film, and it's jarring. Still amazing, but jarring. Unfortunately, I fear the same thing is starting to happen with Shawshank ... although that movie is far more slavishly devoted to its source material. (One last thing about "The Body": the narrator casually references the phrase "going faggot" a few times, which kind of sucks; what's interesting about that is how Red in Shawshank talks about homosexual relationships that are actually beneficial and kind. I have to sort of remember Gordon LaChance is not Stephen King.)But truth be told, I read this now so I could experience "The Breathing Method" again. This was a novella I always considered the weak one of the bunch until something clicked on my fourth or fifth read. Now it's one of my favorites. I've been depressed a little lately - COVID depression, more isolation than normal, seasonal stuff - and I wanted some Stephen King to fall into. King's winter story, scary and unsettling, worked wonders on my mood. I think I might need to re-read some more King after this. Anything to stay afloat. ...more

title: American Cheese: An Indulgent Odyssey Through the Artisan Cheese World
author: Berkowitz, Joe*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Every year, I try to learn a new thing. Usually it’s something with multiple facets: in 2007, when I learned about Disney, there were the movies, the Every year, I try to learn a new thing. Usually it’s something with multiple facets: in 2007, when I learned about Disney, there were the movies, the parks, the man, and more. This year has been all about tiki, and from that locus I can move to architecture, exotic drinks, music, and the history of the South Pacific.I think I got into cheese in 2010 or 2011. The inflection point was when I was eating a cheese plate with a friend and he told me to stop gobbling it like it was Rice Krispies Treats. Slow down. Savor. This piqued my interest enough to read some books on cheese, and start going to cheese shops and listening to what the mongers recommended. The epiphany moment came in Los Angeles where, while at a quiet cheese shop on the edge of the city, I had my first taste of Challerhocker. And I fell in love.As it turns out, I’m not alone in my cheese epiphany moment. Joe Berkowitz describes his in American Cheese like a bright light in the night, a moment of revelation with Rogue River Blue. I love that this happens to other people, and that it affects them in profound ways.Berkowitz’s cheese journey is more ambitious than mine. I’ve found a tasty niche in putting together some pretty good cheese plates with delicious pairings. Berkowitz travels to cheese competitions, works in a cheese shop, crashes the world’s most sumptuous cheese party. It’s a rush to follow along, and if you’re at all interested in cheese making and production, it’ll be even more thrilling.One of my favorite sorts of books is one from the point of view of an outsider coming into a whole subculture (ha!), one with its own rules and language and history, and gets extremely involved. Berkowitz delivers on everything I want from this kind of book, and then some.Is it disappointing that when he finally tastes Challerhocker, he merely likes it? Kind of. But one of the best things about cheese is that it’s different for everyone, and that the world of it is nearly endless. Now it’s time for me to try some Rogue River Blue. I’m whey overdue....more

EitheIs it possible I never read this as a kid? I remember we had copies of it all over Mulcahey Middle, but I can’t recall if my class ever read it. Either way, I didn’t know how the story was going to go, and I’m so glad of that. I really loved this book.In a way it kind of feels like the opposite of Bridge to Terabithia. It’s another lesson in mortality; but this one is all about nothing forever, as opposed to dying young. It’s about a young girl, who has to face the realities of life and death too young to really comprehend them. Only: Winnie, our hero, grows up during this compact story. Her rite of passage out of childhood is in how she grasps the horror of immortality, and comes to terms with it. She’s who Alice in Wonderland might have been, if we’d followed her adventures after the looking-glass. The decisions she makes near the end of the book - to help others, but also to recognize their selfishness and need - are remarkably adult, and that epilogue is a little heartbreaking, even though we knew what had to happen. And now I can’t stop thinking of that toad. ...more

author: Moshfegh, Ottessa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A short novel about and 19th century sailor who has spent nearly his entire life drunk. He’s foul mouthed, and not as introspective as he needs to be.A short novel about and 19th century sailor who has spent nearly his entire life drunk. He’s foul mouthed, and not as introspective as he needs to be. His best friend has been murdered, he has been accused, and he has no memory of what has happened. This is McGlue.I’ve been a fan of a Otessa Moshfegh for a few years now. I started with Eileen, moved on to My Year of Rest and Relaxation, and this year I read Death in Her Hands. I want to call her writing magical realism, but I don’t know if it’s technically that. You believe what she’s writing, at the same time you can’t believe a word she says. None of her narrators are all that reliable. McGlue is one of the least reliable yet, given as he’s usually drunk, and is currently suffering a brain injury so severe that it is clouding all of his memory. Did he kill Johnson, his best friend? And if so, why?For a long time, I thought this book was going to end with a different surprise than it did. And when it did end, the surprise wasn’t really a surprise at all. We have clues throughout the novel about the natures of McGlue and Johnson, about the hell both are going through and why. How their friendship manifests itself on the fringes, on the extremes, is both frustrating and sweet. When you find one person who makes you feel better about yourself than any other person, any other thing, you’ll do almost anything for them....more

title: Bag of Bones
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of my favorite books, and I don't think I've ever listened to the audio, even though Stephen King himself reads it. I'm a sucker for King This is one of my favorite books, and I don't think I've ever listened to the audio, even though Stephen King himself reads it. I'm a sucker for King books read by King himself, ever since 1994, when I bought The Drawing of the Three for my flight to San Fransisco and I fell in love with the man's sort of nasal New England voice. Man, this story means a lot to me. So much was happening in 1998 when Bag of Bones came out. My relationship was falling apart. I was making new friends in the Stephen King EMailERS club (SKEMERS, folks). I was turning into a writer myself. Stephen King had changed publishers and this was the first book from his new publisher. Everyone was on tenterhooks to see if the book would live up to all the hype.It did, of course. I remember a few ers talking about how this was "standard King," with his ghosts and his writers. But some of us saw this as a seismic shift. Bag of Bones was a quieter, more nuanced sort of story from King; a full-on Gothic novel, his first since The Shining. Ghosts bring it out in him. What really struck the world, me included, was the ending. A lot of it talks about Mike Noonan, our protagonist, talking about quitting writing. That was terrifying. This was 1998. King had a new 3-book contract at Simon & Schuster, but the books had already been written. Was he really done writing? Done forever? Of course my fears were assuaged fairly quickly (The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon surprised everyone and we all remembered how compulsive King is when it comes to writing and publishing). But those last words have stuck with me. "I prefer not to." Let's hope not. Not for a long, long time....more

title: Notes from a Young Black Chef
author: Onwuachi, Kwame
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: No pun intended, but Top Chef is my comfort food. Whenever there’s a new season, I dive right in. In more recent seasons, it’s been all about talent aNo pun intended, but Top Chef is my comfort food. Whenever there’s a new season, I dive right in. In more recent seasons, it’s been all about talent and personality and performing at one’s peak. Not too much manufactured drama, which I think a lot of reality competitions think they need. I think the overwhelming success of The Great British Bake-Off/Baking Show has proven that high-adrenaline drama and crying and screaming don’t have to be a part of something like this. During the pandemic, my husband Shawn and I decided to go back and rewatch early seasons of the show. We started with season 2, because the dynamic of Padma/Tom/Gail was a big part of why we were there. And those early seasons DID have that drama. Screaming, posturing bullshit that was sometimes unpleasant to watch. We’re now in Season 8 and things have gotten mostly into the groove that seems the best tenor of the show. We’re closing in on the California season, which I watched when it was on. All the better to read Kwame Onwuache’s book, which touches on his time on the show and explains how he got there. Now, here’s the thing. I’ve read Padma’s and Gail’s books, and they do talk about Top Chef quite a bit. I thought that would be a major part of Kwame’s book, as well ... but I didn’t quite think about the fact that Gail and Padma have been part of the Top Chef world for a good portion of their lives. Kwame was only there for about four months. So the book dedicated some time to the show, but his relatively drama-free season was not what makes this book so compelling. Look: we’re dealing with systemic racism in American culture. We have been - and especially Black and brown people have been - for centuries. What’s insane is how prevalent it is in the current, how bold and out in the open. When Kwame wrote this book, it was a little less overt, but it was still definitely felt. His times in the kitchen where he’s asked to make “African” food, aware (unlike his bosses) that Africa is a continent, not a cuisine. Or when he makes chicken and waffles, and wonders if (1) he’s playing into the stereotype of Black Americans and (2) if he refuses to make it, is he ignoring a food he likes so it won’t be SEEN as a racial thing. This is stuff Kwame wrestles with over and over in his book and it’s heartbreaking and intense, every single time.We don’t start in kitchens, either, and unlike in most narratives about author-doing-thing you know them for, this pre-history is fascinating. Growing up poor, sleeping in a closet, watching his mother barely scrape by as first a caterer and then an executive chef. He deals with an abusive father, an exile in Nigeria, and a long stint at wrestling with his own demons. It’s all compelling, because Kwame knows how to frame his subjects and his own history well.But of course, the book comes alive when he’s talking about food. His explanations on how he works hard to make the best consumme, and how his fanciest and most story-focused food is plated are among the best in the book. Some of this is the drama we see on screen, but most of it is behind the scenes, and marking the topography of the life of a chef. The trauma that shapes him, the racism that does or doesn’t frame his experience, his cleverness and ingenuity ... all of it makes up the young Black chef I saw on one of my favorite shows, and the person behind the chef, as well....more

review: I resisted Gwendy's Magic Feather for a long time. I don't entirely know why. Stephen King and Richard Chizmar co-wrote the first book, Gwendy's ButtoI resisted Gwendy's Magic Feather for a long time. I don't entirely know why. Stephen King and Richard Chizmar co-wrote the first book, Gwendy's Button Box, and for Chizmar to be picking up the story and charting some new paths in Gwendy's spectacular tale made sense. But I kept going back to something King said about The Talisman, way back in the day. "If someone pointed a gun at one of my kid's heads and said, write The Talisman yourself, I could have written a Talisman, but not the one that Peter Straub and I wrote together." I was worried that this sequel would be something like that, lesser for not having King's words mixed in with Chizmar's.Of course I was wrong, and Gwendy's Magic Feather turned out pretty delightful. We're catching up on the little girl who learned about the consequences of magic; she's now a congresswoman, and when the button box that can decide the fate of nations returns to her care, things get weird. She's serving under a dolt of a president. She's back home and there's a serial killer (probably) back in Castle Rock for the first time since Frank Dodd strangled a bunch of women in The Dead Zone. There are so many reasons for Gwendy to use the button box destructively, no matter what good she thinks it might be doing.There's also the box's capacity for good, and while a lot of the resolutions in the book are a little telegraphed, that didn't make them any less satisfying. Also satisfying was finding myself back in Castle Rock. King's been going back to that well a lot lately, and I can't say as I blame him. Back in the pre-Needful Things days, I didn't know that I actually was on the whole Castle Rock tip. King seemed to identify with the town more than anything, but for me it was just another setting. But I've read and re-read his older books a lot in the intervening years, and now to have books like Gwendy's Button Box and Elevation, and now Gwendy's Magic Feather ... I just love being back among these people, these places. I love Chizmar's way of filling in some gaps while not CALLING ATTENTION TO THEM. Nods. Inferences. And moving on. There's been word that King and Chizmar are working on a third book in the series, and I couldn't be happier. These quiet, kind, intermittently thrilling stories are kind of exactly what I'm looking for right now. ...more

title: The Queen's Gambit
author: Tevis, Walter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I attempted, a few years back, to learn chess. I read some books, played a couple of computer games. Made it my year's hobby. It didn't stick, not becI attempted, a few years back, to learn chess. I read some books, played a couple of computer games. Made it my year's hobby. It didn't stick, not because I was bad at it (oh, but I was), but because it didn't engage me like I wanted it to. I didn't have that initial, visceral oomph that the interests that stick around can give me. What I discovered, though, was that I was interested in books about chess. More specifically, books about chess players. I love the sort of pop nonfiction genre about people obsessed with toys or games or puzzles, and the author gets super into their stories and lives. The Queen's Gambit is not that, not really. It's fiction, even though the chess games described within seem very plausible. And our hero, Beth, could be one of those people in the "fans of" books ... but we never really get beyond the object of obsession in those books. Here, Walter Tevis paints a whole life about Beth: how she became an orphan, how that shaped her, how she discovered chess and how it might have destroyed her. That it didn't is a testament to her character.And that this book is not only comprehensible but fun for non-players is a testament to Tevis' writing. In it, he describes in fairly intricate details Beth's chess games against increasingly skilled players. Now, here's the thing: when I read books about baseball or football, I am very much at a loss, because I don't care about most sports and I don't know the rules. I also don't know the nomenclature or intricacies of chess ... but, at least in this book, that doesn't matter. Tevis is a master of making every one of Beth's games seem suspenseful and riveting, even if you don't know what the Sicilian is, or why "Rook to Queen Six" is good or bad. The tension builds, and with it, our deeper connection with Beth. She's not always easy to like, but she's extremely easy to root for. When she's angry, we get why. When she's spiraling, we empathize. Most of the time, she behaves like a chess automaton ... until she doesn't. She's such a good character, I wish I could see what happens next.Quick note: in order to prepare for the TV show adaptation, my husband and I are reading the book at the same time. Well, he read, I listened to the fantastic audio edition. Now I wait for him to finish so we can both dive in to Beth's onscreen world. And I don't think this is going to be my last Tevis. ...more

title: Ninety Years of Classic San Diego Tiki, 1928-2018
author: Lindsay, Martin S.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The more tiki books I read, the more I discover how they fit neatly into categories: full histories, monofocus on a single location, mixology books. TThe more tiki books I read, the more I discover how they fit neatly into categories: full histories, monofocus on a single location, mixology books. Then there’s a whole subset of books that function as local listings of past bars and restaurants in a given area. I don’t always find that super interesting, especially the books that I have to really scratch deep to find anything tiki in what they’re referencing. And often, even though the books are well researched, there’s not a whole lot to go on. Often, any Chinese takeout place that has the word “tiki” in its name gets included. That’s not entirely illuminating.This book is a little bit more expansive. Sure, it’s a chronological listing of tiki bars in San Diego from the late 20s to the late 2010s, but it’s also a little bit more. The time before tiki really took hold in California is referred to as pre-tiki, and the stories are sometimes fascinating. Especially in this book, there’s a lot of talk about gangsters and rum runners, and how they ran the San Diego bar scene back in the 20s and 30s and 40s. While that’s not my real area of focus, it’s interesting to get some of that backstory.But when author Martin Lindsay dives in to the tiki era proper, that’s when things get super interesting. For instance, I didn’t know that a lot of the San Diego bar scene existed on islands that were man-made off the coast. And that one of the most famous proto-tiki bars, Christians Hut, originated on one of those islands. We spend a little bit more time on these histories, and I love all the illustrations, and San Diego artifacts that Lindsay incorporates into the book. This also might be the most current book on tiki that I own. There’s a lot of stuff about the tiki revival, and it brings us current to 2018. This year has affected a lot of tiki bars, but my hope is, reading a book like this, that the revival can sustain itself through this weird year. This book gave me some hope I didn’t know it was going to. So maybe it’s in a category all of its own....more

title: Angle of Repose
author: Stegner, Wallace
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was researching modern Pulitzer Prize winners for a book I'm writing. The title Angle of Repose intrigued me, so I read a little about it. Frontier I was researching modern Pulitzer Prize winners for a book I'm writing. The title Angle of Repose intrigued me, so I read a little about it. Frontier woman who goes West? Her aging grandson writing her life story? Sounds right up my alley. I downloaded the audio and dove in right away.We get to know our narrator right off: Lyman Ward, recently missing half of one leg and somewhat paralyzed, in a motorized wheelchair he uses to get around. He's working on reading his grandmother Susan's letters, most of which are addressed to her closest friend Augusta back home in the east as Susan goes west, following her surveyor husband as he tries and fails to make it rich over and over. I thought that the book would turn out to be a love story between Susan and Augusta, and it is that, but not in the way I thought. Their bond isn't sexual or physical or even romantic; it's just needful and intense, and Susan needs it throughout all the failures of her life. I then thought the novel was going to be about Susan - an artist and writer - coming into her own in the west, growing famous as a brilliant capturer of the Spirit of Frontiersmanship. Nope. While the book never becomes a slog, it really is about constant hope dashed over and over, until hope can no longer grow. What's interesting - and something I didn't pick up on until near the end of the book - is how Lyman's story is mirrored in that of his grandmother's. And that, though we think he's identifying with her the entire novel, he's not. He's trying to understand her. Her motivations, her reasons for staying even when she should have left. He wants to know what motivated her to hold onto an unhappy life, especially after the monstrous thing that brings the whole novel to a head. There are reasons he wants to know. Because of who he is. And who he's really identifying with.I liked this book a lot. I had never read Stegner and I'm pretty sure I will again. I loved all the detail and nuance he allows Lyman to put into his grandmother's story - part truth, part fiction - and I love that he allows Lyman to understand himself, at least a little. This book won the Pulitzer in 1970, and I think I know why....more

title: The Patron Saint of Liars
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: And so we come to the end.Last year, I read The Dutch House, by a writer named Ann Patchett. Well, I listened to it. Tom Hanks was the narrator and I’And so we come to the end.Last year, I read The Dutch House, by a writer named Ann Patchett. Well, I listened to it. Tom Hanks was the narrator and I’d liked what he’d done with his own book about World’s Fairs and typewriters. I was fully entranced. In a literary landscape where I was constantly thirsty for writers who read like John Irving (and where William Goldman stopped writing novels years before he died), I had stumbled across the best and brightest ascendant to the throne. The Dutch House was my favorite novel of last year.When 2020 started 2020ing and everything went into lockdown, I – almost casually – picked up my next Ann Patchett book. Audiobook. That one was Bel Canto, a novel my friend Tracey had given me years ago that I had never bothered with for some reason. Most things come around. I remember, mid-March, trying out my new at-home gym and work and coffee routine, and standing at the sink and listening to Bel Canto. Just stopping everything for a moment and listening to this book unfurling in my ears. I knew The Dutch House wasn’t a fluke. I texted Tracey and asked her what I should read next. She recommended Truth & Beauty, a nonfiction novel about her friendship with her friend Lucy, who had written her own book about her medical condition called Autobiography of a Face. I put it on my list, but first I wanted to read Commonwealth, Ann Patchett’s only #1 novel and one of the two Tracey believed I wouldn’t like. I not only liked it, I loved it. That’s usually how things go with me and Tracey. She said the same thing about Donnie Darko awhile ago. I never forget ANYTHING.Truth & Beauty was so heartbreakingly good that I was forced to also read Autobiography of a Face, knowing Lucy’s fate even as she didn’t. But by then I wasn’t just an Ann Patchett fan, I was a fanatic. I owned Run in paperback – Tracey’s favorite – and I read it in a day. A DAY. I’ve done that maybe five times before: with The Ratman’s Notebooks, with Singularity, with The Colorado Kid, with The Time-Traveller’s Wife, with Elevation. And now Run. I could not bring myself to put it down. By this point, I realized I was going to end up finishing her entire canon too fast. I craved that. I wanted so much to dig into these words and her complicated families and her spare, stunning prose. But I had to put books between hers. I had to space them out. But man, did I ever finish that book on the Kahiki Supper Club as fast as humanly possible so I could read The Magician’s Assistant. Oh wow, did I love The Magician’s Assistant.More nonfiction: This is the Story of a Happy Marriage, which I liked but didn’t love. Or, to be fair, I loved some essays and only liked a few others. It wasn’t bad by any means, but it was the literary equivalent of a cold shower. I was able to put some distance between me and Ann Patchett. I could wait a little longer. But not forever. Tracey’s other “meh”  was State of Wonder, which I thought I would be completely in agreement with. The book jacket said it was about traveling into the Amazon and researching a drug, and it sounded almost … I don’t know, late-era Michael Crichton. But I was determined to make up my own mind and plunged in. HOLY SHIT was this book good. More patched-together families, more awkwardness, with a few action sequences I didn’t expect. Fantastic. Oh shit, I was back in. I went online and immediately purchased the only two Patchett books I hadn’t read – Taft and The Patron Saint of Liars – which just happened to be her first two novels. Oh man, this was going to have some symmetry to it. For me, it’s rarely just about the books themselves. It’s about the experience of reading. I had started with Patchett’s most recent novel. I was going to end with her first. Taft. I mean, did I have any idea how much I would love this one? Like Run, I couldn’t simply read it. I gulped it. My greed for this story was so total that I think it took two days to read it. Patchett does what John Irving does, what Stephen King does, what Lawrence Block often does: pulls me fully into an invented world and makes me forget everything on the outside. I’m sitting here, at my breakfast table. There’s an empty coffee cup and an empty oatmeal bowl. Tom Petty on the stereo. And my paperback copy of The Patron Saint of Liars, a little beat up from having been carried around, within reaching distance. I finished it moments ago. Did I love it? Of course I loved it. It’s Patchett’s origin story, where she first started exploring her fascinations, her tropes, her obsessions. Writing from different viewpoints. Invented families. Religion without being religious. The past returning on the present in unexpected ways. And people leaving. That’s where it always goes. Someone leaves, and sometimes that’s a good thing, and sometimes that’s a bad thing, and sometimes it’s just a thing. In Liars, we find a woman who can’t stop leaving and the place that ends up holding her. She’s a mystery even when we’re inside her life and becomes more and more mysterious as we move away from her. I’m stunned at how assured the writing is this early on, how perfectly the words march from one place to another, painting scenes and drawing people so perfectly imperfect that it almost makes you ache. It’s enough to make you jealous, if you weren’t so busy realizing what a gift it all was.Thank you, Ann Patchett, for all of your gifts this year. I eagerly await whatever your next book is. And now I think I might have to go back and re-read The Dutch House. On paper this time. I don’t want anything between me and the story, even if it is the melodious narration of Tom Hanks. I want Patchett pure and unfiltered. If nothing else, 2020 has been a year of Ann Patchett, and for that alone I am grateful. ...more

title: Minimalist tiki. A Cocktail Wonk look at classic libations and the modern tiki vanguard
author: Pietrek, Matt*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've read a lot of books on tiki and Polynesian pop this year, and most of them fit into a few easy categories: history of the movement, deep focus onI've read a lot of books on tiki and Polynesian pop this year, and most of them fit into a few easy categories: history of the movement, deep focus on a bar or restaurant (or a region's bars and restaurants), and the drinks. There are a few outliers and interweaving of subjects, but that's mainly where we're at. Minimalist Tiki, by Matt Pietrek and Carrie Smith, is definitely in the drinks category ... but it's also hinting at a new category, touched on slightly by some of the other books. It's about where tiki is right now, since the tiki renaissance has really taken off. I crave this stuff. One of the best aspects of my obsessions is that they're not just one thing. Like, Stephen King is the books, sure, but also the uncollected short stories, the movies, the comics, the audio. I should know; I've written books about all those subjects. Ditto Disney and Star Trek and even Springsteen - there's the main aspect, and then there are tangents. And for most of my interests, a lot of those tangents include the present and the future. King is writing more books. Springsteen is releasing new albums. And tiki is discovering its past and reinventing itself for the now. The cool thing about Minimalist Tiki is that it has an absolute reverence for what came before. Pietrek and Smith highlight what they consider the thirty most important concoctions of the "classic vanguard" - stuff like the Zombie and the Navy Grog - based on common ingredients and provenance and other rules. And then we take kind of a deep dive into the world of rums (and rhums, and rons), stuff that Jeff Berry covered extensively in his Potions of the Caribbean book. While I'm into the history of rum, I find I don't care so much about its production. I know you're really supposed to care about that stuff if you're a tiki person, but honestly, I just want to know what's recommended and if the drinks are delicious. Still, I appreciate the book's focus, because it sets up my favorite part: bartenders, bars, and the direction in which tiki is headed. The section at the end, the new tiki vanguard, asks these bartenders and mixologists to remix those Classic Thirty drinks. A lot of them seem too complicated for me right now, but I'm sure they won't stay that way. In March, I had no idea what an allspice dram was. Now I have a bottle of it in my tiki cabinet. Onward into the tiki future!...more

title: Leis, Luaus and Alohas: The Lure of Hawaii in the Fifties
author: Basten, Fred E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So much of my recent obsession with Polynesian pop springs from Hawaii. Like tapa cloth, Hawaii is woven into the history of the ersatz culture of tikSo much of my recent obsession with Polynesian pop springs from Hawaii. Like tapa cloth, Hawaii is woven into the history of the ersatz culture of tiki bars, A-frames, and Chinese food masquerading as South Seas cuisine. The Hawaii craze took off in a big way in the 1930s with music and the first tiki bars, and exploded in the 1950s, when returning vets from WWII had newfound wealth, leisure, and a desire to return to the "simple, relaxed way of life." Hawaii was there to be everything to everyone. This book isn't one of the more probing looks into the culture of the 1950s that continues to fascinate me. It isn't really even about the tiki lifestyle of which I've grown so fond. It's about the USA's obsession with Hawaii itself in the 1950s - the high notes version. To say this book is breezy would be like saying Diamond Head volcano is a biggish hill. Co-author Charles Phoenix is known for his coffee table books featuring Americana's kitsch and culture, and that's pretty much what you get here ... albeit reigned in a little by, I assume, author Fred Basten's more reverent take. Each chapter opens with a short introduction to a facet of Hawaiian culture that excited the folk of the 1950s: food, flowers, entertainment, etc. This is followed by photographs, postcards, advertisements, matchbook covers and more, illustrating the opening thesis and driving mid-century modern nuts crazy. There are some menu covers I must have studied for a good 20 minutes, marveling at the confluence of 1950s graphic design and the culture of Hawaii. The pictures are the point here, and it's a credit to the authors that they totally understand that.I've been on this tiki journey all year, monofocused on this specific cultural obsession that occupied the United States from roughly the mid-1930s to the middle-late 1960s. It was SUCH a prevalent aspect of American life then and it's all but disappeared today. Back then, the lure of the Hawaiian islands was more exotic, more OTHER, because the white people who were busy discovering it kind of didn't know any better. The legacy of suburban America clinging to a tropical idyll that they partially overlaid with their own idea of what a tropical idyll should be ... well, it's not necessarily blameless. But I'd argue that the naive optimism and honest love of the real culture (mixed with rapture of the fake culture) makes this sort of reverence for a bygone era less squicky and more captivating. I loved this book. ...more

review: It’s the fourth Parker book by Richard Stark (aka Donald E. Westlake) and for a little while, I was a tiny bit frustrated at the seemingly formulaic fIt’s the fourth Parker book by Richard Stark (aka Donald E. Westlake) and for a little while, I was a tiny bit frustrated at the seemingly formulaic feel. So far, the Parker books are all the same: parts 1 & 2 are from Parker’s POV, and there’s some sort of heist afoot. By the end of part 2, he’s betrayed in some way. In Part 3, the point of view explodes outward, and we see the double-cross from someone else’s POV. Then back to Parker in part 4 to find out how it all turns out. Then my reading seemed to smooth out, and I fell into the familiar rhythms of a Parker novel, and found I liked it. I guess the lesson here is that the formula is the point ... which I suppose I already knew, but was good to know again. Also: I don’t know if I should be bringing my expectations of “crime masterpiece” to all these Parker books. I’m out here reading The Big Sleep and Mildred Pierce for the first time and maybe expecting this series to be like that. It’s not. The Parker books collectively might be that, but what I failed to remember when I started The Mourner is that these books aren’t making Statements. They’re down and dirty crime books that you devour and then move on. The resonance doesn’t come from the deep characterization or the trenchant plots, but from the structure and the cleverness, the clockwork of the books.That all said, the first 3 books of the series were all just a tiny bit more captivating than this one, about a statue heist. I liked it, but didn’t love it. And yet I polished it off in like a day and want more. So maybe that says it all....more

title: A Moveable Feast
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was 16 and being forced to read The Old Man and the Sea by an English teacher whose Hemingway fixation blinded her to the fact that no one in cWhen I was 16 and being forced to read The Old Man and the Sea by an English teacher whose Hemingway fixation blinded her to the fact that no one in class was enjoying the book, I made a solemn vow that I would never read the man again. My hatred for that book only grew, as I realized it eventually won the Pulitzer, presumably over better, more interesting books. I remember my  of the book at the time almost verbatim: "So he talks about baseball for awhile, and then there's a shark, and then he talks about baseball some more." FURIOUS.Which is why My Year of Hemingway has been so weirdly instructive. I liked A Farwell to Arms quite a lot, and loved The Sun Also Rises. I selected A Moveable Feast because I'd heard it was about writing, and I'm a sucker for books about writing. I had no idea as I embarked on this terrible year 2020 that I would discover an Ernest Hemingway book I loved as much as I loved A Moveable Feast.It shatters some assumptions I had about the man. For some reason, I always picture Hemingway as a Teddy Roosevelt type: a masculine ideal who likes bullfighting and big game hunting and eschews all silliness and sissiness. And he is very much the classic definition of a "man's man" ... but that's really not where the Hemingway story ends. The first section of the book details his friendship with out and proud lesbian Gertrude Stein. As he struggles to understand homosexuality, she gives him a lot of advice about it (a lot of it bad! Stein was very much about lesbians and very much not about gay dudes). To Hemingway's credit, he doesn't seem to trust her judgment on gay men very much. He alludes to an encounter with a guy who was apparently into him, and who now he can't really trust, but whom he still thinks of as a nice guy. It's interesting to think that Hemingway was more okay with gay guys than Gertrude Stein, but that seems to be what I'm getting. And then I'd always heard his relationship with F. Scott Fitzgerald was antagonistic, and that Hemingway hated him, and hated The Great Gatsby, and kind of thought of him as kind of a sissy. (Yes, I'm using that word a lot. It came up in a book I'm reading now and I've fixated.) The truth is way more complicated, as he discovers only slowly in the early time of his friendship to Fitzgerald that the man is an alcoholic and a hypochondriac, and that his wife Zelda is maybe a sociopath. Near the end of the Fitzgerald section, there's a point where Fitzgerald confesses to Hemingway that he thinks he has a small penis, and Hemingway checks him out and spends all afternoon convincing him it's normal, and that he's also probably a grower not a shower. This is a thing that happened in real life, and in this book. I was NOT expecting this.None of that is really why I loved this book so much. Hemingway's love of Paris is so all-consuming that it's impossible not to fall in love with it, too ... but for me, it's the writing and reading. How he would write in cafes long before it was fashionable to make fun of people for writing in cafes. His sort of unconvincing argument that great hunger helps you appreciate art more. The books he reads, the shops he goes to, the writers he knows: this is all catnip for me. I get these weird tingles whenever I read about a writer writing or reading. Books about books are my favorite books. I loved this book....more

review: "Children don't ruin art. Art ruins children."I'm married to an artist. I don't always get what he paints or what he appreciates. Abstract art is some"Children don't ruin art. Art ruins children."I'm married to an artist. I don't always get what he paints or what he appreciates. Abstract art is sometimes out of my realm of understanding, and there are whole genres of art - photographs of photographs, for example - that I struggle to see as art at all. Once, my husband and I went to see a performance piece that I loathed so much I left the space shaking and angry. After having read The Family Fang, I wonder, for the first time, if that might have been the point.The Fangs make chaos art. Caleb and Camilla Fang believe that the act of disrupting the lives of regular people is the most beautiful artistry you can create. Their children, Annie and Buster - or, to use their stage names, A and B - are at first reluctant participants in their parents' "happenings"; then, as they discover their own personalities, they become rebels against Caleb and Camille.At the crux of the novel is the question of whether Annie and Buster are the Fangs' children, or their artistic props. What matters more to the elder Fangs? These are knotty, weighty questions, and what's most frustrating is that even though we get a definitive answer, I'm not sure how much to trust it. The Fangs' art is all about subverting expectations, about shifting the accepted truths of life into absurdity. Is the ending of the book really the ending? Maybe. Probably, even. And still ... still I wonder.Man, did I like this book. Earlier this year, I read Kevin Wilson's Nothing to See Here, and while most people seemed to like it, a lot of the s I read all compared it to The Family Fang. I have a knack for getting into an author after they've hit their pop culture phenom moment. What's weird is how Nothing to See Here is actually a riff on a movie script invented in The Family Fang, making these two books interconnect in a weird way. But are they REALLY interrelated? This novel has thrown all my thoughts into disarray. I think it was meant to. Maybe the book is actually a performance piece itself....more

title: Just Like You
author: Hornby, Nick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Nick Hornby novels are like a cozy blanket you wrap yourself in when it’s cold, but it’s just a little too small and some part of you always sticks ouNick Hornby novels are like a cozy blanket you wrap yourself in when it’s cold, but it’s just a little too small and some part of you always sticks out. Feet. Shoulders. Something. It’s that slightly awkward, vaguely uncomfortable feeling that makes these books work, even as the rest of it is comforting and somewhat optimistic.Just Like You is another of Hornby’s British romances, but there are some disruptions to his norms before it even begins. Joseph is 22, Black, and works at a butcher’s shop, among other things. Lucy is white, 42, has two kids and is working through a semi-messy divorce. There are very, very many ways that this relationship could go wrong. Then it ... kind of doesn’t.I can’t pretend to be super objective about a book about cross-generational romance. When I was eighteen, I was dating a forty-eight-year-old, and it often felt weird and comforting and exciting and baffling, all at the same time. To his immense credit, Hornby understands all of that. The two decades between Joseph and Lucy are a wall. Whether it’s an impenetrable wall, or something that can be climbed, is part of the crux of the novel. There’s also a fascinating vagueness at the center of both Lucy and Joseph’s lives. The questions of whether they really like their own friends, how they get along with their own family, where, honestly, are they going, both individually and together - Hornby examines all this stuff, sometimes closely, but no one really has answers. The fact that that’s fine is a little refreshing, even if you still wonder how long something like their relationship can last. Mine lasted five years. How about theirs?There’s an intriguing moment in the middle of the book where Joseph decides he can’t make a massive decision cogently, so decides to have it both ways. That choice invalidates both outcomes, and it has repercussions ... but those repercussions are not immediate, and they’re not as personally detrimental as he thought they’d be. Only as we’re nearing the end of the novel do we get to see some consequences of making poor choices based on what you want in the moment. I’m not sure Hornby intended quite such a melancholy feeling at the end of a book that generally loves its characters, but you never know. The whole novel is set against the backdrop of the Brexit referendum, and near the end, we unfortunately get to Trump’s reign as president. The political stuff bounces into the lives of these characters but doesn’t really stick around. One gets the sense, however, that that’s not going to be a forever thing, either. I really liked this book. Maybe not as much as High Fidelity or About a Boy or Juliet, Naked, but it hit me in all the ways a good Nick Hornby book should. I’m so happy I read it. ...more
