title: They May Not Mean To, But They Do
author: Schine, Cathleen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Some days, you're just in the mood for dysfunctional family dramas. Last year, I read and loved The Grammarians by Cathleen Schine, and I was determinSome days, you're just in the mood for dysfunctional family dramas. Last year, I read and loved The Grammarians by Cathleen Schine, and I was determined this year to delve deeper into her backlist. I apparently let my determination falter for nine months, because here we are and I'm only at my second book in the Schine canon. But what a book! Most of the novel centers on Joy Bergman, and her life as a mother, wife, widow, grandmother, museum worker, and dog owner. Joy is in her mid-80s now, and her life is just beginning to unravel. Her role as a caretaker for her sick and dying husband is becoming too much for her. So, though she is loath to admit it, is her job at the museum; her department is managed by a scheming jerk named Miss Georgia, who believes the only old things that belong in the library are the exhibits. Joy is running out of ways to belong. What follows after a one-two punch of trauma is her searching for that answer. She no longer moves fast and she does get confused and dizzy, but she remains a viable human, despite how she sometimes feels. The safety nets that used to cheer her - family gatherings, the house Upstate - no longer seem to bring her the happiness she once found there. And her children, in attempting to fix her or cure her or make her feel better usually only end up making her feel worse. They may not mean to, but they do. I've read a few s where Caroline Schine is referred to as a "great comic novelist," but I think that overlooks the very real drama here. Joy's ennui is so well captured and, oddly, vibrant, that it never gets frustrating or boring. What is occasionally frustrating is her children's insistence that they only want the best for their mother, not realizing that what they really want is the best for themselves. None of it's malicious. Everyone's trying to be a good person. It just doesn't always work out that way.Like The Grammarians, They May Not Mean To is a sharp, smart, fun melodrama about family dynamics I honestly didn't want to stop reading. I didn't realize I'd devoured it in two days. What next?!...more

title: River of Teeth        (River of Teeth, #1)
author: Gailey, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, so this book is an alternate-universe Western about hippo ranchers in the American South in the 1800s and almost everyone is queer. I liked it. Okay, so this book is an alternate-universe Western about hippo ranchers in the American South in the 1800s and almost everyone is queer. I liked it. I liked it enough to want to read the sequel next. It's bizarre and audacious, edging toward camp by its nature but playing the whole thing (ironically) straight. The brash fellow at the center of the story is named Winslow Houndstooth, and within the first few pages, he's already getting it on with a federal agent man. Later, we learn that he's at least bisexual, then pansexual. Houndstooth is basically just your average horny bayou scoundrel, even though he's originally from the UK, and he's eager to shack up with anyone who catches his fancy.Things get more complicated when, in gathering his posse for a caper ("It's not a caper," he keeps trying to remind his crew, "it's an operation"), he meets a retired genderqueer hippo wrangler named Hero. Just when you thought the names couldn't get more preposterous than "Winslow Houndstooth." The simmering romance between Hero and Houndstooth is one of this book's more satisfying elements, and the pronouns are only confusing initially if you're used to only him/her. You get used to them - no pun intended - pretty quickly. One thing I didn't expect is how quickly the book could brutal and bloody. Gailey is not afraid to kill off characters, even ones you think are important. The first time someone went into a hippo's jaws, I was caught so unawares, I thought I'd missed something. Then, remembering Crichton's Congo, I remembered how fast hippos could be. Especially the feral ones.I also really loved the double- and triple-crosses, all the stuff that you want to see in a caper (it's not a caper). The venal bad guy. The changes of heart. The rogue assassins. The rogue hippos. River of Teeth is packed with that stuff. I liked it, as I'd said.I stopped short of loving the book for a few reasons, the main one being that I wasn't actually all that invested in the plot. It's interesting, but author Gailey seems a lot more exuberant in the foreword and the AU timeline at the end; while the action is propulsive and interesting, I wonder if a more contemplative Western involving hippo ranchers would have been more involving. Maybe I'm just still reeling from Lonesome Dove. And while I loved all of the characters, I don't really know them all that well. This book is quite short (it might actually be more rightly classified as a novella), and maybe they get some fleshing out in Book 2 (and in the additional stories in the collected volume, American Hippo). It's such a weird concept and I loved the worldbuilding. I just want a deeper dive into the world itself....more

title: Death on the Nile        (Hercule Poirot, #18)
author: Christie, Agatha
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have this compulsion to read books before the movie comes out. I know Death on the Nile has been a movie - and I think a pretty celebrated one? - foI have this compulsion to read books before the movie comes out. I know Death on the Nile has been a movie - and I think a pretty celebrated one? - for quite awhile, but it’s being remade now, and it’s the sequel to the Murder on the Orient Express that came out a few years ago that I enjoyed reading/seeing, so why not?My friend Tracey has been all about Agatha Christie for years and has been eager to get me to read her. When I was in middle school, I attempted to read Hallowe’en Party, to little avail. I’ve been more successful in the era of audiobooks, where charming British narrators can unfurl Christie’s stories of a cosmopolitan group of weirdos who get together in an enclosed conveyance and then murders happen. At least that’s what I get from the two books I’ve read.And they’re good books. So far, they’re not transcendent books, but maybe they don’t have to be. Agatha Christie helped define the detective genre, and what I’m used to reading are the reactions against the detective genre. 1940s crime noir through 2010s recurring characters in deeply conflicted and brutal cases, most of the stuff I like pushes against “detective compiles clues and gathers everyone in a room with a flourish.” Lawrence Block’s Bernie Rhodenbarr does it, but he’s a burglar, and that’s a different sort of subversion.Here’s what I expected from Death on the Nile: a somewhat cozy mystery solved ingeniously by the arrogant Hercule Poirot. I got the second part right. This is a murder mystery and it’s a little old-fashioned, but it’s nowhere near cozy. At one point, someone gets shot and there’s a lot of discussion of bone being shattered, and it’s pretty intense. And there are TWISTS. I didn’t expect the red herrings and the misdirections to take me in so completely. I had a vague idea of who the killer was (turns out, I was actually right about that), but I didn’t expect the last scene’s shocking denouement, or Christie’s super cynical final words, in which she encapsulates the senselessness and futility of murder-as-sensation in a few short sentences. It’s a grim and satisfying ending.One thing, though: I mean, I know it’s de rigeur to apply modern mores on classic works, but ... it’s sort of obvious that Agatha Christie is kind of racist. There’s some “local Egyptian” dialect that is way past cringe, and some other parts of the book where I kind of had to stop and be like, “No, I certainly don’t care for that.” I’ve been thinking a lot about JK Rowling lately, and how distasteful she is, and what a shame it is because I love the books so much. Same for Orion Scott Card. But does Christie get a pass for her racism because we love the books? Do we just ignore the racism? I don’t have an answer. We’ve been reckoning with Lovecraft’s racism lately and that’s been very good. Is there a statute of limitations, or at some point, do we have to put them aside? I don’t want to, but I have no idea. I liked this book a lot - more than Orient Express - and I think I have to like it with the caveat that the racism was distracting and slightly detrimental. Four stars!...more

title: Rebecca
author: du Maurier, Daphne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I keep wanting to give this a lesser grade, because to give it the five stars it deserves seems ... I don't know, too easy? When I was a junior in higI keep wanting to give this a lesser grade, because to give it the five stars it deserves seems ... I don't know, too easy? When I was a junior in high school, my English teacher Mrs. Cosgrove showed the beginning of the Hitchcock adaptation in class and I was hooked. I don't know when I finished watching it - gay movie night at Joe's house? - but man, what an impact. Maybe I want to rate the book less because the movie left such an impact on me. But that stinks. I'm not going to do that.I'm a little stunned I've never read this before. Stephen King cites it as a huge influence on his great novel Bag of Bones (and I'm considering re-reading that next because of it), and I usually like to go back to King's influences after I finish his books. Also, I'm fascinated by du Maurier, because for awhile she was one of the bestsellingest writers in history; something like nine of her novels went to #1, which may not sound like much today, but was a huge feat in the early years. It's the atmosphere of the book I keep going back to. The tone, like creeping fog. "Last night, I dreamt I went to Manderley again" is such a bold opening line. Immediate mystery. Immediate intrigue. We have to lock in to that first bit of story, because the our unnamed protagonist is a bit of a milksop at the start; she's clumsy and shy and basically Bella Swan for the first fifty pages. A handsome rich man named Max DeWinter swoops in on Monte Carlo and whisks her away from her paid companion job. Brings her to his rambling home in the countryside; this is Manderley, which the first Mrs. DeWinter - Rebecca - had once been in charge of. She drowned, though, and literally everyone is mourning her. Especially Mrs. Danvers, the creepy as fuck head housekeeper who likes to fondle Rebecca's underthings. You don't really want to route for the new Mrs. DeWinter at first. She works against herself. Her shyness and inability to stand up for herself are major liabilities. At parts, you want to be like, LADY, GET IT TOGETHER. But you can't blame her, really, because her paranoia isn't wrong. There IS a lot stacked against her. Mrs. Danvers actively hates her. Maxim is remote, seemingly still in love with his dead wife. Everyone has good words about Rebecca. The dead woman hangs over the novel like a human shroud, and it's both fascinating and tragic to watch her fight against Rebecca, then be consumed by her. It's all SUPER gothic. The tone lifts a little when we get to the murder mystery in the last quarter of the book. It's not that it drags, it's just that we know the truth and it's simply not as interesting to see a police procedural insert itself into this haunted love story. It all has a point, though, and by the time we get to the close of things, that creep factor is back. The final sequence (different from the movie, and I'm debating whether one element in the film was an improvement) (yes, it was) is nearly as chilling as a scene between Danvers and our heroine midway through the book, where there's a power struggle by a window. It's remarkably dark and hideously satisfying. I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Time to go seek out more du Maurier....more

title: The Last Battle        (The Chronicles of Narnia, #7)
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** Well that was a rush, wasn't it? The entire Narnia series in a little over a week. I'll tell you, this whole adventure was pretty in**spoiler alert** Well that was a rush, wasn't it? The entire Narnia series in a little over a week. I'll tell you, this whole adventure was pretty intense. At first I'm remembering having read half the series, then discovering I only read the first chapters of most of them, then forgetting large swaths of the ones I KNEW I'd read. Every novel is connected to every other, but because time moves oddly in Narnia, sometimes thousands of years pass between books. It's weird to see Prince Caspian as a boy in book 2, and then as a rugged middle-aged man in book 3, and then, whoa, a dying elderly guy in book 4. It's a head trip.Also a head trip? THIS WHOLE LAST BOOK. I recently read the memoir Bookworm, by Lucy Mangan, and in it, she talks all about slowly coming to the realization that this is a book about Christianity by the end of Last Battle. I think a child of four could have heard this story and been like WAIT A MINUTE, is this THE BIBLE?!I mean, kinda? It's the harshest book in the series. The subtitle is "A Tale for Children," but it's KIND OF NOT. Within the first few pages, we've got false gods and slavery and bloooooood. Then there's a terrifying TOTALLY NOT MIDDLE-EASTERN god named Tash that also might be the devil, unless the White Witch is the devil, in which case Tash is just an older god than the one that gave us Jesus, I mean Aslan. Oh btw, CS Lewis makes so much use of the word "darkies" in this one it's almost like Tarantino directed it; the fact that it's only said by Dwarves who refuse to see paradise all around them only softens the blow a little.I mean, the racism? The Calormene are consistently referred to as evil and dark-skinned, almost as if those terms were interchangable (and they are!). There's one GOOD Calormen in the book at the end, but he's only good because he renounces his faith to Tash and pledges allegiance to Aslan in the end. So that's ... interesting. I've been reading Michener this year. I know how missionaries operate. The misogyny is tamped down a little in this one and Jill of all people is finally allowed into battle. And she KICKS ASS. She's basically the Eowyn of Narnia, and she almost balances off Susan, who pretends Narnia isn't real anymore because she's basically the Meg March of Narnia before Meg became a housewife and found it SUPER FULFILLING. Also (do I have this all hidden under spoilers, yes I do) THEY'RE ALL FUCKING DEAD. Come gather 'round children, and hear this tale of boys and girls just like you who dreamed of being kings and queens of a magical land that was so awesome THEY DIED IN A TRAIN ACCIDENT AND NOW THEY'RE IN LION HEAVEN. Oh by the way SO DID THEIR BLAMELESS PARENTS. What the absolute fuck, CS Lewis? It's not even couched in "they passed from that land to this"; he straight up goes, "So yeah, remember that little girl Lucy you loved from page one of the first book? Mangled to death in a train wreck. Oh but here comes Mr. Tumnus the faun! He has also died. Everyone you ever liked is dead. Super dead. Also you're going to watch Narnia die and btw Heaven is a Tardis. SWEET DREAMS."I mean, I did like it. I liked it less than the others because a lot of it seemed less about story and character and more about DO YOU SEE WHY IT'S GOOD TO LOVE JESUS, CHILDREN? But 1. the audiobook was read by Sir Patrick Stewart, so right there A++, 2. I kind of loved everyone seeing characters from the past books (except, apparently, Aravis from Horse and His Boy, because maybe she made a grievous error and forgot to stop worshipping Tash when she saved Narnia from invasion, but whatever). It's probably the best ending a series like this could have, but it doesn't mean I have to love it like I love some of the other ones. In fact, now that we're at the end, let's do a list of my favorites in order.1. The Voyage of the Dawn Treader2. The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe3. The Magician's Nephew4. The Silver Chair5. The Horse and His Boy6. Prince Caspian7. The Last BattleThe first 5 are fairly close, Prince Caspian is just sort of dull (and features The Worst Susan), and The Last Battle is what it is. Also, despite the fact that I've numbered these doesn't mean you should read the books in this order, despite the fact that we can just arbitrarily renumber Narnia however we choose and tell people it's the right way to read it.Anyway, thanks for coming on this journey with me! High fantasy and Christian parable is over for now. I think I need something dark and gothic and weird. ...more

title: The Magician’s Nephew        (The Chronicles of Narnia, #6)
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So the assumption was going into this whole Narnia adventure was that I’d read The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe and The Magician’s Nephew all theSo the assumption was going into this whole Narnia adventure was that I’d read The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe and The Magician’s Nephew all the way through. Also that I was pretty sure I’d read Prince Caspian and Voyage of the Dawn Treader, but not The Silver Chair. And I for some reason opted out entirely of The Horse and His Boy and The Last Battle.YET! For years I had OPINIONS about the Narnia books. Which order they should be read in (publication order, because I’m not a RUBE; more on this in a moment), what the Christian themes meant, that I was SO well versed in Lion, Witch that I didn’t have to reread it for my Alternate Worlds elective in school and I BOMBED THAT TEST. As we’ve seen, I’ve read almost none of the Narnia books. The Lion, the Witch, YES. And then, curiously, first chapters of a bunch of others. All the others? When I got to the part in this book about the rings, I knew - KNEW! - I had read it before. But then there’s a bunch of stuff in the middle about the wicked witch in our world, and this weirdly interminable “comic” sequence that goes on for like 20 pages about the animals not knowing whether Uncle Andrew is a plant or an animal. Reading it now, with fresh ears and eyes, that’s the book’s only real dead spot. This book is pretty damn magical.I LOVED the idea of the pools that take you to other worlds, and how they dry up when the worlds stop living. Digory and Polly are basically precursors to ... well, not Edmund and Lucy but Eustace and Jill. And they’re fun to know, too, and adventurous and exciting. It’s cool that Polly loves adventure as much as Digory, if not more-than. Plus, Aslan is a one-lion Genesis device and the whole scene where Narnia is being born is a wonder of storytelling. Lewis gives us just enough detail and moves on. Weirdly, we don’t know how the country of Calormen is created, except that Aslan didn’t seem to create that as he’d created Narnia and Arkenland ... so yay for retroactively damning those false gods!Two things before I finish this so I can hopefully read The Last Battle for the first time: one, the books are getting far more blatantly Christian as the series goes on. I mean, it hooks you with the little girl and the faun and the Turkish delight and then you’re six books in and it’s like wait did I just read Let There Be Light in my kid’s adventure novel? Apparently so. It doesn’t distract much because you can totally read these books as surface-level stuff, and except for a few turns of phrase here and there, Lewis doesn’t really soapbox. So that’s nice.Two: I am now firmly (and learnedly) on the side of publication order. Certainly much of the story of Magician’s Nephew happens before The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe ... but here, Aslan just sort of shows up, and he’s majestic and shit but there’s nothing of the slow-build nature of seeing him for the first time in that first novel, all mystery and shadow, and getting to know him over the course of the books, so that when he appears here, you know how important he is. Then there’s minor mysteries like the provenance of the lamppost in the forest that have way more impact as something solved here rather than just blurted out if this one is read first. Publication order, I’m convinced, offers a richer, more adventurous tapestry. Onto the finale!...more

title: The Horse and His Boy        (The Chronicles of Narnia, #5)
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, so let’s get the racism out of the way forthwith. Is this book racist? Like ... maybe? The bad guys are mostly darker-skinned people who are fanOkay, so let’s get the racism out of the way forthwith. Is this book racist? Like ... maybe? The bad guys are mostly darker-skinned people who are fantasy-story analogues of Middle Easterners. They kidnap and plot and call Aslan the Devil, so there’s just a lot going on there. Still, and maybe I’m grasping here, maybe the best character in the whole book is Aravis, a Calorman girl who’s running away so as not to be married off to a wizened vizier. So ... maybe.One of the more interesting things about this one is how women are slowly becoming more viable as characters. Aravis has a whole lot going on, and even her valid friend has some levels. And Lucy Pevensie shows up and people are like, oh yeah, she’s kind of like a man so she’s cool. Of course Susan’s here and it’s FINE. She’s not actively being a jerk to everyone, so that’s a plus. Of all the books in the series so far, this one reminded me most of Prince Caspian, if that book had been a lot more exciting. The escaped slave Shasta (who is FAIR SKINNED UNLIKE THE BAD GUYS *dogwhistle*) meets a talking horse and together they decide to journey out of Calormen and into Narnia and the North. Like Dawn Treader on sea and Silver Chair underground, this takes us across a huge desert and into bazaars and it’s all exciting and exotic and fun. All four of the main characters are fun, too: Shasta, Aravis, and the talking horses Bree and Hwin. I liked seeing Lucy and Edmund again (not Susan), and there’s even a cameo by Mr. Tumnus. I admit, it was pretty jazzy to see them all again.One note about the order: if I were to read these books in the new “chronological” order, I would severely be depriving myself of the slow, deliberate build of these books. Each one has a specific mood, and the books build on that mood as time goes on. Plus, books refer to other novels from the past all the time. It would be silly to refer back to a novel you hadn’t read yet. Okay, fantastic read, teeny bit racist, better in the misogyny, ON TO BOOK 6!...more

title: The Silver Chair        (The Chronicles of Narnia, #4)
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So I think I figured it out. Except for The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe and The Magician's Nephew, I only read the first chapter of these early So I think I figured it out. Except for The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe and The Magician's Nephew, I only read the first chapter of these early books. I very clearly remember getting into them, then either getting bored or distracted and putting them away. To the point where, based on my knowledge, the Narnia books read as follows: British kids keep getting sucked into this magic place and then no adventures happen. Do they get back? *SHRUG* The advantage of this is that I'm thrilling at discovering these books for the first time. And for the first time since the first book, The Silver Chair has a female protagonist - Jill Pole, the first person not related to the Pevensies to journey into Narnia. She goes in with Eustace (from Dawn Treader) and they're sort of bickering classmates who hate their school that lionizes bullying and hates individualism (and the Bible, btw). What's kind of fascinating about this one is that neither Eustace nor Jill are all the way likable. Eustace reformed a lot in the last book and apparently kept it up, and neither of these two are bad people. But they're kind of cranky and sometimes brutish and it's mostly awesome. Like, in the earlier books, you were either a saint or a sinner, and if you were a sinner, you MIGHT be able to change your ways (as both Edmund and Eustace did). Or you were Susan, who was irritating and never got to go to Narnia again and good riddance. But sometimes Peter's valiance and Lucy's precociousness kind of got ... I don't know, too broad? Both Jill and Eustace here behave mostly like real kids, which is a new change of pace. Plus, like Dawn Treader, this one is full of many adventures. It actually takes the same template as the last book, and just applies it over (and sometimes under) land. More than anything, this book reminded me of a video game, wherein you get some basic commands at the start, and maybe there are some side quests, and if you don't listen to the commands, bad stuff is going to happen to you. One sequence logically leads to another, and there's a whole air of creepiness in this one that only suffused parts of Dawn Treader (the island where dreams come true? the hag and the werewolf? Y I K E S). I would say I liked it almost as much as Dawn Treader, with a huge BUT:I mean, so girls just aren't allowed to fight in battle? They don't get swords? And at one point, Jill's all like, "Well in MY world, the MEN don't let their WIVES boss them around." Like it's a good thing? I also rolled my eyes at the end at the hard-as-nails headmaster - "who was a WOMAN!!!" - goes into hysterics over a glimpse of Narnia. Although that might be a long joke about British politics, which feels more Lewis Carroll than CS Lewis.Oh, and I went a little nutty about the title. Like, in the first few books, you're introduced to the title stuff immediately. Ah yes, there's a lion and a witch and a wardrobe, first ten pages. Ahhh yes, Prince Caspian, page 20. Well hey there, Dawn Treader, page like 3, are you on a VOYAGE?! And then this one, we're halfway through the book and there's NO mention of chairs, silver or otherwise. And then as soon as Lewis says it in the book, I went Avengers-live-audience bonkers. "THE SILVER CHAIR! THERE IT IS! THAT'S THE TITLE OF THE BOOK INSIDE THE BOOK!!!" I might be a little wrapped up in these stories right now.I really don't want these books to end. I'm about to delve into the first book I really know nothing about - The Horse and His Boy. I vaguely recall reading parts of this one when I was eight and lying in my bed, not sleeping, using a flashlight to see the pages. But mostly I was just entranced by the cover. ...more

title: The Voyage of the “Dawn Treader”        (The Chronicles of Narnia, #3)
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Prince Caspian, the book, disappointed me so much after The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe, I was a little loath to go on. Susan, who had made thinPrince Caspian, the book, disappointed me so much after The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe, I was a little loath to go on. Susan, who had made things so dreadful in the second book, was notably absent from this one ... only to be replaced by righteous creep Eustice, Edmund and Lucy's weird cousin who hates things. Then they get pulled into a picture of a Viking-type ship and all three of them are in Narnia, and Eustice is STILL a little shit. Until something awesome happens. You know how one of my favorite things is seeing a sea change in a nasty character and then they're on the side of the good guys? Of course that happens with Eustice, but the way it happens is really, fantastically amazing. I think I spoiled too much in my last , and I don't want to do the same here. Basically, I didn't expect it at all, and for someone to learn humility and grace after such a fiery trial was thrilling and satisfying.BUT THAT'S NOT THE END OF SATISFACTION. This book is CRAMMED with adventure and intrigue and a LIIIIIIIIIIITTLE bit of misogyny. I mean, girls still aren't ready for battle, and one character is defined only as the daughter of one man and the wife of another (she's never given a name! Come on, CS Lewis!), and at a few points I wanted to throttle people and say, "HASN'T LUCY EARNED YOUR TRUST BY THIS POINT," but beyond that ... just wow. The Dawn Treader visits all these islands that sort of lead toward the end of the world, and there is a NEW and EXCITING adventure on almost every island. Every one is enchanted in some way - good or bad, and in one case balls-out terrifying - and the way Lewis wraps us in the adventures is so refreshing and thrilling after the weird stasis of Book 2. I was so desperate for them to get to a new island, and when they did, I wanted them to solve the mystery and get to a new island right away. I was legit enrapt on every page.And look, I'm almost positive there are religious and Biblical parallels to this stuff. But I'm interested in that! It's like learning all about the whaleship Essex after you read Moby-Dick. I'm actually eager to dig into some fan sites and get a deeper understanding of what Lewis was going for, even though the story can totally be read as a secular fairy tale, without any super religious allegory or overtones (except Aslan is TOTALLY Jesus, but whatever). But this book - which I totally thought I'd read before but I hadn't - was so so so good (maybe better than The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe?!) that I want to know everything about it. Now: onto The Silver Chair!...more

title: Prince Caspian        (The Chronicles of Narnia, #2)
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** Okay, so I thought I’d read this book. I hadn’t. I think I got to the island part at the beginning and stopped. This means that I ne**spoiler alert** Okay, so I thought I’d read this book. I hadn’t. I think I got to the island part at the beginning and stopped. This means that I never read “Dawn Treader” either. Meaning my entire primary knowledge of Narnia has been based on two novels not in order. Did I pick up names and other clues by osmosis? I know for a fact that I’ve heard the name Reepicheep, but I don’t know why. I liked this one ... but with reservations. For the first half of the book, Prince/King Caspian is a really interesting character. He’s interested in history and astronomy and wants to make something out of himself. Then he’s sort of sidelined in the second half. I think he screams sometimes. It’s so weird. Peter is a more interesting character here, and a more important one. A lot of the book is about him coming into his own. Maybe that’s the point. The name of the book is PRINCE Caspian, even though he’s technically a king. Only at the end does Aslan make him a legit king. That’s another thing: what’s the deal with Aslan? Is his whole disappearing act trying to trigger faith in the children from this world? Lucy believes, and Edmund kind of does, but Susan and Peter are like, “Yeah, okay Lucy, just because you’ve been right about literally everything, that’s no reason to start believing you now.” Oh and don’t get me started on Susan. In the first book, the White Witch is the on-top villain, and Edmund is the real enemy. In this one, the fake King Miraz is the Big Bad, but Susan is like WAY worse. She’s gone full Amy March, and seeing her chastened for sort of believing Lucy but not caring because she prefers to be lazy is not as satisfying as I want it to be. Look, I know a lot of this is parable stuff. Belief in your higher power, belief in yourself, belief in magic - it’s necessary in a book like this, especially if you’re taking the Christian parallels into it. But it doesn’t make Aslan less frustrating or Susan less insufferable. I was also a little taken aback by the huge major battle in the middle of the book, which takes like three paragraphs. It’s kind of funny that we spend like seventy pages on Peter and Susan and Edmund and Lucy and Trumpkin getting lost in the woods, and then when it comes to the big battle sequence, it’s like, “Wow, so a lot of people died and Miraz twirled his mustache. Anyway, let’s see what’s happening in those Blair Witch woods where the role of Mike will be played by Susan Pevensie.” Okay, so all this seems like I didn’t like it. I LIKED IT A LOT. There’s a lot of world building and deep fantasy history and I loved all that. And I think I liked Caspian as a character, and want to see him grow and change. Oh, and speaking of sulking obstacle Susan: one of my favorite tropes in books is when the bully character redeems themselves, and it was so good to see Susan wielding that bow and arrow like she’s Katniss Everdeen and saving Trumpkin from the marauders.Oh, and there’s one sequence that is OUTRIGHT TERRIFYING. One of the other dwarves brings a few friends into Caspian’s hiding place and one of them is all, “I am the personification of death and I will destroy my enemies from the inside out” and you’re like Y I K E S and the other one is like, “BTW I’m going to bite people and even if I get killed, you won’t be able to pry my jaws open with a crowbar, ps I’m totally a werewolf.” It’s AMAZING. The whole book feels a little transitional, and not really like a complete story in itself. I think I might have to get through the rest of the books to know where I’ll put this in context. ...more

title: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe        (The Chronicles of Narnia, #1)
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was a wee lad, my preschool teacher and my mother somehow became good friends. Her name was also Michelle, and eventually I would go to her houWhen I was a wee lad, my preschool teacher and my mother somehow became good friends. Her name was also Michelle, and eventually I would go to her house when my mother went calling, and peruse her book collection all afternoon. Michelle was a big one for high fantasy and light science fiction. It was in her library that I first saw that book on gnomes, and where I first heard of Douglas Adams.She was especially keen on Narnia. I was a tiny bit too young to read The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe on my own, but I distinctly recall her reading it TO me, a few pages at a time. Did she come over and read to me at bedtime? Why do I think she did? I can hear her pronunciations, her inflections. The way she said Narnia with a slight Boston accent, so that the R was a suggestion more than a rule.I remember falling deeply in love with this novel. I know I read it to myself at least once thereafter. Not twice, which was a mistake. In junior year of high school, I took a class called Alternate Worlds, in which we read classics of horror, fantasy, and science fiction. I believed I was SO versed in this book that I didn't need to re-read it, and got a lot of dodgy grades. It occurred to me only later that I was sixteen and I'd last read TLTW&TW when I was probably eight. A lifetime before! At some point in my erstwhile childhood, I either borrowed or received the next two books in the series - Prince Caspian and The Voyage of the "Dawn Treader." And ... I MIGHT have read them? I know I didn't read The Silver Chair, and I made a feint toward The Horse and His Boy but I didn't get very into it. I absolutely read The Magician's Nephew and somehow skipped The Last Battle. The vagaries of youth. For the first time, I'm reading them all. In publication order, which I believe to be the "correct" order. My plan this year was to re-read the Harry Potter books, but I'm going to give them space to form a protective crust around themselves, protecting themselves from their author. Instead, it's back to Narnia I go, for the first time again. Off to book 2! ...more

title: Ironweed
author: Kennedy, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For research on a book I'm writing, I looked up a list of Pulitzer Prize winners for fiction, and stumbled across this book. I remembered a still of tFor research on a book I'm writing, I looked up a list of Pulitzer Prize winners for fiction, and stumbled across this book. I remembered a still of the movie - Jack Nicholson and Meryl Streep looking like hobos - and got so het up to read it, I immediately put it onto the top of my list.I've read books about homelessness before. Heck, I've written at least one. But this one hit harder than most, and I'm unsure why. At the center of the book is Francis Phelan, a man who accidentally killed his infant son while drunk, the incident that causes him to run away from his family. We catch up with him when he returns to his home town of Albany during the Great Depression. There, we meet the alcoholic friends he hangs around with, the woman, Helen, he might love ... and the ghosts of the people he has killed. For awhile, we can try to comfort ourselves with the fact that, along with his son's death, his first murder might have been accidental. Slowly, as we come to realize Francis' nature, we begin to doubt. He's not any sort of serial killer or homicidal maniac, never think that. His brutal impulses only come out when he faces injustice, and as a homeless man in the Depression, that's more than a little.Maybe the most fascinating thing about Francis is his panicky stasis. Over the course of the novel, not very much happens. He drifts from place to place, earning money doing a day's worth of work, then either spending it frivolously or giving it away. He has little aim, little gumption. Everything is swallowed up in the whale of guilt inside of him. The same guilt that causes him to give away anything that will make him feel better - money, food, even Helen's love - is the same that causes the ghosts to follow him everywhere. He can't ever escape his past, especially in Albany, where the past is present. There's an edge to this novel that isn't on top, isn't obvious. It underlines every sentence, every character, every interaction. Everyone is desperate and pretending they're not. No one kids themselves that they aren't "bums," but any time they get a moment to remember who they were in their previous lives, they grab at it. For Helen, it's a brief singing gig. For Francis, it's an old suit he used to wear when times were more prosperous. There's a great scene where he's about to give someone his new pants, and then reclaims his dignity, just for a moment, understanding that he deserves this new/old outfit, at least for a little while.I don't quite understand the ending. I don't know if Francis has really gotten free of his demons or not. Maybe that's intentional. Either way, I'm finding myself ruminating on this novel, feeling it scratching at my brain and heart. You want to cry for the dead, but you don't, because there's always going to be more dead. And there's going to be more living, too ... and that might not be much better....more

title: Washington Black
author: Edugyan, Esi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'll be honest: I had no idea what this book was about when I downloaded the audio. The cover captured me: what looked like an airship cruising over sI'll be honest: I had no idea what this book was about when I downloaded the audio. The cover captured me: what looked like an airship cruising over some unknown jungle. I was convinced it was a steampunk novel, and while the aesthetic has always fascinated me, I've never read a book in the genre. It was with that intention that I downloaded and dove in.How differently I might have approached the book if I had seen the other cover, the one accompanying the hardback. Two dark figures in a blinding sea of white. How did these two images match up? What was this book about?Washington Black is a boy slave working on a plantation in Barbados in the late 1800s. The plantation's name is Faith, one of the book's cruel ironies. In charge of Faith is the Master, a deliberately brutal white man whose entire personality appears to be cruelty for cruelty's sake. Somehow, this doesn't make him a caricature, an important distinction given the revelations late in the novel. Opposing the Master is his brother, a kind, scientific man named Titch. Inadvertently, he rescues Washington - called Wash - by enlisting him for aid in his experiments with aeronautics. Just the right size, Titch thinks, to be used as ballast for his experimental new flying machine. And that is where Wash's adventures begin.As it turns out, Wash also has a scientific mind, proving more valuable to Titch than simple ballast. Before long, Wash starts to view Titch as his entire salvation - his entire WORLD - so that when he is forced to make his own way in larger society, he is for a time lost. That hardcover illustration shows two figures surrounded by all that white, but what we don't see is what happens almost immediately after: Wash, alone, in a world of white.Maybe an obvious metaphor, but that doesn't stop it from being true. Wash is a Black boy in a world that sees Black people as lesser beings by their natures. He is hunted by slave catchers, haunted by abandonment, and only gradually determined to make something grander out of his life than mere existence. Most of the resolutions in Washington Black aren't neat. Bad people die, but most of those deaths aren't as satisfying as they should be. Washington's brilliant scientific mind leads him to invent what amounts to a place of captivity for living, free creatures - an irony lost on Black himself, but not author Edugyan. We make the acquaintance of an octopus who is captured to be displayed. For a time, the octopus doesn't seem to know it's in captivity. Its experience mirrors and somewhat parallels Wash's, as it grows sicker in its close quarters, and Wash lets obsession with finding the truth about his past overtake him.So: it's not a steampunk novel, though there is briefly an airship. And it's not an adventure novel, either, despite the fact that we travel to the Arctic, to Canada, to Amsterdam, to London, to Morocco. It's not entirely about white cruelty, but that's a big part of it, especially that cruelty that comes from allyship that comes bundled with barriers. In final measure, it's the story of discovering one's self despite (and because of) the hell of one's past, and how mysteries might be best left unsolved ... and how, when someone tells you they think of you as family, you should ask yourself if that's really a good thing. ...more

title: In a Lonely Place
author: Hughes, Dorothy B.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Occasionally, I'll stumble upon Book Twitter and spiral. I don't know how I arrived at Sarah Weinman's blog post about Dorothy Hughes, hardcore crime Occasionally, I'll stumble upon Book Twitter and spiral. I don't know how I arrived at Sarah Weinman's blog post about Dorothy Hughes, hardcore crime fiction writer from the 1940s, but once I got there, I was hooked. Weinman's post talked up Hughes so effusively - but not in a fannish way - that I started to believe Hughes COULDN'T be as good as all that. Often when we talk about classics, even forgotten classics of misbegotten genres like crime thrillers, we put a healthy spin of borrowed nostalgia on them. This book is good because it's supposed to be good; therefore, if I read it and hate it, it's my fault. But sweet goddamn is In a Lonely Place a good book. After finishing it, I started poking around on the internet for s and background info, and I was astounded that Big Jim Thompson wrote The Killer Inside Me AFTER this. In fact, there's evidence that Hughes, with this book, actually invented the serial killer story - or at least popularized it. All the tropes are there: the wildly shifting internal monologue, the mood swings, the sense of male power and persecution. Travis Bickle in Taxi Driver calls himself "God's lonely man"; a version of that type of madman originated here. One of the most fascinating confluences of my reading is that this book, set in the noir world of Los Angeles after World War 2, dovetails into my deep dive into tiki history and culture. One of the tenets of the tiki thing is the concept of escape into a fantasy world of artifice masquerading as otherness. A lot of men came home from the war to a country fundamentally changed; with newfound prosperity, they were expected to become "the man in the gray flannel suit" - upwardly mobile and slotted easily into the suburban concept of domesticity. Tiki was a release valve for the many men who came back broken or haunted by war and couldn't handle "normal."In A Lonely Place offers a different take on a returning serviceman who can't handle normal. His name is Dix Steele, and the male porn star nomenclature is not accidental. In her keen afterword, Megan Abbott puts forth the idea that instead of a femme fatale, this novel has an homme fatale; Dix Steele kills because it makes him feel as powerful as flying planes in the war did. Also because he's a psychopath. But man, what a fascinating psychopath. His motivations are so random, and his wild stream-of-consciousness thought comes up with impossible situations that Dix immediately conceives solutions for, and then congratulates himself on job well done. The problem is that he's not particularly smart, and not half as clever as he thinks he is. His attempts at misdirection are almost laughable, and while his paranoia is eventually justified, it also comes across as childish. He wants things: money, status, a beautiful girl who loves him. He just doesn't want to put in the work. All he wants to do, really, is kill, and then reap the benefits he believes he deserves.Much has been made about the feminist finale of the book, and while I won't go into details, I will say that it's one of the most satisfying endings of any crime novel I've read. This novel proves that women in noir can be smart, interesting, and sexy without necessarily being also manipulative and evil. If that makes it a feminist book, sure. I'm just happy I have a new author to read. ...more

title: Taft
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was worried as I was going to the earlier books in the Ann Patchett canon, that I would find them less interesting, or less well-written. I, of courI was worried as I was going to the earlier books in the Ann Patchett canon, that I would find them less interesting, or less well-written. I, of course, was wrong. Taft is the story of a man named John Nickel, who runs a bar in Memphis Tennessee. When we first meet him, he is first meeting a girl named Fay, and hiring her to be a waitress. That this is a mistake is some thing that Nickel knows almost immediately, but why it’s a mistake makes for a very interesting story.Here we have another of Ann Patchett’s ad hoc families. Two, in fact. John’s bar family, and his former partner’s family. Marion was never his wife, but she is the mother to his only son, Franklin. Franklin, it seems, is the only person Nickel loves in the whole world.When Fay reveals that she has a brother named Carl, and Carl starts coming around to the bar, Nickel finds himself in the odd position of surrogate father - first to Carl, then to Fay. There are so many complications in this arrangement; not the least of which is that Carl and Fay Taft’s father is dead. In trying to make some sense if his own messy relationship with Marion, and his need to connect more with his son, Nickel weaves a story about Taft, his own surrogate, in the days before Taft’s death. This is a novel about fatherhood, and how being a good father is sometimes knowing when to get help. The front story of Nickel and Marion and Cyndi from the bar is fantastic, but so is the invented story of Taft, and what happens when you ignore the warning signs of some catastrophic event. Pstchett’s love of created families, false histories, and strange parents seems to begin here, though I do have one novel left. Once more! ...more

title: The Book Of Tiki
author: Taschen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Before this whole pandemic, the tiki revival was in full swing. Lots of local tiki bars were open or getting new recognition. New bands were making exBefore this whole pandemic, the tiki revival was in full swing. Lots of local tiki bars were open or getting new recognition. New bands were making exotica and tiki lounge music. Tiki conventions and shirts and mugs were all making comebacks. And most of it can be traced back to this book.Now, it’s absurd to suggest that a single 20-year-old book started a revolution whose entire ethos is built around leisure, escapism, and fun. But I’ve been reading books about the tiki experience for about three years now, and every single book agrees that The Book of Tiki started it all. It’s easy to see why. Sven Kirsten assumes you know very little about the world of tiki culture, and treats this book as a primer. Here’s what you need to know - the basics - to step into this weird, enthralling world. You get the capsule history that begins, roughly, with Donn Beach and ends when fern bars take over from tiki bars. (There’s even a chart that shows the motifs of pre-tiki exotic bars and how they became tiki.) There are chapters on tiki architecture, tiki “power places” (major bars and restaurants), and a special chapter on libations by master mixologist Jeff “Beachbum” Berry. It’s a fantastic place for anyone to start, and if I were alive in the year 2000 and new I was going to develop this fascination, I would have bought it. The problem is that it’s been out of print for over a decade, and it sells on the secondary market for over $100. I bought it for my birthday and I am thrilled, but I’ve already spent so much on rum it’s hard to justify that kind of expense in the interest of study/worship. Don’t worry: I totally justified it.All the books I’ve been reading have paid homage, one way or another, to The Book of Tiki. It justifies the price, and eradicates all worry that it wouldn’t live up to the hype. It so absolutely does. Now if I could only find Tiki Modern, the sequel, for less than $450 I’d be thrilled....more

title: Lonesome Dove
author: McMurtry, Larry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have been meaning to read Lonesome Dove for about twenty years. During my bookstore years, my friend Dave was a nut about Larry McMurtry. This was tI have been meaning to read Lonesome Dove for about twenty years. During my bookstore years, my friend Dave was a nut about Larry McMurtry. This was the same guy who got me into Bruce Springsteen and Daredevil, so I had no reason to doubt his taste. I picked up the novel from a used bookstore and tried to start it time and again, to no avail. Ah well. One less Pulitzer novel I'll try. But a strange thing happened over the years. I became ... if not a McMurtry fan, then surely an admirer. I took The Last Picture Show out of the library one morning before a temp job at which all I was expected to do was sit at the front desk and answer the phone, which never rang. I devoured that novel, and ranged out to find more. Loop Group, for some reason (it was good!) I read his three memoirs: Books, A Literary Life, and Hollywood. And still Lonesome Dove eluded me. If there's one thing this pandemic has taught me, it's that taking chances with literature usually leads to reward. On a whim, I downloaded the audiobook of Lonesome Dove when I was just finishing up another epic James Michener book. I didn't necessarily want to get into another enormous audio, but to my way of thinking: why not?And of course, the book starts slowly. I vaguely recalled that this was a novel about a cattle drive from Texas to somewhere, but I was the equivalent of a hundred pages in and no cattle were being driven anywhere. As the main thrust of the book got underway, though, I was glad for those first hours in relative stasis in the town of Lonesome Dove. I got to know the people, get a feel for how they worked together and lived together. And because it's a Western, we have two mythical figures at the forefront - the stolid, silent captain Woodrow Call, and the laughing, talkative Augustus McRae, former Texas Rangers who helped tame the west. But because it's this Western, the tropes of the mythic Rangers and cowboys come a little down to earth. In another book, McRae might be relegated to a sidekick character. In this, he's the bright and shining center of the novel. He's in love with a Whore With a Heart of Gold, but he's not the one to take her out of town. He's also one of these types that wistfully think of the girl he left behind. But when he catches up to her, there is such an unexpected turn of events that I don't know if anything else could have pleased me more. McMurtry does this throughout the book, challenging expectations and making good on why his challenges were necessary - so necessary that you can't conceive of another outcome. Call is the sort of ur-cowboy: strong, silent, unable to come to terms with his emotions so he comes across as hard. These are the romantic qualities we seek in our Western heroes, but near the end of the book, he's given to wonder if this nature of his might not be for the best. I liked that a lot, the idea that even if people can't change, they can at least be cognizant that not changing has ruined them. I approached Lonesome Dove cautiously and only gradually fell into its rhythms. Then, sometime around the first shocking death, the book caught me and didn't let go. For the first time, I realized that these were people attempting something new and rampantly dangerous, and completely unpredictable. That gave the rest of the novel an edgy, high-wire quality while also staying emotionally resonant. I came to the downbeat end of this novel wishing that it didn't have to end, and glad it was ending so that I could let my emotions recover. I loved this book. ...more

title: Pulp
author: Brubaker, Ed
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’m not particularly a fan of Westerns, but I wandered into the comic book store and saw Ed Brubaker’s name and jumped. The comic store guy who sold iI’m not particularly a fan of Westerns, but I wandered into the comic book store and saw Ed Brubaker’s name and jumped. The comic store guy who sold it to me was thrilled by it, a new self-contained graphic novel by Brubaker and artist Sean Phillips. Who cared if it was a Western? I was in.PULP asks the question: what would happen if Jesse James survived into 1930s America and had to contend with Nazism? Max Winter, once known as the Red River Kid, has long since hung up his gunslinging ways, and now writes vaguely autobiographical pulp stories about his glory days for pulp magazines. But a mugging and a heart attack make him realize that he might have some of that old fight left in him, if only he can summon it.This book revels in twists and reveals, but even the shocking moments follow a logical progression. Winter goes from the pulp fiction of the Western to a sort of crime noir in the space of a lifetime, and it’s satisfying to see a man whose personality was so suited for one line of work can be so easily transferred. Times change, but people? They retain what’s important.The art is stunning. Scenes set in the present day are as flat and 1930s New York City as you’d expect. But the flashbacks and internal fiction are set apart by Phillips’ choice to render everything in outline (aside from the Red River Kid’s signature red shirt), and paint the backgrounds in muted watercolors and gouche, giving the past a mythic feeling that would be impossible to attain in mere words.I picked this book up on a whim and immediately fell in love with it. I think I need to jump into the rest of the Brubaker/Phillips oeuvre. Pulp makes a compelling argument....more

title: Death in Her Hands
author: Moshfegh, Ottessa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Seventy two-year-old Vesta Gul is out walking in her back woods with her dog Charlie when she discovers the note: “Her name was Magda,” the note, heldSeventy two-year-old Vesta Gul is out walking in her back woods with her dog Charlie when she discovers the note: “Her name was Magda,” the note, held down by a series of small rocks, says. “Nobody will ever know who killed her. It wasn’t me. Here is her dead body.”But there's no dead body, and there's no indication anywhere that there has been a murder. But this does not stop Vesta from supposing what might have happened. Indeed, her entire novel is like the comment section coalescing around a rumor: first she makes a blind, grasping guess as to what might have happened, then she decides the guess is real, then she proceeds as if her wild, untethered imaginings are the only real truth. Is Vesta unhinged? Maybe. It's that maybe that keeps this book moving, despite (because of?) Vesta's constant side-tracks and imaginative peregrinations. We don't entirely know if she's an unreliable narrator. It's obvious that her flights of fancy are covering up real pain, shock, and grief. We get glimpses of those wracking emotions from time to time, mostly in conjunction with her deceased husband, Walter. There are indications that he treated her very badly; Vesta tries to shrug off her emotional abuse and gaslighting, but the revelations of her marriage keep unraveling her, long after Walter has been cremated. Maybe this is why she's given to flights of fancy. And those flights might be whimsical, charming even, if not for the fact that they are causing Vesta to pull herself apart. She imagines herself as a sort of Jessica Fletcher of the woods: there's a mystery here, and she's going to solve it. She can't trust the police, because they obviously hate and resent her. If someone is going to find Magda's killer, it will be her. But she does have to interact with other people, and if they don't meld to the random character profiles she's been inventing around Magda's life, she dismisses them, or wraps them into her persecution complex. And along the way, she grows careless.I've read some s that are S H O C K E D by the messy ending. All I can say is that we're dealing with a narrator who is unhinged and somewhat dangerous. The ending fits, even as it's horrifying. And as it comes right after we think we've discovered the ultimate truth of Vesta's state of mind, and right before the end. I liked this book a lot. Moshfegh's characters in Eileen and My Year of Rest and Relaxation are big fans of creating fantasy worlds to help them cope with the world outside. In those other two books, this is mostly a positive thing. Here, it isn't. It really isn't. And yet, that's why Death in Her Hands (a title larded with multiple meanings) is so damn compelling. ...more

title: The Answer Is…: Reflections on My Life
author: Trebek, Alex
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Normally, I don't talk specifically about the audio editions of books I read. Mainly because of the structure of a sentence like that: I didn't READ, Normally, I don't talk specifically about the audio editions of books I read. Mainly because of the structure of a sentence like that: I didn't READ, precisely, I LISTENED. But I'm of the opinion that audio reading is still reading, so long as it's not abridged. And in the case of Alex Trebek's new autobiography, the audio makes a few fairly significant changes that colored and nuanced my love of the book.First off, Alex doesn't read most of the book. Often when I see two readers on the front cover, the non-author has written a foreword and is now going to read it aloud; the author takes on the narrative duties for the rest. In this case, Alex has asked Jeopardy! mega-winner Ken Jennings to narrate his life, with small narrative insertions by Alex throughout the book. This is initially jarring in a couple of ways. Alex has a very recognizable voice, so to hear someone else say things like, "When I started hosting Jeopardy!..." Most people will get over that faster than me. My bigger stumbling block is the fact that I'm a Ken Jennings fan. I've listened to audio recordings of his other books, and I like his reading voice a lot. So going in knowing this author I like is reading in the persona of this media figure I like, and the fact that both of them have recognizable voices ... well, it was a bit of a mindscrambler for me. I got over it.It was sort of easy to get over it, because this is not a demanding book. Each chapter is broken up into little vignettes of Alex's life, with each chapter title taking on the form of a question: "What is Life?," "What Is a Soulmate?," "What is Humility?" It's charming. Anyone expecting an in-depth look at the seedy underbelly of America's Uncle Alex isn't going to get it. But for a nice-guy, late-Boomer white heterosexual Canadian who had to invent a (remarkably charming) vice to fit in with "the guys," it's still pretty compelling. I mean, it's Alex Trebek. You want him to have had a pretty good life. One last thing about the audio: Alex does pop in from time to time. He does the foreword and afterword. He takes over from Ken when the book starts talking ABOUT Ken. And when The Answer Is... gets into more intimate details of Alex's marriage to his soulmate, Trebek takes over with so much feeling that it made my eyes water. Some might dismiss this "greatest hits" version of a biography as slight. I wouldn't agree. For a quiz show host who has spent his life giving us the answers in rapid succession, leaving us to ask the questions, Alex stays true to his character here. What questions we might have when the book is finished all boil down to one: how much longer do we get to have this great man with us?...more

author: Cleeves, Ann*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm finally starting to get a feel for Shetland Island. I read the first book in Ann Cleeves' series a little while ago, and for whatever reason, the I'm finally starting to get a feel for Shetland Island. I read the first book in Ann Cleeves' series a little while ago, and for whatever reason, the characters didn't stick in my head as firmly as I maybe wanted them to. Good characters, great story, but they didn't leave the lasting impression that some characters in mysteries do.White Nights made more of an inroads in my brain. I'm still near-incapable of figuring out whodunit (I had two major guesses and both were wrong), but sometimes with books and series like that, the crime at the center of the thing isn't the most important part. I, for one, am just as immersed in detective Jimmy Perez's love life, and whether or not he and Fran can work things out. And inspector Taylor from Inverness with his need for speed and impatience with Perez's Shetland methods. I'm also pretty entranced by the history of the island; this book delves a little deeper into how the past frequently comes back to rattle the present - a British sort of Harlan Coben vibe. I'm interested in seeing how that comes back in later books. I bought the next two almost immediately after starting this one, because I want to continue to explore this world.Also: there's an arrogant mainlander [red herring] writer who appeared midway through, and I'm a sucker for writers' stories, so I'm hoping there's more of him later. Even though I might hate him. I'm always on the lookout for new mystery/crime series to dig into, and I'm so happy Tracey basically forced me to start Ann Cleeves. Onto the next!...more

title: Beachbum Berry's Potions of the Caribbean: 500 Years of Tropical Drinks and the People Behind Them
author: Berry, Jeff Beachbum*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My tiki history reading continues apace, but maybe not in the way you'd think. I've now read more books by Jeff "Beachbum" Berry than I have by HemingMy tiki history reading continues apace, but maybe not in the way you'd think. I've now read more books by Jeff "Beachbum" Berry than I have by Hemingway this year, which is pretty funny. The first I read, Sippin' Safari, was one of those standard - yet immensely exciting - delves into the tiki culture in America, starting with Donn Beach and through Trader Vic and the Mai-Kai and Kahiki Supper Clubs and so on and on. I picked up Remixed, which is straight-up mixology, a refined combo of his Grog Log and Intoxica! books, and the one I use most weekends in conjunction with his Total Tiki app to make my exotic cocktails.I thought Potions of the Caribbean would be a little more of the same. Another look at tiki history, with drink recipes interspersed. And that's part of it. But most of it is the history of the exotic cocktail itself, and how it's not really a Polynesian thing at all. In fact, I don't know why it took me so long to figure this out, but while the look and feel of tiki bars and restaurants is an intoxicating swirl of idealized South Seas living, the food and especially the drinks come from elsewhere. This is such a simple concept, and I never got it until this book.Vic Bergeron, aka Trader Vic, gets a spotlight here as someone who thought actual Polynesian food was garbage, and instead went for the generically "exotic" of Chinese, Hunan, and Indian foods. The drinks? Almost all of them came from the Caribbean, in the Atlantic. IN THE ATLANTIC! Berry dives deep into what amounts to an alternate - and very much true - history of tiki drinks as they made their marks earlier, somewhere other than the continental US. I was unprepared for - and delighted by - the history of Sloppy Joe's and the other bars in Cuba. How Hemingway and Noël Coward were a big part of what made the Caribbean popular to mainlanders. How piracy, slavery, and imperialism threatened these islands, and how tourism both saved and condemned them. And how very atrociously the Piña Colada nearly ruined everything. This book was a deeper (and sometimes darker) look at the past of exotic cocktails, where they came from and why they survive. We're still in the grips of the tiki revival, and knowing the backgrounds of these amazing drinks feels oddly important. This is a history lesson I didn't know I needed, told entertainingly and intelligently. I want more....more

title: A Farewell to Arms
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My re-evaluation of Hemingway is going pretty well, I think, except I now need to reckon with the fact that the book I just read might actually be bleMy re-evaluation of Hemingway is going pretty well, I think, except I now need to reckon with the fact that the book I just read might actually be bleaker than the reality I'm in. Maybe that's good.This is my third Hemingway, after my disastrous first delve in junior year of high school with The Old Man and the Sea, to my far more interesting journey into The Sun Also Rises earlier this year. I've read none of the very extensive critiques of his work, and I'm interested in getting some insight into these novels I ended up, despite myself, liking very much. A Farewell to Arms is set during World War I, a fact that I apparently forgot about, even though I knew the book was published in the 1920s. ("Why," I asked myself, "would this Frederic Henry guy be an American in the Italian army if Italy was one of the Axis powers?" I'm absurd.) Henry's experiences in the war, especially an all-encompassing love affair with a Scottish nurse named Catherine, are all pretty fraught. Henry gets badly wounded, convalesces, then goes back to the front. He watches Italians kill people on their side either through paranoia or accident. His only salvation is Catherine herself, and there's every indication that he's going to lose her forever midway through the book. It's all pretty damn sad.What's odd to me coming to Hemingway from this late date is that I have an idea of the man built up in my head. My facts are these: he was a larger-than-life figure, had a lot wrapped up in his idea of masculinity, and he was a big game hunter who eventually killed himself. (Also, through the book on Caribbean rum I'm reading now, I discovered he was a pretty intense alcoholic, too.) So here we have this pretty definitive anti-war novel, with our main character a deserter whose entire world becomes about the love he has for a woman. A lot of these actions and opinions seem to run counter to the image I've long had of Hemingway, and I wonder why that is. Was F. Scott Fitzgerald not a swell cynical of his own class? Was Betty Smith in fact like an heiress who wore mink stoles and wrote her books on verandas in France? Everything I thought I knew about classic writers is a lie now.A Farewell to Arms kind of suckerpunched me in the end, even though I had a fairly good idea what was going to happen. I don't know if it's devastating me, because 2020 has already done a fair job of that by itself ... but I think it's going to linger a while, and I think I'm going to read more Hemingway before too long.  ...more

title: The Outfit        (Parker, #3)
author: Stark, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Can the word formulaic be a positive?According to Wikipedia, all the Parker novels by Richard Stark have the same basic structure: each book is divideCan the word formulaic be a positive?According to Wikipedia, all the Parker novels by Richard Stark have the same basic structure: each book is divided into four sections of roughly equal length, each in turn subdivided into shorter chapters. The first and second sections are written in a limited third-person perspective focused entirely on Parker as he plans and undertakes a robbery or heist with colleagues. The second section ends on a cliffhanger, as Parker is betrayed -- often injured and left for dead. Section three shifts to the perspective of Parker's opponents, usually in flashback as they plan and execute their double-cross. Section four returns to Parker's perspective as he survives the plot against him and sets out for revenge.I've only read three of these books so far, and that's been the setup each time ... but, for ruthless crime novels involving lots of dead people, there's something oddly comforting in what Stark does. It's like a Harlan Coben character stumbling upon an aspect of their past that they thought was long buried, or an Ann Patchett character railroaded into initially inhospitable circumstances into a makeshift family she comes to rely on. I like seeing Parker steal things, I like his plans being fucked up, I like discovering his antagonists' motivations, and I like seeing Parker win. He's a sociopath. He doesn't think deep thoughts. He doesn't worry about the toll on his emotional health. He just plans scores and follows through with them, and sometimes he kills people. That's it. One of the ongoing issues I wondered about in the first couple of books is how Parker was ever going to get away from the syndicate that hates him and wants him dead. For me, it seemed like a narrative hamstring that Stark was going to have to resolve someday, maybe off page. Or maybe Stark would keep them around as shadowy heavies. As it turned out, there was another option: make solving the problem of the Syndicate its own novel. And it was great.Look, I'll say this: these Parker books are popcorn. They're not trash, but they're easy and fun to devour and don't take a whole lot of thought. A good antidote to the Michener I finally finished. There's enough of these books that I can use them as bright little desserts whenever I finish something long or dense. I'm looking forward to exploring this important side of noir I'd never even dabbled in before. ...more
