author: Conley, Jen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is what happens when you follow crime writers on Twitter. I’ve been following Lawrence Block for awhile on the site, and through him I found writThis is what happens when you follow crime writers on Twitter. I’ve been following Lawrence Block for awhile on the site, and through him I found writer Thomas Pluck. A few days ago, pPuck hyped up his friend Jen Conley’s YA novel, Seven Ways to Get Rid of Harry. The title was promising, the cover was great, and having suffered a few stepparents in my day, I was ready for a book like this.YA has changed since my heyday. You can say stuff like “shitty” and “dickweed,” and even reference the effword without really saying it. But it’s not just the language; there’s a sophistication in this book that feels beyond the stuff I used to read. (Though I could just be remembering wrong; Judy Blume’s Then Again, Maybe I Won’t had a similar feel, with a lot of the anger and introspection that makes Conley’s Danny Zelko so exciting to read.)Danny’s biggest problem is his mother’s terrible and emotionally abusive boyfriend, Harry. One of my expectations coming into this book was that Harry might not really be that bad, that Danny was just upset about his father’s death and was projecting it on Harry. But no: Harry really is that bad. And Danny makes a plan to get rid of him.The plans are childish and naive - Danny’s only thirteen and still very much a kid - but his turmoil is very real. His anger comes not just from Harry, but from a world that seems weighted against him. When he’s bullied in school, he gets blamed. When Harry makes a racist remark, Danny gets the punishment for it. Worst of all, his mother is turning into an alcoholic and Danny can see no way to stop her.Throughout Danny’s sudden rages and pitiable self-doubt, we never feel alienated from him. We ARE him. Not everyone has been in this situation, but everyone has been thirteen. With no control over the world outside or inside, you can end up feeling lost and alone and hated. Danny’s ultimate solution is a good one - the best one - and one hopes it will sustain him. I just want the kid to be happy....more

title: Alaska
author: Michener, James A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How do I assess a novel like Michener’s Alaska? I’ll tell you, I was pretty surprised I got back into Michener so soon after the 52 hours I spent withHow do I assess a novel like Michener’s Alaska? I’ll tell you, I was pretty surprised I got back into Michener so soon after the 52 hours I spent with Hawaii (and the relatively compact 14 hours with The Novel). Why was I suddenly into these hyper-long books? Did I even like them, or was I just happy to have a long, singleminded narrative to somewhat soothe me during Our Time of COVID?I literally don’t know. Hawaii kind of exhausted me - not emotionally, necessarily; it’s not that kind of novel - but intellectually. I needed a break and I got it. Re-read some old Stephen King friends. Did some tiki books. Closed the gap on my Big Ann Patchett Read. And then I started an audiobook of the third Richard Stark novel, The Outfit, and it was too quick and brutal for me for my state of mind at the time. So I said, OK, Kev. You've been to Alaska. Let's get into this.So I got into it. And, like: it's Michener, so first I had to find out how plate tectonics created the landscape. Then there are native people who walked over a land bridge from Siberia and became the first settlers. On and on, and from small things big things come. A makeshift family on the run become two of the most important players in Alaskan politics. A Black sea captain becomes a hero, mostly. A thousand-year-old mummy woman tells the future, sort of. There's a whole macro chapter on salmon fishery that I thought was going to be super dull but wasn't. Michener has us follow a sockeye salmon from birth to death and names it and everything, and it's not absurd. It's all gripping. For fifty-five hours I was mostly compelled.I'm still not sure why, though. It's a greatest hits of history: the first animals in Alaska, the first people, the first white people; the Yukon gold rush, statehood, climbing Denali. The characters all have pretty interesting internal lives, but they still feel a little stock. And yet I cared about them. I wanted to know whether the young schoolteacher was going to escape her domineering mother. I wanted to root for a good man to stay good, even though he was the head of a kind of evil corporation. I wanted the girl with the pet bear to take over the whole book and become a John Irving novel. I liked it, is the thing. I think I want to read more Michener, is the further thing. My new Ann Patchett obsession I understand. I do not understand my Michener love. Maybe it's the lockdown. Maybe it's the fact that I'm about to be 45 and this is what I do now. Or maybe I don't have to analyze why I like books sometimes. ...more

title: Autobiography of a Face
author: Grealy, Lucy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What is identity? How much of who we are is dependent what we look like? What sort of person can we be when our appearance never stays the same?These What is identity? How much of who we are is dependent what we look like? What sort of person can we be when our appearance never stays the same?These were questions I first wrangled with when reading Ann Patchett's book Truth & Beauty about her best friend Lucy Grealy. My friend Tracey suggested I read Patchett's book before delving into Grealy's own account of her life, as it would make Lucy easier to approach. Patchett's take on Grealy isn't especially sympathetic; sentimental, sure, because these were friends who loved each other. But Patchett's memory of Lucy is often spiky, always unflinching. Lucy Grealy had flaws that would haunt her for the rest of her life, and to what degree that had to do with the state of her face is a matter of perspective.If anything, Grealy's own memories - which intersect only briefly with Patchett's - let us see the constant turmoil behind the self-destruction. And it's dire, sure, but it's also not off-putting, not in the way you'd think it would be. One of the most fascinating things about this book is Lucy's long, arduous decision to not see herself as others see her. For a long while, it's not a conscious decision. Because of the cancer that necessitated removing her jaw, Lucy has to suffer through chemotherapy; during the moments she's not in the hospital, she thinks people only gawk at her because she's bald. That's a malady that makes sense, something she can control easily with a hat. She either refuses to acknowledge or honestly can't acknowledge the face below the bald head.There are all these way stations in Lucy's life that force her to see herself for who she is. Once, trying on a dress in store, she looks at the mirror and really sees herself - asymmetrical, and in her opinion, ugly. A wig that's been gifted to her by a well-meaning friend becomes something of a family joke, right until the moment it isn't. Closer to the end, her face constructed as well as it ever will be, Lucy has to reckon with the idea that her face can't be a crutch anymore; that she, as a whole person, is responsible for being loved and loving in return. That being loved thing is really at the heart of this book. Having the foreknowledge of Ann Patchett's thoughts on this, we know Lucy was probably a sex addict, using it to make herself feel wanted and loved and lusted after. Consistently, she required not only the love of friends and family, but of men who would make her feel desired, if not attractive. Knowing her later issues with drugs puts an early sequence involving pain pills in a starker light; a foreshadowing for a future this book doesn't know about yet. But: BUT. I have to assert that this book feels optimistic. Throughout her surgeries and self-re-assessments, Lucy sees herself as honestly as she can. She doesn't always like herself, but she wants to like herself, and that's the crucial bit that stops this book from feeling like a slog of body horror. Even knowing what happens later, one can't help but come to the end of this book hoping that Lucy will find peace within herself, and within the world. She certainly earned it....more

title: The Big Sleep        (Philip Marlowe, #1)
author: Chandler, Raymond
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have loved crime novels most of my life. I didn't think that was where my interests were necessarily headed when I was young. The only author I readI have loved crime novels most of my life. I didn't think that was where my interests were necessarily headed when I was young. The only author I read with any regularity during my school years was Stephen King, and when I got a little older, it was natural that I would gravitate toward horror more. Some SF, too. I was a speculative fiction fellow. Then my friend Tracey introduced me to Robert B. Parker and it was all over. From Parker, I spun out in all directions of crime writing. Harlan Coben, Dennis Lehane, Donald E. Westlake. More recently, Jacqueline Winspear and Ann Cleves. And especially Lawrence Block, whose Scudder and Keller novels are among the best things I've read in crime fiction, and that's not even touching his Bernie Rhodenbarr comic capers and his one-off novels like Dead Girl Blues and Defender of the Innocent. Eventually it became clear that I needed to dig into the past. I read some Jim Thompson. I read James M. Cain's The Postman Always Rings Twice and Mildred Pierce and The Cocktail Waitress. The Hard Case Crime imprint has been especially helpful in getting me into classic crime novels (and new ones in the classic style) that I might not otherwise have uncovered. But there were still some major gaps in my crime-fiction history, and none so vast as the lacuna composed of the absence of Raymond Chandler, and his creation, Philip Marlowe.I bought The Big Sleep at The Last Bookstore when I was in Los Angeles last year. I try to purchase books about the place I'm in when I'm in a new place, and having recently seen Chinatown for the first time, I was ripe for some 1930s detective noir. But at first, I didn't think I was going to have any luck. The Big Sleep is a short book - little more than a novella - but initially I found the words impenetrable. I wondered if it was that the language read so oddly that it was hard to take seriously. Cliches and pastiches all have a locus, and this was ground zero for crime fiction. What felt like the timeworn fictional tics, like over-the-top slang and moody violence out of almost nowhere, were fresh and new when The Big Sleep was published. Somewhere the book turned a corner for me, and this is kind of a personal thing. As a gay reader navigating the world of largely straight (and white, and cis, and male) fiction, I've learned to look nuggets of gay acceptance and progressivism. Before gay characters and writers were more open about, we queer readers had to scavenge, and feast on scraps. It's no coincidence that Stephen King started becoming my favorite writer when I read his depiction of gay guys in It; what some took for homophobia, I took for a pretty thoughtful look at a gay couple in the 1980s. The good guys are horrified at one of the gay men's murder, the local gay bar is discussed respectfully, and the couple themselves have some real moments of tenderness. Well, in The Big Sleep, a bisexual guy is murdered, and his boyfriend kills the guy he thinks is responsible. Marlowe throws around words like "fag" and "queen," but I saw those as descriptors rather than derogatory remarks. He goes out of his way to protect the boyfriend from harm or capture, knowing he was devastated by the death of his "friend." I don't know why, but that sort of made me see Marlowe in a new light.Of course I hate the smoking - it's the thing I cringed the most from, and the reason it's hard for me to watch noir film. But the book ended up really working for me. The language became its own rhythm, and eventually I just stopped worrying about who was doublecrossing whom, and the motives as to why people got killed. It all gripped me, just the same. The end is pretty genius, and those last paragraphs I read as if they were a monologue in my ears, over a long shot of cars racing down a wet street in Hollywood in 1935. Now it's time for some more Marlowe. And Dashiell Hammett. Oh, those gaps. ...more

title: Bookworm: A Memoir of Childhood Reading
author: Mangan, Lucy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The cover got me. This isn't the first time this happened this year. I had no idea who Lucy Mangan was (further research after the fact has determinedThe cover got me. This isn't the first time this happened this year. I had no idea who Lucy Mangan was (further research after the fact has determined she's a writer and journalist and that she wrote a book on the writing of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, which I must now read). I didn't even know she was British. But after the somewhat harrowing, somewhat melancholy experience of Washington Black (not to mention my ongoing re-read of The Stand), I wanted some comfort. The subtitle - A Memoir of Childhood Reading - promised a literary grilled cheese and tomato soup ... and boy, did it deliver.Mangan makes it clear very early on that, while she's going to give some publication and background history of the books she's discussion, the memoir part was going to be first and foremost. This stuff is candy to me. There's always that paradoxical truth of stories, real and fiction, that the more personal and idiosyncratic they are, the more universal they are. Therefore, I had no worries that this British writer would discuss only European children's books and would thus leave me lost in a sea of references I didn't understand. The books might be different. The experiences aren't.Understanding that is crucial, because sitting here, basking in the afterglow of this wonderful book, most of my memories are of how the stories affected Mangan, rather than what the stories were about ... or even, in a lot of cases, what the stories were. She makes the act of devouring books as a child feel both like the most thrilling adventure and the laziest indulgence, and that's because both things are true. It doesn't matter that she was reading Little Women at 11 and I was obsessed with Judith St. George and Daniel Cohen's books about ghosts - the feelings of discovery, of immersion, of escape were all the same. (I felt the same way about Gabrielle Moss' Paperback Crush from last year. In fact, both books have lengthy sections on the whole horse book genre which entirely passed me by, but which are immensely pleasurable to read about from an outsiders' point of view.)Of course, there are going to be some obvious touchstones, direct memories that most people who were bookworms as kids remember: Eric Carle's The Very Hungry Caterpillar, the collective works of Roald Dahl and Judy Blume, the book Dicey's Song, which was the last and most grown-up book I had to read in 7th grade English in order to win my class an ice cream party. See the thing was that when you finished the book, you had to write a little book  on it to prove you read it before you could get a reward and I just figured out why I interact with GoodReads this way. I was a little disappointed that Mangan's section on the school book genre didn't touch on Bruno and Boots, a Canadian boys' school series that taught me the different spelling of pyjamas, and that no one seems to remember William Sleator as well as I do, but there's a LOT here to love. Mangan has convinced me to re-read the entire Narnia series, which ... I don't think I finished as a child. And it's been long enough; time to delve back into Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. I got the new annotated edition and those always make me feel smart. I love this book because it reminded me that being bookish in school did not make me the social outcast my mother's friends seemed to think it would (my personality did that well enough), and that I was not alone in my deep love and continued reverence for the books that guided me through childhood, and that are still around, just waiting to be loved again. ...more

title: The Art of Tiki
author: Kirsten, Sven
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My fascination with tiki culture this year has led to so many estuaries of interest. Mostly what I've focused on is the history of the Polynesian Pop My fascination with tiki culture this year has led to so many estuaries of interest. Mostly what I've focused on is the history of the Polynesian Pop movement - pre-tiki and tiki-era bars, restaurants, and architecture from the 1930s through the 1970s. This book, by tiki revivalist Sven Kirsten and tiki expert Otto Von Stroheim, brought me deeper into the world of art, primitive, fine, lowbrow, and everything in between.The whole concept of tiki didn't become an American thing until the 1950s, when American versions of Polynesian carvings started making their way into beachcomber/trader bars and the concepts merged together. One element I always find funny is that "Tiki" is basically the embodiment of the "first man" - essentially the tiki version of the Biblical Adam. I wonder what it would be like to go to Tahiti or Bora Bora and see them drinking out of wacky versions of Adam and Eve. That's a tangent.What I didn't know about this book before going in was how rigidly the authors would stick to the idea of "tiki" - meaning carved statuary, mugs, poles, and the like. The other ephemera I associate with the movement - lighted floats, bamboo, puffer fish, palm trees - only matter inasmuch as they support the literal art of tiki. I learned a lot more about the history of this specific art form than I had in any of the books about supper clubs and beachbum bars. I also learned about some of the subcategories of tiki/pre-tiki from mid-century, which ... I mean, we're already skating on the thin ice of cultural appropriation with tiki itself, but some of the more salacious stuff in the tiki subcultures are pretty horrific. Cannibals and "African savages" had to have been suspect even back in the day, right? By the end of the book, Kirsten touches on the tiki revival, which started in the late 90s as a strange and fascinating outgrowth of punk purveyors shifting their sensibilities to "lounge" culture. Artists like Shag came up in this revival and are still active today. One thing I particularly found interesting is something that happens with a lot of "low" culture that sticks around long enough to become respectable: the lowbrow and tiki art movements tried so hard to be recognized as the fine art that it is, it could no longer be considered for the lowbrow art galleries in which it made its name. I love all eras of the tiki movement: pre-tiki, tiki, and tiki revival. As I read this book, however, it became clearer and clearer to me that my love of tiki, somewhat ironically, is only secondarily related to the tiki itself. I'm so fond of the architecture of a-frames and wooden bridges over indoor rivers, the glowing floats and the bamboo. I love the tikis themselves, but they're not necessarily my primary focus. I will say, however, that I find them most pleasing in the revival movement, which probably says more about my love of lowbrow art than anything else.All in all, I appreciate the culture and the history of tiki, more now than when I started. More and more, I'm growing to respect and stand in awe of this strange American underground movement and culture that I wasn't even aware of, really, until a few years ago. More tiki please!...more

title: State of Wonder
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: And the numbers dwindle downward.One of my great joys of this pandemic - and there have been some - has been my full immersion in the work of Ann PatcAnd the numbers dwindle downward.One of my great joys of this pandemic - and there have been some - has been my full immersion in the work of Ann Patchett. Within the craft of her words, quirky situations don’t feel “quirky,” and her characters don’t feel like pieces moving around on a chessboard of plot and situation. These lives feel lived-in, sometimes haunted, often trapped. And the books feel like markers of real life, normal life. A life before a virus fundamentally changed how we live. No matter how tragic her characters’ circumstances, they are out in the air, breathing and living and suffering in a life before covid. State of Wonder takes Patchett’s basic plot structure - a group of people trapped in a situation, and a complicated woman (alive or dead) as the fulcrum on which the novel turns - and explodes it. Marina Singh is a pharmacologist who used to be a medical doctor. The circumstances that changed her course of study and career are tragic indeed, and we get the feeling that her whole life is being lived in penance for a single moment of error. When her coworker and friend dies deep in the Amazon trying to ascertain how far along a Dr. Annick Swenson is in developing a fertility drug, Marina almost jumps at the chance to go find him. This might also be penance. But maybe not. Dr. Swenson was once Marina's mentor, whether Swenson knows it or not, and the overarching grief of Marina's life is tied inextricably to the guilt and shame of letting Swenson down. The idea that her read on Swenson might be false never enters Marina's head; Swenson is, after all, the central mother figure in her life, one she cannot bear to disappoint.It is this dynamic that State of Wonder hinges on: mothers and children, and the puzzling, contradictory relationship between the two. The fact that the drug Swenson is developing comes in the midst of a secretive tribe who never stop birthing babies only lays the groundwork. Swenson herself is the symbolic mother of three children who abandon her in different ways, while Marina, who never considered pregnancy, now becomes a surrogate to a child who may not have come to Swenson's base camp honestly. This child's name is Easter, and we are more than happy to indulge Patchett her symbolic names here, especially because while birth is common, rebirth is still rare. State of Wonder isn't necessarily a story of resurrection, but we find it here anyway. My friend Jeff recently said that Ann Patchett is easy to read, and that's true, but it's not because these novels are simple things. It's that they are crafted so well, with an eye toward complicated people and situations told in accessible ways. I have only two Patchett novels left before I've read through her entire fictional (and most of her nonfictional) canon, and when I dive into those, I know I'll be looking for a good story, well told, just like all the rest. I loved this book. ...more

title: The Novel
author: Michener, James A.

review: Apparently I’m a Michener fan now. Who would’ve thought?Here’s the thing: I probably won’t read every Michener novel. I picked Hawai’i because I love Apparently I’m a Michener fan now. Who would’ve thought?Here’s the thing: I probably won’t read every Michener novel. I picked Hawai’i because I love Hawai’i, and I was fascinated at the idea of a book starting millennia ago and bringing it up to the present. Or the present as it was when the book was written, in the 1950s.Of course this one caught me because it was about books, and I’m a sucker for books about books. And I was intrigued at the conceit: tracking the course of a novel through four different points of view: the writer, the editor, the critic, and the reader. I’d assumed some sort of Roshomon deal, where we’d see a novel being written and read, all sort of concurrently.That’s not how it went. And that was good.The first big surprise is that it was set in Pennsylvania Dutch country, amongst the Amish and the Mennonites. The second is that Lucas Yoder, the author, also writes novels set in this region, and that after four misses, Yoder had become a runaway bestseller. God I love books like this!The first conceit is that the new book is too staid for his readers, but Michener doesn’t like staying on one conceit. We then get to the editor’s story, which is really the editor’s backstory, and I LOVED her backstory. Then of course the critic’s tale, which is a gay love story set in the 80s, and you know what that means. By the time we get to the reader’s story, there are some new young writers and a murder and character named Applebutter and it all hangs together. Mostly. I’m still not sure exactly how Yoder’s new novel ultimately fared.But maybe that’s not the point. The characters and how they find each other, and what community they make - that’s the point. And the idea that when writers are writing, it’s not only what they do but who they are. I was thrilled to find a novelist like Michener talking about books and writing and reading. I want all my favorite writers to do a book like this. ...more

title: This is the Story of a Happy Marriage
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Midway through Ann Patchett’s book of essays, a common theme began to emerge: most of these short glimpses into Patchett’s life is how hard love is, aMidway through Ann Patchett’s book of essays, a common theme began to emerge: most of these short glimpses into Patchett’s life is how hard love is, and how rewarding.Some of these essays are about a love of writing, tinctured with anecdotes about how difficult writing can be. She doesn’t believe in writer’s block and she hates the notion that “characters start to behave on their own.” (I disagree on both counts, but she’s had a number one novel and one of my short story collections did reasonably well by the standards of a niche publisher, so.)Love of reading is also in here, sometimes a vehement, fiery love of reading, as when she’s defending her last nonfiction book, Truth and Beauty, against bizarre charges of pornography and lasciviousness. One of my favorite aspects of this book is how one essay will be about writing something, and the next will be that something. It’s like she’s her own opening act. Other types of love proliferate: love of her family, of her dog, of her (eventual) husband, of her favorite teacher. In each essay, Patchett talks about the bitter, turbulent road toward that love, how it can wound and bite and tear and still be absolutely wonderful, absolutely necessary. “Every relationship ends,” Patchett’s mother proclaims in the title essay, and Patchett proves it over and over.If I didn’t like this one as much as Truth and Beauty, it may simply be its fragmentary nature. Also, it might be my own selfish desire to want only a collection of essays about Patchett’s own writing. I am a sucker for stories about writers and writing, and maybe I wanted a memoir of the internal life of an author. I’m not mad at this book for giving me something different from exactly what I wanted, because that’s insane and also this book is very good. But let’s do some fiction next....more

review: There are relatively few Stephen King books I've only read once. Some of the newer ones - The Institute, The Outsider, Sleeping Beauties - and of courThere are relatively few Stephen King books I've only read once. Some of the newer ones - The Institute, The Outsider, Sleeping Beauties - and of course Black House, which didn't entirely work for me but which I want to give another chance. But 11/22/63 has been one of my favorites since I first read it nine years ago, and I tend to read my favorites over and over again.Well, the course of my busy life has long taken me down the path of audiobooks. Head to work: audiobook. The gym: audiobook. Repetitive tasks at work, doing the dishes, making dinner - they're all chances for me to read by ear. And if there isn't an audiobook, or if I don't like the reader, I haven't made a whole lot of time to sit and read the physical book.But right now is the perfect time to sit and read. If one good thing has come out of the pandemic/lockdown, it's that I've found plenty of time to curl up with a good book. And after finishing my latest Ann Patchett novel, it was time to duck back into the King well. I had tried the audio of 11/22/63 a few times before, but the reader's take on several characters grated on me. You don't get that with physical books. It was, um, time. You know what's funny? When this book came out, there was a collective sigh by the literati. "Finally," a lot of the ers seemed to be saying. "Stephen King wrote the book we always knew he had in him. A political thriller with a supernatural twist and a tragic love story at its center. A few gory sequences but no outright horror. We're so glad Stephen King finally did something of this caliber." As if he hadn't published The Dead Zone in 1979.What's interesting is that I read The Dead Zone earlier this year and the comparisons are somewhat superficial. Yes, they're both political and yes there is an extremely well-formed love story in both (those who used to say King couldn't write believable female characters over eight or under sixty conveniently passed by Sarah Bracknell), but there things diverge. Jake Epping, our time-traveling everyman, knows his goal at the start. Not to stop a presumptive president but to stop an assassin trying to kill a past president. But along the way, he finds himself living in the past, and falling in love there. On my first read, nine years ago, I found the ostensible A story a little draggy; I knew Epping's main objective was spying on Lee Harvey Oswald and stopping him from killing JFK. But it got in the way of his life in Jodie, TX, where he meets a woman he loves, makes some friends, and has a major impact on the lives of the students he teaches. That was the story that sang. This time around, I was a lot more invested in the Oswald plot, because I knew how both stories converged together. I didn't have to race to find out what happened, so I could savor the language, the tone, the feel of everything. King gets batted around for not knowing how to write endings a lot ... and I agree, sometimes, that the whole "everything blows up" can get a little familiar. Even in my favorite novel of all time, It, the ending is a little extra. But he has some amazing finales in his canon: The Dead Zone, The Dark Half, Bag of Bones, Finders Keepers, Misery, and more. But rarely is an ending so poetic as 11/22/63's, when the novel's underlying theme - dancing is life - comes to the fore, one last time. I love this book. ...more

title: The Magician's Assistant
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ann Patchett is a relentless novelist, and one whose stories never seem to go in the way you’d expect. The eponymous Magician’s Assistant is a woman nAnn Patchett is a relentless novelist, and one whose stories never seem to go in the way you’d expect. The eponymous Magician’s Assistant is a woman named Sabine who was married to a gay man whose longtime companion died of AIDS. That’s a lot of information up front, so here’s more: the magician in question dies on page one, but not in the way you’d expect. Misdirection. Illusion. Tricks.When I got into the book, I settled in expecting the story of a tragic life lived in the shadows of a famous person who’d died. It was a Los Angeles story, and I’m a sucker for stories set in Los Angeles, especially if at any point, someone drives into the Hollywood Hills at night and looks down on the lights of LA. That’s it’s own magic.But the book isn’t about living in the shadow of tragedy. It’s about second acts. By the time Sabine met Parsifal, the man she loved who loved men, he was already on his second act. His past was a misdirection entire; his best trick as a magician was in conjuring himself whole as Sabine knew him. But everyone has a past, and no matter how much patter you throw at your audience, sometimes the brilliant disguise of your former self falls away. Truth is the opposite of illusion, but this book dares to look at the truth inside the illusion. It’s a hell of a magic trick. Every time I thought I had a character’s motivations pegged, my expectations were upended. By the end, you start looking for the tricks, the illusions, and are sometimes confronted by the idea that some things are exactly as they present themselves. And truth becomes the misdirection. Everyone finds a way to surprise you, and none more so than the woman at the center of the story, who - for the first time - learns how to perform her own magic. This book was quietly and effortlessly thrilling. One night I stayed up until 3AM because I needed to know what happened next. I loved this book....more

title: Kahiki Supper Club: A Polynesian Paradise in Columbus
author: Meyers, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I remain fascinated by these stories of fantastical tiki palaces. It’s funny; I didn’t become a tiki adherent until about a year ago. I’d been to backI remain fascinated by these stories of fantastical tiki palaces. It’s funny; I didn’t become a tiki adherent until about a year ago. I’d been to backyard luaus. I’d been to both Trader Sam’s on Disney property. But the whole tiki “thing” didn’t hit until last year when my buddy Jeff and I started visiting famous tiki bars in far-off California cities like San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Palm Springs. I could feel the interest growing before then, though. On a trip to visit my friend Josh in Los Angeles, I found myself in a bookstore at The Grove, and there I bought a book on California Tiki. Slender, factual book. But it gave me the tools I needed to go further and deeper, if I wanted to. It didn’t hurt that I’d recently come back from my honeymoon in Hawai’i, where the libations were strong and the moon over the South Pacific was high. I brought these experiences with me, and in 2020, I decided to go full bore.That book on California tiki had a sequel: a book, fascinatingly, on Ohio tiki. Ohio? What the? And yet I read it, and from that I began to sense the scope of how all-encompassing the tiki trend really was in America at the mid-century. Ohio wasn’t a place like California, with it’s Don the Beachcombers and Trader Vic’s. It wasn’t like Florida, with its warm climate to attract visitors to the Mai-Kai. But Ohio has something no other place had: the Kahiki Supper Club.Can I just say how tickled the term “supper club” makes me. It seems so square, but it’s also kind of pleasant and homey. And it fits the Kahiki, which I’d read a little about in that Ohio tiki book ... but I had no idea how deeply attached people were to this place. Man, how I would have liked to have visited in the 1960s.We get the whole story here: a repeat of tiki’s American origins, how the Kahiki was proposed and built, who made the pottery and who served the food. All to the good. However, some chapters deal with some controversial elements in the restaurant’s history that felt out of place; racial tensions and terrible crimes that seem ... not sensationalized, but maybe too “real” in this book that wants to show you escapism and how it was attained.You know, maybe I wouldn’t have gotten this into Polynesian pop if not for this quarantine thing we’re all going through. It’s given me a unique perspective on the concept of escape to a faraway place that’s only real in the imagination. That’s what a place like the Kahiki Supper Club does - offers an ersatz escape from the Midwestern humdrum that nevertheless feels real and vital and important. I never saw the Kahiki when it was around. I wish I had. But at least now, I have a deeper understanding why it succeeded for a little while, and why some people wish they could journey back to it even now....more

title: Run
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Slowly, I am coming to understand why I love Ann Patchett's work so much. For me, she's a John Irving. I didn't know I needed more than one, but now ISlowly, I am coming to understand why I love Ann Patchett's work so much. For me, she's a John Irving. I didn't know I needed more than one, but now I have her. It's not that she apes Irving's style or plot structures necessarily, but that her books move with the same fluid cadence of Irving's complicated family tales. When I was reading Commonwealth, I couldn't help but be reminded of The Hotel New Hampshire. And for anyone needing the kind of jolt you got from A Prayer for Owen Meany, may I direct you to Patchett's marvelous Run.I always think I'm going to sip Patchett's pages slowly; by the time I realize I've been gulping, it's two AM and I'm nearly finished with the book. That's the first definition of the title word, and not the most important. The story - concerning a small Boston family over the course of two days - is propulsive. Even in its moments of respite, the words race on their own momentum, and all the reader can do is keep up. Like most great novels, it's not the plot but the people who keep things moving. And the people of Run are fascinating. I can only tell you so much without spoiling the whole book, and I desperately do not want to spoil this for anyone reading it the first time. Here are some facts: Bernard and Bernadette Doyle are white, wealthy-ish people with a young biological son named Sullivan and two adopted sons, Tip and Teddy. There's also a religious statue, passed down from generation to generation, that bears a striking resemblance to Bernadette, who dies before the book starts. (Eventually the statue business reminded me of the mannequin form in Owen Meany, but most of the parallels of the book aren't that specific.) There's also an accident, one that jumpstarts the fascinating course of events over the following two nights.But I won't tell you what the accident is, who it involves, or what happens next. What I will say is that Run is a family novel, about people we lose and gain and how they are tied to the trajectories of our lives. The things you run toward, run away from, run for. In its own way, it's a mirror image to Commonwealth which explores why families bust apart. Run is why they don't. It's as brilliantly written, but it's a lot warmer, a lot more inviting. I could have read a book double the length about these people and never gotten bored. I loved this book. ...more

title: Dead Girl Blues
author: Block, Lawrence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How does someone live with guilt? And how does someone who's supposed to live with guilt live without it?These are the central questions of Dead Girl How does someone live with guilt? And how does someone who's supposed to live with guilt live without it?These are the central questions of Dead Girl Blues, the unexpected short new novel from Lawrence Block. The lead-up to the publication of this book has revolved around a warning, which may or may act as a fractured come-on: there's a scene of such queasy, unrelenting violence right up there at the start that regular readers of Block, especially those who know him primarily from his Bernie Rhodenbarr books, may find wholly unpleasant. For those of us willing to stick it out past this extraordinarily dark scene (hint: there's a murder, and that's far, far from the worst part) are rewarded with a contemplative novel about the nature of guilt. It's also, I suppose, about the nature of people: do they change? Can they change? More pointedly, is a sociopath always a sociopath, or can they reform?It's interesting, that word reform. Because the man who committed that especially heinous act does a lot of reforming over the course of this long, ruminating confessional. Starting out as a lonesome, aimless drifter, the crime he commits gives him a sudden sense of purpose. Immediately, he needs to hide out inside a life where no one can find him. Discovering that he likes that life is unexpected - and unexpectedly rewarding - and while he doesn't seem to make a conscious effort to change, slowly he becomes the person he pretends to be. So we come to the heart of this book, and the questions it doesn't answer. What makes a man a sociopath? A single, brutal act? Fantasies about that act, casting different people in violent sexual scenarios? Play-acting with your wife, during which you get to recreate some echo of the crime you committed, and got away with? I don't know. I don't think Block knows. That's to this novel's credit. Asking the questions is the important part. Well, no: the important part is how absorbing this book is, how deftly written, how bizarrely exciting. I don't know what I was expecting when I first heard about that hardcore early scene. Was the whole book going to be like this? When the novel turned out to be a weirdly quiet, weirdly gentle story of a man who may have gotten away with worse than murder, and how he lives with it ... well, it surprised me. I didn't know how compelling such a contemplation would be, and how tense and thrilling. Block lampshades a Chekov's gun midway through the novel, and one of the cleverest things about Dead Girl Blues is that it doesn't matter whether it goes off. It's that throttling sense of not knowing that makes this bizarre book so fantastic. Come for the violence. Stay for the if....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked up the book Tales of the South Pacific while I was in Hawaii, and for a long while I didn't read it at all. I started with the introduction bI picked up the book Tales of the South Pacific while I was in Hawaii, and for a long while I didn't read it at all. I started with the introduction by Steve Berry, and he talked about reading the book Hawaii for the first time, and why it made him a Michener fan. As I started getting into that book, I was finding it dragging just a little. Then I cast my mind back to the intro and I was like, "That book sounds more interesting. Maybe I'll try that!"So on a warm day in early May, I launched into the longest book I'd ever attempted that didn't have the name Stephen King on the front. The jacket copy promised that the book would tell the lightly fictionalized history of Hawaii ... and history is right. The audacious first chapter is all about how the islands formed geologically, then biologically. Some millions of years later, chapter two focuses on the first settlers of Hawaii, those seeking religious freedom from Bora Bora. And it's all fascinating. At the beginning of almost every chapter, I would think, "I will never be able to remember this name," and then it appears so often and you get wrapped up in all these stories that they become eventual friends and enemies. A book that includes such people as Jerusha Hale, Char Nyuk Tsin, Kamejiro Sakagawa, Keoki Kanakoa, Malama, and Wild Whip Hoxworth seems like you'd get easily lost in the names; instead, you find yourself lost in the people.In Michener's book, no one is all good or all bad (except for Abner Hale, who might be mostly bad). Not the missionaries who come to the island and assert their ways of life in the islands, against the will of many native Hawaiians. Not the gambler who is charged with taking a kidnapped woman to the islands to work in a brothel. Not the labor leader whose heritage is Japanese but whose nationality is American, who fought as an American in World War II. There are shades of gray everywhere, and because Michener is such a gifted storyteller, I was drawn into all of those shades. But it's not just people.And if you think Hawaii is only about mapping the course of family histories from the 1700s through the mid-20th century ... okay, well that's most of it. But it's also freakin exciting! This book has explosions! Human sacrifice! A leper colony! Fireworks! Sex work! Tsunamis! It's amazing! I had no idea when I started this year of reading that my two big discoveries were going to be Ann Patchett and James A. Michener. But that's the best thing about reading. Constant discovery, constant enjoyment. ...more

title: Truth & Beauty
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In the midst of my Ann Patchett jag, my friend Tracey (who, in a roundabout way, introduced me to Patchett) recommended this book. It's nonfiction, anIn the midst of my Ann Patchett jag, my friend Tracey (who, in a roundabout way, introduced me to Patchett) recommended this book. It's nonfiction, and while it's about Patchett's life, the main character is her best friend Lucy Grealy, the writer of Autobiography of a Face. Lucy had beaten childhood cancer, but had been left with a somewhat misshapen jaw and teeth. This aspect of Lucy had, somewhat counterintuitively, made her very popular in high school. Ann, an invisible student, has only one encounter with her before they become roommates in college, and it's an inauspicious one: Lucy has no idea who she is.For the remainder of the book, that moment seems to hang over this friendship, through the highest highs and lowest lows (which are, ironically, sometimes the same). Both friends become writers, and while Ann's books are published, they are not immediately popular. Lucy, on the other hand, writes her biography, and is thrust hardcore into the limelight. Again, Lucy is tremendously popular. Her book affects millions. Ann quietly writes more books, and supports her friend, who needs it.It's not mere attention that Lucy craves. It's love, and for a good portion of this book and her life, she struggles with the concept. Early on, she constantly wonders when she'll have sex again, lamenting that it might not happen. But it's not really sex that she needs to survive, it's romantic love, which keeps eluding her. She can have all the sex she wants, and be on television, and be adored by a reading public ... but none of it is enough. "Do you love me?" she asks Ann, so frequently it can be seen as pathological. She needs to be reassured, because as the outside of her, especially the topography of her phase, changes so often; she needs to know that the inside is stable. This addiction to love and to being loved eventually (inevitably?) leads to other addictions. One wonders if she undergoes elective surgeries so that doctors, who she reveres, will pay attention to her. She drinks and eventually takes drugs. There's a moment in which Ann gazes on a gigantic bottle of Oxycontin in Lucy's apartment, terrified of its presence. We're terrified, too. Lucy's neediness can sometimes make her unlikable, which is fine. One of the worst things you can do in both fiction and nonfiction is to turn those you love into saints. Lucy is human, and flawed, and broken in ways that have nothing to do with her face. Sometimes you can't save a person like that, and maybe that's the terrible truth of the title. The terrible lie is beauty. I listened to the audiobook of this, which was read by Ann Patchett herself. It's kind of a devastating listen, even more so than Commonwealth, which I finished right before this. Tracey suggested I tackle this and Lucy's book, Autobiography of a Face, back to back. I think I need a buffer. There's a lot of pain at the heart of Truth and Beauty, and a lot of love, too. Maybe not enough love, because, in the end, is there ever enough?...more

author: DiCamillo, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, so I read this book in two hours flat, because I picked it up to read a few chapters and I couldn't stop. Of course, everyone who has read this Okay, so I read this book in two hours flat, because I picked it up to read a few chapters and I couldn't stop. Of course, everyone who has read this already knows this about the book. I'm catching up, slowly.One of the things I've been trying to do with my reading life is catch up on the stuff I was supposed to read in school, but either the school failed me or I failed myself. Since I was young, I was into discovering a writer I liked and then devouring everything about that writer. I did it with Dr. Seuss, then Roald Dahl, then Judy Blume, then Stephen King. That was my childhood to adolescence. I've continued with Robert B. Parker and Lawrence Block and Harlan Coben. I'm doing it now with Ann Patchett and Susan Orlean. So these amazing young adult books I'm discovering years after I probably should have, books like Hatchet and Because of Winn-Dixie, are stunning me with their depth of character and feeling. I would have LOVED these books when I was younger. It's a good thing they still work.Because of Winn-Dixie is a deceptively simple story about a new girl in a quiet Florida town. Her name is India Opal, but her father, a preacher, just calls her Opal. Opal is lonely because she has no friends and because her mother ran off long before Opal really got to know her. The book is about how Opal befriends a stray dog she names Winn-Dixie, and how she goes about gathering all the other strays in town, and finding her place among them. It's a gentle story about found family, and about how sorrow and sweetness are intertwined. It's about finding friends, and about realizing that good people aren't always good, and bad people aren't always bad. And it has one of my favorite storytelling tropes: a young person reading novels to an old person. I can't get enough of that.Apparently the author, Kate DiCamillo, has other books. Now I have to read those, too. Just because I'm catching up on the classics doesn't mean I'm not still me. ...more

title: Commonwealth
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think it's safe to say that, barring some major writing catastrophe, Ann Patchett is now one of my favorite writers of all time. And what catastrophI think it's safe to say that, barring some major writing catastrophe, Ann Patchett is now one of my favorite writers of all time. And what catastrophe could be as bogged down as The Tommyknockers or as stultifying as A Son of the Circus, two books by my two favorite writers that were kind of sloggy? Because of the age and time and place in which I first discovered and fell in love with Stephen King, it's unlikely that anyone will ever top that kind of first experience with an author. But John Irving came close, when I read Cider House Rules, The World According to Garp, The Hotel New Hampshire, and A Prayer for Owen Meany in rapid succession, absolutely blown away by how magnificent each one was.That's the feeling I'm having now. Will The Dutch House ever be topped for me? Probably not, but Bel Canto and now Commonwealth are these rare, beautiful books I know I will want to get lost inside again, to revisit all the characters, knowing ahead of time what future tragedies are coming, and how they find redemption in the end.I've read a few differing opinions on Commonwealth. A friend on Twitter said it was the definition of a perfect book. My friend Tracey disagreed, loving the writing but finding all the characters too unpleasant to root for, or live with. I'm leaning more toward perfect, though I see Tracey's point. A lot of these people - and there are a lot of these people - are selfish, and angry, and listless ... sometimes. See, I think the main takeaway from Commonwealth is that everyone deserves a new chance at life. Maybe more than one new chance. Now, what they do what that chance is up to them, and some may choose to squander it. Our ostensible main character, Frannie - it's her christening at the start of the book, and it's her we close on when we finish - spends so much of the novel aimless that you almost want to shake her and tell her to stand up for herself, to make something of herself. But for a long time, she's stuck inside herself, at first because she isn't cut out for the life she's been steered toward and later, more disastrously, because she falls in love with an author who listens to her childhood stories and weaves them into a bestselling novel. You don't get to be yourself when your only job is being someone else's muse.One of the fascinating things about this book is how easily and frequently Patchett slides back and forth through time. In one scene, our characters are children, and in the next scene, that's a memory of the adult versions of them. Some readers have complained that the structure is too chaotic, and it is ... but that's part of the appeal. Keeping up with every member of this family - even the ones who don't seem all that important - is a joy on every page, even if they disappoint, especially when they don't. And maybe for large swaths of this book, there were characters I didn't like. Patchett would introduce them through the lens of other people, so we only saw their terrible aspects. Then we met them, and found ourselves in their heads and looking at the world through their eyes. I ended up liking almost every one of our main characters, and if I didn't like them, I got to understand them. I think that's what you want most from fiction: to achieve a level of understanding. It's the writing, the language, the style and tone, the crackling mood of it all: this is a writer working at the peak of her craft. I can't wait to see what's next....more

title: If It Bleeds
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I want to talk about Holly Gibney first, this private detective who started off as a side character in Mr. Mercedes and grew throughout the whole BillI want to talk about Holly Gibney first, this private detective who started off as a side character in Mr. Mercedes and grew throughout the whole Bill Hodges trilogy. She showed up again in The Outsider, again as a side character, this time to Ralph Anderson’s skeptical police officer. In the title story of this four-novella collection (itself part of a once-a-decade tradition starting with 1982’s Different Seasons and continuing through 1990’s Four Past Midnight and 2010’s Full Dark, No Stars), Holly is for the first time our main character, and by now attuned to the habits and tics of supernatural creatures. When she believes she sees one on the news following a devastating terrorist attack on a school, she reluctantly – but thoroughly – jumps into action. This time, she’s ready to believe.	When the third book of the Bill Hodges trilogy – End of Watch – skewed supernatural, it initially felt like King falling back on familiar ground because he didn’t trust himself to play it straight. Mr. Mercedes had been a very good procedural novel, a new sort of endeavor for him, and its sequel, Finders Keepers, became one of King’s best books of the 2010s. Developing antagonist Brady Hartfield’s psychic “push” powers a la Firestarter’s Andy McGee seemed unnecessary at best, and undercutting at worst. Why did this supernatural/psi power concept have to intrude on a fun new style of writing? 	By now, though, even if it wasn’t King’s original objective, the slow shift from private-eye procedural to supernatural tale now seems intentional. Ditto the character development of Holly Gibney, who goes from barely functional in Mr. Mercedes to a strong, charismatic character at the center of “If It Bleeds.” We needed those books to witness Holly coming into herself, and she needed those books to at first believe, then to trust her own instincts when it comes to the supernatural. So what we’re witnessing here is the birth of a hybrid sort of story for King – the supernatural procedural with a recurring character. It’s as if Robert B. Parker’s Spenser became a vampire slayer, or Lawrence Block’s Scudder discovered literal demons living in New York City. “If It Bleeds” couldn’t have existed without the slow burn of the preceding four books. As a bonus, we get what amounts to an origin story for Holly herself: a look at her past, and why she was the way she was at the start of Mr. Mercedes, and how she’s grown in the time since. The longest novella in here (King actually referred to it as a short novel in a promo clip for the book), it might be the book’s strongest.	But that’s not to say there isn’t a lot to love about the other tales here. “Mr. Harrigan’s Phone” takes the creepy classic story trope of being buried alive and turns it on its head. King relates the probable origins of this story to the eerie concept of a phone ringing in a place of the dead. That’s the part that gives this novella its scare factor, and it’s good at the scare factor. What gives it its resonance is the relationship between young Craig and the eponymous Mr. Harrigan, an old, rich man who pays Craig to read to him and do light chores around the house. We’re immediately reminded of Bobby Garfield and Ted Brautigan in Hearts in Atlantis (and to a lesser degree, Jerome Wireman and Elizabeth Eastlake in Duma Key), and while Craig and Harrigan’s friendship doesn’t necessarily go as deep, it’s strong enough to withstand death. Craig is an extremely likable kid and a good character on which to hang a novella; you identify with him at once, which is important when makes a few decisions that are a little bit horrifying. What slowly comes clear in all four of these stories is that regular people, when faced with the inexplicable, have choices to make. And they have to live with those choices, for good or for ill. 	“The Life of Chuck” tells its tale backwards, in an almost picaresque fashion. At the start, we’re thrust into the middle of our world falling apart, bit by bit. The internet only works occasionally. California is sliding into the ocean like the mystics and statistics said it would. No explanation is given for the destruction, but we keep seeing signs lauding a man named Chuck Krantz for “thirty-nine great years.” In part two, we actually see Chuck, and watch him dance. One of King’s underrated gifts is his capacity to bring us into a character’s transcendent moment of joy. Witness Rosie McLendon’s first moment in her new apartment in Rose Madder or Devin Jones’s first time “wearing the fur” in Joyland. Watching Chuck Krantz start dancing on the street in Boston is like that, and he brings two other characters into his joy as well. We get hints as to how this straight-laced accountant-type fellow learned how to dance, but we only delve deep when we get to the final story. “Act I: I Contain Multitudes” explains both of the other stories without diminishing the impact of either – the calm terror of Act III, the excitement and happiness of Act II – while giving us another look at a good kid who contends with the supernatural and still has to go on living. 	These first three stories are fantastic modern King, working with more recent tropes and character types and experimenting with new storytelling styles. “Rat,” our closing tale, is straight-up classic King – a story about how writers write, and what they’re willing to give up to do it. In that manner, “Rat” belongs in the same canon as Misery, The Dark Half, “Secret Window, Secret Garden,” Lisey’s Story and more. It’s also kind of a fable, the sort of tale where someone gets their greatest wish granted, but doesn’t consider the ramifications. Plus, we’ve got a real awesome groaner as the last line, which I wouldn’t dream of spoiling here. It’s phenomenal. 	In full measure, If It Bleeds is a worthy addition to King’s Novella Books series. I think there’s something for every King fan here: the gentle horror of “Mr. Harrigan’s Phone,” the experimental but involving “Life of Chuck,” the writer-at-the-hands-of-his-creation “Rat.” There’s a faction of fans who don’t like Holly Gibney, but I hope that this newest iteration will win them over. It’s the best take on Holly yet, and hopefully a harbinger of more stories to come. ...more

title: Tiki Road Trip: A Guide to Tiki Culture in North America
author: Teitelbaum, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, so I may have read this book wrong.It’s called Tiki Road Trip, right? So I decided to read it straight through, thinking it might be like a narrOkay, so I may have read this book wrong.It’s called Tiki Road Trip, right? So I decided to read it straight through, thinking it might be like a narrative of a proposed road trip to tiki venues across the USA. When I realized it wouldn’t be that, I just kept reading. So: maybe I read it wrong.You know, something similar happened to me when I read that Ohio Tiki book: at some point, I the book became what amounted to a list of all the open and closed tiki bars Ohio has it had to offer. Tiki Road Trip did that in the macro. Author James Teitelbaum takes us first on an alphabetical state-by-state look at the best (and worst) open tiki bars, and then, against a gray sidebar backdrop, all the ones that have gone away. The problem with reading a book this way is that it becomes, eventually, an exercise in repetition. What tiki bars make great Zombies and have a fantastic TiPSY (Tikis Per Square Yard) factor. Which so-called tiki bars are really just Chinese restaurants, sports bars, or strip clubs with an exotic name and cool sign. And which long-lost, lovingly-described bar I desperately want to visit was burned down in 1971. That last made some of these chapters a little sad.Plus, and this is not the book’s fault, but it was published in 2007. The tiki revival was just getting started then. This is before Smuggler’s Cove and Latitude 29. Heck, this is before Shore Leave in my hometown. Many of these bars are likely closed, and many new ones have opened up. Then again, Teitelbaum LOVES what he’s talking about here. His passion for this amazingly odd moment of our past is clear on every page. He champions the revival bars that “get it,” decries tiki fakery, and really wants others to grok his obsession and join in. So maybe I read it wrong, but it was written right. ...more

title: The Dead Zone
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I remember where I was when I first started The Dead Zone. And where I was when I finished it, too. When I was a teenager, on Saturdays I'd take the cI remember where I was when I first started The Dead Zone. And where I was when I finished it, too. When I was a teenager, on Saturdays I'd take the crosstown bus from Braintree to Quincy Center. This was in 1990, when bookstores still existed and even independent ones could do fairly well. Infinity Books was my bookstore, the one that boosted my early Stephen King collection (and obsession) and which was part of my Saturday ritual. I'd buy a King paperback I didn't own yet, then head to the movie theater and buy a ticket for whatever looked good. This particular Saturday - was it during the school year? It had to have been - I remember buying my movie ticket for a film not showing for an hour or so. I grabbed something small to eat somewhere and parked myself on a set of stairs under the movie theater and I launched into this novel, this wonderful, quiet novel. I blasted through it, because while most Stephen King books are compulsively readable, this one feels even more so. It flows so easily, and every new plot point and character moment seems vital, seems thrilling, even if it's reluctant psychic Johnny Smith just talking with his Dad in their living room. Right now, the tactics Greg Stillson uses to become a politician - jokey, clowny stuff that many people simply laugh off until he actually becomes a member of the House - feels so resonant to the political climate today. It was a little hard to read, to get into the mind of Stillson, knowing there's a maniac pretending to be president right now. But the grim fascination was there, too. King's bad guys usually have charisma, and Stillson is no exception. All in all, though, I'm glad for the actions Johnny takes, and how satisfying it is when he blunders so spectacularly. I can only imagine what would happen if the exact same scenario happened today. Or maybe I don't want to imagine.How I first finished The Dead Zone, and why I know it was a school night: I was up late, reading. My Mom came into my room and told me it was time to go to sleep. I think she thought I had the TV on. And I told her, "I only have two chapters to go! I really want to finish this book!"I remembered the bewildered look that came on her face, how odd it was for me to be so captivated by a novel that I couldn't put it down. I don't think she'd encountered that type of request before. Reading was about to be the dominant force of entertainment in my life, and I think that night was the start of it. I just polished off The Dead Zone in three days - my seventh time reading it - and I love it just as much as I did that first time, on that long-ago day, when I was fifteen. ...more

title: Dreyer's English: An Utterly Correct Guide to Clarity and Style
author: Dreyer, Benjamin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Every once in a little while, a book on grammar, writing style, spelling, and the whole English language charms and delights me to no end. It happenedEvery once in a little while, a book on grammar, writing style, spelling, and the whole English language charms and delights me to no end. It happened with Stamper's Word by Word awhile back, and of course with Stephen King's On Writing. I'm happy to report that I have added Dreyer's English exuberantly to the list.You wouldn't necessarily think so. Dreyer, as the cover of the book spells out, is the Copy Chief of Random House. He lays his book out in a few sections: proper punctuation, proper use of numbers in prose, proper grammar in fiction writing, and misspelled or misapplied words in a variety of categories. That's it. This thing could have been a fusty, dry, lugubrious piece of work and still managed to get to all the cogent points. Instead it was thoroughly engaging - accessible to the usage-curious, but robust enough to hook in writers like me who think they know everything. (We don't.)When I got to the lists of misspelled words midway through the book, I thought, Well, I'll just breeze past this. Let my eyes glaze over a little. I know all this. Nope. Specifically calling out one of my personal trip-ups (Alanis Morissette) and confirming something I'd long suspected but could never prove (things jibe together, they don't jive together. I thought I was going nuts.), Dreyer kept my interest; more, he ramped up my interest, making this smallish grammar book a full-on page-turner. Of course I'm writing this  on the lookout for grammar and punctuation mishaps. I nearly put an en dash for the semicolon in the previous paragraph, but GoodReads doesn't do en dashes. I'm taking my chances here. But that's all right. I just want everyone who loves the English language and how Americans use it to read this book ... even if Dreyer's dismissal of the delightful interrobang is unforgivable. ...more

title: Duma Key
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve read Duma Key three times now, and I always forget how potent it is, how unusual and exciting. It’s King’s first Florida novel, and I think the cI’ve read Duma Key three times now, and I always forget how potent it is, how unusual and exciting. It’s King’s first Florida novel, and I think the change in location got him revved up for something deep and involved and scary and resonant. The second time I read this, I was in a low place. It was the recession of 2009, and I’d been laid off. I took my severance money and went to Disney World, trying to cheer myself up. I brought along this book to read in queues. I have a very vivid memory of waiting in the atrociously dull line for Soarin’, sitting down on the ground and trying to get lost in this book.It wasn’t working. Being in my favorite place and reading a book by my favorite writer didn’t make me not depressed. It helped, but I was alone and sad and angry. My predicament somewhat mirrored the plot of the book, where the protagonist Edgar Freemantle heads to Florida to put together the pieces of his shattered life. Painting brings him joy, then sorrow. I somehow skipped over the joy.And so what did I do? While the country is going through lockdown and there’s a lot of fear and uncertainty and I’ve been dealing with my anxiety by doubling my daily dose of Zoloft, I started Duma Key again. Isn’t the definition of insanity doing the same thing over and over, expecting different results?Well call me insane, then. This time, it worked. I loved Edgar’s relationship with his wife, his reaction to his emerging talent, his friendship with Jerome Wireman, his complicated relationship with his daughters. Edgar is a complete person leading an incomplete life, and when the supernatural comes in, it feels like an outgrowth of that life. Everything works.I listened to the audio version this time, read by the fantastic John Slattery. His voice made it easy to escape into other worlds and lives while I worked out or did the dishes, while I brushed my teeth or showered. Losing myself in a good book is fairly easy for me; giving myself over can be difficult. Not this time. I love this book....more

title: Holes        (Holes, #1)
author: Sachar, Louis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn’t read Holes all in one sitting, but pretty close.My friend Tracey has been trying to get me to read this book since last year. I was going thrI didn’t read Holes all in one sitting, but pretty close.My friend Tracey has been trying to get me to read this book since last year. I was going through a good reading patch so I bought it based simply on her recommendation. Then my good reading patch got waylaid by life, and I lost the book.When I was cleaning out my home office to reclaim it in this time of COVID, I found Holes again and set about reading it. What struck me at first was how adult it was, and how intense. Are middle-grade books like this now? Within the first few pages, a boy of 16 or so has to choose between going to jail or going to a sort of labor camp. Stanley Yelnats chooses the camp, because he doesn’t know what awaits him.What awaits him is basically torture. The camp leaders make him and all the other incarcerated boys dig holes - five foot wide by five foot deep. Every day. In the hot sun. With little food and not much water. It reminded me of the Sunlight Gardner Home in The Talisman.The holes seem purposeless until we get some of the far-flung backstory. These moments take on the tone of legends - ancient seers and hapless young men who break promises they were meant to keep, and send a curse of bad luck reverberating throughout future generations. Stanley, of course, is the cursed great-great grandson of the original Stanley Yelnats. Will he break the curse? Will he find out what’s at the heart of it? And how are the little tin gods in charge of the camp so cavalierly evil? All these questions are answered, mostly. This book was so compelling, I literally couldn’t put it down. Basically I read it one day. It’s 2:30 AM here and I needed to finish. There’s apparently a sequel and I’m going to have to read it. I just shouldn’t start it late in the day....more
