title: Tiki Pop: America Imagines Its Own Polynesian Paradise
author: Kirsten, Sven A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My fathoms-deep dive into into the world of tiki and Polynesian pop was always going to lead me to Sven Kirsten. His The Book of Tiki (impossible to fMy fathoms-deep dive into into the world of tiki and Polynesian pop was always going to lead me to Sven Kirsten. His The Book of Tiki (impossible to find for under $65 now) is credited as an origin text for the tiki revival. Someday I will own it. Until then, there’s Tiki Pop.This book was written (or republished?) in conjunction with an exhibition on Poly pop for the Musée du Quai Branley in Paris, and it’s trilingual - English, German, and French. This edition seems to be still in print, and hallelujah. If you’re an English reader, you’ll thank the pages with the other translations, simply because there’s more room for pictures and illustrations and artifacts. Tiki Pop is packed with full-color photos of the entire tiki movement from its earliest beginnings through to the current revival.And that’s interesting. Most books I’ve read on tiki start at Donn Beach and go from there. Some discuss pre-tiki, but not deeply. Tiki Pop delves a little deeper into the actual indigenous South Seas origins of the movement, and then - and this is crucial because I had never really understood the whole picture before - the Poly pop trend BEFORE tiki was even a thing. Before there were tiki bars, there were Hurricane bars and bamboo bars, all building the groundwork for what would come next. Each point in the evolution of tiki and Poly pop connects seamlessly with the next. And Kirsten gets out of the bars and restaurants, too, taking a look at the culture as a whole, from tiki apartments to bowling alleys to amusement parks and more. He also discusses the demise of the movement in the 80s and 90s, a painful time other authors had merely alluded to. Warning: the pictures in this chapter are rough.But we come back around to the revival, and that’s where we’re at now. There are so many more books I want to read on tiki, but already I can tell that this overview is going to be one of the most comprehensive. Long live tiki!...more

title: Norwood
author: Portis, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You know, I'm not quite sure what to make of Norwood, either the book or the main character. I liked it - and I liked him - and I laughed out loud a fYou know, I'm not quite sure what to make of Norwood, either the book or the main character. I liked it - and I liked him - and I laughed out loud a few times while reading it. Maybe that's the point. Maybe the point is that there is no point.After reading such a magically cohesive and brilliant book as True Grit earlier this year, I was interested in what else Charles Portis had to offer. Norwood seemed to be the one folks were gravitating toward most, so I selected this from Audible and launched in.I think Portis' best trick in the book is to present a whole wealth of unlikable characters and then make you like them. Norwood, who isn't entirely bright and who isn't entirely kind, but is at least a little of both, gets hoodwinked in the first few pages by the Kredit King, who basically tricks Norwood into running stolen cars for him. Norwood doesn't know they're stolen until midway through his trip. What he does with them, and the woman who's along for the ride, sets this whole story in motion.Well; stories. Except for The Sisters Brothers, I have never read a book that cold be described as accurately as picaresque. Characters and the bare bones of Norwood's journey carry through from chapter to chapter, but each chapter also feels like an entire situation with a beginning, a middle, and an end. It's like binge-watching a dark-humor sitcom. And so much of it is patently absurd, from the girl Norwood picks up on a bus to the little person he meets in a rooming house to the "college-educated" chicken named Joanne he liberates from her life of servitude. None of these characters and situations should go together. The fact that they all seem perfectly normal in the course of the book is Portis' genius.I think I'm going to be thinking about this book for awhile. True Grit was brilliant, but its brilliance was accessible. Norwood might also be brilliant, but its charms are a little less on the surface. I wonder what's next for me and Portis....more

title: A Trawl Among The Shelves: Lawrence Block Bibliography, 1958-2020
author: Zobeck, Terry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was first getting into Stephen King, one of the main accelerants of my interest was a book called The Shape Under the Sheet: The Stephen King EWhen I was first getting into Stephen King, one of the main accelerants of my interest was a book called The Shape Under the Sheet: The Stephen King Encyclopedia. That’s exactly what it was, too: a full-on encyclopedia, listing all the books, all the characters and places and things, and going for a semi-deep dive into first editions and such. At the time, I thought all authors had a similar concordance. It didn’t have to be as detailed as this, but something, anything, that allowed my fandom to grow and blossom.The problem is that most of my favorite writers - William Goldman, John Irving - aren’t nearly prolific enough to support a book-length examination of the facts and figures of their publication history.But Lawrence Block is. Oh my, is he.Block’s brand-new afterword is titled “The Man Who Wrote Too Much,” and it’s cheeky but it verges in truth. What Terry Zobeck has done here is nothing short it extraordinary for Block fans: uncovered and listed - with occasional insightful commentary - literally everything Lawrence Block has written.The Scudder novels, of course. The Rhodenbarrs and the Kellers. And, sure, the Ehringraf short stories and the Tanner series and the Kit Tolliver stuff. But while you might have heard Block started his career writing soft-core porn, you probably don’t know just how gosh-darn MUCH of it there was. For awhile, Block was cranking out (heh) a novel a month. And then there was the letters column originally titled “Group Grope.” All this, from saintly writing teacher and novelist Larry Block! You may be appalled! But will more likely be impressed.This book isn’t narrative in the strictest sense. The chapter introductions are insightful and fun, but most of the book really is “just” a bibliography. But I read this thing like it was a page-turning thriller, excited to find out where some of my favorite Block books and stories got their start, and what juicy gems Zobeck had uncovered from Block’s fecund early career. I’ve long wanted a book like this, and Zobeck delivers on almost every conceivable level. I’m so glad this book exists....more

title: Ohio Tiki: Polynesian Idols, Coconut Trees and Tropical Cocktails
author: Chenault, Jeff
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I'd gone through the most obvious books on tiki culture - Berry's Sippin' Safari, Cate's Smuggler's Cove - and finding it financially inadvisableWhen I'd gone through the most obvious books on tiki culture - Berry's Sippin' Safari, Cate's Smuggler's Cove - and finding it financially inadvisable to seek out Sven Kirstin's Book of Tiki (for now), I searched afield. I'd read tales of Southern California tiki culture, where it all started. Hawai'i, where it came (back, sort of) to. Florida, which was tropical. And then this book, which struck me as completely incongruous to everything I knew: Ohio? A tiki Mecca? What this book proves first and foremost is how pervasive the tiki and Polynesian pop movement was in mid-century America. Evolving alongside mid-century modern's elegant lines and Googie stars was this whole aesthetic of escape and exoticism. And it struck me: of COURSE Ohio. You're in the middle of America, your greatest body of water is Lake Erie, why NOT have the sort of escape afforded to ocean coasters?What surprised me is that one of the nation's biggest and best Polynesian hotspots was located in Columbus, Ohio - the Kahiki Supper Club. (I don't know why, but the term "supper club" makes me giddy.) It had a fountain called George. It had a Mystery Girl and a Mystery Drink, like the Mai-Kai in Ft. Lauderdale. And at least two generations of fans grew up with this place, which was razed to make a Walgreen's in 2000. Author Jeff Chenault is very good at making you understand his love for the place, and for the robust history of tiki in Ohio. It's very difficult to convey emotions surrounding a place most of us have never been, but Chenault does a very good job of making us see the place - and all the tiki haunts and history in Ohio. I had worried that a listing of all the exotic restaurants and bars Ohio had to offer would be dull (a few years ago, I read a book on the history of LEGO that decided in its second half to meticulously discuss every single playset the company had ever put out. It was mind-numbing.) On the contrary, these pocket histories - hinting occasionally at not only the past exotic but also at the involvement of the criminal underworld of the 30s and 40s - were each fascinating in their own way.Not many drink or food recipes as in most books on tiki, but that's all right - it's not what this book is for. It's sort of easy to imagine the early days of the tiki movement in warm places that have their own exoticism to them. Hollywood. Ft. Lauderdale. Waikiki. Sure, of course. But to really understand the extent of tiki's mass appeal, get yourself to Cleveland, Columbus, Euclid. There's a whole world of tiki out there....more

title: Are Snakes Necessary?
author: Palma, Brian De
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** There's a twist in the middle of Are Snakes Necessary? that I was so unprepared for and so shocked by, this book immediately shot to**spoiler alert** There's a twist in the middle of Are Snakes Necessary? that I was so unprepared for and so shocked by, this book immediately shot to the top of my favorites list. The only problem is that it didn't really change anything in terms of plot or character. Everyone involved in the twist ends up either dead or deluded, so it's almost as if it exists outside the rest of the book. And it's not like the book isn't good. It's really good. Are De Palma and Lehman swapping off chapters? There are these subtle tonal and authorial shifts that seem to me to be the work of two authors' styles occasionally jarring when usually they gel - but even the jarring is fun. This book is mostly fun. I mean, it's tragic and sad and a little tiny bit hopeless, but De Palma finds a way to work Hitchcock in, so it's fun. You can imagine his cross-cutting and dual-screening in the double denouement. I read this book exceedingly swiftly, and the short chapters were like M&Ms: I gobbled one, and then thought another couldn't hurt. Before too long, I'd eaten half the bag and wondered where the time had gone.The cleverness. The way the big cast of characters weave in and out of each others' lives. The unputdownable speed at which the story progresses. All this is to the good. To the almost-great. But that big twist (tell me it wasn't obvious. Don't tell me everyone else saw it coming and I was too blinded by the excellent writing to see it.) had boatloads of potential and to see it sort of squandered like it was ... I couldn't help but knock it down a star or two. But if either writer has a new book in the future, you can bet I'll be picking it up.There's a twist in the middle of Are Snakes Necessary that I was so unprepared for and so shocked by, this book immediately shot to the top of my favorites list. title: Bel Canto
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is Bel Canto one of the best books I've ever read? Quite possibly. Last year, Patchett's The Dutch House immediately became one of my favorite books. Is Bel Canto one of the best books I've ever read? Quite possibly. Last year, Patchett's The Dutch House immediately became one of my favorite books. Do that once and it's a wonderful fluke. Do it twice and it's a pattern. I am now a major Ann Patchett fan.It's so hard to know how to describe this book. It begins with a botched terrorist takeover of a birthday party held in vice president's home of a host country that remains unnamed. Somewhere, it seems, in South America. The birthday party is for Mr. Hosokowa, opera fan, and the guest of honor is Roxane Coss, beloved opera singer. The other guests are luminaries from a clutch of nations: Russia, Spain, France, America, Japan, more, and s the situation settles and this disparate group of people remain together for longer and longer, an unexpected camaraderie develops. Not just amongst the hostages against their captors, but often between hostage and captor. To say this feels trite. You could say Stockholm Syndrome, and I'm not entirely sure you're wrong. But the care and love that develops out of this bizarre and unexpected situation feels so natural, so right, that it resists simple analysis. At the center of this whole story is Gen Watanabe, the translator who works for Mr. Hosokowa, and his elevation from side character to the beating emotional center of the book. For the time spent in the vice-president's mansion, life becomes something of a dream. Sometimes a bad one. More often not. Every character changes, and almost every one for the better. They discover new compassion, new talents, sometimes so unexpectedly that it takes us a moment to catch our breath before we accept it. But we do accept it.Which is out mistake, even though we cannot help it. We're told at the very start of the book how, in general, it's going to end. But near the end of the book, Patchett discusses the type of forgetting those in extreme circumstances sometimes retreat into. One character forces themselves to forget the person they're in love with is a terrorist. Multiple characters forget that the people they're thinking of as schoolchildren are their captors. Music, which is at the center of this book, does not stop this situation; it only changes it. We forget all of this because we fall in love with everyone in this book. And that's why it's a tragedy. Because we know what's going to happen and we care anyway. And that's also why it's a brilliant novel. One of the best I've ever read. ...more

title: Mai-Kai: History and Mystery of the Iconic Tiki Restaurant
author: Glazner, Tim*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm getting more and more specific in my tiki obsession. Smuggler's Cove gave a pretty comprehensive overview of the big names and deep history of theI'm getting more and more specific in my tiki obsession. Smuggler's Cove gave a pretty comprehensive overview of the big names and deep history of the movement. Sippin' Safari got a little more granular, giving stories of the lives of the bartenders and the folks behind the scenes that made classic tiki so inviting. Glazner's Mai-Kai gets even more specific, honing on the history of one tiki restaurant: the Mai-Kai in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, a continent away from the South California epicenter of the original trend. The way Mai-Kai, the book, works is only vaguely linear. Glazner says at the start that he wants to focus on stories, vignettes of the early days of the restaurant. This leads to a little discombobulation and, at least in one case, of a contradictory fact (exactly WHO was fired for lying about her age? There are a couple answers.) But in measure, none of that matters. Histories of tiki are rife with tall tales, exaggerations, and myths. It doesn't all have to be 100% truthful to be compelling.And this book is extremely compelling. Glazner's way of discussing the Mai-Kai's owners and operators pulls no punches; it's obvious that he reveres them, but does not shy away from their thornier sides, either. There's a lot in the way of famous people who'd eaten here, particularly Johnny Carson and Ed McMahon. I was particularly gratified to read some stories about the women behind the enchantment: Pua, who, in her research of the ancient and almost forgotten Hawaiian art of kapa, brought the fabric art almost singlehandedly back to prominence. Ann Campbell, who was the first woman to explore the underwater Sacred Well in Chichen Itza. Marielle Palmer, who was almost fired for not being able to dance, eventually became lifetime choreographer at the Mai-Kai. These are the stories I love in tiki history, and couldn't get enough of.Unlike those other two books, this one is short on cocktail recipes. That doesn't really matter, either. One of tiki's main components is its exotic cocktails - and there are chapters on the Mystery Drink and the Mystery Girl who proffers it - but that's not the end-all, be-all. I came to this book hoping for an even grander concept of the history of tiki, and I got it. And now I can't wait to go to Fort Lauderdale, after this whole quarantine is finally over....more

title: The Sun Also Rises
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Man, was I not into Hemingway.Here's why: when I was 15, a teacher of mine proselytized on why Hemingway was The Best Writer. She went on and on aboutMan, was I not into Hemingway.Here's why: when I was 15, a teacher of mine proselytized on why Hemingway was The Best Writer. She went on and on about it. Compact sentences. Gruff exterior, soft interior. A man's man and a writer's writer. She then got us to read The Old Man and the Sea, which I detested. I summed it up in my school journal as "it's a guy who's like 'I'm gonna go fishing' and then he loses the fish and then there's stuff about baseball." HATED it.And for nearly thirty years, I held onto that hate, thinking that if this was all Hemingway was about, I wasn't missing much. But of course two factors colored this grudge: 1. the time of my life during which I read The Old Man and the Sea, a time when I was into reading Stephen King and nothing else, and 2. I had very little experience. In reading, in the world around me. One of the reasons I glommed onto King is because I understood his New England milieu, and the people who lived there. That's not an excuse for being less open-minded about a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel most people love; that's just me saying that I was fifteen, and maybe I didn't get it in the way I should have gotten it. (Or hell, I might still find it terrible.)I was in a bookstore at Christmas and I randomly picked up The Sun Also Rises, wondering if I should give this Hemingway fellow another chance. The first paragraphs hooked me, and I put it on my to-read list. A week or so ago, I downloaded the audio read by mumbling drudge William Hurt, cranked the speed up to 1 1/4 so that Hurt sounded normal, and got into it.At several points, I thought, Wait. Have I read this? The answer is no. The answer is that I've read The Great Gatsby, and I'm a little surprised as to how close in tone and circumstance these two books are. Both books involve Jazz Age Americans, and both involve a woman so desirable that every man wants her and most are driven to ruin because they can't have her. But Brett, the woman here, isn't Daisy Buchanan, isn't really willfully using anyone. She, like all the men obsessed with her, is just bored and frustrated and unfulfilled and doesn't really know why. It's a travel novel. A hangout novel. In short, Jacob - our main character, also very much in love with Brett - loves Paris but agrees to go to Spain with Brett and his ostensible best friend Robert Cohen. A bunch of other guys tag along. There are bull fights and restaurants and cafes and one particularly, uh, gory scene. Everyone's drunk and in vague lust and no one's all that happy. Then why did I love it?I think these books set in the 20s are just on the edge of my understanding. Like, I can read something like Little Women or Moby-Dick and get involved with the characters and plots, but they're always a little removed from my personal experience. But the 20s, just before Steinbeck, are a little less elusive. I know people who lived in the 1920s. And these ex-pats trying to escape themselves in Paris and Spain and each other seem almost real to me, almost vibrant and knowable. I understand their frustration, because it's a frustration that never goes away. I could write a book about it now. Hell, I have. I think I was sold a lemon on Hemingway's reputation. This book is about men, sure, but not about Men. Not about Men who aren't in touch with their feelings, or who hate or use women, or who beat their chest all day to appear more masculine. The guys in this book pine but don't force. Loving women doesn't make them weak; loving this woman might, but that's Brett's doing, not Women's doing. Dudes cry. They don't know how to say good-bye to each other in a way that shows they care for one another ... even though it's obvious they want to. It's men (and women) drowning in their fiestas, wanting to stay above water but not knowing that it's up to themselves to do it.I like it. I liked it a lot and I want to read more now. Maybe, as I have grey in my beard and I'm looking 45 in the eye, the time has come for me to be into Ernest Hemingway....more

title: The Boy from the Woods        (Wilde, #1)
author: Coben, Harlan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If there's one thing this quarantine is good for, it's getting me through books fast as hell. Here's the thing: I love reading. But I read damn slowlyIf there's one thing this quarantine is good for, it's getting me through books fast as hell. Here's the thing: I love reading. But I read damn slowly. I always have. With the possible exception of Stephen King novels - those generally seem to go quickly for me - books move more slowly when I'm reading them than when I'm writing them. I get so jealous of those people who can pick up a paperback in an airport store and finish it by the time they get off their six-hour flight. So finishing a book in three days might not sound fast, but trust me, it is.Part of that is circumstance: I'm indoors all the time, without outside distraction. So I'm reading way more. But part of that is simply Harlan Coben. Man, this book is good.I've been reading Coben since 1997. I saw his name on a Yoo-Hoo fan site (his recurring character, Myron Bolitar, is a Yoo-Hoo fanatic) and I picked up one of his books. Sports mystery! Why would I care about a sports mystery? But of course I loved it, and for a tiny while, Coben and I actually talked on AIM, before the internet got way bigger and Coben got justifiably famous. I love the Bolitar series so much - it's one of my favorite book series - so it took me awhile to get into the rhythm of his standalone titles. The plots follow mostly the same pattern: flawed people are confronted with the worst part of their past and it fucks up their now. Nothing really different about The Boy From the Woods ... except it does feel different, somehow. Fresher. Brighter. We get re-involved with perennial side character Hester Crimstein, who has this whole backstory I'm sure I was once aware of. There's stuff about Wilde, the titular boy from the woods, whose entrance and exposition are short enough that I'm positive he was in another Coben book, too, but I'm not sure of which one. It doesn't really matter. The characters all come to life in this book, immediately demanding your attention and sympathy and interest. Are the bad guys quickly drawn? A little. Is the quadruple-twist at the end maybe one twist too many? Hard to say. But Coben's like King - the good guys are always more interesting, no matter how much we say we love to read about bad guys. And hell, if I'm grinning THIS much at that final twist, something worked. Did I mention the plot? No? It's great, it's fun, and it gets the job done. You come to Coben for the characters, and that's what I got. I loved reading this. Fast....more

title: Beachbum Berry's Sippin' Safari:  10th Anniversary Expanded Edition
author: Berry, Jeff Beachbum*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, so I don't know what's happening to me. Is this a mid-life crisis, this whole tiki thing? Maybe. I picked up that California Tiki book last yearOkay, so I don't know what's happening to me. Is this a mid-life crisis, this whole tiki thing? Maybe. I picked up that California Tiki book last year without any idea of the effect it would have on me. Then my buddy Jeff and I started going to tiki bars, and Palm Springs came into my life, and we went to Smuggler's Cove and THEN I read the book by the owner of Smuggler's Cove. Guys, it's been a whirlwind.If California Tiki was a broad overview of the tiki movement in the 1950s and 60s and Smuggler's Cove gave a more specific look at the big names who pioneered the trend, Sippin' Safari goes a little deeper into the people who kept it going. Unsung Filipino bartenders and restauranteurs who mixed the drinks in the back rooms finally get their due here, with deep histories before, during, and after the tiki craze. At first, I wondered if these guys would have as fascinating a history as Donn Beach and Trader Vic Bergeron; boy, did I underestimate these lives. And as Berry's roughly chronological guide follows the biographies of these amazing folks, it also charts the course of the entire tiki "thing" as it moved from Hollywood back to Hawaii. Discovering that Hawaii wasn't "tropical" enough for tiki aficionados was a major revelation for me. From Hawaii and California, tiki and Polynesian pop moved all over the country, landing especially in Chicago and Florida, and eventually New Orleans. All the famous bars - the Tiki-Ti, the Mai-Kai, the Luau - are profiled with tons of period pictures, along with drink recipes if you want to replicate the feel at home. Now, I actually don't want to do that. I love exotic cocktails, but I love them in context of tiki bars. But the history of these drinks remains fascinating. It's almost art, the construction and execution of tiki drinks, and learning about the ways the drink mixes were kept hidden using unbreakable codes and how they were stolen and approximated elsewhere ... a lot of this is pop archeology. It's pretty awesome.This is the 10th anniversary of Sippin' Safari, and I had no idea how major the impact of this book was. There were a lot of factors that went into the tiki resurgence, but this book was one of the major catalysts. I loved the long afterword that discusses the worldwide impact of the original book, and what's happening right now in the world of Polynesian pop. It also has a huge index of books in the back that I now must also read, because when I'm into something new, I don't stop until I get enough. And I haven't had nearly enough. I loved this book....more

title: The Man With The Getaway Face        (Parker, #2)
author: Stark, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Parker's in a bind, because he's supposed to be dead and he's in deep shit with The Syndicate. But a little plastic surgery and he's right back in theParker's in a bind, because he's supposed to be dead and he's in deep shit with The Syndicate. But a little plastic surgery and he's right back in the thick of things, preparing a new heist and moving on with his life.But it's sort of like the fallacy of a geographic cure: changing your face doesn't mean you leave all your problems behind. You're still you, and Parker is still Parker. Complications arise from all sides, from the possible double- and triple-crosses involved with the heist, to the lingering aftereffects from the doctor who changed his face, to the people he can't trust but has to. The structure of the Parker books is fun. Every book is divided into four sections of equal length; the first two focus just on Parker, with the second part ending in a cliffhanger. Part three gets omniscient and flashbacky, and then we're back to Parker in part four, where he gets his revenge and finishes the score. Neat.The Man With the Getaway Face FEELS like boilerplate Parker, but Stark is just getting his sea legs under him by this point. From what I understand, the later books dive deeper and get more complex. But this was not a bad way to spend a few hours, and I can't wait to get back into Parker's world....more

title: The Woman in the Window
author: Finn, A.J.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What's the best way to judge a mystery novel? Is the mystery the point? Or is it the characters? I read a lot of books about private investigators andWhat's the best way to judge a mystery novel? Is the mystery the point? Or is it the characters? I read a lot of books about private investigators and police detectives, and for me, it almost always comes down to whether the people are compelling. For that reason, I'm giving a couple pretty big thumbs-up to The Woman in the Window.The reason I'm asking these questions, though, is because the mysteries at the heart of the book - and there's a few - aren't all that hard to figure out. I understood one plot device about a hundred pages before our main character got there there, and the whodunit of it all came to me way before the end. Does this stuff matter? Maybe. A little. But what matters more is the woman at the center of the book. Anna Fox, Child Psychologist. She's an agoraphobic, and has been stuck in her house for nearly a year following a major trauma we learn about in increments. She's got a fairly active life in her home: she watches old Hitchcock movies (some of which seem to comment directly on the plot), she plays online chess, and she gives out free therapy to users on a message board called The Agora - a meeting place for shut-ins. She's in stasis, but stasis doesn't seem as bad as all that. Oh, sure, she drinks way too much, and medicates inefficiently, but that seems par for the course for titles with females inside prepositional phrases (I very much thought about The Girl on the Train during this). But Anna's life gets turned upside-down - again - when she sees her neighbor get stabbed from her window. The only problem is: DID she, though? No one else believes this woman exists. And for all Dr. Fox knows, she doesn't. Because don't some of her pills give her powerful hallucinations? Especially when taking them with alcohol?What I liked most about this book is Finn's take on those with mental disabilities and disorders, and how they should be taken seriously. I liked Anna Fox a lot, even when she was drinking and acting dumb, because it's balanced with a hell of a lot of being smart. Weirdly, the book was fun. Even though the whole thing is predicated on trauma and its aftereffects, this book was fun. Now I can't wait to see the movie and complain about everything they got wrong. ...more

title: Smuggler's Cove: Exotic Cocktails, Rum, and the Cult of Tiki
author: Cate, Martin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Late last year, I had the pleasure of visiting Smuggler’s Cove, in the midst of a tiki bar crawl in San Francisco with my buddy Jeff. The whole tiki bLate last year, I had the pleasure of visiting Smuggler’s Cove, in the midst of a tiki bar crawl in San Francisco with my buddy Jeff. The whole tiki bar culture has been new to me, and kind of overwhelming. Those who know me know that I rarely relax, and the whole point of tiki is relaxation and escape. Also, I don’t really drink that much.Except ... maybe now I do. Because tiki bar crawls are not really unusual for me anymore. I’ve developed a taste for rum along with my interest in the mystery and wonder of the wholly imagined and absolutely real culture of tiki.Martin and Rebecca Cate’s book is partially about the history of their bar - which is astounding - but it’s also the history of everything in the exotic world of tiki. It touches on all the mainstays: Donn Beach and Trader Vic, the origins and evolution of tiki bars, the history of a movement that was largely invented by frustrated mid-century men who needed a release valve. But the Cates go deeper, and we get into the history and manufacture of rum (and rhum), a chapter I thought I would find dull but was actually fun and informative. Near the end, there are tips for starting your own home tiki bar, how to throw the best tiki party, and where to get aloha shirts that won’t embarrass you when you travel out to the Tiki Oasis gathering. Sprinkled throughout are classic and new tiki cocktail recipes, some - like the mai tai - with accompanying histories, all fascinating.It may not be the definitive history of the universe of Polynesian Pop, but it’s damn close. All I want right now is an A-frame roof, some exotica on the jukebox, and a chilled rum cocktail in my hand. Reading this book made me feel like all those things were happening. I LOVED this book....more

title: The Burglar in Short Order
author: Block, Lawrence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've come to the realization that Lawrence Block has, almost stealthily, become my third-favorite writer. Stephen King, known for horror, and John IrvI've come to the realization that Lawrence Block has, almost stealthily, become my third-favorite writer. Stephen King, known for horror, and John Irving, known for ... I don't know, quirk? ... are the only authors above him. Unlike with those other two, there are quite a few Block books that don't really interest me. I tried to get into the Tanner series and gave up after the first book. He has a whole passel of early erotic fiction, often written under pseudonyms, that I simply don't want to delve into. But a lot of his one-off books (Getting Off, Resume Speed, Defender of the Innocent, to name a few) are killer. Of course, I'm not original. The books that grabbed me the most were the Matt Scudder books, the Keller books, and the comic mysteries of gentleman burglar Bernie Rhodenbarr. We got what might be a final Keller book last year. Now it's Bernie's turn. To be fair, most of The Burglar in Short order isn't exactly new stuff. There's a long introduction in which Block details where the selections all came from - catnip to a publishing nerd like me - and most of them are short stories, selections from Bernie novels, and weird ephemera in which we see Block interacting with Bernie inside his bookstore. Most of the short stories have been collected before - I specifically recently read "A Thief in the Night" in the older Block collection Enough Rope. But a lot of it was new to me, and I loved all of it. Especially the locked-room mystery "The Burglar Who Smelled Smoke," which made me so happy I literally giggled reading it. The last bit is brand-new, a meta-take on how some series characters never age. I won't spoil it, but it reminded me very much of the Pinocchio character in the comic book Fables, who had been granted the wish to become a real boy ... only the Blue Fairy had been frustratingly literal. Man, I loved this book. Like all fans who've had their hearts stolen by the gentleman burglar, I want the adventures of Bernie Rhodenbarr (and Scudder, and Keller) to continue forever, even though that's not possible. As it stands, The Burglar in Short Order is a good way to go out ... unless, lurking somewhere in Lawrence Block, another novella just HAS to come out. A reader can dream. ...more

title: True Grit
author: Portis, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have been trying to read True Grit for literally years. After seeing the more recent film with Jeff Bridges and Hailee Stanfield (I've never - shockI have been trying to read True Grit for literally years. After seeing the more recent film with Jeff Bridges and Hailee Stanfield (I've never - shock! - seen the John Wayne version), I immediately searched for an audiobook. I think I found one at once, but it was in some weird format, because the internet was wild back then. I found reasons to put off getting a good copy. And then it faded from the immediacy of my need.That changed last week, when I learned that its author Charles Portis had died. I don't mean to be ghoulish. When I got into Vonegut, I was always bizarrely proud of the fact that I'd begun Slaughterhouse-5 BEFORE he died, so I wasn't being awful. I've mellowed on stuff like that, and I'm glad I have. True Grit is a fantastic novel.The exceedingly simple plot for those not in the know: Mattie Ross's father has been killed by the drunk and cowardly Tom Chaney. She lights off on a quest to see him brought to justice. Along the way, she enlists the service of equally drunk federal marshall Rooster Cogburn (and, secondarily, a Texas Ranger named LeBoeuf) to aid her on her quest. That's it. That's the whole plot. But it's not the whole story. Mattie, you see, is a preternaturally serious 14-year-old girl with a single-minded mission that will take her through the wilds of the wild West. Murder doesn't faze her. She's not scared off easily. She feels things like exhaustion and soreness and - eventually - life-threatening pain, but she refuses to be deterred by it. There's comedy in her singlemindedness, but there's also nobility. She seeks Cogburn because she needs someone with true grit beside her on her quest. It says something about Portis's considerable skill that he never has to point out that Mattie is the one with REAL grit. You know it from page one, and that knowledge only deepens and resonates as the novel continues. I don't know why I took so long with this book. I listened to the version read by Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Donna Tartt, and her essay following the text about why she loves this book so much was enlightening. I wish I'd read this as a kid so that I could go back and love it with fresh eyes as a grownup. It won't be my last read, I can guarantee that. ...more

title: Raven Black        (Shetland Island, #1)
author: Cleeves, Ann*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My friend Tracey, who gets me into new writers, has been trying to get me into this book since last summer. She gave me a copy for my birthday and wasMy friend Tracey, who gets me into new writers, has been trying to get me into this book since last summer. She gave me a copy for my birthday and was all, "You're going to like this," and I said "scoff," because what has Tracey ever done for my reading except introduce me to the genre of modern crime and detective fiction in 1993 with Robert B. Parker? (To be fair, I introduced her to Dennis Lehane and Harlan Coben before they were big, and when she still liked Harlan Coben.)Anyway, what broke the ice was Ann Cleeves' new series, The Long Call which was not, I discovered, about someone chatting on the phone cross country. I liked that a lot and decided to finally give Raven Black a go. I'm so glad I did. The only real British mysteries I've been able to get into until recently have been the Maisie Dobbs books, and they're period pieces; there's a lot about World Wars and trauma and stuff to scratch the Dad gene I apparently have inside me that's fascinated with this stuff. With this book, I just had to care about people and a small island community. Cleeves doesn't rush that caring, either. Slowly but efficiently, we're introduced to the Shetland folk, measure by measure, and the language and tone are so well-captured that by the time we find the body, we already have a ready list of suspects in our head. The spiral of tension doesn't radiate out from the body, but in from the community. Maybe everyone has a motive. Maybe no one does. Only then are we introduced to Detective Jimmy Perez, the ostensible lead character, and again I was impressed by Cleeves' deftness and economy of words. As readers, our minds have been trained to view the "cop from away" with suspicion, especially once we've gotten to know the community. But we get inside Perez's mind, backstory, and motivations almost immediately, and he's woven into the fabric of this place so quickly that we don't have time for all those awkward "you're not from here, you don't know us!" scenes that can get tiring. The book just zooms along. Part of that could be that I'd borrowed a library audiobook that was due today and I listened to eight hours of it yesterday on 1 1/4 speed to make sure I got through it. But part of it was that, although Cleeves definitely takes time to let us know the characters and why they're doing the things they're doing, she doesn't WASTE time. We know exactly what we need to know, plus some character moments and shading, and then we move on. Well ... I mean, there are the red herrings. Like SO many. And I'd get annoyed but ... look, when I read mystery or crime fiction, it's not that I shut my mind off. I'm just normally along for the ride. But with this book and a handful of others, I was actively trying to figure out the mystery, and going down rabbit holes with Perez made it all the more fun. (Also fun? Thinking that "Up Helly Aa" was like a French word spelled "Apelier" until I gave in and looked it up. The pitfalls of audio reading.)So far, two Cleeves books this year. They will not be the last. I've got a few more books in queue before the next Jimmy Perez, but I'm hoping to blast through the whole series this year, if possible. So, Tracey, if you're reading? You were right, once again. (This is a lesson I'll forget when you try to get me into a new author, btw, fair warning.)...more

title: The Orchid Thief
author: Orlean, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve taken my time with this one, which feels odd. I blasted through the paperback of Rin Tin Tin very quickly, and through the audio of The Library BI’ve taken my time with this one, which feels odd. I blasted through the paperback of Rin Tin Tin very quickly, and through the audio of The Library Book so fast I couldn’t stop. I attempted the paperback of this, but I kept stopping and starting. I have so many issues with distraction that it’s kind of a wonder I became such a Stephen King nerd back in my youth.I finally downloaded the audio and the book moved under its own power instead of my stilted one. The Orchid Thief was Orlean’s big breakthrough book, and I thought for some reason it was going to be transcendent in a way The Library Book and Rin Tin Tin weren’t. But those books WERE transcendent. And I think what I’m discovering is this is where her style probably first asserted itself.Pop history and pop anthropology are just neat to me. Someone focuses on a specific thing, and then spirals our to discuss everything that thing touches, in all facets. Here, it’s not just orchids - it’s what collecting does to people, how obsession grips people, what is it about plants, specifically. We get a history of Florida and a cultural medium dive into the world of the Seminole people. And like in her other books, Orlean doesn’t remove herself. Her book-long quest to see a whole ghost orchid powers some of this. Whether she makes it or not by the end of the book is almost beside the point. Or maybe it is the point, just not the one we were expecting. Either way, it’s a fantastic book....more

title: The Hunter        (Parker, #1)
author: Stark, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wikipedia calls this "a crime thriller," and of course it is. We come into thing in medias res, and swiftly learn about our antihero, Parker. He's broWikipedia calls this "a crime thriller," and of course it is. We come into thing in medias res, and swiftly learn about our antihero, Parker. He's broken out of prison a few days early, murdered a guard, gone home to his estranged wife who tried to kill him during a heist gone sour, and goes about exacting his revenge. That's it. That's the story. It's a good one.I've been reading Donald E. Westlake a lot this year. They're complicated books, these long-ago Westlake titles. Memory is heartbreaking and sentimental, but tough when it needs to be. The Comedy is Finished is a dark semi-political thriller, but the jokes in it are pretty smart and actually funny.Westlake wrote the Parker novels under the Richard Stark name, and as far as I can tell, they're nothing like his own books. They're nasty. They don't seem to follow any kind of moral code. Parker is a bastard, but so is everyone. One of the bad guys beats a prostitute and steps on her head without any moral compunction. Parker accidentally kills someone and we spend little time worrying about them. Some. Not a lot. The Hunter is a streamlined, exhilarating novel (I finished in a day) in which crime and murder and death are all part of the score. Parker isn't like John Keller, from the books by Lawrence Block. Parker doesn't wrestle with his conscience much. He doesn't like killing, but he does it when people are between him and the things he believes should be his. He's not a psychopath. At least in The Hunter, we never get deep enough inside him to really understand what he is.My only experience with Parker so far has been the graphic novel for Slayground, which I picked up because I liked the mid-century art. I think I'm going to get the graphic novel based on this one, as well. And then I'm going to read the second book in the series. Wikipedia explains that most Stark novels follow the same format:Each book is divided into four sections of roughly equal length, subdivided into shorter chapters. The first and second sections are written in a limited third-person perspective focused entirely on Parker as he plans and undertakes a robbery or heist with colleagues. The second section ends on a cliffhanger, as Parker is betrayed -- often injured and left for dead. Section three shifts to the perspective of Parker's opponents, usually in flashback as they plan and execute their double-cross. Section four returns to Parker's perspective as he survives the plot against him and sets out for revenge.I'm into that. VERY into that. The Man with the Getaway Face is next....more

title: Nothing to See Here
author: Wilson, Kevin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's the story of a presumptive Secretary of State who had an affair and ruined his family. It's the story of that man's twin children, who lived withIt's the story of a presumptive Secretary of State who had an affair and ruined his family. It's the story of that man's twin children, who lived with their mother until their mother died. It's about how those two twins spontaneously combust sometimes. And it's the story of Lillian, this book's main character, and how she came to be the twins' governess for the summer. The premise is what drew me to the book, but what kept me and held me immediately was Lillian's voice. Based on initial s, I thought she was going to be this hard-bitten woman who hated life and now had to clean up her act to be nanny to fire children. But it's not like that at all. From page one, Lillian proves herself to be smart and sure and amazing ... and fucked over by life at every turn. There's a huge betrayal in the first third of the book that had me screaming, because Lillian is awesome and I didn't want her to get this ruined this quickly. But then she does become the governess of the fire children, Bessie and Roland. I didn't know that this would be the core emotional component of the book, Lillian and these two firestarter kids who have also been fucked over by life. Their initial meeting is fraught, to say the least, but their slow and deliberate understanding of one another is one of the best and most compelling situations I've read all year. Midway through the book, there's a revelation as shocking and sudden as the one I mentioned above - maybe more so. It makes you understand the kids more, and it makes Lillian's deepening connection to them make sense. Eventually things go right, and then they go wrong, and then there's another late-novel twist I totally should have seen coming. All of it makes sense, especially Lillian's complicated connection with Madison, the twins' stepmother and her lifelong best friend and first love, who'd taken part in that massive betrayal I keep coming back to. Like most people in this book, sometimes I hate Madison and sometimes I love Madison, and I think that's how we're supposed to feel because that's how Lillian feels.And oh my god this book is funny. There were several moments where I legitimately laughed out loud, so much so that I had to pause the audiobook and rewind it. Couple that with a full-novel sweep of compassion and earnest, earned goodness, and you come away with a novel that feels good but that makes you work for that feeling. I loved this book. ...more

title: Vacationland: True Stories from Painful Beaches
author: Hodgman, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't know how well you know my book purchasing and reading habits. You're certainly not expected to know them. You came here for a light summation I don't know how well you know my book purchasing and reading habits. You're certainly not expected to know them. You came here for a light summation of a John Hodgman book and you're getting what seems to be similar to the preamble you find on recipe blogs, where before you can learn how to make that tarragon chicken dish in three easy steps, you must slog through an interminable story about how the blogger's big brother left her at the candy store by accident when she was four and now the only way she can place balm on the suppurating sores of her trauma is by using a little extra balsamic on this quick and easy Tuesday-night recipe. Very quickly: when I travel to a new place that is not the place I call home, I invariably buy a book written by a local author about that place. I was in Maine with my Dad and my stepmom and my husband and some family friends, and we wandered into a bookstore and I saw Vacationland. Oh! I said. It's the I'm a PC guy. He's supposed to be funny! I bought the book and returned home and put it in my to-read pile and it's been a year and a half.In the meantime, I happened to read Hodgman's Medallion Status, a second book of essays that serves as sort of a sequel to Vacationland. I've done it backwards before with humorists' books of essays. I read Slone Crosley's Look Alive Out There years before her big breakthrough book, I Was Told There'd Be Cake. The difference is that Crosley's books seem to exist in a bubble; sure, they make more and better sense if you read them in order - you get a writer's progression, which I value highly. But Look Alive wasn't a sequel, per se. In Hodgman's Medallion Status, he references specific and very intricate details that follow up on chance asides and hints in Vacationland. That whole story about revisiting his alma mater's secret society, years after he remembers none of it because of an alcoholic fall down some stairs and the concurrent blackout? Vacationland has its origin story. I can only imagine how much more I would have liked that whole tale if I'd read this and thought, "Oh, there must be more to it. I hope I find out someday."A lot of Vacationland is origin stories. How Hodgman came to own two vacation homes, even though, despite his self-shamed white privilege, he's not really all that wealthy or connected. The whole mystery of the famous author who once lived and died in his town emerges first here, and Hodgman's discussion about how the locals never discuss it so delightfully reaffirms my concept of Mainers I was giddy throughout. And he talks about his mother, who died of lung cancer, and how, achingly, you can want a person to be alive and still be positively transformed by their passing. It's fantastic writing. Hodgman allows himself discoveries and doesn't undercut the wonder of them. He's self-deprecating, but not in a way that feels false or showy. He talks about Stephen King a lot, and with some reverence, so I'm all about that. (He also references Bruce Springsteen as a singer he doesn't like - boo - but whom he acknowledges is great - fine.) Most of all, Hodgman finds himself in the midst of impossible situations, occasionally of his own design, and he has the talent and gumption to make us laugh at them. It's a skill a lot of people think they're good at and aren't. The reason people think they're good at it is because of folks like John Hodgman, who make it seem so damn easy. ...more

title: The Comedy is Finished
author: Westlake, Donald E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've been all about vintage crime fiction this year, and my rediscovery of Donald E. Westlake has been kind of a thrill. The previous book I finished,I've been all about vintage crime fiction this year, and my rediscovery of Donald E. Westlake has been kind of a thrill. The previous book I finished, Westlake's Memory, was very good, very involved, and absolutely not a crime novel. This one is, and I'm going to go ahead and agree with the copy on the front of the book: this is Westlake's great final novel.The premise is this: what if, in the early 1970s, the Symbionese Liberation Army kidnapped Bob Hope in exchange for the release of political prisoners? Now, I don't know all that much about the left-wing rebel factions that cropped up during the sixties. I know they felt that their voice needed to be heard, and I know they were passionate about revolution at any cost. Any cost sometimes meant killing. Any cost sometimes meant dying. And it's no mistake that the Bob Hope analogue is named Koo. But what this particular group of militants discover, like so many characters in so many novels I read written by Baby Boomers, is that the sixties eventually ended. Revolution stopped being popular. And what they have done is kidnap a beloved American comedy institution - something of a symbol of the previous generation's hopes and dreams - and attempt to pit his life against an apathetic new era they don't understand. Honestly, though, it's not as political as all that. The premise is political, but the story is very human. We learn all about Koo Davis's checkered past. We meet his sort-of ex-wife, the sons he can't connect with, his worried agent. We live in the world of the FBI agent in charge of bringing Koo back alive. And we dig into the internal lives of the revolutionaries ... especially Mark, the deranged psychopath who has a pretty obvious secret that shoots off in astoundingly un-obvious ways. Westlake moves his plot quickly, forcing it to slow down by introducing multiple viewpoints (and cleverly putting Koo Davis' point of view in present tense, heightening the sense of immediacy). You end up understanding almost everyone this way, if not always liking them (especially Peter, who seems like a minor character at the start of the book and becomes a major pain in the ass). And like Davis, you kind of understand the terrorists' rhetoric, but you can't like that, either, because none of it justifies their actions. What we come away with, I think, is that some characters discover only too late that their worldview isn't a worldview after all, and that they really only care about themselves. And some characters kind of come to the opposite conclusion. I liked it a lot. Let's find more Westlake....more

title: Memory
author: Westlake, Donald E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Donald E. Westlake, one of the great crime writers of our time, is known mainly for two series characters: Dortmunder, whose novels appear under WestlDonald E. Westlake, one of the great crime writers of our time, is known mainly for two series characters: Dortmunder, whose novels appear under Westlake's own name, and Parker, whose novels appear under the Richard Stark name. Both series showcase Westlake's breadth of styles, from comic to noir, and his flexibility of genre. Or so I've heard. I've read neither.This is both my confession and my absolution. I have read Westlake, and loved Westlake. Just not in the ways you'd suspect. Back when I was still working in bookstores, I picked up the 1997 novel The Ax, a crime thriller about downsizing. I couldn't put it down. Three years later, in 2000, his dark novel about the publishing industry, The Hook came out. I felt the books were spiritually related. I loved them. I loved Westlake. And then I promptly stopped reading Westlake. What can I say? Robert B. Parker's Spenser was forefront in my mind then, whenever Stephen King wasn't releasing anything. Then I discovered Harlan Coben, and Dennis Lehane, and when I wanted to dip back into classic crime, I picked up a Jim Thompson novel, a good way to love writing and hate the world. The confluence of two outside influences brought me back to Westlake: I found Lawrence Block, he of the Scudder and Keller and Rhodenbarr novels, and I decided to explore the Hard Case Crime publishing house beyond the Stephen King stuff.Hard Case Crime publishes terrific vintage crime novels that have gone out of print, plus current crime novels written in that style. It republished a classic Westlake book, Somebody Owes Me Money, which I read and enjoyed ... though it didn't stick with me. Then, halfway through Lawrence Block's fantastic collection of essays, Hunting Buffalo with Bent Nails, I came across a recommendation: Westlake's long-lost, never-published Memory, which Hard Case Crime put into print for the first time in 2010. Memory: I remembered buying the book when it first came out, but as it sometimes happens with me and novels, I get distracted and put them aside. I'd liked the first few pages I read and chastised myself for not reading more. Then I remembered I'd also purchased the audiobook. I had two copies of this book just lying around, a book I intended to read, a book I wanted to read, and yet I hadn't hunkered down and actually read it. Must have slipped my mind.Well, as you can see, that's no longer the case. I queued up Memory three days ago on my Audible app. And then could not stop listening. Here's the premise: a man is caught in bed with a beautiful woman by the woman's husband. The husband picks up a chair and bashes the man over the head. He wakes up in a hospital with a concussion ... and a form of amnesia that works on both his short-term and long-term memory. He can't quite remember how he got to the hospital. He doesn't remember his parents. He knows he has a sister but can't remember her married name. And that's just the beginning of Paul Cole's story.I almost want to stop it there, because Memory is a book that rewards the reader who doesn't know much going in. And it's funny that I'm using the word "rewards," because there's so much unsatisfying about the book ... but it's in a funny sort of satisfied way. It's not a crime novel, despite the opening gambit. It's a novel, really, about identity: who we are when we don't remember who we were.It's this friction that drives so much of this fantastic novel. Paul's drive to get back to the version of himself he was before he lost his memory takes up a significant chunk of the book's middle section, set in New York City. He knows he used to be an actor, so he's determined to be that again. He knows who his friends were, so he forces himself back into their world. And it's frustrating at times, because the Paul who came away with the memory loss wasn't that person anymore. "I'm an actor because I'm supposed to be an actor," he tells himself a few times, before realizing over and over again that the only real acting he's doing is pretending he's something he's not.It's a ruminative novel. It's not like Memento, the movie whose protagonist suffers from short-term memory loss. That is a crime story, and maybe my hesitation was that it would be too similar to that. They're nothing alike. You root for Cole because he's lost, and you feel for him because he's going out of his way to not be found. The novel ends on a declarative note, but it's not the note you might think. Paul's entire story is about creating a whole self based on who he is in the moment, and there's something grand in that ... but also something tragic. I'm going to jump into some more Westlake now. Maybe through his famous characters' series. Maybe I'll dig into more Hard Case Crime books. One thing I know for sure: Memory is a terrific novel. If you'll pardon the pun, it's one I won't soon forget. ...more

title: Hunting Buffalo With Bent Nails
author: Block, Lawrence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Man, I love Lawrence Block.When I was young and almost exclusively a Stephen King reader, my diet of King was omnivorous. The man was writing horror nMan, I love Lawrence Block.When I was young and almost exclusively a Stephen King reader, my diet of King was omnivorous. The man was writing horror novels? Sure! There’s a children’s fantasy book? Yes! A novel about a woman who may have killed her husband and her employer, with virtually no supernatural elements? Please! It was the voice I came back for, time after time. It didn’t matter what Stephen King wrote, as long as it was him writing it. People who didn’t think this way baffled me. When I first became extremely online, I would find Stephen King nuts who would say, “Eh, that new one doesn’t look interesting to me. I’ll skip it.” My paroxysms at such insouciance were legendary.As I got into the larger world, though, my viewpoint began changing. Not on King - god, never - but on other authors. I would attempt to approach them as I’d done King, and that would work for awhile ... but a great deal of authors write in a variety of styles and I’m not always interested in them. More, I’m not as into the completionist mindset. If I don’t read every sentence an author wrote, it doesn’t mean I’m not a fan. Even my beloved John Irving wrote a book of essays that were, to my weary brain, interminable.That’s why Lawrence Block has been such a treat. I got in through the Scudder novels, moved into his comic Rhodenbarr thief books, and became a Blockovore with the Keller books. Last year, he came out with two books of collected nonfiction: one about stamp collecting, and this one - a clutch of essays from his long writing life that don’t center around a particular theme.Hunting Buffalo With Bent Nails is, then, a rococo clutch of dispatches from the world and mind of one of America’s best and most entertaining writers. In here, there’s a short essay about traveling the world and a long essay about traveling the USA - in search of towns with Buffalo in the name. Essays on audiobook abridgment, on Raymond Chandler’s connection with one of Block’s occasional passions, coin collecting. And the best essay, a long and incisive pocket history of the life of his mother, at once beautiful and engaging.I loved this collection. I think I’d have loved it even if I wasn’t a Block nut, but there’s something thrilling about finding a writer through their fiction and then diving deeper. It’s like getting a peek behind the curtain. Or, in this case, many peeks. Now I have to finish that stamp collecting one. I don’t care a whit about stamps, and yet I already know I’ll love it. ...more

title: Uncommon People: The Rise and Fall of the Rock Stars
author: Hepworth, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So, apparently I read books like this now.Last year (or the year before? the time flies when you're getting old) I read Steve Hyden's Twilight of the So, apparently I read books like this now.Last year (or the year before? the time flies when you're getting old) I read Steve Hyden's Twilight of the Gods, which was about how the commonly-regarded definition of the concept of a "rock star" has both burned out and faded away. Gone are the scary/nostalgic days of drugs and booze and endless sex on the road, chasing the high that rock music once gave you, terrified that the ride would end, praying that it never would. It was a fantastic book, and apparently I liked it so much that I wanted to read it again, from a different point of view. That's where Uncommon People came in.Despite its title, the book never mentions Pulp (not even in the tossed-off half-page discussion of Britpop near the end). But it seems to mention everyone else: Elvis, the Beatles, Dylan, Janis Joplin, Jimi Hendrix, Bowie, Ozzy, Duran Duran, Nirvana, more. By using the gimmick of singling out one day in every year from 1955-1994 - the era of the rock star - Uncommon People manages to differentiate itself from Twilight of the Gods by providing what seems to be a narrative history with interlocking chains. Mostly, though, what it does is remind the reader that those days are gone, and they ain't never coming back. I read a book in my teens on rock deaths, because I was morbid for awhile. It was pretty salacious. Kurt Cobain had just died and it was all anyone could talk about. The rock deaths book seemed to acknowledge his suicide was part of an ongoing thing in rock; not a pattern, per se, but some sort of established rhythm. John Lennon was shot. Skynyrd died in a plane crash. Freddie Mercury died of AIDS. Janis and Jimi found drugs. Without coming out and saying it, the book seemed to be telling me that death was a part of the whole legacy, part of the deal with the devil rock stars made. You lived rough, partied hard, lived your fullest life and made undeniably fantastic music, and you paid for it all by dying young. What this book and Hyden's book do is challenge that concept, try to rewrite the narrative a little. While both books occasionally linger excitedly on the bad stuff, the thrust of these exegeses is that none of what happened was normal. None of it was predestined. None of it had to happen. We accepted it because that was the whole rock star thing. But it's been a long time since Cobain died, and living like a rock star - or dying like one - no longer feels a prerequisite for fame and idolatry. I think that's good, and both of these book also think that's good ... even as we listen to and tell the stories about the rock god lives over and over again. ...more

title: A Tree Grows in Brooklyn
author: Smith, Betty
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is my friend Tracey’s favorite book. I’ve read it twice now (curiously, she hasn’t read my favorite novel, It, even once; she also hated my seconThis is my friend Tracey’s favorite book. I’ve read it twice now (curiously, she hasn’t read my favorite novel, It, even once; she also hated my second-favorite book, The World According to Garp. What I’m saying here is that I’m winning the book wars.)Man, this book is great. I love stories of lives - from the beginning and stopping somewhere between marriage and death. That what draws me to most John Irving books, and it’s why I loved The Dutch House so much last year. Francie Nolan is my favorite kind of character, bookish and solitary. Plus she’s a writer, which is catnip to me. That was my in with Little Women, and in fact there are some echoes of Little Women in this book. There comes a time when Francie is told to destroy her “bad” writing - her truthful stuff - and go on writing the anodyne rubbish that got her As in school. She goes home and does the opposite. I cheered.The best thing about Francie and her family is that they’re not saints. All of them try their best, but slip up and do bad things or make messes that are hard to get out of. There’s the aunt who doesn’t quite understand that she’s committing bigamy ... or her husband who only kind of understands that his child is actually his, biologically. An alcoholic father who keeps trying not to be. A long-suffering mother who almost - but not quite - makes a fetish out of hardship.It’s a full book that envelops and embraces. It doesn’t beg you to love it, but you love it because it’s all real and true and weird and normal. I certainly didn’t have a childhood at the start of the 20th century, but childhoods are childhoods, and Smith brings them to vivid life here. I wanted to reread the book because of a book I read last year, about the Armed Services Editions books that went overseas to soldiers in WWII. A lot of them praised A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, which I initially found odd. Hardened soldiers falling for a book with a young girl protagonist? But as I kept reading, the truth, as always, wins out. It doesn’t matter what a book is about or who it’s about, but how it’s about them. Those soldiers found an analogue of themselves in Francie Nolan, and I think I did, too....more
