my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you're a fan of the TV show Steven Universe, you know that one of the primary factors defining the show in its use of fusion: two beings (at least If you're a fan of the TV show Steven Universe, you know that one of the primary factors defining the show in its use of fusion: two beings (at least one gem) fusing together to create something new. Midway through the first season, we learned Garnet was a fusion of Ruby and Sapphire, borne out of love. Fusion became a weapon against Jasper, when - in her guilt - Lapis decided to drag her to the bottom of the ocean. Steven and Connie become Stevonnie, a way of being closer than friends and still not quite lovers. It's a fascinating process that has all sorts of connotations. Fusion for Beginners and Experts, a young-ages book, defines the indefinable in ways that even young children can understand. Fusion can be seen as a love allegory, or a sex allegory, or just a closeness allegory. The book discusses all of those avenues, explaining that sometimes people use fusion to be bigger, or better, or stronger. In true Steven Universe fashion, though, it also explains that sometimes people don't want to fuse, and that's okay (there's a picture of a very relieved Peridot in boxer shorts accompanying this bit, making the subtext of her asexuality pretty text ... which is kind of mindblowing for a young readers book).Look: I know this is a kids' book. It didn't take me long to read and I've already written more words ABOUT it than are IN it. Someone at work loaned it to me and I ended up loving what it had to say about the complexities of fusion in the simplest possible way. There's no one right way (or reason) to fuse; this book wants you to make up your own mind about what it means to you. ...more

title: Medallion Status: True Stories from Secret Rooms
author: Hodgman, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve owned John Hodgman’s previous book, Vacationland, for over a year. I have this habit when I travel of buying a book about that area while I’m in I’ve owned John Hodgman’s previous book, Vacationland, for over a year. I have this habit when I travel of buying a book about that area while I’m in that area. I was in Maine and I already had every Stephen King novel, so I picked that up. It’s still sitting on my to-read pile by the side of my bed.And then Medallion Status, his new book that operates as a quasi-sequel came out, and I bought and read it immediately. The vagaries of reading.I wasn’t sure what I was expecting. Probably not what this book was. I thought there would be some funny travel stories, like how funny it is to be in Bhutan or something, but of course that’s not what this is. It’s the story of a man losing his status, and trying to replace it, and what that means.Hodgman defines himself in a lot of ways: a father, a quasi-famous person, a television actor, a cat dad, and a member of his favorite airlines’ elite status program. Over the course of this book, his hard grasp on most of these things slips away. What is it like, to be semi-well known, and then not be? What would you do to be accepted?The fact that Hodgman is a straight white middle-aged man is not lost on him, and it is especially evident in the chapters dealing with the Trump inauguration, and how scary it all was and is. He knows he is a person of privilege, and doesn’t want to overextend that privilege, because he sees where it can lead. This becomes evident much closer to home later, as a stranger comes to town and tries to throw his wealth around. At the same time, Hodgman is struggling to hold onto his identity, which keeps redefining itself. And it’s interesting to see how important his medallion status becomes. He recognizes the absurdity of all of it, which is why it’s funny. And the whole book is funny. That’s the part that I almost forgot sometimes, until Hodgman made me laugh out loud. It’s maybe not the book I thought I was looking for, but it’s a better book than that. We are all trying to find out what our medallion status is, before we lose it....more

title: National Geographic Student World Atlas
author: Kids, National Geographic
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, so there are two Jeopardy! connections here.First and foremost: late last year, I finally read a book that had been knocking around my Audible qOkay, so there are two Jeopardy! connections here.First and foremost: late last year, I finally read a book that had been knocking around my Audible queue for literally four years. Ken Jennings' Maphead made me realize that I never took geography in school, and that I literally had no idea about places and the things that shaped them. It had never seemed important to me as a suburban kid who was never going to go anywhere. And now, here I am at 44, a world traveler who goes places but still doesn't know places. So I made up my mind to learn more about the world I live in in 2020.Which brings us to James Holtzhauer, the other major Jeopardy! winner. When asked how he crams so much trivia into his brain, he responded, "I read kids' books of facts." It makes sense. Grownup atlases and stuff sometimes assume you want stodgy lists of facts and figures. Kids' books, desperate to make you remember the things you need to remember, put all those facts in colorful boxes on glossy paper. I think it helps you digest this stuff more easily.My friend Marty got me this National Geographic Student World Atlas for Christmas, and I've spent the last few weeks poring over its facts and figures before sleepytime. And man, was it worth it: the maps taught me topography, political borders, weird stuff like how some countries have two capitals - one cultural and one administrative. There was a really neat illustration of where all the manned stations on Antarctica are. I learned a lot about Oceania, which is SORT OF part of Australia, but not really? And that, though politically Hawai'i is part of the US, geographically it's part of Oceania. Who knew?I honestly don't know how much I retained. I want to learn, but I also want to enjoy what I'm doing. I'm willing to read anything fun and see what sticks on its own. This was step one (well, two; I read that book of maps last year and I couldn't discern most of the factoids because the book used a lot of similar colors and I'm all colorblind). On the hunt for more stuff like this! (I read atlases now. I've always been a nerd but whoa.)...more

title: The Long Call        (Two Rivers, #1)
author: Cleeves, Ann*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My friend Tracey and I have been friends since I was eighteen and she was nineteen. When we met, I literally only read Stephen King books. That was alMy friend Tracey and I have been friends since I was eighteen and she was nineteen. When we met, I literally only read Stephen King books. That was all I read for about three years. Slowly, Tracey introduced me to new writers; the one that sticks out the most is Robert B. Parker, he of the Spenser novels. In turn, I eventually introduced her to Dennis Lehane and Harlan Coben, whose later books are no longer in her wheelhouse, but we had a good go of it. For years, we've tried to find new books and new authors for each other to try, always hoping that something will spark. We're rarely successful (a Bowlaway here, a Tana French there), but sometimes it works like gangbusters. It worked this time. Tracey has been trying to get me into Ann Cleeves for at least six months, and for Christmas she gifted me with The Long Call, the first book in the Matthew Venn series. "He's a gay detective!" she exclaimed during the holiday party. And I thought, sure, I need a new crime detective and gay could be good. Let's give it a whirl.At first, I was worried that I wasn't latching onto anything. A dead body. A thousand suspects. The abduction of a woman with Down's syndrome. All of it was sort of interesting, but none of it was clicking. And then suddenly, it did. I don't know if it was Detective Venn's inner life that did it, or the fact that we were seeing things from multiple points of view. Maybe it was that no one really had an issue with a gay man in authority (except maybe Matthew himself), and that the rivalry between Jen and Ross - two junior detectives who had to be partners - didn't feel as if it was rooted in misogyny, or, on the other hand, any too-pat buffoonery on Ross's part. Everyone has shades of characterization and deep histories that have led them to this point, and that's the main of it, and that's the main of any mystery or crime novel I fall in love with: the case is great. The people are better.So: this is the first book in this series and currently, there isn't another one. With the case wrapped up well and a lot of personal stuff still up in the air, I'm eager to start a new book. Last year, Tracey gave me another Ann Cleeves book called Raven Black, which I barely attempted because I was distracted or maybe I needed to read Firestarter again or something. I'll be reading it now. And she and I will keep trying to make each other's reading lists. I'm excited to keep trying. ...more

title: Joyland
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a wonder. It's not a horror novel by any sense of the imagination, even though Stephen King's name is on the cover. It's only kind of a cThis book is a wonder. It's not a horror novel by any sense of the imagination, even though Stephen King's name is on the cover. It's only kind of a crime novel, despite the awesome Hard Case Crime logo also on the cover. It's also sort of a romance and sort of a psychic-kid book and sort of a ghost story. Joyland flirts with genres in the same way that the Dark Tower novels do - honestly, like most Stephen King books do. But this one's sweeter than most. That's the word I keep coming back to, and it's and odd word to apply to a Stephen King novel. King has written kind stories before - "The Reach" comes to mind immediately - but rarely have those stories been this moving. And here's the thing: it's not profound. It's not revelatory. It's the story of a kid named Devin Jones who got his heart broken by a girl, and who decides to get over it by working at an amusement park. His crazy summer is a coming-of-age tale, and even when the guns come out and the blood starts flowing, there's a gentleness to this story that's hard to describe. It's in the white spaces between the words, I think, the quiet pauses after periods and question marks; it's a story everyone's experienced, even if you haven't.I think Joyland represents an entirely different kind of writing for King, even though the style sort of hearkens back to his early novels. If this book had come out after The Stand and before The Dead Zone, I don't think it would have shocked anyone. It feels like the work of a young man, which seems ironic. The only other King book I feel I can compare this to is Elevation, another gentle story about a sad man who finds he has more to give of himself than he thought. And look: I love horror. Maybe not as much as some might think, given my lifelong love of King, but I do love it. I love gore and unease and fear and loathing. But horror's not why I come to Stephen King. His books make me feel something that nothing else makes me feel (except maybe the work of Bruce Springsteen), this ineffable quality of well-being and righteousness. Jack Torrance can be chasing his son down a corridor with a roque mallet and I still feel that. The good guys don't always win and the bad guys aren't always punished, but these books seem to establish a balance in things. When I close the cover of a Stephen King novel, I know I can pick it up again and always get that feeling. It's not chasing the dragon if the dragon's always there, ready to greet you. What I'm saying here is that Stephen King novels make me happy, and Joyland makes me happier than most of them. This is my fourth time reading it and I'm excited to read it again. I was going to write that I wish all books made me feel this way, but that would take away from what these books make me feel. I just finished Joyland, and I am joyous. ...more

title: Brilliant Maps for Curious Minds: 100 New Ways to See the World
author: Wright, Ian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As part of my ongoing new interest in geography, I am trying to start learning new things about maps, countries, and the world. The first snag I hit wAs part of my ongoing new interest in geography, I am trying to start learning new things about maps, countries, and the world. The first snag I hit was reading this book: I am unfortunately colorblind, and I did not realize how big a stumbling block that was going to be.The information in this book is quite interesting, from Maps about which countries have the largest number of homicides, to historical data on where lions used to exist, to some really cool information about which countries are friendly with which other countries. The problem I had with the book was my problem not the book’s problem. First off, I didn’t always know the countries that were singled out (although a map of the world in Mercator projection is included at the front of the book. This was helpful, but not as helpful as I wanted it to be.) The biggest issue, of course, was the fact that I couldn’t always match the key up with the map itself. If the colors were too close together, I couldn’t always tell which countries have the highest speed limits, say, or which countries had the most gold. There is one maddening map included about the winners of the Miss World pageant, and they are all shades of pink, and I couldn’t for the life of me figure out which shade was which.A lot of really interesting facts did come from the book, like how to differentiate between England, the UK, and Great Britain. But my take on studying geography using children’s books in the new year may help me out. A lot of books for younger readers tend to use brighter, more contrasting colors, Which should help me out. I remember listening to an interview with James Holzhauer, the Jeopardy! genius, in which he said that studying children’s books on facts helped him more than adult books. So I’m going to take that tactic into the new year....more

title: This Is How You Lose the Time War
author: El-Mohtar, Amal*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I haven’t read a lot of science fiction as of late, unless you count Stephen King’s The Institute last year. The psi talents at play there probably maI haven’t read a lot of science fiction as of late, unless you count Stephen King’s The Institute last year. The psi talents at play there probably make it more SF than horror, but I haven’t dug into a real SF world since Weir’s Artemis, a few years back. I’m glad my hiatus is over. So there’s a time war. I’m actually not quite sure WHY there’s a time war, and maybe that’s by the authors’ design. War is meaningless, Amal El-Mohtar and Max Gladstone seem to say, especially if you can make war, undo it, and make new war throughout time. But if war is forever, they argue, then maybe so is love. That’s not a trite aphorism here, either. This romance between two enemy agents - Blue and Red - is a long, slow build throughout the history of the world. (It’s our world, by the way, only sometimes skewed.) These warrior women seem opposed by tradition rather than ideology, and that’s part of why, when one spots the other in a battlefield, she is moved to write her a letter to find somewhere in time. The letters are some of the cooler SF touches: they can be written into seeds, plants, a cup of tea, only to be unraveled and read later. The world-building itself is pretty awesome, too - a lot of neat butterfly effect causes set into motion across time, plus the fascinating way we discover Blue is ... well, born? I don’t know if I quite grasp the mechanics of time travel, but I don’t really have to. I grasped the love story, which is far more important.At first, Red and Blue fall in love with each other’s way of thinking. Only gradually do we see how they fall in love with each other. It is a fascinating journey whose title belies the actual point of the book. I would love to read more in this universe, and by these writers....more

title: How to Hide an Empire: Geography, Territory, and Power in the Greater United States
author: Immerwahr, Daniel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I thought I knew what I was getting into, first book of the year. I only kind of did.A lot of How to Hide an Empire is harsh, and it should be. The fiI thought I knew what I was getting into, first book of the year. I only kind of did.A lot of How to Hide an Empire is harsh, and it should be. The first half of this book tells about the USA's obsession with Manifest Destiny, how our lust to conquer and own got us the continental United States, Alaska, and Hawaii. It also delves deep into the confusing histories of the Philippines and Puerto Rico, and how they were once (or still are) American territories owned by the US. Trigger warning: there's a LOT of war stuff, and a lot of it isn't the "draped in glory" war stuff. It's dark. We were a conquering people - of both the natives in this country, and throughout the Pacific and beyond. This book sheds a light on a lot of history I didn't know about, especially on the start of WWII, in which the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor ... and then went on to keep bombing US territories, fully overtaking Guam and more. What? This HAPPENED?!The second part of the book is less thrilling but just as fascinating, because a lot of it focuses on what's happening now. Are we an empire still? Kind of. Just in a much quieter way. We might not be going out and claiming islands as our own anymore ... but we have all these military bases all over the world, collectively stringing our superpower together globally. Immerwahr also sheds a lot of light on how 9/11 came to be, and how it's connected to our power grabs and our belief that we are generally right about everything. It's not a book that's down on the US. It's a book that makes you think about the US in ways you may not have before. It's a much darker and denser first book of 2020 for me - way darker than that book about the TV show Friends I finished first last year - but How to Hide an Empire is surprisingly readable and so intriguing that it's hard to put down. ...more

title: Little Women
author: Alcott, Louisa May
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was my firm belief that I was going to have trouble with any book written before 1940. Not trouble, necessarily, but roadblocks in language and styIt was my firm belief that I was going to have trouble with any book written before 1940. Not trouble, necessarily, but roadblocks in language and style that couldn’t be helped. A friend of mine once told me that translated literature from the past was always easier than books written in English, because the translations are updated for modern readers, but the books in English always stay the same. How glad I am to be wrong!I picked up Little Women for the first time in my life because the new Grega Gerwig film is almost out and I’m eager to see it. I thought I was going to have a real issue with the language - a barrier between me and these beloved characters - as the book was written in the 1860s and that seems so impossibly ancient to me now. But far from creating a problem for me, the language and the writing WELCOMED me. Not once did I struggle with a sentence or get mired in a paragraph. This clarity and accessibility of writing helped me to like that characters at once - not JUST like, but get into their lives as if they were the lives of real people.I went on social media and chastised Meg for going to a fancy party she wasn’t prepared for. I bitched out Amy for burning one of Jo’s manuscripts. I was so disappointed in Jo for being such - curmudgeon around Aunt March that she never got to go to France. And Beth ... well, I was afraid Beth was going to be all too saintly to take seriously. I knew she died and I was afraid the melodrama would be too much to bear. But she wanted a piano. And the fact that she wanted something made her a lot more human. The fact that her actual death takes place off-page is another smart turn: we don’t need to watch her die to feel the sadness of it.And there’s so much more! Jo’s struggles to be the writer she can be, not just the one she thinks she should be. Meg’s transformation into kind of a boring mother and Amy’s change from spoiled and conceited brat to someone you really like and admire. The love stories all make sense, the quiet ambitions that change and mutate, the depth to which Alcott plunges with each of these people to make them real and contradictory and compelling: all these elements make this one of the best books I’ve read this year. Now, what’s my next classic I should have read ages ago? ...more

title: Maphead: Charting the Wide, Weird World of Geography Wonks
author: Jennings, Ken
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve had Ken Jennings’ Maphead in my Audible library for a few years. I bought it when I was in full Jennings fever after the whole hat trick of his JI’ve had Ken Jennings’ Maphead in my Audible library for a few years. I bought it when I was in full Jennings fever after the whole hat trick of his Jeopardy! appearance, his memoir, and his book of trivia. I was eager for more Ken Jennings, whose name - like some other authors like Ruth Reichl - need not include a surname in my house. I said Ken, and my husband understood who I was talking about. He was a celebrity to us.Then ... I don’t know if my interest in Ken waned, or if this new book - about geography, rather than trivia or Ken himself - was simply less interesting to me. I’ve never been big on the subject; as Ken so astutely puts it in the book, it stopped being taught as a discrete subject in schools before I was born. Maybe I never really had a chance to get into maps the way I got into novels and trivia and video games. The most involved my life ever got was when a huge wall map and its metal hanging structure fell on my algebra teacher’s head and we had a substitute for three weeks.But I do love my accessible, poppy books on subjects I’m not familiar with, so when I was casting around for something to get me out of the sad novels about dead girls rut I seemed to be in, I hit on Maphead.The book worked in exactly the way I wanted it to. Thesis statement about why maps are important and why they’re important to Ken. The broad history of maps and geography, mostly American-centric but taking the context of the world into much consideration. Eventually we move into the futuristic now: chapters on GPS and geocaching and there’s a complicated math/geography chapter I didn’t quite understand. A really neat discussion of Google Earth. Thoughts about whether the future of maps will eliminate paper altogether. Closing, cautiously optimistic statement about the next generation of mapheads. And fin.But that’s just the structure. It’s the structure pop writers take when writing books about difficult subjects for a mass audience. And I like the structure. It’s comforting, and only a little samey. What matters is how it’s tackled. Who’s writing it. How much of themselves they put into it. I read a history of salt earlier this year that was popular and I found it dull. Ken Jennings isn’t dull.What comes across most in Maphead is how very, very much Ken likes maps and geography. And because he’s passionate about the subject - at times, you kind of think the book should be called Mapstan - YOU become passionate about it. I’m suddenly fascinated with geocaching, and also with fixing my geography blind spots and finally knowing all the state capitals, and not just the big ones like Boston or Orlando or Los Angeles. If you have an interest in subjects you should have learned in school - or learned better - and want an in, this is that sort of book for you. Or if you just like nerds being nerds, and perhaps are a nerd. You might come away with a sudden craving for a National Geographic atlas. PS it’s on my Amazon List and Christmas is two weeks away....more

title: Belinda Blinked 5        (Belinda Blinked, #5)
author: Flintstone, Rocky*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At one point in this book, a duchess rides a horse into a safe house where men are playing strip baccarat, or something. It's one of the sanest momentAt one point in this book, a duchess rides a horse into a safe house where men are playing strip baccarat, or something. It's one of the sanest moments of the book. But let's back up. Belinda Blinked is the atrociously-written, biologically-suspect, family-shaming book of erotica written by the pseudonymous Rocky Flintstone (which: delightful). Flintstone gave the manuscripts of the first few books to his son Jamie, who was horrified. So he did what any sane child of a budding porn novelist would do: started a podcast with his two best friends - James and Alice - to read the book and react accordingly. In the first book alone, one man fucks a woman and enters her cervix, breasts hang like pomegranates, and an older woman's nipples are described as looking like the "three-inch bolts that were used on the fateful Titanic." What IS this thing? WHY is this thing?My buddy Joe introduced me to the podcast, My Dad Wrote a Porno, a few years ago on a road trip from Athens, GA to Orlando, FL. I got hooked immediately. Jamie reads the books; his friends Alice and James react. Sometimes Jamie reacts, because the sheer weight of the fact that it's his Dad who took time out of his life to pen this lunacy. Plus, the fact that they're all British - and that Jamie has taken to doing accents for the most colorful characters - just makes the whole thing kind of charming. I mean it's crass and it's baffling, but it's not MEAN. Book 5 took a weird turn away from the world of cookware, where our hero Belinda Blumenthal is some sort of executive, and became a spy novel. It makes no sense. There are long chapters involving trading sex for a cookware spot on Australian television. Someone fucks a book, maybe. There's a horse named Toffee Apple Chew. It's all ridiculous. I can't recommend it enough. Why four stars instead of 5. Well, I'm pondering that myself. Like, how does Belinda Blinked 5 stack up against Where the Crawdads Sing, or Little Fires Everywhere? Who can say? Is it as good a novel as The Shining, which I re-read this year? Your mileage may vary. I may have TRIED to give it five stars, but the small critic inside me who read Mildred Pierce and The Dutch House and The Goldfinch this year threatened to cut my hand off, so I guess we're stuck with 4. Now the long, hard, sensuous wait for Season 6....more

title: Mildred Pierce
author: Cain, James M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I keep thinking that I've never read James M. Cain, one of the big-name hard-boiled writers for whom the term noir fiction was named. And I think it'sI keep thinking that I've never read James M. Cain, one of the big-name hard-boiled writers for whom the term noir fiction was named. And I think it's because I haven't dabbled nearly enough in this genre, the prehistory of the detective novels I love now. To know James M. Cain is to understand Robert B. Parker and Lawrence Block and Dennis Lehane. Modern noir, maybe. I think this because I've long carried a worry that I'm not nearly well-read enough; not in the canon, not in genre classics, not in the stuff I ought to have read in school but never did. But of course I have read Cain (and Westlake, and Jim Thompson; my inferiority complex when it comes to reading conveniently ignores the facts). The Postman Always Rings Twice was as raunchy and thrilling as the film version with Jack Nicholson and Jessica Lange, and The Cocktail Waitress, a lost novel finally published by Hard Case Crime a few years back, was far more gripping than I thought it would be, hinging on, of all things, thalidomide. Could I read more in this genre I clearly love? Sure. But to keep pretending I'm ignorant of it is silly. So let's move past silly. I saw the film version of Mildred Pierce over a decade ago for Gay Movie Night. I'd heard it was some sort of camp classic, but I didn't really see it that way. It surprised me in its depth and its gothic affectations, and stunned me with its characterization of Veda, one of the more loathsome characters ever on screen. It didn't occur to me then to follow up with the book, but when I was in a huge used bookstore in Los Angeles this year, and given my predilection for buying books about the places I'm visiting, I couldn't resist. If I thought the movie was shocking, man, this novel. It's a tragedy, in its own way, and it almost doesn't have to be. The most exciting aspect of the book is watching Mildred recover from the aftereffects of a shaky marriage to build a small empire for herself. The dogged way she goes about it, the way she forces herself to use the talents she has and acquire new ones to not only survive, but thrive. Cain's insistence on giving us a lot of the nitty-gritty of this reminds me of Arthur Hailey's aphorism that people like reading about other people's work. If it's not their line, it's fascinating; if it is, it's comforting. The big albatross around Mildred's neck is her daughter, Veda, who she loves with an almost unreasonable grandness. It's fascinating to watch the dynamic, because as Mildred is building herself and her reputation up, incrementally making something impressive of herself in the midst of the Great Depression, Veda keeps trying to tear her down. When Mildred takes a job as a waitress, hating herself for it but knowing she has to support her children, Veda basically tells her she's a no-class hobo she's embarrassed of. Veda's not the last person who will use Mildred for her money while degrading her for making it, but she's the most insistent. She's also darkly brilliant, able to think around corners Mildred can't, because Mildred is essentially a good person who made the mistake of loving the wrong person too much. Veda reminds me of Cathy in Steinbeck's East of Eden, an irredeemable human without a sense of morality that the better people in her life can't help but masochistically love. One of the most interesting aspects of Mildred Pierce is that I had long thought of Cain as one of these tough-guy writers: guys are guys and dames are dames, etc. But this book is a novel about a strong, independent woman who doesn't have to "act like a man" in order to be taken seriously by men. It's surprisingly feminist, even as its most horrible character is also a woman, the manipulative and borderline evil yin to Mildred's goodhearted and ambitious yang. It's such a good book, and I'm so happy it actually completes my 2019 reading challenge - 60 books in a year. Everything after this is gravy, so I couldn't be happier that I got this juicy hunk of meat to finish off the main course. ...more

author: Cooke, Darwyn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay so; I’ve never read a Richard Stark novel. For someone who claims to be a fan of detective novels, especially the noirish ones with a lot of brutOkay so; I’ve never read a Richard Stark novel. For someone who claims to be a fan of detective novels, especially the noirish ones with a lot of brutality and a sliding scale of morality, I recognize this is a failing.Stark is the pseudonym of Donald Westlake, an author I HAVE read. He wrote two fantastic books about the publishing industry - The Ax and The Hook - neither of which are available on audio, which in itself is a crime. Westlake is known more for somewhat lighthearted mystery and crime fare; his famous quote is that when it was sunny out, he wrote as Westlake. He wrote as Stark when it rained.Darwyn Cooke is the person responsible for the DC Comics New Frontier graphic novel, one of my favorite DC title ever. He’s a whiz at mid century grit and wonder, and the cover of his adaptation of Parker’s Slayground hooked me at once. It’s like a Googie explosion. The art inside just keeps getting cooler, marrying the murder noir and the atomic age sensibility so well that I was legitimately giddy reading it. The book focuses on a heist gone bad and Parker - our brutal thief - hiding out in a Disneyland-like park until he can get away. That’s it. That’s the whole story. But what a story! It’s clever and smart and every murder is a short story of guile and efficiency. Plus there’s a fold-out park map! This book has everything.The only drawbacks here are my own: 1. This is the fourth book in the series, and so I don’t know much about this Parker fellow, and 2. I really don’t have the prose basis of the book to inform the whole exciting story. I need to read the novel. Heck, I need to read all the Parker novels. It’s been a long time coming....more

title: Hatchet        (Brian's Saga, #1)
author: Paulsen, Gary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sometimes I think I skipped 90% of the young adult reading I was supposed to do in my middle school years. My early years were a straight line from DrSometimes I think I skipped 90% of the young adult reading I was supposed to do in my middle school years. My early years were a straight line from Dr. Seuss to Roald Dahl to Judy Blume to Stephen King. I missed so many of the Newbury Award Winners that I wonder why, exactly, I read in school. I know The Pigman was in there, and It’s Like This, Cat, and The Outsiders and The Pinballs. But most of it is hazy.Hatchet, for example. Hatchet is a book I absolutely would have gone nuts for back when I was eleven and was pretty sure I could live by my wits in the forest. Both My Side of the Mountain and William Sleator’s Singularity proffered the romance of isolation, and that was a major asset in a life as far as I was concerned. I’d like to think I would have thought as well or as skillfully as Brian Robeson, the hero of Hatchet, who finds himself stranded somewhere deep in the Great North Woods. His story of survival is candy for a man who once thought he could be a certain type of boy, the type with the smarts and rigor to survive and even thrive in the wilderness. Maybe I never was, but books like Hatchet make me think I might have been.Is the ending abrupt? Maybe. But maybe it has to be because after so much hard endurance, Brian’s story is about to fundamentally change. Gary Paulson, the writer, might not want to have followed that change. I’m glad he didn’t. Though I now see there are sequels and I might have to find those, wanting a lot more of this story than this small volume could provide. On and on, always!...more

title: Krakatoa: The Day the World Exploded: August 27, 1883
author: Winchester, Simon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I know I liked this book. I’m giving it four stars because apparently Goodreads doesn’t allow 3.5, which is more accurate. I’ll explain.Simon WinchestI know I liked this book. I’m giving it four stars because apparently Goodreads doesn’t allow 3.5, which is more accurate. I’ll explain.Simon Winchester’s Krakatoa is about the 1883 volcanic explosion that decimated cities, killed thousands, and made an island disappear. Winchester comes at this central point the way I like my pop nonfiction to do so: from all angles. He sets us firmly in the time and place (in this case, an East Indies island under Dutch colonial rule) so that we’re seeing through his eyes. Then he dives deeper.How volcanoes work. What plate tectonics are. How Krakatoa came to be under Dutch rule. Winchester delves into science, history, even philosophy. It’s all great, if sometimes dry, like Bill Bryson decided to collaborate with Neil DeGrasse Tyson. Hashtag Tryson.But the back half of the book drags just a little too much for me to give full endorsement of Krakatoa. It’s a shame, too, because the fallout (literal and figurative) is pretty fascinating. But Winchester frontloaded the book with so much interesting stuff about the aftermath - how sunsets changed, how art and writing were impacted, how the explosion was the first major event the whole world knew about at roughly the same time - that he has only a few avenues to turn to after the eruption itself. What he focuses on are the political and religious aftercurrents of Krakatoa, and how the people of the East Indies ended up revolting against Dutch rule. It sounds great. It reads a little dull.Winchester saves himself a little near the end, talking about the new, volatile islands that have cropped up and erupted in irregular intervals over the grave of Krakatoa. How new life comes to new places. It’s fantastic stuff. The epilogue, in which Winchester visits this new island and is terrorized, kind of, by a prehistoric beast from the jungle, is excellent. So maybe it does deserve those four stars. Maybe. ...more

title: Everything I Never Told You

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was waxing rhapsodic about Celeste Ng's Little Fires Everywhere, the big bestseller of this year and last, to my friend Jeff, who hadn't read it. HeI was waxing rhapsodic about Celeste Ng's Little Fires Everywhere, the big bestseller of this year and last, to my friend Jeff, who hadn't read it. He had read her first book, this one, and he couldn't stop talking about it. We were in an independent San Francisco bookshop when I first picked up the novel and read that gutpunch of a first sentence, which I won't repeat here because it's so good in context. I hoped the rest of the book would live up to that promise. A few months later, I can say with confidence it has. One great book is a great book. Two great books is a great writer.The story follows the Lee family at the tail end of the 1970s. James, who is Chinese-American, and Marilyn - who is not - marry in an era when such mixed marriages are still illegal in some states. Marriage gains them so much but it costs them, too. The individual shames of their upbringing - James to be a traditional Chinese boy, Marilyn to be a traditional American girl - propel them to become their own people. Then they have their own kids, and without realizing they're doing it, behave the exact same way.We open on the death of their middle child, Lydia, and she becomes the center of the book, both metaphorically and literally. Through extensive flashbacks, we understand Lydia's life better than either parent, or her brother, or even her clever little sister, so used to being unnoticed that she knows more secrets than anyone. Eventually, as the book winds to its close, we know why and how Lydia died. Her family never quite gets that luxury, and it's mostly that tension that propels this novel.I loved this book. I'm apparently a sucker for tense family dramas that take place over the course of years. This and The Dutch House back to back make me crave the new John Irving novel even more; he's sort of been my template for this stuff, and I've been re-reading him a lot lately, too. And now, frustratingly and excitingly, I also have to wait for Celeste Ng's new novel, too. It took Ng six years to write Everything I Never Told You. I hope her next one comes just a little bit more quickly....more

title: When Books Went to War: The Stories that Helped Us Win World War II
author: Manning, Molly Guptill*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s so exciting when I discover a somewhat forgotten chunk of American history, especially when that something isn’t racist or sexist or homophobic oIt’s so exciting when I discover a somewhat forgotten chunk of American history, especially when that something isn’t racist or sexist or homophobic or otherwise problematic. In World War II, American soldiers not only faced the horrors of war in the European and Pacific Theaters, but also the very real enemies of homesickness, boredom, anxiety, and depression. To help combat these latter ills, the US military worked with a number of American publishers to create the ASE, the Armed Services Editions: books small enough to fit in a back pocket that GIs could take anywhere. To say they were a hit would be understating things. To say they helped win the war would not be overstating.I came into When Books Went To War expecting something different. I thought Manning was going to delve deep into how WWII established certain books - like Smith’s A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, or Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby - as new entries into the American canon. Manning gets there, but this book is a far deeper and more nuanced work. We start at Kristallnacht, at which dozens of German students burn hundreds of books - anything that disproves or argues against the notion of Aryan superiority. Beginning here underscores Manning’s intent in explaining why we went to war, and why these small paperbacks were such an important weapon against Hitler’s policing of free thought and free speech.Of course, because America is full of ironies, we also get to learn a bit about the censorship threats that befell the ASE program, and some interesting stuff about Republican vote tampering decades ahead of its time. And because this is World War II, Manning can’t quite skirt the blatant horrors of war, nor the deep American malaise following its aftermath. At all measures, however, Manning presents a compelling and truly enlightening slice of American history, something I knew nothing about but am so glad I now do. And Manning does not truck with dry history. Her incisive and accessible prose, her ability to move from the personal to the global, and her obvious love of the concept and practice of reading make this a thoroughly entertaining read, as well. I loved this book....more

title: How I Killed Pluto and Why It Had It Coming
author: Brown, Mike
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My Very Energetic Mother Jumped Slowly Under New Potatoes. Or maybe they were Narwhals.I remember once, back in the mid aughts, I happened to read BreMy Very Energetic Mother Jumped Slowly Under New Potatoes. Or maybe they were Narwhals.I remember once, back in the mid aughts, I happened to read Breakfast at Tiffany's and Breakfast of Champions back to back. Entirely coincidentally. This year, I've finished three "how" books in a row. That has no bearing on this book, but I do think it's kind of funny to consider How to Hide an Empire, This is How You Lose the Time War, and How I Killed Pluto and Why It Had It Coming as a sort of loose trilogy about geography and astronomy and time travel. Anyway, the whole idea of Pluto - which I'd learned about as a planet since my first days of school - no longer being a planet has always fascinated me. My husband remains furious. I take a more measured approach. Why did it happen? How did it happen? And what's a dwarf planet?I was worried that the approach would be a little dry, despite the kicky, adversarial title. But Mike Brown has a way with putting the science of the Solar System in everyone's grasp. Late in the game, there's a reluctantly-given physics lesson, but even I understood that. Did you know I failed science once in school? It was chemistry, but mostly I failed because I couldn't wrap my mind around the precision of it, the math and specificity. There's a ton of math involved in astronomy (I saw Hidden Figures!) but Brown seems to know that the general public wants fun, not fusty. He delivers on that fun. The joy of discovery as Brown and his team discover orbital objects in the sky - are they planets? planetoids? asteroids? - not once but several times never stops being thrilling. I also love that they give them fun temporary names like Easter Bunny and Xena; they might be nerds, but they're cool nerds. We get astronomical history: how the planets were discovered, and by whom, and how the designation of Pluto as a planet was always a little controversial. I love the history stuff interwoven through the narrative - it's like a Bill Bryson book with a current timeline throughline. By the time we got to the whole controversy, and the legislative body of astronomers deciding what Pluto's (and Xena's, and others) designation was going to be, I was hesitant. I had loved Brown's whole story up to this point (including and especially the stuff about him becoming a husband and father during the whole planet discovery stuff), so I worried that this part would drag on and become less personal. I was wrong about that. Brown manages to keep his story about his team and his discovery, and even inject a whole level of intrigue I wasn't expecting. There are a lot of people, like my husband, who wanted Pluto to stay a planet just because it had always been one. There's a cultural connection, an emotional bond to this thing far, far off in the cold vastness of space. Quite a few people wanted science to let Pluto stay a planet of our solar system, simply because they loved Pluto. But that's not how science works. And now I understand why....more

title: The Dutch House
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a glorious novel! The Dutch House is the story of a brother and sister, Danny and Maeve, and the house they grew up in. The Dutch House remains tWhat a glorious novel! The Dutch House is the story of a brother and sister, Danny and Maeve, and the house they grew up in. The Dutch House remains the center of their lives, both physically and metaphorically, even when they no longer live there, and even when the house isn’t technically theirs. It’s also the story of parents: Danny and Maeve’s father, their mother, and their stepmother ... and Maeve herself as she becomes Danny’s caretaker. It’s how the mistakes of the past echo on the dreams on the future, but not violently, as you’d expect with a book whose beginning is as tumultuous as this one. The echoes are gentle, nudging, and yet so exciting and involving that you’re compelled to read on, gobbling up the next sentence and paragraph and chapter.To say much more would be to spoil all the twists. The first one, the big one, knocked me for a hell of a loop, and then they all kept coming. All of them shocked me, and all of them built logically out of the story and these fascinating characters. By the end of the book, I was fully in love with every person in it, and wanted to know everything about their lives. I was greedy for closure, and when I got it, I wanted more story. That’s how good The Dutch House is: you wish it would continue indefinitely. What a glorious novel....more

title: Down and Across
author: Ahmadi, Arvin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I first spotted Down and Across when I was in an indie bookshop in San Francisco. When I travel, I always look for local fiction that will get me moreI first spotted Down and Across when I was in an indie bookshop in San Francisco. When I travel, I always look for local fiction that will get me more involved in the place around me. I wasn’t finding what I was looking for in SF, but this book, with its hint of a YA love story involving crosswords, spoke to me from out of a dump-bin. I scanned the first page and saw it was set in Washington, DC. All the way back on the coast of just left.But I bought it anyway and let it simmer for awhile before I finally picked it up. I’m glad I did. As it turned out, it wasn’t a love story really, and it wasn’t super about crosswords either. It was about people growing up, and doing only an ok job of it. I think this might have been my first New Adult novel, a category that didn’t exist when I was a new adult - somewhere in the nebulous region between YA and adult fiction. Basically, everyone’s still pretty young and figuring stuff out, but you can say fuck and describe a breast. It was pretty good.I was a little concerned when Scott, an Iranian-American running away from his internship while his parents are out of the country, runs into a quirky, free-spirited girl named Fiora on the bus. I’d assumed I was going to get a big dose of Manic Pixie Dream Girl, but that didn’t quite happen. The author actually lampshades the trope, which can sometimes be an excuse to double down on the whole thing, but author Ahmadi is smarter than that.I liked the messiness if the story; coincidences happen, but they don’t define the book. And I liked how Ahmadi avoids pat, easy endings. I wanted a little bit more of the Iranian perspective, and a LOT more time with Fiora’s cruciverbalist buddies, but I couldn’t find myself disappointed in this one. Well-written, full of appealing characters with realistic enough lives. Fully satisfying....more

title: The Grammarians
author: Schine, Cathleen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had never heard of Cathleen Schine before I stumbled upon The Grammarians at the Harvard Coop; it sat on the corner of the new releases table, unassI had never heard of Cathleen Schine before I stumbled upon The Grammarians at the Harvard Coop; it sat on the corner of the new releases table, unassuming and smallish with its picture of rosy-cheeked twins under that arresting title. I glanced at the back copy flap - two girls, Laurel and Daphne, and their deep sisterly bond which breaks over word usage, something like that - and I knew I had to read it. I am so glad I did.I'm a sucker for books about full lives, and Daphne's and Laurel's lives are packed. We see them as babies first, their parents unsure of what to make of their baby-talk conversation that the girls instinctually understand. This is only the beginning of their lifelong obsessions with words, culminating in the arrival of a massive, totemic dictionary that becomes almost a third sister. Laurel and Daphne are easy people to like, even when they're prickly and even when they work against their better natures. Maybe because of that, because the reader can see where they might be stepping wrong ... and then discover, occasionally, that they stepped right, after all. It is in these small twists that the book works the best, watching as things that shouldn't work out absolutely work out, and sometimes vice versa.Plus, the whole book is populated with fascinating supporting characters, especially Daphne and Laurel's eventual husbands, Larry and Michael, and in their cousin Brian, who we watch grow up on the periphery of the twins' lives. Everyone is interesting, with multifaceted lives that honestly feel lived-in. I especially liked the flash-forward ending, which could be cliche but doesn't really feel like it. The somewhat harmonious coupling of various tertiary characters could seem pat, but instead feels like an outgrowth of the deep-rooted bond of The Grammarians' two main characters. Their lives aren't always easy, but The Grammarians is - thrillingly so. I read it in massive gulps, only wanting to know more, to uncover more, as the words spooled out and revealed themselves. I absolutely loved this novel....more

title: The Year of Reading Dangerously
author: Miller, Andy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A few years ago, I read Moby-Dick for the first time and I haven’t shut up about it since. The Great American Novel actually kind of was ... though soA few years ago, I read Moby-Dick for the first time and I haven’t shut up about it since. The Great American Novel actually kind of was ... though so are Stephen King’s It, Steinbeck’s East of Eden, John Irving’s The World According to Garp, and dozens of others. The thing that set Moby-Dick apart was that it was a classic, part of the canon of Great Works ... and it had been difficult to read. Sometimes crazy difficult, like those thousand or so pages explaining why whales are fish. I finished it, and part of the reason I think I’m so enraptured with it is the fact that it WAS difficult. I don’t know if I quite understood all of it, even though certain passages really moved me. Melville was adamant that his white whale not be thought of as a metaphor, but of course it’s become one of THE metaphors. For me, the book about the white whale was MY white whale. So after I read it, I read books about it. I read a book about The Essex, the whaling ship The Pequod was based on. I even watched the movie In the Heart of the Sea. I got very involved.I bring this up now because of something Andy Miller says near the beginning of The Year of Reading Dangerously: shouldn’t some books, he asks, BE difficult? Shouldn’t they challenge you, throw up roadblocks you have to barrel through in order to get to the magic of the book. Miller argues yes. I’m still on the fence.That accomplishment I felt finishing Moby-Dick of course was due to the fact that I did have to fight my way through part of it. Miller actually includes Melville’s book on his List of Betterment, his chronological book mountain that also includes The Master and Margarita, Anna Kerenina, War and Peace, and more. While careful to avoid sounding snobbish (though he can’t help himself occasionally), Miller determines that reading books the old-fashioned way - on paper, with eyes and hands - is the best way to do things. And that if you train yourself away from the screen distractions like Twitter and Facebook and blogs about cheese or whatever, you can become the type of reader you probably tell people you already are.And it’s good. A lot of this is good. I do most of my book “reading” via audio, though I’ve read a clutch of physical books this year and at least one ebook. But I remember loving physical books, and sometimes I wish there was more time in my life to simply sit and dedicate myself to the pursuit. Miller also has a hugely busy life and he has done it, which of course makes me think I can, if I only apply myself. More, I’m suddenly interested in reading War and Peace, which might be my next white whale. Sorry, Herman.The Year of Reading Dangerously is, in measure, a pretty entertaining book about a man who got into a bunch of classic novels that engaged him and transformed him. Maybe that journey will happen for you. Maybe it’ll happen for me! But I’m still not sure I necessarily need to read, say, Bleak House to make my bones in the world of reading literature. It might help, but maybe it’s not necessary. And I wonder what it says that when I went looking for War and Peace tonight, I went looking for it on Audible. ...more

title: Something Wicked This Way Comes
author: Bradbury, Ray
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read Something Wicked This Way Comes for the first time at twenty-one. I’ve been a huge Stephen King fan all my life so I didn’t think books could sI read Something Wicked This Way Comes for the first time at twenty-one. I’ve been a huge Stephen King fan all my life so I didn’t think books could scare me. This one scared me so much I threw it across the room. Only two other books have scared me that badly: Jack Ketchum’s The Girl Next Door and William Goldman’s Marathon Man.I digress. I was a little afraid to reread this, because I knew I wouldn’t have the same perspective or feeling I did when I was 21. But it holds up pretty darn well. Bradbury’s occasionally flowery prose often works against him in short stories, but I generally like it in his novels. He just FEELS so HARD. And he wants you to feel just as hard.You know, I’d forgotten most of the stuff about growing up and growing old in this book, which is odd since it’s the entire backbone of the story. I just remembered Mr. Dark and being afraid. This time around, the themes of aging out of childhood and accepting adulthood were far more trenchant and vital. It’s not a horror story, but a story of childhood and adulthood where the real horror is being ashamed of the age you’re in. It could seem a little hokey. The fact that optimism and laughter is the best weapon against the dark seems a little trite on the surface. But Bradbury sells it, just like he sells every other aspect of this book. Stuff that absolutely shouldn’t work - a midnight fight with a balloon, for instance - works very well. Everything is so well intentioned, and so well meant, that sometimes it almost feels like a put-on. But Bradbury, for all his haunts and spooks and scares, is simply a nice person who populates his books with nice people who deserve nice things. Well, at least here. Fahrenheit 451 is a lot darker. But that’s a story for another day. ...more

title: Odd Adventures with your Other Father
author: Prentiss, Norman*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What’s the opposite of magical realism? Real magicism? That’s the closest I can come to categorizing Odd Adventures With Your Other Father. Not that iWhat’s the opposite of magical realism? Real magicism? That’s the closest I can come to categorizing Odd Adventures With Your Other Father. Not that it really needs categorization: it’s just a fantastic story, well-told.It’s also, I was a little surprised to find, about a gay couple in the 1980s, and their travels throughout America, framed in part as a series of stories told by one dad to his daughter. The last creepy story I read involving gay husbands with a daughter was the ultra-terrifying home invasion story The Cabin at the End of the World by Paul Tremblay. I was understandably hesitant.But while Odd Adventures has elements of horror, at its heart it’s a love story. Two men against the world, facing horrors that can occasionally be read as metaphors but that work equally well as fiction. The fact that these men are gay isn’t incidental and isn’t one of those “just happens to be gay” type stories. This basic fact of their identity follows them and haunts them across their trip through America, finding them in small towns and big cities that always seem to be testing their resolve. (Other stories are hinted at, and my only real complaint here is that I wanted to read those other stories, too.)But theirs is an uncommonly strong bond, one that trips irrevocably into the supernatural, and is made even stronger for it. That bond continues beyond even death, leaving us with a brilliant, satisfying ending I could never have predicted. Scary, sweet, and ultimately wonderful. I really loved this book....more

title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
author: Jackson, Shirley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** I'm spending my October reading spooky stuff, because I never met a theme month I didn't like. After reading Monster, She Wrote, it **spoiler alert** I'm spending my October reading spooky stuff, because I never met a theme month I didn't like. After reading Monster, She Wrote, it occurred to me that the only Shirley Jackson novel I'd read was The Haunting of Hill House, and that I'd really liked it, and that it was weird that I'd never read We Have Always Lived in the Castle, even though I'd owned the book since the 90s.I've rectified that now and I'm still a bit puzzled by the whole thing. It's a good puzzled, to be sure, but because I want to discuss this in depth, I'm hiding the  due to pretty massive spoilers. The book is magnificently written, and our narrator, Merricat Blackwood, is just barely this side of unreliable. She, her sister Constance, her disabled Uncle Julian, and her cat Jonas all live in the stately Blackwood house, which used to be more populous until the rest of the family was poisoned to death at dinner one night. We get this information slowly, the book sneaking up on it as the tension ratchets tighter and tighter. Constance, who had made dinner the night most of her family died, was tried and acquitted of the murders. There was arsenic in the sugar, you see; Catherine doesn't eat sugar, Merricat was sent to bed without dinner that night, and Uncle Julian had only taken a very little bit - leaving him paralyzed but alive. It's at this point that we begin suspecting our childlike narrator, Merricat, was actually the murderer ... but there are roadblocks in our way. There's the boorish intrusion of a cousin, Charles, who comes into the house and tries to take over. We kind of hope he gets poisoned, too. Three quarters of the way through, Uncle Julius drops the bomb that Merricat isn't actually alive - that she'd died in the orphanage of neglect while Constance was on trial. This doesn't seem to actually be the case - it goes against the book's internal logic - but it throws off any sense of surety of who these characters are and what, exactly, is happening in that house. Late in the book, the house is nearly destroyed in a fire, devastating Catherine but seeming to free Merricat. It's only here that we get confirmation that yes, young Merricat was the one who killed the rest of the family. By this point, the revelation isn't shocking ... but knowing the truth forces the reader to consider Merricat's narration and state of mind. I don't know if we ever get a sense of how old she is, but she consistently has a childlike concept of the world. Some people are mean and should die. Some people are nice and shouldn't. The way she'd murdered is clumsy and obvious, the way a child would do it. Merricat isn't cruel and she isn't precisely evil; her understanding of right and wrong is simply too skewed to make rational sense. This comes across most strikingly in the things she "isn't allowed" to do. She doesn't much mind that she'd murdered her whole family ... but she isn't allowed in Uncle Julius' room, so she never goes in there. Speaking of Uncle Julius, Merricat is constantly reminding herself to be nicer to him. Only after we get concrete proof that she tried to murder him and failed do these repetitions become more starkly horrifying. We end on a real downbeat note that pretends to be, in Merricat's view, the happiest moment ever. Catherine, who was deliberately spared from poisoning, is now locked in a crumbling house with a - psychopath? is that right? - and seems to think that much of it is her fault. We have to wonder at the mundanity of evil, and how it's allowed to perpetuate. While the horror at the heart of We Have Always Lived in the Castle may not be supernatural, we still end the book with virtual ghosts; we are forced to wonder if the true horror comes not from the actions of a person with a sick mind, or from those that enable that mind, and allow it to prosper....more

title: The Body: A Guide for Occupants
author: Bryson, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have been a Bill Bryson fan for quite some time. I first read A Short History of Nearly Everything when it came out, and I was stunned at how much II have been a Bill Bryson fan for quite some time. I first read A Short History of Nearly Everything when it came out, and I was stunned at how much I understood and liked science. I even understood string theory for a total of about six minutes. But it was something!I have been on the Bryson tip since then, usually with rewarding results. I have loved his books on travel, the English language, Shakespeare, and more. I couldn’t quite get into At Home, but I think I might want to retry that one, because I loved this book. It does everything that a listicle will do for your sense of understanding, but probes deeper and casts a wider net. It is so much more interesting than those pithy articles from the Internet.We get to almost all of it: birth and death, sight and taste, emotion and sex. Some of the historical names get lost in the morass, but that doesn’t matter so much if, when you’re reading it, it compels you this deeply. And indeed it compels, giving us history of communicable diseases, the dividing line between when a zygote becomes a baby, and how, exactly, my color blind eyes work.There should be a tendency to get grim. There are so many statistics, so many I don’t knows, that it might be simpler for Bryson to simply shrug and say science doesn’t know much. But one of Bryson’s strengths is that he loves to follow footnotes to sources. The Body is thorough; but that doesn’t mean it’s dry. I listened to the audiobook read by Bryson himself. I love his orating voice, and the way he emphasizes certain words in his half-British/half-American accent. He is very good at what he does here, in both delivery and content. If you really like Brysons earlier work, I highly recommend trying this one out. You won’t regret it....more

title: Nice Try: Stories of Best Intentions and Mixed Results
author: Gondelman, Josh
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay so, full disclosure: I know Josh Gondelman. This isn’t a humblebrag or starfuckery or a way to inflate my own stature in the world because I happOkay so, full disclosure: I know Josh Gondelman. This isn’t a humblebrag or starfuckery or a way to inflate my own stature in the world because I happen to know an Emmy-winning comedian/writer.I say it because most of this book exudes niceness, a quality too many of us conflate with being wishy-washy or bland. I told a friend of mine he was nice once and he took it as an insult. I don’t think Josh would take it as an insult. He actually addresses his niceness right up front, setting the stage for a whirlwind collection of personal essays that are at once exciting, fun, touching, and kind. He talks about why being nice is both important and sometimes a liability. Why “Nice Guy” can actually be code for a bro dude doing the bare minimum of performative good. And how balancing nice without losing yourself is difficult and worthwhile.I read a lot of books of essays by funny people, and some of them are acerbic and some are cutting, and there’s definitely a place for those. I like those qualities in other books. I’m just glad they aren’t part of this book.The essays are all compelling: he talks about the three origin stories of his relationship with his wife, and who gets to know which version. There’s one on the mysterious past of their adopted dog, Bizzy. Or the time he may or may not have tried MDMA. Gondelman, unlike one of my favorite essayists, Chuck Klosterman, made me care about sports in a moving, elegiacal tribute to his grandmother. And, unlike most every other book of essays by New Yorkers I’ve read in the past few years, there isn’t one on 9/11, which might be a bit of a relief.I listened to the audiobook version of this collection; Josh himself reads it, and it’s comforting to hear it all in his voice and inflection. It reminds me of his standup and storytelling from when he was laying his comedic foundations in the Boston comedy scene. One of the best things about the book is that you come away happy, because whether Josh is making you think or cry or laugh, it’s a joy to get insight into his life and his way of thinking. The only thing more satisfying than knowing Josh Gondelman, it turns out, is knowing him better....more

title: Messenger of Truth        (Maisie Dobbs, #4)
author: Winspear, Jacqueline*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: By the fourth book in a mystery series, the mysteries themselves - even if they're good - start mattering less than the characters you've been followiBy the fourth book in a mystery series, the mysteries themselves - even if they're good - start mattering less than the characters you've been following. Maybe that's true all the way through, but especially on book 4, when you go beyond the boundaries of a trilogy and start settling in for the long haul. It's a good thing Jacqueline Winspear gave us a clutch of memorable characters right from the start. Maisie Dobbs - and to a slightly greater extent, her assistant Billy Beale - come to emotional crossroads in Messenger of Truth, and all their decisions make sense, given what we already know of them.The interesting thing is, the plot of Messenger of Truth actually does impact, and hard. We're still dealing with shockwaves from World War I, and the horrors of that war keep revealing themselves to Maisie and the assembled crew. The whodunit aspect is interesting and the denoument is satisfying, but nowhere near as interesting or as morbidly exciting as the "what" of the thing - the missing art at the center of the book, and what its subject is, and what it means.One of the best aspects of the Maisie Dobbs series is how it captures a very specific time and place - England in the years after The Great War - a time and place I rarely thought of before now. WWII is the one that fascinates people, because of the obvious good vs evil conflict and the very real horrors of human suffering. But there was plenty of suffering in the first World War, and plenty of horror, and to find that here in the midst of a story about art theft and family politics should be jarring. But it's not, because the horror of war touches every part of this series, yet somehow manages to not drown in it. As always, I'm going to wait awhile before diving into the next book - not because I'm not interested, but because I want a little time to think about Maisie and Billy and the stuff they're dealing with, as we wend our way closer and closer to the madness of the next war, and how they'll react to that....more

title: The Institute
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Full disclosure: I’m a Stephen King nut. I have been since I was eleven. My Dad took me and my brother to see Pet Sematary, and my brother freaked outFull disclosure: I’m a Stephen King nut. I have been since I was eleven. My Dad took me and my brother to see Pet Sematary, and my brother freaked out and Dad took him to see another movie instead, leaving me there with Church and Jud and the Creeds. I was awestruck. Later that summer, Dad bought me the paperback. Since then, I’ve read every novel, every short story. Most books about him. Hell, I’ve written a bunch of books about him. So it’s an emotional connection. That said, I can be critical of the man. I re-read The Tommyknockers for the fifth time this year and it’s a solid three out of five star novel. It should have been edited better, but there’s such a solid tale underneath. So I can be critical. Then again, I have read The Tommyknockers five times.I said all that so I could say this: The Institute is the best book I’ve read so far this year.The plot is pretty simple: a brilliant kid named Luke is snatched from his home and brought to a facility in the middle of the night. There, he discovers he’s caged in with a bunch of other kids, all with one commonality: mild psychic abilities. Luke has TK - a very quiet form of Carrie White’s telekinetic power. Others are TP, kids with a smidge of telepathy. What the doctors of The Institute are using these kids for is a pretty damn good secret that we come to in due course. HOW they’re using these kids is another story. In short, they’re torturing them.There are obvious political parallels to draw here: these are kids in cages, after all, and those in authority have no compunction about whether they live or die. They’re not quite human to them. Of course, the kids use this to their advantage; if you’re beneath contempt, you’re beneath scrutiny. And sometimes that’s how revolutions start.I haven’t even talked about the novel’s parallel storyline, involving an ex-cop named Tim who winds up drifting into a small South Carolina town and becoming the town’s “night knocker,” an evocative term for an overnight beat cop. Tim’s a great Stu Redman/Dale Barbara character: a good guy with a rough past who’s trying to do well in his new circumstances. Eventually Luke and Tim’s paths cross, and wheels, King reminds us, turn inside wheels.Quite a few of Stephen King’s novels end almost happy, with the price our heroes have to pay too much and too hard for true optimism. That’s The Institute: there’s a lot of real loss inside this book, some that’s a little difficult to take. Is it worth it? In order to create the best book I’ve read in 2019? I’d say yes....more
