review: I read Sloane Crosley's newest book of essays, Look Alive Out There, last year, and fell pretty hard for it. I love books of personal essays - give meI read Sloane Crosley's newest book of essays, Look Alive Out There, last year, and fell pretty hard for it. I love books of personal essays - give me Klosterman, give me Irby, give me Sheffield (seriously, more Sheffield, all the time). The book was funny, sardonic, a little cutting and a lot compelling. At once, I began looking at her other books. Everyone - literally everyone who recognized Crosley's name - told me I had to read I Was Told There'd Be Cake. HAD to. It was a moral imperative. How dare I NOT have read it; me, a supposed reader! Further, how dare I read a DIFFERENT book by Crosley before picking up her seminal masterpiece? This is like owning Human Touch before buying Born to Run (GUILTY!)So I finally read it, and I really liked it. But I'm very fearful that I fell for the hype machine here. In my opinion, Crosley's become a better writer. I Was Told There'd Be Cake was quite good, and I was especially drawn to the final essay, in which she talks about the possibility of having a rare-ish blood disease. (Without spoilers, I will say that a very similar thing happened to me, with regards to a potential heart attack.) I also loved her take on being the maid of honor for a bride she didn't know very well anymore; it takes on the whole "Bridezilla" thing from a fresh perspective, looking at friendships between women and how they morph and change. I had to skip much of the essay on Crosley working in a butterfly exhibit in a museum; my overwhelming motteophobia actually forced me to pull over to the side of the road and, shuddering with revulsion, skip to the next chapter.Liking it wasn't the problem. It's that I'm comparing it to her later work, which I came into first, and which I liked more. While the essays in this one are very well-written and smart and funny, they feel like they were written at a bit of a remove; stories relayed from a close observer, rather than an active participant. There's nothing at all wrong with writing that way; I just missed the more intense internal focus of her later book.Of course, she has a second book of essays, How Did You Get This Number, that I want to now read immediately, bridging the gap between the old and new (plus a novel! It's called The Clasp! I'll read a novel!) If you've never read Crosley, I'd recommend starting here and then branching out. I'm worried this  sounds negative, and it absolutely shouldn't. I Was Told There'd Be Cake is very, very good, and points the way toward even better work in the future. ...more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's been some controversy over The Goldfinch receiving the Pulitzer Prize. Is it literature, or is it just fiction? Is it art, or is it just populThere's been some controversy over The Goldfinch receiving the Pulitzer Prize. Is it literature, or is it just fiction? Is it art, or is it just popular?The book itself makes the same argument, in part about the titular painting at its center. Tartt, through her troubled main character Theo Decker, asks a lot of intense, deep questions and doesn't really try to answer them. Does art matter? Does life matter? If everything is awful, what's the point of living? If everything is wonderful, what's the point of dying? Theo, and The Goldfinch, live uncomfortably with contradictions; everything is painful, but everything is beautiful, too.This is a book that absolutely should not compel. Theo is almost entirely unlikable, but it's not really his fault. Three of the most important catalysts of his life happen in the same violent instant: his mother dies, he is forged together with a girl named Pippa who will be his great absent love ... and he acquires the painting against which his entire life will be compared and contrasted. Like his mother and Pippa (the only two people he loves without complication) the painting is both itself and a symbol of the person Theo might be if he wasn't so busy being his own mostly ragged self.We follow Theo through his life. There are moments when it seems as if he will be drawn out of his terrible circumstances and move into something better, only to watch the rug be snatched out from under him. Only later do we sense that the awful things happen so that even more awful things do not; life, it appears, has a sense of humor, and Theo is often the butt of the joke. It's not that he plays Job, because when he's finally old enough to choose his own path, he chooses badly. It's that despite being a full-on fuckup for most of his existence, we still like Theo and want him to succeed, to do better, to be better. And maybe that happens. And even if it doesn't, it's one hell of a journey.The Goldfinch won the Pulitzer Prize, and the controversy seems to stem from the fact that it is a readable page-turner with pop-culture touchstones like Harry Potter and Lady Gaga. Real literature should be timeless, the naysayers seem to argue. But the best art, as Tartt and The Goldfinch argue, reaches up through time no matter when it's created, and dazzles us if we are receptive to being dazzled. The Goldfinch is a dazzling book. ...more

title: California Tiki: A History of Polynesian Idols, Pineapple Cocktails and Coconut Palm Trees
author: Henderson, Jason*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked up this slim history of California Tiki because of what it advertised: a rollicking jaunt through the culture, drinks, music, and aesthetic oI picked up this slim history of California Tiki because of what it advertised: a rollicking jaunt through the culture, drinks, music, and aesthetic of the whole Tiki thing. And I got that. And then it got way deeper than I expected.The book starts fun and breezy, talking about how Tiki culture emerged in California following WW2, when returning G.I.s were keen to bring back a slice of Polynesia with them. There’s talk of Thor Heyerdahl’s Kon-Tiki and James Michener’s Tales of the South Pacific. Standard touchstones.And then the book takes a bit of a deeper look into the world the returning G.I. was thrust into following the Second World War. The life of the Man in the Gray Flannel Suit, expected to return from the horrors of war and come home to an upwardly-mobile family and business life. We tend to think of PTSD as something more modern, but an entire generation felt it after the war, and had no means of coping with it. The institutions just weren’t there. So they invented escape in the concepts of half-remembered “exotic” refuges they found in the Pacific theater. This is tiki culture, along with tropical drinks and rattan, and it’s part of why I want to read more deeply on the subject. The authors bring up the specter of cultural appropriation - of the fact that tiki in America is mainly the invention of cis-straight white guys, and the fact that by utilizing the “exotic,” they other cultures that aren’t their own. But they also, rightly I believe, point out that tiki isn’t taking from a monoculture. It has some resemblance to actual Polynesia and Hawaii, but it really is a place made of imagination, as fantastical as Disneyland. “Tiki,” they argue, “is for everyone.”If I’ve made this book seem sloggy, it’s not. I learned a lot about exotica and surf music, about beach party movies and how to make the perfect Blue Hawaiian. There’s a lot of history packed into this small book, most of it oriented to pop culture, and most of it breezy. But an understanding of tiki isn’t complete without understanding its roots, and why it was so important to a generation who was still struggling to find its own identity, and so made one up....more

She argues against rulemongering, classism, and snobbery, all in the service of propping up the misunderstood punctuation. title: Where the Crawdads Sing
author: Owens, Delia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I hemmed and hawed about this one for awhile. It *seemed* like the kind of book I'd like, and I'd read the first few pages and they were compelling enI hemmed and hawed about this one for awhile. It *seemed* like the kind of book I'd like, and I'd read the first few pages and they were compelling enough. But for some reason, it didn't seem to insist on being read.That changed real quick the second I got past those first few pages. So, one of my favorite tropes in fiction is a person alone, finding a way to survive. When I was young, My Side of the Mountain (George) and Singularity (Sleator) were among my favorite books. (Singularity holds up; My Side is a little burdened by the weight of its status.) When I got older, it was Stephen King's The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon. So to find that this book was about a little girl named Kya who is abandoned in a shack in the marsh by a family too scared (or angry) to stay ... well, it was a revelation. Much of the fun and excitement of the book is in watching Kya figure out how to live in the marsh, and bring herself up. With the help of her friend Tate, she learns how to read, and develop a scientific mind. She never goes to school but she becomes brilliant. Most importantly, she never feels hemmed in by the marsh or her circumstances; her dedication to resilience is one of the more powerful aspects of this book. Interwoven through this narrative is the story of an investigation, set about a decade from Kya's introduction, of the possible murder of a local man named Chase Andrews. At first, I simply didn't care about the investigation. It just distracted from the awesome story of survival in the marsh. As the two timelines and storylines converged, though, they began to inform each other, illuminate one another. It's a stunning feat by author Delia Owens to intertwine these narratives together in a way that makes sense and that continues to deepen our knowledge and empathy for Kya, while still leaving room for mysteries.Revelations abound by the end of this book, and not just the ones you think you want to know. In the last couple pages, I was blindsided by the answer to a question I didn't know I had. Owens could have ended this book satisfactorily in a number of ways (even an unsatisfactory ending would have been satisfactory, he said in a cagey way you'll understand when you read it). But I'm so happy with the ending we got, and I'm so happy this book exists. Rich without being dense, filling without being heavy. Pretty damn perfect. ...more

title: Thinner
author: Bachman, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This has to be the fifth or sixth time I've read Thinner, and I always find new shades in it. The books Stephen King wrote under his Bachman pseudonymThis has to be the fifth or sixth time I've read Thinner, and I always find new shades in it. The books Stephen King wrote under his Bachman pseudonym are all marked by a hearty cynicism, and a deep indictment of modern society. The Bachman books generally focus on a single man, an outcast from society who refuses to play by society's rules and is punished for it. That doesn't hold for all seven of the Bachman books, but it's close enough. In Thinner, Billy Halleck is part of the society that makes the rules. He's a lawyer, he lives a comfortable - too comfortable - life, with a wife and daughter he loves. Then he accidentally kills a gypsy woman and gets away with it. The leader of the gypsy band finds Billy and whispers that titular word. And soon Billy Halleck is, in fact, getting thinner. King approaches gypsy curses in 1985 suburban America as he approached the concept of vampires in mid-70s rural America in 'Salem's Lot: as realistically as possible, while holding onto the tropes of myths and legends that came before. As with that earlier novel, King here uses the supernatural to examine the ills of society in a stunningly frank way. How quickly and effectively can a person go from being a have to a have-not? Is it as simple as going from too fat to too thin, or is there more at play? And what lessons, if any, can be learned on the fringes of the society you thought you knew so well.I love this book. I've always loved it, even though there's some squickiness in the premise. Is it racist to even write a book about gypsy curses? I'd argue no, given the way King fleshes out the Romany characters and makes them people, and given the fact that most of the book is an indictment of "polite Connecticut society." What I find most interesting is how Billy Halleck, who is put through the ringer here, SHOULD, in the course of his trials, learn real lessons he can then apply to the rest of his life. He learns the wrong lessons, and that's part of what makes Thinner one of King's bleakest novels.The other reason is that King, able to speak the worst truths as Bachman, argues that there IS no right lesson. Blame, guilt, rage - all those things always exist, and have to go somewhere. And if you're too cowardly to take it on, you have to pass it on. These are hard truths from an exciting and sort of fun book; they're also what elevate it, and make Thinner a book worth reading over and over again. ...more

title: Monster, She Wrote: The Women Who Pioneered Horror and Speculative Fiction
author: Kröger, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've been into a lot of books about horror lately. From Mallory O'Meara's The Lady from the Black Lagoon to Grady Hendrix's Paperbacks From Hell to thI've been into a lot of books about horror lately. From Mallory O'Meara's The Lady from the Black Lagoon to Grady Hendrix's Paperbacks From Hell to the spooky chapter of Gabrielle Moss' Paperback Crush, I've been kind of reflecting on the whole world of horror fiction and film. Most people think I'm this balls-to-the-wall horror nut because I love Stephen King, but the weird fact is, I mostly just like Stephen King. I like horror quite a bit (and I've read horror beyond King this year, and plan to read more), but I prefer crime fiction and "literary fiction" (or whatever you call what John Irving and Donna Tartt write). But horror as a thing excites me, and the history of pop culture stuff also excites me. So I was immediately drawn into Monster, She Wrote, a book delving into the deep and varied history of women writers of horror and dark fiction. Kröger and Anderson dive into the wayback, before even Mary Shelley and Frankenstein to lay down the lineage of the women who crawled so Anne Rice could run. One of the things about history that scares me is how completely stuff can be utterly lost. Because a lot of history has been written from a white male point of view, entire huge writing careers of women writers from the past - massively popular women writers from the past - can simply disappear. Look at someone as recent as Daphne DuMaurier, whose Rebecca and "The Birds" are bedrock fiction of the gothic and horror genres (in part because of two great Hitchcock films based on the work). For awhile, DuMaurier was also one of America's bestselling writers, hitting the #1 spot over and over and over. Nowadays, most readers have no idea who she is. And we're talking a twentieth century writer here! To say nothing of the lost careers of women in centuries past. This book is a step toward rectifying all that.I liked how the authors also delved into "lit" writers like Joyce Carol Oates and Toni Morrison, who still write horror even when they're being nominated for Pulitzers, and I was surprised how up-to-the-second the book is (included is a discussion of Oyinkan Braithwaite's My Sister, the Serial Killer, which I just read like THIS YEAR). I honestly thought this book would stop somewhere in the 70s, probably because that's where Stephen King's Dance Macabre - another great history of horror - stopped, and I'm conflating the time before I was born with what "history" is. So, welcome to my self-absorbed point of view.If you're interested in horror fiction, women's fiction, women's horror fiction, fiction, writing, or history, I can recommend this book. It's punchy and fun to read, while also delving deep enough into every author so that you come away wanting to read pretty much everything mentioned. Even if you like horror less than everyone thinks you do. ...more

title: Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend
author: Orlean, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At one point late in Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend, Susan Orlean laments the sad truth that "we outlive our dogs." An odd sentiment in a book tAt one point late in Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend, Susan Orlean laments the sad truth that "we outlive our dogs." An odd sentiment in a book that spends over three hundred pages proving the opposite.I am a little loath to admit that I never really cared about Rin Tin Tin in my life. He didn't make an impression on my childhood, as he had Orlean's. My childhood was more about cartoon pups: Scooby-Doo and Snoopy, and Copper from The Fox and the Hound. If I wanted to take a trip in the Wayback Machine, Nick at Nite was more than happy to provide Lassie reruns for me. So why did I pick this one up? I read Orlean's The Library Book late last year and fell in love with the writing. Jeopardy! had a clue on this book and my immediate thought was, "Huh. I should read more from her." So, despite me not caring about the subject of her book, I bought this and dove in.Boy, am I glad I did! The book is very much about Rin Tin Tin, both the real dog rescued from the battlefields of World War I by caretaker (and Rinty's best friend) Lee Duncan, as well as the dog as a concept. It's this second idea that Orlean seems to find most fascinating as the book marches on, the idea of what makes a name, what makes a legacy, and who can lay claim to it. What matters most: the dog or the idea of the dog? How much is dependent on bloodlines, on perception, on how deeply embedded in our collective consciousness this dog is? Orlean doesn't truck with easy answers. She asks questions, and then ponders whether answers are necessary. It's also the story of a hundred years in America, starting before World War I and ending somewhere in the early 2000s. One of the most exciting throughlines is in how stars are made and perpetuated: from silent films through talkies, radio and television, merchandising and traveling nostalgia shows, Orlean tackles the ins and outs of pop culture stardom through the history of modern entertainment. Sometimes you forget you're reading about a dog (or dogs) and simply think - as early newspapers did - as Rin Tin Tin as an actor whose legacy has left a lasting mark. Along the way, Orlean gets to something even meatier: what drives people on the path of singular interests and obsessions? What makes a person so focused on a single interest that all else pales in comparison? The caretakers of Rin Tin Tin, those people who want the dog to live forever, are examined closely, but it's really a question for anyone whose hobby becomes more than a hobby. Orlean turns that question around on herself a few times, and wonders if her own interest in this long-ago dog is all that different from Lee Duncan's.I didn't care about Rin Tin Tin before picking up this fascinating, perfect book. Now I do. So the legacy, at least a tiny little corner of it, lives on....more

title: Step by Step: A Pedestrian Memoir
author: Block, Lawrence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When you're a big fan of a prolific novelist, it's sometimes difficult to picture them enjoying other stuff. You tend to have this image of them, huncWhen you're a big fan of a prolific novelist, it's sometimes difficult to picture them enjoying other stuff. You tend to have this image of them, hunched over typewriters or keyboards, pounding away at whatever novel comes next. When they're not writing, they're reading, absorbing the work of so many others so that it recombines and reconfigures and adds and subtracts and becomes something brand new. When Stephen King releases On Writing, it makes sense. I wasn't prepared for a book on race-walking by Lawrence Block.I love Block. His three recurring-character series focusing on Keller (the hit man), Scudder (the PI), and Bernie Rhodenbarr (the gentleman burglar) have managed to fill the Spenser-sized void in my life for the past few years. I've enjoyed a lot of his one-offs, especially Getting Off and Defender of the Innocent and The Girl With the Deep Blue Eyes. More, I've liked Block's books about writing - his approach to the craft and how he's worked to perfect it. When, in his latest newsletter, Block entreated fans to take a listen to the new audio version of his memoir about footraces and let him know what we thought, well, I was game but skeptical. I don't care about running races. I live in Boston and the Marathon is interesting, but I don't really pay that much attention. How was I going to care about a long book, whose audio version wasn't even read by Block himself, about a subject I care nothing about?Here's why: because it's not a book about race-walking (a sort of hybrid type of racing that's not running but not quite the power-walking, either), not really. It's a book about experience, and determination, and self-will. It's also a book about an old writer who considers himself, questions his origins as he explicates them, but, almost paradoxically, refuses to ponder deeply the reasons why he races, and why he walks.Block's brilliance in this book is in not bogging the work down with detailed descriptions of the same sorts of races over and over. Once we understand what race-walking is, and what a standard race (or half-marathon, or marathon) is, we move along; subsequent similar races are summed up. We're here for the surmounting achievements, the way that Block, in his upper 60s, pushes past his own barriers and wins on his own terms. There's also a lengthy, alternately serious and hilarious segment focusing on Block and his wife Lynn's walk across Spain via the Camino de Santiago. Block brings his trademark wit and casually nonstop storytelling to this section; one of my favorite parts was in how Block and Lynn maintained their sobriety by holding impromptu meetings daily, and during stressful moments along their journey. If you're a fan of Matt Scudder, you know how important the meetings can be; for some reason, I never quite connected Scudder's sobriety with Block's; here, it makes perfect sense.The meetings become an integral part of Block's denoument, as well. Near the end of Step By Step, Block finds himself losing touch and verve with the things that brought him the most pleasure, especially the three Rs: writing, reading, and racing. I won't say what the outcome is, or exactly how the meetings play a part, because Block is better at telling it than I am at summing it up. That's another thing: Block's writing - always accessible and exciting and often plain-spoken - is simply magnificent here. Despite me saying that this book isn't really about racing or race-walking, there are quite a few moments in which Block offers stats on his run/walk times. The fact that he can make that interesting and not feel bogged down in numbers is a testament to the quality of the man's prose.One thing about the audio: it's always a little weird listening to the audiobook of a memoir not read by the author. You can get bogged down in the "wait, YOU didn't do this in your childhood; you weren't even BORN yet." It can be especially odd if you've heard the author read any of their other books, and like what you've heard (as I have with Block, whose craggy, New York inflections give some of his audiobooks a flavor and verisimilitude I love). That said, narrator Michael Bonner gets you past those preconceptions very quickly. He has his own take on Block's pauses and asides that are almost immediately charming, and by the time you're on the Camino, the tenor of Bonner's voice has woven into Block's recollection so well that you forget it's not Block speaking to you.You don't have to like racing, or walking as a sport, to like this book, though it may help. You don't have to like Lawrence Block's novels to like this book, though it will give you some flavor and a sense of his greater struggle with writer's block. All you have to like is a tale well told, and on that measure, Step By Step is anything but pedestrian. ...more

title: Bee Season
author: Goldberg, Myla*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I worked at one of the many bookstores, I avoided this one because (and I did no research here) I thought it was about beekeeping. What finally sWhen I worked at one of the many bookstores, I avoided this one because (and I did no research here) I thought it was about beekeeping. What finally spurred me into reading it was the realization that it was about spelling bees. Dur!Only ... it’s not really about that, either. It’s about a family of four and the very, very different ways they uncover their spirituality. If that sounds dull or off-putting, trust me that it’s not. Goldberg has an exciting and energetic way of allowing readers into these characters’ spiritual and religious journeys without ever feeling like she’s pandering or proselytizing. Even the character whose entire religion is based on theft and mental illness seems sound enough when you’re in their head. But Goldberg doesn’t condemn, only reveals; what, she occasionally seems to ask, is a person’s relationship to their spiritual self if not a sort of mental aberration from the norm? All four of these characters - married couple Saul and Miriam, their teenage son Aaron, and tween Eliza - find God (or a reasonable facsimile) in radically different ways ... but all, in the end, in selfish ways that end up hurting others.What’s fascinating is that all four of these people could seem terrible - and often do seem terrible from others’ perspective - but Goldberg compels you into their stories and their actions and you can’t hate any of them. The ordering of letters into words - the backbone of modern communication - is where this book starts. As Bee Season attests, once you start breaking words down into components, start hoarding your communication and keeping it secret, it gets harder and harder to put it all back together again.I loved this book....more

title: Not Comin' Home to You
author: Block, Lawrence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Having read nearly all of Lawrence Block's major series (Keller, Rhodenbarr, Scudder), and his more recent one-offs and collections (Resume Speed, TheHaving read nearly all of Lawrence Block's major series (Keller, Rhodenbarr, Scudder), and his more recent one-offs and collections (Resume Speed, The Girl with the Deep Blue Eyes), I've been delving deeper into his back catalog. Some of these excursions have paid off excitingly: Getting Off, about a serial killer who chooses her victims based on her past sexual experience, was thrilling. Grifter's Game - a Hard Case Crime book - was similarly exciting, as was Deadly Honeymoon. There's a lot more Block I love than Block I don't love.But I didn't love this one.It's based loosely on the Starkwether/Fugate spree killings of the 1950s, with a couple of kooky kids named Jimmy John and Betty standing in for the real-life folks. That's sort of the problem. It doesn't seem to get beyond that, most of the time. This is a "ripped from the 20-year-ago headlines" story, based on real events and then sprinkled with fiction dust ... but you rarely get the sense that these people are real and not just playing parts. Some moments elevate the story: a sex scene at the site of a multiple homicide is grisly and horrifying; Jimmy John's reluctance to kill animals as he's killing people almost arbitrarily; a quiet domestic scene where we can see who these kids might be if they weren't criminals. Good scenes that hint at Block's future mastery of the form. But for me, the best part of the book was the afterword, where Block talks about Terence Malick's Badlands, which came out as his screenplay adaptation of Not Comin' Home to You was being shopped around. I'm a sucker for writers talking about the history of their fiction, and I was a sucker for this revealing afterword. Long story short: it's a fairly good, fast read from one of the nation's best writers. ...more

title: The Bookshop of Yesterdays
author: Meyerson, Amy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am a sucker for bibliolit. If a book has pictures of books on the cover, if there's a promise of people reading or writing, if there's a bookstore (I am a sucker for bibliolit. If a book has pictures of books on the cover, if there's a promise of people reading or writing, if there's a bookstore (or, even better, a bookSHOP) featured, I'm all in. I was immediately drawn to Meyerson's Bookshop of Yesterdays with the promise of a woman with a past she didn't know was shrouded in doubt, a bookshop in trouble, and a dead uncle who left behind a series of clues and riddles for his favorite niece to puzzle together and unveil a major secret. All these elements are elements that set my brain tingling. But there's one problem with the novel, and it's a pretty big one:The main character.Miranda should be compelling. Her parents are keeping secrets from her about her uncle. She loves reading. She has an interestingly complicated relationship with her boyfriend. They're both history teachers. When she's handed this mystery in the wake of her uncle's death, she springs to solving it. But she's ... she's not really likable. Worse, she's not all that compelling. Okay, so full disclosure. I'm a white gay dude writing this . There's a whole thorny issue of someone like me saying that a female main character isn't likable. But it's that compelling thing that I keep coming back to. She's at the center of the novel, so we're supposed to believe her when she tells us that everyone thinks she's just great. But her behavior is kind of appalling. She furiously snaps at anyone who doesn't fall in line. She's understandably upset at her slacker boyfriend, but she seems to get mad at the wrong stuff. She treats the people in the bookshop badly, and while some react accordingly, it's only temporary. Within pages, everyone loves her again. I didn't really get why.Look, here's the thing: Miranda is grieving. I know she's grieving. And grief makes people lash out. But when you lash out constantly at every person, it gets dull. Especially when they immediately forgive you. Near the end, Miranda makes two life-altering choices that made me want to cheer for her; they're be choices that might shade an enjoyable character with an edge, even as we recognize they're the right decisions. But for Miranda, they just seem like par for the course. What's most frustrating is that every single other character is more interesting. I would love to see this book told from the point of view of Miranda's rising-star best friend. Or her mother. Or the famous author she befriends. Or Malcolm, the gruff dude who was Uncle Billy's best friend. Either of the baristas. Anyone. In measure, I liked the book in spite of Miranda instead of because of her, which is faint praise but praise nonetheless. I'm interested in reading what Meyerson does next....more

title: Where'd You Go, Bernadette
author: Semple, Maria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** I had no idea what to expect from this book. I’m glad.Here are the basics: it’s about a woman named Bernadette Fox, a once-famous ar**spoiler alert** I had no idea what to expect from this book. I’m glad.Here are the basics: it’s about a woman named Bernadette Fox, a once-famous architect who may or may not be currently going through a break with reality. It’s also about her daughter, Bee, and her husband, Elgie. They live in Seattle, a predicament Bernadette is extremely discomfited by. The neighbors hate her. Her husband feels alienated from her. And Bee, her best friend, wants to go with her family to Antarctica.From these basic foundations, the book twists and turns expertly, following plot threads and character motivations for a time before more information reveals itself and everything shifts. A lot of this book is epistolary, which seems a little gimmicky until it absolutely doesn’t. Is Bernadette crazy? Maybe. How about Bee? Another maybe. Because nothing is as simple as pat answers. The brilliant title is open to so many interpretations, all of them fascinating, only some of them literal. I read this and Charlotte Ng’s Little Fires Everywhere almost back to back; both are about complicated, interesting people in hard situations, and both are brilliantly written. But I think they come to opposite conclusions: Little Fires starts optimistically and doesn’t really end that way; most people, it argues, are often too flawed to recognize their best selves. Bernadette presents us with complicated, often terrible people, and eventually comes to the conclusion that most people are generally good. I loved reading both, but I ended Bernadette with a smile on my face....more

title: Paperback Crush: The Totally Radical History of '80s and '90s Teen Fiction
author: Moss, Gabrielle*

review: I randomly ran into this author on Twitter, and she was funny so I looked at her profile, found that she wrote this book, and immediately bought it foI randomly ran into this author on Twitter, and she was funny so I looked at her profile, found that she wrote this book, and immediately bought it for myself and my friend Tracey. I'd say for every 3 books I give Tracey, she likes one of them, which I think is a good track record. She LOVED this one, and read it in a single sitting. Already my anticipation was high.Tracey and I came up on a lot of the same books. More of our commonalities seemed geared younger (Taking Care of Terrific, by Lowry, the whole Judy Blume oeuvre, our constant and consistent discussion over whether Beverly Cleary's Dear Mr. Henshaw is a work of genius or not [ps it is]). But we were both rabid for The Baby-Sitter's Club, and we had both read the tragic Ghosts of Departure Point individually and talked about it obsessively in our early friendship.She read broader in YA lit than I did, so this book was definitely more geared to her than me. (My favorite YA novels of all time - Haunted, by Judith St. George and Singularity, by William Sleator, weren't mentioned in here. It's not the fault of the author. The YA horror chapter had a lot to cover and just because my seminal works aren't discussed doesn't mean the book is really missing something.) But what I didn't know, I loved hearing about. I knew nothing about Sweet Valley High books except that one of them was the good girl and one was a psychopath, so hearing a little more about their exploits was fun. Ditto the whole subsection of Lurlene McDaniel and her sick-lit books. I'd heard of Lurlene due to listicles and Buzzfeed nostalgia, but this one offered a deeper understanding of the genre and McDaniel's place in it. And even that was fun. That's the whole book: fun, through and through.This was like a YA lit version of Grady Hendrix's Paperbacks From Hell, talking about a subgenre of 70s-90s paperback fiction and delving deeper than I did. Moss's chatty prose and semi-frequent asides are the best way to present this material, but she can also turn serious and scholarly when the material demands it (especially when discussing the lack of diversity in these books). I listened to the audio and missed the book cover reproductions, and will thus have to buy the physical book as well. It's going to be money well-spent, in my opinion. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was so beautiful.I know that’s kind of weird to say about a novel with such sadness in it. It’s a book about mothers and children, about whaThis book was so beautiful.I know that’s kind of weird to say about a novel with such sadness in it. It’s a book about mothers and children, about what makes a family, about the choices we make that stray us from the people we think we are. Every character - from the sweet, innocent Moody to the secretive Mia to the blandly diabolical Mrs. Richardson - has hidden sides, and layers to their personalities that are not immediately apparent. A shallow girl has remarkable depth an compassion; a petulant agent of chaos is kind and thoughtful; a good kid turns his love into hate at the worst possible moment. Every one is worth reading about. And I haven’t even touched on the trenchant court case at the center (and, oddly, at the fringes) of this book. It’s funny how your loyalties shift from side to side, because it’s surprisingly difficult to fault any character for her or his choices.It’s beautiful because the characters are so well-drawn and uniformly smart and interesting. But it’s also the language Ng uses, the vividness of her scene painting and talk about art and people and love. I loved this book, even as I’m haunted by it....more

title: Daisy Jones & The Six
author: Reid, Taylor Jenkins*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I like books about rock and roll, but I generally tend toward the nonfiction side. Most novels about rock can’t seem to communicate exactly how songs I like books about rock and roll, but I generally tend toward the nonfiction side. Most novels about rock can’t seem to communicate exactly how songs and music make you feel, and what’s it’s like to be inside the music. I wrote two books about rock and roll - one fiction, one non - and I know how difficult that is. I think Mark Childress’ Tender has come closest to the mark.Until Daisy Jones & the Six. I’d been hearing the buzz and it’s a Reece Witherspoon pick, and for whatever reason, she and I seem to have the same taste in books. Almost immediately after I fired up the audio, I nearly stopped it. An oral history? I’m sort of meh on oral history stories. I honestly don’t know why. But I stuck with this one because I’d just heard Rob Sheffeild’s short bio on Stevie Nicks and I wanted to keep that sort of party going. I’m so glad I did. Daisy Jones & the Six is about rock and roll chaos and excess ... and is also very much about the stuff underneath all that. What promises mean, how creativity sparks, and the age-old question of what happens when you love someone more than anything and they can’t or won’t love you back? That last question is at the core of the whole book, and it applies to more than Daisy Jones and Billy Dunn, lead writers and singers, who might hate each other and who might love each other, or both, or neither. What’s most fascinating about this is that you think, as in some books about rock, that there’s going to be this undercurrent of, “yeah, this stuff is all fun for awhile, but eventually we’re all going to have to grow up and have families.” There’s some of that, but the book is very careful to posit that as ONE of the options, and that some of the others are viable and tenable. Rock and roll CAN be healthy and it CAN destroy. It’s all about what you’re bringing to the table.It’s a fantastic book; if you can, I recommend getting it on audio, because the voices really made it for me. Jennifer Beals and Benjamin Bratt are absolutely fantastic readers, as is the rest of the cast (shout-out to Judy Greer, my favorite voice on here). The author, Taylor Jenkins Reid, has been publishing since 2013; time to see what else she’s written....more

title: The Wild Heart of Stevie Nicks
author: Sheffield, Rob
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We're only two books in, but I think I'm in love with Rob Sheffield's pocket biographies of classic rock singers.Honestly, I don't know if he's planniWe're only two books in, but I think I'm in love with Rob Sheffield's pocket biographies of classic rock singers.Honestly, I don't know if he's planning on more, but I sure hope so. His On Bowie, written in the wake of David Bowie's sad passing, firmly set the tropes in place: some scant pre-career biographical information, a glancing look at the rise to fame, and then a deep dive into the big moments. These books are short and punchy and Sheffield knows what we came here to read about. Or, because this is an Audible original, hear about.Stevie Nicks just got inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame as a solo artist, the first woman to be inducted twice, so it's with a sense of ceremony that Sheffield launches into this engaging tale of Nicks' life in and out of Fleetwood Mac. We get it all: recording Rumours, the Rolling Stone album cover that led to one of Stevie's clandestine affairs, the making up, the breaking up, the cocaine, the shawls. All of it is relentlessly positive, even when discussing Nicks' long, dark, Benzo-induced haze; Sheffield allows these books to be tributes rather than takedowns, and he never met a lyric he couldn't spin into a profound paragraph closer. It takes a special and specific talent to glide over a full career in such a short span of words, capturing the grandeur and sweep of a life lived in rock, and dipping down only when it's most important and relevant. I've long loved Sheffield's music-focused memoirs (Love is a Mixtape; Talking to Girls About Duran Duran; Turn Around, Bright Eyes), but these small bios (and I could even include his very good Dreaming the Beatles in this) really pop. Now I'm just holding out for a Springsteen one. ...more

title: Save Me the Plums: My Gourmet Memoir
author: Reichl, Ruth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ruth Reichl kickstarted my love of food writing (mostly; Julie & Julia came just slightly before). Coming off my year of learning how to cook French fRuth Reichl kickstarted my love of food writing (mostly; Julie & Julia came just slightly before). Coming off my year of learning how to cook French food (I did okay, sticking mainly to peasant stuff that's been elevated in recent years in the US), I was hungry for some more thoughtful discussion about food. On a whim in the aughts, I picked up Reichl's memoir Tender at the Bone and fell in love with the words she used for cooking, eating, and savoring food. I was shocked at how forthright she was about the stuff I was ignorant about, especially stuff about butchering that I'd very carefully avoided thinking about in order to remain an omnivore. She made me think about it. I'm still an omnivore.Ruth's following books narrowed in focus - Comfort Me with Apples was just as good, but more inward-looking, and Garlic and Sapphires was all about the lengths she went through to disguise herself when she was ing for the New York Times. Great writing and fascinating, but slightly less accessible. I can't remember if I read her memoir about her mother, but it seems I must have.Save Me the Plums seemed at first like it might be Reichl's least accessible book yet. It was all about her running Gourmet, a high-class magazine for gourmands. I knew it wasn't going to be pretentious or anything because that's not how Reichl operates, but I worried that I wouldn't be as interested on the day-to-day of running a fancy-food magazine aimed at people who were a lot richer than me. I bought it anyway because I liked Reichl's writing, and she was reading her own audiobook. It's pretty damn fabulous, and it reminded me of a few things: 1. Most people, no matter how fancy they seem, are concerned about the same stuff. Is my kid eating right? Am I going to get this job I really want? What if I fuck up on the job? Is my new boss going to be a jerk? Am I being true to myself? Reichl tackles all these things and more, being up front about her anxieties and insecurities, but also about those moments when she took big risks to make her creative endeavor more exciting and relevant. And 2. Why was I so concerned about accessibility? I've read Michael Crichton novels. I've read hard SF. If a story - fiction or not - is well-written, ANYTHING can be accessible. Save Me the Plums absolutely is. And now I want those pancakes....more

title: Best. Movie. Year. Ever.: How 1999 Blew Up the Big Screen
author: Raftery, Brian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love movie-year exegeses. Mark Harris' Pictures at a Revolution is the gold standard, tackling the five 1967 Oscar nominees for best picture - the hI love movie-year exegeses. Mark Harris' Pictures at a Revolution is the gold standard, tackling the five 1967 Oscar nominees for best picture - the hows and whys. Raftery's book does the same thing with 1999, a year I remember thinking was kind of a big deal at the time. The author doesn't generally focus on the Oscar nominees for Best Picture (and in fact calls one - The Cider House Rules, basic fake-highbrow Oscar bait. What's interesting about that is that I just read an entire book on the making of The Cider House Rules, and it was pretty damn controversial itself, with its pro-abortion stance). What he does focus on are the stories behind the big-budget blockbusters and small-budget indies that changed movies.The Blair Witch Project. The Best Man. Fight Club. The Iron Giant. Being John Malkovich. Election. Rushmore. American Beauty. American Pie. Boys Don't Cry. Magnolia. Star Wars Episode 1: The Phantom Menace. The Insider. The Matrix. Eyes Wide Shut. The Sixth Sense. All movies that signaled all these mini-revolutions in Hollywood in beyond. The found-footage genre began. Major directors who changed everything in the previous generation were met with confusion and derision (Kubrick and Lucas). Black movies that weren't about violence and drugs began making inroads (The Best Man, The Wood). Completely new types of filmmaking entered the conversation - The Matrix - and with them, new voices and directions making their mark. I loved almost all of what Raftery had to say here; some of these films in 1999 are my favorite movies ever (Magnolia and Blair Witch and maybe Fight Club). Everything is reported with enthusiasm, but not fanboy churlishness. I also liked the way Raftery uses the Wachowski sisters' (and Brandon Teena's) correct names and pronouns, even when discussing the past. And I loved hearing all these background stories of all these great movies (and not-so-great movies) I want to watch again....more

title: The Lady from the Black Lagoon: Hollywood Monsters and the Lost Legacy of Milicent Patrick
author: O'Meara, Mallory*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was young - seven or eight - my Dad and I used to watch Creature Double Feature on Channel 38. Usually these were city-destroying monster movieWhen I was young - seven or eight - my Dad and I used to watch Creature Double Feature on Channel 38. Usually these were city-destroying monster movies like Godzilla or King Kong, but I know the Gill-Man showed up a few times. Later on, the Creature from the Black Lagoon showed up in an awesome cheesy movie called The Monster Squad, and that’s when I fell in love with him. As a teenager into horror, I got this whole collection of glow in the dark monsters, and the Gill-Man was my favorite. He was even in It, my favorite novel of all time.Specific behind-the-scenes names of horror and monster movies never really stuck (despite me being a longtime Fangoria reader), but artists and designers who did - like Bernie Wrighton, Tom Savini, and Rick Baker - were all men. This didn’t really strike me as strange; for the longest time, I was under the impression that those jobs were just ones men did. I’ve grown up a little since then, but that didn’t change the reality that the most celebrated names were men.So it stunned me that the person who created the Gill-Man was a woman named Millicent Patrick (at least sometimes). It was similarly stunning when I discovered that Linda Fennimore created the cover for Stephen King’s Pet Sematary, or when I found out that Joann Daley was the artist behind the Creepshow movie poster. I want to get to a point where I’m not stunned by this stuff.Mallory O’Meara’s book is a great guidebook for that. She details the story of Millicent Patrick’s life in and out of monster movies, and shines a light on the rampant misogyny and privilege enjoyed by the industry. How Patrick’s career was derailed by one man’s bruised ego, how she was disowned by her family for daring to be an artist in Hollywood, and how her legacy was obscured for decades. This book brings that legacy to light, along with - almost incidentally - showcasing a number of other talented and forgotten women of Patrick’s time who also forged their own path and made themselves successes.I also loved the way that O’Meara brought herself into the narrative, as well as sharing how difficult and fun the research was. For a book all about the hard work of creation that people don’t acknowledge, it makes sure you know what went into its own creation. It made the book even more fascinating, and rewarding....more

title: The Talisman
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is probably my fifth go-round on The Talisman, the very first collaboration between Stephen King and another author (in this instance, Peter StraThis is probably my fifth go-round on The Talisman, the very first collaboration between Stephen King and another author (in this instance, Peter Straub). I remember when I got it, too. My uncle Dave took me to New York City for the first time when I was fourteen, and he brought me to this gigantic mega-bookstore, because they still had those in 1989. He told me I could pick out anything in the store, so I picked out this book and Art Speigleman's Maus. It was a raucous trip to the bookstore.One of the last audiobooks on cassette I ever bought was this book, right before cassettes were no longer a thing. I've owned my audiobook of The Talisman since Frank Muller recorded it; it was one of the last things he did before his motorcycle accident. And yet I only just listened to it now. One of the things that an audiobook can do is stretch out the time of a book. Sometimes, when you're in a repetitive or dull section, you can skim a little bit until your eye catches on something good. Nothing in The Talisman was quite like that, but it's one of Stephen King's and Peter Straub's longest novels, and by the end, I was definitely feeling the weight of all those pages. There are about three or four climaxes of the book, and while that's not necessarily bad - all of them are earned, and all of them feel necessary - I eventually grew a tiny bit fatigued. It's funny; when I remember the book, it's usually as a fantasy adventure novel with some scary stuff. That it is! But it's also kind of a brutal book, intent on testing our hero Jack Sawyer along a road of trials that only ends with the last lines of the book. I loved his spunk and tenacity, and Straub and King do give him a few breaks, but MAN is this kid put through the ringer. Which, I suppose, is the point.I do love this book. I think I love it even more now, because Muller's reading made me slow down and digest everything that happened. There's a lot, and most of it's fantastically well-written. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this to anyone....more

author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: John Irving is one of my favorite novelists, but I haven't read much of his nonfiction. He might not HAVE much available nonfiction, but I always enjoJohn Irving is one of my favorite novelists, but I haven't read much of his nonfiction. He might not HAVE much available nonfiction, but I always enjoy his forewords and afterwords to his novels. I like novelists with introspection. I had passed this slim book by more than once, and even now I don't know why. My journey with John Irving began with The Cider House Rules. The film was coming out in fewer than two weeks, and my friend Tracey and I challenged each other to finish the book before we went out to see it. I had never read a book like Cider House Rules (likely because I'd never read any Dickens), but I immediately fell for the author's way with words, his dialogue, his semicomic situations. I plowed through Cider House ... and then was hugely underwhelmed by the movie.I was mad about every change, especially the wholesale elimination of Melony (a hugely important character) from the whole thing. I didn't think Michael Caine deserved the award for Best Supporting Actor (I was holding out for Haley Joel Osment in Sixth Sense, Michael Clarke Duncan in The Green Mile, or Tom Cruise in Magnolia). Now, looking back, I may have unfairly maligned the film. Reading My Movie Business, that seems all but assured.I loved hearing the behind-the-scenes stuff about movies based on Irving's books, even the stuff that kind of makes him seem like a jerk (one insight: Rob Lowe was a hot teen actor; Jodie Foster was not). My biggest wish is that the book didn't end with the wrapping of the film. I wanted to see how Irving reacted to the popularity of it, winning an Oscar, etc. etc. You always try to rate art on what's there rather than what isn't, but this seems like a missed opportunity. (Caveat: there is some fictionalized discussion of this in Until I Find You, but it's not the same). All in all, I liked this book a lot, and it's always good to "discover" a work by a writer you love that you haven't yet dug into. Which reminds me, I've never read Setting Free the Bears. Time to jump in to that pre-Garp world! ...more

review: A good, punchy book about some of the more hard-to-grasp concepts of astrophysics, including stuff like dark matter, quasars, the way gravity works beA good, punchy book about some of the more hard-to-grasp concepts of astrophysics, including stuff like dark matter, quasars, the way gravity works between celestial objects, and more. title: Bruce Springsteen: The Stories Behind the Songs
author: Hiatt, Brian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've been a Bruce Springsteen fan for over half my life. I got into him during the lull between Human Touch/Lucky Town and The Ghost of Tom Joad. ThisI've been a Bruce Springsteen fan for over half my life. I got into him during the lull between Human Touch/Lucky Town and The Ghost of Tom Joad. This gave me ample time to scour Springsteen's back catalog, starting with Nebraska, then Tunnel of Love, then everything else, all at once.A lot of that back catalog has been covered; books like Glory Days and Springsteen's own Born to Run tend to focus on the years between Springsteen's origin story and the Brucemania of the 80s. Coverage drops off precipitously after that, despite Springsteen's return to massive popularity with The Rising and beyond. This book rectifies that, giving ample time to Springsteen's well-trod history and shining some light on newer work and recordings that have gotten lost in the shuffle of an epic career.Hiatt digs deep into what makes the early songs so significant, offering backstory and the occasional technical note. Through an impressive array of interviews with band members, engineers, and more, he's able to shade these stories with information and expertise from all sides ... even if some memories don't always match up to others. Casual fans will be impressed by the full sweep of Bruce Springsteen's career; hardcore aficionados will find so much unearthed history to pore over and discuss, it's like discovering these songs anew.For someone who came into the Springsteen "thing" later in the game, a book like this is necessary. I love how later work - especially controversial work like Working on a Dream - is covered objectively and with curiosity. One of the best books on Springsteen I've ever read, and one of the best books on music in the ever-growing corpus....more

title: Pardonable Lies        (Maisie Dobbs, #3)
author: Winspear, Jacqueline*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm a huge fan of the Maisie Dobbs mysteries. Set in England in the years following The Great War, these books have a grim bedrock but with a resourceI'm a huge fan of the Maisie Dobbs mysteries. Set in England in the years following The Great War, these books have a grim bedrock but with a resourceful, brilliant character at their core. With Pardonable Lies, Maisie learns that some truths are not absolute, and she has to decide what she wants to believe, and what she wants others to believe.Which sounds kind of fraught for what is really an entertaining and memorably gritty outing in the series. We've got some contemporary social issues that Winspear manages to work into this story of the early 1900s; some codebreaking; mysterious people trying to kill her (literally everyone is trying to kill her); and of course Maisie facing her own demons she keeps trying to tell herself she left behind in the war. I wouldn't quite call it Boilerplate Dobbs, but it's like finding wrestling and bears in a John Irving novel: the touchstones are there to make you feel welcome, but the story takes on a lot of heft beyond them.Only one thing holds this book back from being five stars. As the novel wears on, we get the sense that it's a placeholder book. WWI is many years ago, and we get hints that WWII is on the horizon. But it's not here just yet, and while Winspear does a great job peppering the story with historical precedent, she seems to just want to get to the Nazis more quickly. This book feels a little rushed because of it.Other than that, a highly entertaining and exciting entry in the fantastic Maisie Dobbs series!...more

title: Super Mario: How Nintendo Conquered America
author: Ryan, Jeff*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read a lot about the history of video games, which is a little odd because I'm a game dipper rather than a real gamer. I get into whatever the new MI read a lot about the history of video games, which is a little odd because I'm a game dipper rather than a real gamer. I get into whatever the new Mario or Zelda game is, I usually finish Mario (and leave Zelda for my husband, unless it's in the style of Link to the Past/Link Between Worlds), and then go back to other pastimes. But I find the HISTORY of gaming just so much fun and exciting, and I can't even figure out why. Last year, I read Bit by Bit and Console Wars, both of which got a little long. Super Mario: How Nintendo Conquered America, is a lot more compact, choosing (wisely, I think) to stick to using the core Mario games as its backbone and expanding out from there. It's mostly great. It's a lot of fun to delve into the weird Mario side-quests - games that I'd never heard of, especially ones designed just for Japan. Unfortunately, all books on the history of gaming, including this one, fall into that trap of unnecessary prognostication at the end: where things are headed, and why. I guess that's the nature of books about an expanding medium. This book ends as Nintendo is flying high with the Wii, so doesn't have the further history of the semi-failure of the Wii U or the bounceback of the Switch, but as a good compact history, it mostly hits the mark.Side note: I did the audio of this, and it's almost uniformly terrific ... except that the narrator doesn't know how to pronounce "Bob-Omb," and it's funny, every time....more

review: One of the best things about a Harlan Coben book is that, no matter how horrific the past is, or what stranglehold it might have on the present, the FOne of the best things about a Harlan Coben book is that, no matter how horrific the past is, or what stranglehold it might have on the present, the FEEL of the book is like coming home. Coben has tamped down the easy, almost rococo narration of his earliest Myron Bolitar novels, but I hope he never loses that entirely. I love those little asides his characters have, especially when they’re content. The book concerns a man named Simon and his daughter named Paige, who is a junkie. There’s a LOT of other stuff in here: hired assassins and drug lords and cults and private detectives and black market babies. Just so much. Most of it makes sense. It’s all pretty damn compelling. Like most Coben novels, it moves at an unrelenting pace and doesn’t usually let up for air. I liked it a lot. I didn’t love it, but I didn’t have to. Coben gives me a lot of pleasure in these short annual bursts, and then I move on. And I love THAT. ...more

author: McCracken, Elizabeth

review: I picked up this book knowing very little about it. The cover flap mentioned a woman waking up in a graveyard not knowing how she got there, and buildI picked up this book knowing very little about it. The cover flap mentioned a woman waking up in a graveyard not knowing how she got there, and building a bowling alley in the town in which she woke in. That’s an accurate description, but it doesn’t touch on how fun, how weird, and how deep this book gets.In reality, Bertha Truitt is only where this book begins. From her awakening springs this amazing picaresque novel about generations of Truitts, and the bowling alley to which they’re tied. It’s populated by weirdos and other fascinating people against the backdrop of an America growing and contracting, from roughly 1915 to the early 1970s.Bowlaway is so well-written, with a flowing, occasionally rococo style that is immediately engaging. My only wish would be very slightly more depth into some of the characters - I could have read a whole book about Minna Sprague - but I thoroughly enjoyed what I got. ...more

title: Stephen King, American Master: A Creepy Corpus of Facts About Stephen King & His Work
author: Spignesi, Stephen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm struggling to rate this objectively, as I have an essay in this one. Maybe it's not objective. I'm okay with that.Spignesi is one of the best writI'm struggling to rate this objectively, as I have an essay in this one. Maybe it's not objective. I'm okay with that.Spignesi is one of the best writers on Stephen King. His Shape Under the Sheet: The Stephen King Encyclopedia offered a vast-ranging and semi-academic look at King's work up to 1991, around the time that George Beahm's Stephen King Companion was giving new fans an accessible overview of the writer's oeuvre. Spignesi has continued the trend, giving us a King "best-of" list (The Essential SK) and a book about King's then unpublished work (The Lost Work of SK). All are presented in fan-accessible style that supposes fan interest but not obsession. That's the perfect thing for this book, and also the reason I might have liked it a lot more if I was just getting into King now.My problem is that I'm a Stephen King expert. I've read everything King has published and a lot he hasn't. I've written my own books on King. So SK: American Master wasn't really a book meant for me. Still, as a fan, I do get excited about King's newer work being represented in companion books like this. I remember reading a newer version of Beahm's Companion and seeing a listing for Desperation and The Regulators as upcoming books, and I got so pumped. Also, the more time that goes by, and the more books King writes, the more we get to see King's work as an entire body of work, stretching back farther and farther in time. This allows us to have contemporary essays (like mine in here, "The Stephen King Immersion Phenomenon") that tackle themes of King's newer work, and compare and contrast with his more vintage stuff. Basically, if you're new to the world of King, get this book. Even if you're not that new, get this book. The only King fans who don't need a book like this are ones with essays in the book....more

review: I didn’t know I wanted to watch Matt Scudder grow old, but it’s been fascinating. (And kinda hot.)‬ Like Spenser before him, Matt Scudder has gotten oI didn’t know I wanted to watch Matt Scudder grow old, but it’s been fascinating. (And kinda hot.)‬ Like Spenser before him, Matt Scudder has gotten older (though his origin story hasn’t changed). That’s not to say that his story isn’t vital, or isn’t interesting; in some ways it actually is more so. There’s a good, sexual mystery/crime at the center of this book, exciting enough for long time crime readers ... but every Scudder book is more than just the crimes he’s involved with. The Scudder series has almost always been the story of a man struggling to understand himself and better himself. That’s no different in this book.I think the main reason why I liked A Time to Scatter Stones so much is because none of it seems perfunctory, or out of place. It all seems like a logical continuation of Matt’s - and Elaine’s - story. While a number of characters I really like never got the chance to show up, I almost respect the book more for that. You don’t have to throw in fan service if the story is compelling enough, and the main characters are still interesting, and fun to read about.Now I want more....more

title: Last Night in Twisted River
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There really is nothing like getting caught up in a John Irving novel. They're so dense, packed with detail and character, that you often feel like yoThere really is nothing like getting caught up in a John Irving novel. They're so dense, packed with detail and character, that you often feel like you're living the lives of the characters along with them. They are often full stories of lives - of witnessing the youth of a child or children and then following them until at least their old age. There's always something satisfying about that.Last Night in Twisted River is no exception, and has the added layer of John Irving remarking on his own career and writing style through the lens of fiction. The novel is ostensibly about two men - a young cook named Dominic Baciagalupo and an older logger named Ketchum - and the woman they love, Rosie, who dies. It's also about the son of Dominic and Rosie, Danny, and something terrible - and accidental - he did when he was twelve.It starts there, sort of, in the New Hampshire logging town of Twisted River. There's also a young runaway named Angel, who also dies early on, and how his and Rosie's deaths reverberate through the remainder of the novel. Irving is fond of unusual families, and Dominic and Ketchum become something of platonic co-parents to Danny, trying always to keep him safe. That doesn't always work out, because it's an Irving novel. Also because it's an Irving novel, we get: farting dogs, moving outside the US to live, photographs of dead children hanging up on walls, missing hands, and, of course, bears. Like Until I Find You, the book goes on a LITTLE long, even though I can't really figure out a way to trim it that would seem satisfying. Every scene feels necessary, it just sometimes feels slowish. But it's not a bad kind of slowish. This maybe shouldn't be anyone's first Irving (Cider House Rules, Garp, A Widow for One Year, or The Hotel New Hampshire would be better suited for that role), but once you understand his style, this is a perfect novel for long winter nights....more

title: Thanks a Thousand: A Gratitude Journey
author: Jacobs, A.J.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love AJ Jacobs books, ever since reading The Know-It-All back when I worked in a bookstore. Most of his books are about taking on some sort of absurI love AJ Jacobs books, ever since reading The Know-It-All back when I worked in a bookstore. Most of his books are about taking on some sort of absurd challenge - reading the entire Oxford English Dictionary, spending a year following Biblical scripture literally, following every diet trend and fad for a year - and writing about his journey. He always manages to be insanely involving, insightful without becoming preachy or heady.Thanks a Thousand is all about gratitude; Jacobs' quest now is to thank one thousand people who went into making his morning cup of coffee. That includes everyone from the barista who serves him to the farmers who pick the coffee to the graphic designer that created the coffee shop's logo, and much, much more. It's a relatively short book, and Jacobs is a little breezier here than in other books, but it's to Thanks a Thousand's benefit. And it's odd: you'd think a book about having more gratitude would feel treacly or mawkish, but it never does; there are even feints toward acknowledging that there are often bad people along the path to making a good thing. The whole thing is refreshing, and it continues to reiterate what seems to be Jacobs' macro-thesis: the more we know about the world around us, the better people we'll be. ...more

title: Dolores Claiborne
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wish I could recapture the thoughts of the boy who first read this, over Christmas break in 1992. It was - as far as I can tell - the last Stephen KI wish I could recapture the thoughts of the boy who first read this, over Christmas break in 1992. It was - as far as I can tell - the last Stephen King hardcover another person bought for me before I could buy it for myself. Dolores Claiborne was my prize for making the honor roll in my first semester at senior year at Braintree High. I didn’t distinguish myself academically as much as I probably should have, but I’ll hold onto that as an achievement to be proud of.I remember loving the book, but it taking me a little while to understand the structure as a monologue. I was a dumb 17-year-old; I initially thought there were pages missing from the beginning. But it carried me away soon enough, like most of Stephen King carries me away. One of my fondest memories is sitting in my grandparents’ warm dinner nook, lost in this hardcover and waiting on Charlie’s Hot Dogs to boil so we could have supper.Was I alienated by the narrator, by the fact that until the pretty frisky murder at the center of the book, it wasn’t really a horror story? That much of the opening was about the hell two older women put each other through? No. I don’t think I was. By 17, I’d been so deep into the King thing that I was willing to accept almost any writing and at least give it a fair shake. Because of that, I opened myself up to a lot of style and experimentation over the years, stuff that primed me for other writers. I’ve gone back to this book a lot over the years, mainly because the audiobook read by Frances Sternhagen is so good. But in this impossible year, I’ve rediscovered the joys of reading these novels as I had the first time, after buying them from a shop and cracking them open to feast my eyes on that first page for the first time. The magic in these books still exists, and rarely if ever fails to make me happy....more

title: The Stand
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading The Stand during a global pandemic is a bit of a tricky business. Maybe I did it because I wanted to try to make sense of everything, or try tReading The Stand during a global pandemic is a bit of a tricky business. Maybe I did it because I wanted to try to make sense of everything, or try to put human faces on the numbers that scroll up and up on the CNN chyron. Or maybe I was just trying to reconnect with a happy time in my life.It's probably strange, looking in from the outside, how many joyful, happy, rescued moments are connected with Stephen King novels. He writes fearsomes, after all, and doesn't skimp on the gore or dark thoughts or the unsavory sectors of the human condition. But they always make me feel, to believe in something beyond myself. And I have a history with these books. A history stretching back to when I was just entering puberty. I was fifteen when my mother bought me The Stand for Christmas in 1990, and it was the first hardcover bought specifically for me. (Along with Four Past Midnight, at the same Christmas. That was the year I also got The Gunslinger, Danse Macabre, and Christine in paperback. It was a very good Christmas.)Things aren't great with Mom and me now, which is a shame as much as it's an inevitability. But I re-read this edition of The Stand, the big one, the complete and uncut one I've owned for thirty years, to connect with the feeling of that Christmas morning. How plainly happy I was to get the brand-new Stephen King novel, and it was in hardcover, and it was MINE. My mother wrote a little note inside the front cover, and it's sweet and kind and comes from a time less fraught. I love this book very much - I love Stu and Frannie, Nick and Larry, and even Harold Lauder, who made all my darker impulses manifest and made me understand them a little better. I love this book for the story in this book, so much. So very much.But I love the book itself just a little bit more. ...more

title: My Year of Rest and Relaxation
author: Moshfegh, Ottessa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You wouldn’t think a novel about sleeping all the time would be this gripping, this engaging. You’d be wrong. At first our unnamed narrator just driftYou wouldn’t think a novel about sleeping all the time would be this gripping, this engaging. You’d be wrong. At first our unnamed narrator just drifts in a prescription-drug-induced haze, as we uncover details about her past and present she is too exhausted to care about. Eventually this aimlessness coalesces into a plan, an actual decision to cure herself of both her ennui and addictions.That all this takes place in New York a few months before 9/11 isn’t coincidental, nor is it gimmicky. A few jolting moments in the text remind us where and when this is all happening. Unlike in Steve Martin’s An Object of Beauty, the attacks on the Twin Towers do not sneak up on us. They’re a Chekhov’s Gun, subtly peeking out through the story before hiding again. This isn’t to make light of the tragedy - the book’s entire thrust is learning how to survive in the face of tragedy, and to be happy, even when your world falls apart.This is Ottessa Moshfegh’s second novel, and the second book of hers I read this year. Tonally, it’s similar to Eileen - the claustrophobia, the slippery sense of self - but it’s otherwise very different. Despite being set in New York, this book feels a lot more intimate. And optimistic? For a book about a past of sadness and a future of tragedy, yeah. I’d say it’s optimistic....more

title: My Sister, the Serial Killer
author: Braithwaite, Oyinkan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wasn’t quite sure how to classify this book at first. My determination to read new writers this year mixed with a fair amount of hype surrounding itI wasn’t quite sure how to classify this book at first. My determination to read new writers this year mixed with a fair amount of hype surrounding it got me interested in Braithwaite’s novel, but I knew nothing going in. After the first couple of chapters, I told people it was a thriller, but it’s not that. It’s far more subtle.It’s the story of sisters, and to what degree you will protect your sister, even if she’s maybe evil. Our narrator Korede isn’t unreliable, but she’s deeply ambivalent about the actions and reactions of her sister Ayoola. That ambivalence sharpens to focus and determination as more of their shared past surfaces, and Korede realizes that sisters are bonded for life, like it or not....more

review: East of Eden is one of my favorite novels. It’s almost a thriller, a dark story of lineage and evil and free will. I can read it over and over and nevEast of Eden is one of my favorite novels. It’s almost a thriller, a dark story of lineage and evil and free will. I can read it over and over and never get sick of it.The Grapes of Wrath is probably a better novel. It’s a more important novel. To go further, it’s probably Steinbeck’s masterpiece. It details the plight of the starving, the poor, the untethered during the Great Depression. It is a devastating book, because there’s no way out of the ongoing misery. What little light in the book is found in human kindness. But that kindness comes with a price. Those are the reasons it's never going to be my FAVORITE Steinbeck. Wonderfully written, deserving of the Pulitzer, but simply not as fun or exciting as East of Eden (and it never intends to be). But it’s never a slog to read. It’s always compelling, and the Joads are fantastic, spellbinding characters. But I kept finding myself having to put it aside for a bit before continuing on. It’s a hard read. Fantastic, but hard....more

title: A Prayer for Owen Meany
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've spent long enough away and I've read so many books in between now and then that I'd forgotten many of the particulars of this most spectacular noI've spent long enough away and I've read so many books in between now and then that I'd forgotten many of the particulars of this most spectacular novel. It's a spiritual novel, and a religious novel, but it doesn't ever become a PREACHY novel, something that struck me even more this time around. Another thing that struck me is the fact that our narrator - why it's Johnny Wheelwright! - might be a little bit more in love with Owen than on a strictly friendship basis. There's an interview with John Irving at the end of this audiobook in which Irving confirms my suspicions. Characters speculate whether Johnny is a "nonpracticing homosexual," and Irving basically says, "yeah, he is." I wonder if that's why I've always related so much to this book. But it's more than that. It's the specificity. It's the small-town New Hampshire life. It's Irving's tropes - theaters, lost fathers, sexually aggressive older women, writers. No Amsterdam here and, as far as I can tell, no bears. But the language is Irving. The FLAVOR is Irving. And the ending, as always, is so, so sad. I've described this book as densely plotted, and it is, but I don't mean that to sound like the book itself is dense. It's almost airy in parts, even though we're dealing with intense subjects like faith and belief and the horrors of war and the hypocrisy of government. Despite those things, the book feels so hopeful. It's not as cynical as I remember it being. And of course this tickles my love of superhero narratives. I'm going to put this aside for a little while again. Maybe I'll do another whole John Irving jag this year, but this book is too important to me to read too often. ...more
